review:
First interview completed so far, haven't been invited for the second one and I can't comment on an offer because the process is ongoing. The first one is to screen out candidates that don't fit. Interviewer was nice and it was a good experience. 

Just prep for a week at 2hrs a day on common interview question asked by Microsoft. Search that on youtube and you'll find some experts who go through "top 25 questions" or something of that nature. You'll know it when you see it. Good luck and remember to prepare quality answers!

1) Contacted by recruiter on LinkedIn.
2) Called by recruiter to discuss opportunities. Completed application after phone call and emailed recruiter to push it to the next step.
3) Completed Codility assessment to qualify for interview event. Three questions, not bad. A couple string questions and exploiting a bug in a given algorithm.
4) Contacted to schedule virtual interview event.
5) Event consisted of four interviews on MS Teams, 45 minutes each. Each interviewer asked behavioral questions and a coding question using Codility.

The interview was OK overall. The process was pretty easy to follow and there was lots of communication leading up to it. Took 3 business days following the interview to get my result. My experiences with each interviewer are down below.

The first interviewer was very pleasant. Easy question, relaxed discussions on my experience and friendly overall.

The second interviewer was about 5 minutes late and was extremely difficult to understand. Spoke very fast and had a thick accent. Seemed a little high-strung There was a bit of a language barrier as he asked me the same behavioral question like three times, all phrased a little differently.

The third interviewer was pretty relaxed, similar to the first. Was helpful with answering any questions I had.

The fourth interviewer asked the most when it came to behavioral questions. He was very interested in my responses and asked lots of follow-up questions. Was also very nice. Unfortunately, this left only about 20 minutes to solve the tree question he asked. On top of solving it, I was also asked to implement the tree data structure (as shown in the prompt) and add a bunch of test cases to test my algorithm. I felt pretty rushed having to bang this out in 20 minutes, but it's doable if you have practiced a lot with trees and searching algorithms.

I recently changed jobs and had the opportunity to interview with several companies. In total, I had on-site interviews with 7 well known tech companies, including Microsoft. Out of those 7, Microsoft's interview process was the absolute worst.

I went through their event-based interview process. I was told that I would be interviewed by 4 people, with each person being from a different team, and I would have the opportunity to be recruited by any of those teams.

That turned out to be a lie. All 4 of my interviewers were from the same team, and it was a team that I was not interested in joining. I went through the interview anyway, and it was a mess the entire way through.

For my first interview, the interviewer was 10 minutes late and didn't even know how to turn on the coding software, so they wasted another 5 minutes trying to figure it out. Eventually, I ended up having to do a screen share and coding in a plain text editor to continue the interview. The coding problem was very easy so I still finished it on time.

The second interviewer had a coding problem that was a variation of the first interview, so that was easy to solve. I solved the problem optimally in time and space complexity, but afterwards the interviewer kept telling me to optimize it more. I responded that the solution was already optimal in both time and space, but the interviewer insisted that I over-optimize by short circuiting some loops, even though it wouldn't change the asymptotic running time. I just did what was asked even though it felt like such an odd request.

The third interviewer was also late by 5 minutes. Not much else to say here.

The fourth interviewer asked me a coding question that I had already solved on Leetcode, so I knew exactly what to do. While I was coding it, the interviewer stopped me and insisted that the way I was doing it wouldn't work. I said that I felt it would work and after some back and forth the interviewer allowed me to continue. Sure enough, I coded it and ran tests through it and it all worked as expected. The interviewer didn't say anything about being wrong.

Compared to the other 6 interviews I had, this interview with Microsoft was the worst experience. I won't be bothering to interview with Microsoft again.

Long, but very fair and with a lot of help from the company. Technical and behavioral interviews mixed after an online assessment. Mainly algorithmic and data structure question with some system design as well

It was not too hard. Technical questions and a few open ended personal questions about work ethic and work preferences. They asked a lot of questions I had seen online for other technical interview prep

Included an information call with the recruiter, followed by an online technical screen (OTS) - consisted of 3 questions, 60 mins

Interview Day - 4 rounds - 45 mins each, with 15 min break in between
Each interviewer asked a mix of questions - behavioral questions, questions related to current job role, 2 system design and 2 LC questions - maximum length palindrome, LRU cache

Went through three rounds of interview. First was a recruiter. Second a manager. Third a full day round robin on Teams with four different people. After that I received an email from the recruiter with the results of the process.

Ask me the reason why I apply this job. The data processing skills and ability to organize event. Give me some scenarios to answer how to solve the problem. Real practice in decide the target audience and translate.
Very thorough HR department with resources to prepare. They provide updates often, and the careers website allows you to track status of your application. STARs format followed. Used teams video.

Good for the first few rounds. Great people along the way who described how we'd be working together. Most everyone seemed impressed at the value we'd have working together. A bit puzzling approach in the final round with a senior person, however.
It was a string problem. The problem wasn't too hard, and the interviewer was patient. I did not have to actually use the test cases. The interviewer just asked me to talk it through.
Codility test then, then interview scheduled with four Engineers. Each Engineer asked similar questions and one gave a coding test.  They are very warm and ready to answer questions asked.
Had first round interview with a PMM, then after 5 weeks or so heard back about second round. Second round was three back to back 45 min interviews with various cloud marketing people.
Phone screen internet history screen cookie search. Not bad but you gotta do what you gotta do. Honestly better than what other companies have at times. It's an ok process

I had an initial screening and then a full day of interviews with four different leaders within the organization including the hiring manager and some of whom that had either working in the role or close to the role and

2 questions,  limited to one hour in which your'e doing an online interview - the interviewer was really nice.
Good preparation beforehand can help a lot. 
Second stage is another interview with some more technical question,
It was friendly, they always made us feel like we were talking with friends. Personal interviews were direct but informal, making it clear that the company is a very free mindset kind of.

There was online coding rounds. On clearance was invited for a onsite interviews.
Then, there were 4 rounds of interviews. After all the rounds HR contacted me revealing the offer. It was great

The process was very simple. Recruiter contacted me on LinkedIn. Finished the online coding assessment. 
From there a Microsoft Hiring Event day was scheduled. 

Interview was pretty simple, Straight up leetcode. didn't even change the examples. 

1st interview was medium leetcode. When I solved it in 15 mins, 2nd question was asked, After that a behavioral. This interview was finished in under 40 minutes

2nd interviewer asked a very common leetcode question. He asked me if I saw that question on leetcode. when I solved that he asked me to optimize it which I did. And then a behavioral. 

3rd interview was OOD after a behavioral question. The interviewer did not ask any follow up questions. This interview was finished in under 40 minutes. 

4th interview was a Tree based question which was also solved in the most optimal way. Interviewer mentioned that he has very less experience in java and couldn't understand some of the code. No follow up questions. there was another behavioral question. This interview was also done in 40 minutes. 

When i checked with recruiter I was told that I was rejected. I was very confident about this interview. I still don't understand why I was rejected.
Process was very straight forward, talked about the benefits that the job had to offer as well as the responsibilities for the role. Interview was very nice and easy going. QUESTIONS ASKWEED

Went through the process with a third party recruiter. Made it through technical screening and onsite to receive a verbal offer.

However they ended up not contacting me again after I stated my reasonable salary expectations (ranges backed by current market rate with sources).

The process was brief and strait forward.  They asked a few questions about the resume presented and then wanted a coding problem solved. Overall it took 30 minutes and I was notified within two weeks.

They are quite stuck to book instead of observing the overall candidates attitude and approach to answer.  And the environment is not quite motivational or comfortable for the candidate to show the full potential.
If successfully passed phone screen, but they forgot to invite me to onsite. I end up with another compony who was faster. May be I was just unlucky.  I will not try again.
I interviewd during a hiring event. After a coding online assesment with 2 questions, I interviewd onsite (microsoft teams) with four members of the team. Unfortunately I didn't receive an offer.

Was mostly DSA. Interviewer friendly. We discussed my resume, relevant projects I had done first, Asked me about Javascript CSS HTML, how I learnt React. basics of DSA- complexity, some basic array problems.HR round interview was nice, friendly

1 round hiring manager phone interview

4 round tech interview (coding + sys design)
general coding questions, such as min heap, queue, mean of unsorted array.
1 round skip mgr interview, talk about career planning, department scope and responsibility

phone screen -> onsite. Onsite has 2 rounds, depending on the interviewer the 2 rounds  could range from fully behavioral to fully technical. Technical questions leetcode easy-medium-ish. The interviewer are very likely the team that will hire you if you get an offer.

It was a friendly proccess although didn't end up with an offer. The head of the team interviewed me personally via online.  He briefly explained the purpose of the interview before going into details of my background and skills. The interview was generally easy going and I didn't feel under a lot of pressure or any unreasonable questions.

Very gentle, great attitude!!! very welcoming and onboarding experience. the technical review is average.
good equity and salary
Very gentle, great attitude!!! very welcoming and onboarding experience. the technical review is average.
good equity and salary
The were two rounds. The first was a phone interview with a somewhat basic question involving strings. The second was with the office I'd work for which had two questions.
There was a video interview after submitting the resume. It was in Budapest time zone and the interviewer asked some questions. The question was on the level of easy for leetcode.

I filled out a questionnaire and then spoke with the hiring manager who mainly just answered questions I had about the position. Next, they gave me a case study to work through and I spent a day interviewing with 5 people on the team back to back. Only 1 person asked about the case study that I spend a lot of time on. I was told I would hear back within a week. I followed up 2 weeks later to see if a decision had been made and received no reply. 2 months later I received an automated rejection notice that says you can asked for individualized feedback, but then says you shouldn't respond to the automated email. Not sure if I'm supposed to ask the recruiter who doesn't respond to emails? I honestly felt very disrespected I had to take a day off a work only to receive no feedback for 2 months. Really negatively impacted my perspective of Microsoft as a company.

Very nice people and interviewers, wrote code online and the meeting held through microsoft meet. 
I learned something new from each interviewer and got feedback as well. hope to try again sometime soon.

It was pretty good. It was done virtually through Zoom because of the current pandemic. They asked about my experience and my background. For me, it was a one-on-one interview so I was not really nervous at all.

Very smooth process. Got encouraging interviewer who wasn’t trying to destroy you. I would highly recommend getting an interview there. Microsoft is a dream place to work in. Make sure you have practiced some questions on data structures etc

My very bad experience in the intreviews started when i had a two on-line intreviews. 
One in coding, i was nervous and had difficulties to answer(coding an iterator), but next was in design and went very well(design a calculator).
Yet i got a decline. Later they call me again for different position, i passed the phone intreview and they sent me codility exam. I did all 3 questions almost succesfully in 90 min. But with no explanation, i was declined again.
Microsoft intreview process is so frustrating. 
I am very dissapointed.
I really recommend to consider if you want to move such frustrating process.

Was smooth interviewers were very friendly and interactive. 3 rounds in total. 1st was technical questions from data structures, algorithms and OOPS concepts. project explanation according to the interviewers choice. 2nd was managerial round was mostly general talk like how much do you know about microsoft and how will you tackle a situation in your work space etc. 3rd round was LIKE HR general discussion and project related discussion (was completely out of required role)
Challenging and fun and felt like a Larsen press of future and a good explanation of the day of the day of the year ahead and you can watch the event of a half day

This was a remote interview. The recruiting team sent an email with the Teams link about a week in advance, and then another the day before. As context around why this was a negative experience - they also did not send an invite of any kind, just that email with the link. 

I have Teams downloaded, have been using it for over a year during the pandemic. The night before the interview, I log in to Teams to make sure it's working - it is. The day of, I log in about 5 minutes before the interview and click the link - and it doesnt work. I try closing/restarting teams, I try changing my internet connection - nothing works. I immediately email the recruiter to let her know and ask for her help. The time for the interview arrives and passes. I continue to try to get into the link. About 10 minutes pass, and I am finally able to get in. The interviewer is not there, she joins a few minutes later and immediately does not give me the benefit of the doubt. I continue to have tech issues - my audio doesn't connect, I need to call in but there is no call in number as I never received a formal insight. The interview begrudgingly sends it over chat. We finally get on and I try to lighten the mood - TECH ISSUES HAPPEN. We all know they've happened over the past year - we've all been through this. 

For the remaining 15-20 minutes of the interview, the interviewer was outright rude. I knew it was over, but I kept a positive attitude, asking about her work and her thoughts on MSFT - showing genuine interest. 

We get off the call, and I notice the recruiter had finally emailed me back saying she could reach out to the interviewer to let them know about the technical issues. I respond back, thanking her, letting her know about the issues and asking for the interviewers email so I could send a thank you for her flexibility. I NEVER heard back - nothing. Really disappointed, as MSFT prides itself on compassion and inclusion. Pretty terrible process overall.

There are a total of t4 interviews.  Each about 1 hour long.  Expect to be asked common interview questions for example...give me an example of a time when you help your client change their mind about X situation.   My advice is to space out your interviews in separate days so you won't feel the zoom fatigue which can set in very quickly.

Well-structured process, it took about 1 month in total. I had an initial interview, then two more interviews, one was data analysis in Excel in French and the other interview was behavioural in English.

Applied on Microsoft Career Site. Recruiter reached out to me with a questionnaire asking why I think I was qualified, what I want to join Microsoft, and what experience relates to this job, prefer salary, etc. Few days later, we had a phone interview and discuss the role.

Recruiter asked for good interview dates and scheduled the earliest one. 

Had 3 rounds of technical/behavior interview with 3 different team members. 

Interview was resume and job description based. They asked what you do at your current/recent job, then dives into the job related qualification. For me, it was mainly active directory, network key, customer handling scenarios, etc. 

First two interviewer each also gave me an article to read and ask me to summarize the main points. 

Last interview adds on top of it with some escalation scenarios. Also discuss the team formation and how things function in their team. Gave me so much hope that I had a good chance but no...

Overall I think  my experience with the interview was good and deserves a A- if I had to scale it.  Besides the long wait.

Very systematic interview about 4 hours. Assess communication skills. there are 4 interviewers. Ask mainly past experiences. You should be specific an dbe yourself. prepare for giving specific examples. not generic. Prepare for SAR methodology describing your expreriences.

The process was standard. I made it to the final round where I interviewed with 4 individuals over the course of 2 days since we are remote. I was told the interview was purely behavioral by the recruiter and even asked if there was any technical I needed to prepare for, which the answer was no. One of my interviews turned out to be a technical which I was not ready for. My advice to Microsoft is to make sure the recruiter and hiring team are on the same page. This was a poor experience as I did very well in the of other 3 rounds. I also received a rejection email on a Saturday and that to me is not appropriate and is a poor experience.

Applied online and was contacted by email by a Mr Lewis Milford. Quite interested in setting up a call, ask Cortana to book a time for us in the calendar. Turns out, the day of the interview about an hour before he decided that he was too busy and they would be getting back to me, obviously apologising for the delay. Still waiting to hear back but glad to see the level of professionalism

The interview process consisted of 4 rounds. 3 Technical rounds and 1 Behavioral round.

The first stage was mostly discussion about what I do and then some relatively easy coding task.

Second stage was 2 Technical Interviews back to back same day with 2 engineers. Very smart guys very friendly discussions and no tricky questions. Each interview consisted 3 to 4 tasks. A simple one in the beginning, then they would make it a bit harder, then harder again and then a difficult one.

If you are well prepared(Leetcode, Codesignal, Algoexpert, e.t.c) then you have nothing to be afraid of.

Overall I was impressed with the experience because it was fast, professional.

4 round Interview with problem solving Questions,experience. questions on CI / CD technologies
Algortithm based questions using codility tool.
An Interview with team panel to know more about the team and they answered my questions and what are their expectations

5 Rounds,  long waiting process, Interviewed on campus first, the second round was 6 months afterward. People are generally very nice, you might be interviewed with departments you are not familiar with, but be confident with what you know is important.

Had to meet with 4 interviewers, the last one being the optional “as appropriate” interview.  All coding questions.  You are evaluated on how you solve the problems.  I was very nervous which wasn’t held against me.

4 stage interview.

1st with internal Microsoft recruiter and an initial discussion around interest, why etc.

2nd with a peer and focused on the role and day to day stuff.

3rd again with a peer and more technically focused.

4th with the manager hiring.

All done via Teams.

From application to 1st interview was around a month.  

Interviews 2, 3 and 4 conducted over a week.

It took Microsoft 5 weeks after 4th interview to tell me I was unsuccessful.  Feedback from recruiter was clear as concise from interview 2 and 3.  There was no feedback from the 4th.  

Recruiter offered to get the feedback, however none received and it been 3 months.

Process is slow and don’t expect full feedback.  From application to rejection took about 3 months.
Phone screens with the hiring manager and the director, virtual interview system for 30 minutes long with each of them.  Questions were fair and clear, it was a good interview experience.

Initial 30 minute interview with software manager asked 1 or 2 technical questions and 1 or 2 questions about general interest. Follow up virtual onsite two 30 minute interviews with software engineers.

Got the interview through a recruiter, entire process took almost 45 days. Initially received a coding challenge and which a call with the recruiter. 
Finally the 4 round loop, all rounds were single person (one-to-one) interviews taken by Indians. First two rounds went well but the last round felt as if he is totally disinterested in the interview process itself. Felt unprofessional and seemed like every one were sharing the interview notes with each other

3 50-min Skype interviews. All involved some discussion of resume and behavioral q's but bulk of it was technical coding questions over a virtual platform. Interviewers were very helpful and supportive as I worked through the problems.
I did not have an interview for this position at Microsoft. I received an email directly from a representative from the Human Resources department notifying me about the hiring decision.

The interview process was very haphazard. Took about 6 months with HR disappearing for 3 months in between. 5 rounds with 1 round for HR. Mainly asked about machine learning questions and data science questions. p

Larga y tediosa pero todo es explicado con claridad. No hacen preguntas tecnicas solo como te desenvuelves en sus principios, growth mindset, teamwork, etc. Tambien toman en cuenta tu vida personal como hobbies y que te presentes autenticamente
Invert a binary tree. This was the easiest interview ever. Thank you Microsoft for giving me 120k salary from inverting binary tree. I found on YouTube solution. Very simple and straightforward.

- Headhunted by one of their talent scouts. 
- Interview with scout. 
- Interview with hiring manager.
- Interview with senior recruiter. 
- Chased hiring manager and no reply back.
- Chased scout a week later and they said a rejection email should be coming. 
- Came away with a feeling that it was a body-shop and not Microsoft. 
- Overall poor process and subjective casual interview style.

It's a  Day Activity. Interviewer made me comfortable. Two Technical Interviews  happened for me. I have answered well and interviewer also said Many positive things about me and Finally Result came as Negative for 2nd round. Up to my Knowledge It's was right and It's a Shock for me to digest the Result. I think it's just fo the number they call for the interview. Please give proper feedback, If you are saying in the end "Your profile is very impressive and it was Nice Learning with you, Sharing knowledge mutually etc and I will update the same to HR" afterwards Result Negative means?
Out of the Box Performance.

Applied the job in their career website and recruiter schedule an interview directly with software development manager. We met with on Teams. I was asked general software engineer questions and one coding test.
One round of interviews split in to two parts, One technical and 1 managerial. They spoke about how Microsoft has changed into being "One Team, One Microsoft." Using the people around you to help you

On Campus Process online round was quite easy try to modularise the code and try to write efficient code.
Selected for the next round but unfortunately did not got the offer.

I applied online, then a phone interview with a sourcing recruiter, then half a day of interviewing that consisted of three (3) 45 minute interviews with various team members. Each interviewer has a different area of focus (i.e. Cultural fit, technical aptitude, strategic thinking skills, etc.) The interview questions were reasonable and the individuals conducting the interviews had the level of professionalism that one would expect from a large, Fortune 500 company.

So, I completed the interviews over a month ago. I was told pre-interview that I would receive an update within 1 to 2 weeks after completing interviews. Unfortunately, this was not at all accurate. I never received any follow-up communication at all... Absolutely nothing. When I log into Microsoft's application system, my application is in limbo and the status has neither been rejected, nor changed at all since my interview was scheduled. I reached out to the recruiter twice by e-mail, but received no reply at all. Deeply disappointing, rude, and unprofessional behavior on behalf of the recruiter. Definitely not even close to an adequate response after I invested half of a working day interviewing, and actually used my personal vacation time to accommodate the interview time slot. Even being informed that Microsoft just wasn't interested would be better than being left in limbo indefinitely with no update. I have lost all hope of every receiving the courtesy of a response of any kind. Human Resources at Microsoft really needs to re-think making use of the third-party recruiting firm(s) that they use to source candidates and schedule interviews, as the candidate experience is miserable due to being mismanaged by unprofessional third-party recruiters.
The interview process was flawless up until the point where I received a standard rejection letter. I had been in 5 interviews at that point, and would have appreciated some personalized feedback.

Went through three rounds of interviews, and no news for more than two months since then, until today.
Tried to reach out to recrutiment team, but no reply as well.
I don't believe this would take more than 1 month to get a conclusion.

3 rounds
1. phone screen with hiring manager 
2. 4 separate 30min-1hour meetings with individual team members

3. Final interview day consisting of 5 1-hour long interviews back to back and presentation of sample work to date
The interview went for around 45-50 min. It was AA round and focused on aptitude and overall candidate profile. Overall the process the smooth and the interview was kind enough and helpful.

Two easy codility questions followed by two technical interviews, one hour for both of the codility questions and the other two take 75 minutes. the codility questions were relatively easy, while the technical interviews were more challenging.

The interview process is positive. The interviewers were friendly and provided guidance during the interview process. The process is consisted of three technical rounds (no dedicated behavior interview). I received the call from HR two weeks after the last round of interview.
It was one of the best interviews. It was long- but less technical more behavior. They provided a lot of support and resources for you to prepare for the final interview day.

Online application, Hiring manager viewed my Linkedin Profile, and then contacted me directly for a MS team interview (45 Min)
Coming from a software engineering background I was expecting a more personalized interview based on the experience. It felt like a hasty process or like the decision was already made and the conversation was only formality. The interviewer were not genuinely interested to hear and also analyze my answers. He even mentioned a few times that we can't spend much time on this part of the interview, need to move on, etc. I was asked about a system design if a company should do and how and a couple of standard behavioral questions.  I did not even get the chance to ask all my job related questions due to the time constraint. 
To me it looked like I did good enough but I got the rejection letter a day after.
Guide : Cracking the PM interview book is a must read :)

Applied online, was contacted by a recruiter almost a month later to set up a call with the hiring manager. 

The call was bizarre. Interviewer never asked about my background, rather launched straight into software engineering-related questions (stack vs. queue, classes, etc). It was obvious they had not looked at my resume (they were surprised when I mentioned my degree). I genuinely wonder whether there was a mix-up in the job posting, and whether the interviewer was looking for a software engineer.

Received an automated rejection a day later.

The process itself was very slick, professional and (seemingly) friendly. A written set of questions, interview with a senior in the same role, then another interview with hiring managers. Feedback 
throughout was quick, and positive. Until the final decision - then ghosted, no explanations or even a one line email just an auto notification. Don’t give good feedback at each stage and then no explanation at the end. How can people learn from mistakes or gain experience for next time?

The coding round had 2 questions, they were pretty much simple. Many people did those questions and the latter part of filtering candidates were based on their CPI values. Over all it was a good experience.

Muy ameno. A través de agencia de rrhh
 Preguntas basicas. Adaptarse a resoover vosas indeindependientemente. Puesto remoto. Buena entrevista.Muy ameno. A través de agencia de rrhh
 Preguntas basicas. Adaptarse a resoover vosas indeindependientemente. Puesto remoto. Buena entrevista...

Screening Round and then followed by interview by hiring manager. Both the rounds are telephonic and through VC. Initial Screening is for 30 mins and then followed by interview by hiring manager for 1 hour. Questions are behavioural and based on past experience. Their expectations is that candidate gives short answers.
The process was very easy and we were all treated well by the interviewers. I had two rounds of the interview, They were supportive and nice. Overall I had a great experience.

It was an on campus opportunity, So we were provided Job ID from Microsoft and were askes to apply on career portal of MS for CGPA > 7.5 and then date for our OA was decided:
It was a test of total 80 minutes with 2 problem.
Both the questions were of grid type and difficulty lying between medium to hard.
I was able to solve only 1 problem so my name didn,t came in list of 40 students shortlisted for interview round.
This was my first opportunity.

- First resolve an online coding test on codility, 3 LeetCode problems in 1 hour and 30 min.
- Then an online onsite interview with 3 senior software engineers, 2 coding questions and 1 design.

4 rounds - 3 Techincal + 1 Managerial. Appeared for the Azure compute team hiring.
Technical rounds included system design and some basic DS & algo. Managerial round was more of another technical round where the manager was trying to show off his knowledge in OS. It looked like he was interviewing for some kernel developer which was nothing related to my work experience. The guy seemed least interested and was yawning and coughing throughout the interview process. Some lame questions were asked which was mostly related to the work his team does, any outsider without enough domain knowledge would find it difficult to comprehend any of it in 10 mins and come up with the design for it which otherwise must have been built by a team working over a period of time. Kept asking things from C/C++ which was not even my skill set. Overall a very bad experience, expect the manager to just spend some time over the candidate profile  to look for basic match before calling for interviews, it was a such waste of time.

The interview was really nice. Interviewers cooperated well, and gave me a proper chance to showcase my skills. I ran out of time in one interview, but the interviewer sticked with me, as he saw I was very close to the solution.

It was on campus hiring program.It was pretty interactive. The people in microsoft were very friendly and they want to hire you so do not give them a chance to reject  .  Pro tip- have good projects on your resume and it will give an edge over others.
There was an online test which was followed by interview rounds.There was maximum of 3 rounds in interview,I could get through 2 rounds but could not make it to final round
It was very long, we had a first interview and then the tree of us that made it to the last round of interviews had two interviews and a group exercise in the same day

Interview process is very long and drawn out.  Be patient and persistent and good things will happen.  Scheduling can take forever.  I was contacted in the final weeks of May.  I had to send out follow up emails twice over the next 2 weeks to the recruiter.  After the delay I was able to schedule time with the hiring manager directly as it was given by the recruiter.  Met and cleared second interview late second week of June.  Was able to go to round 3 of the interviews but this happened 3 weeks later on the second week of July.  After clearing that round 1 week later I was in round 4 where I met with 4 interviewers over 2 days.  I had a 1 hour call with the recruiter who set great expectations on what was to be asked of me and prepped me well.  Final round was 3rd week in July and offer received 4th week and accepted at end of July.  Total time was probably 75-80 days which seems very long and drawn out but honestly worth it to join such an amazing company with amazing benefits.

in der zweiten Runde werden ca. 10 Fragen gestellt, die man jedem Kandidaten / jeder Kandidatin stellt, um die Antworten dann im Nachgang zu vergleichen. 
Die Atmosphäre ist sehr freundlich und locker, jedoch wird zu jedem Zeitpunkt mit geschrieben (mitgetippt) was ziemlich ablenkt.

Four rounds of interview. One coding round was there which consisted of 2 coding questions and was conducted on Codility .
2 technical rounds and 1 HR + Technical Round was there

Phone screen, followed by panel interview consisting of four 1:1 interviews with engineers. My recruiter was communicative and, though she was occasionally late on calls, highly responsive.

The only hiccup in the process was when she took a week of vacation after giving me the verbal offer (I fully support this) and passed my application to a different recruiter to complete the offer process. The other recruiter completely dropped the ball, and I had to call my recruiter when she came back to follow up on getting the offer details lined up.

It consisted of 2 rounds of 1 hour each. They asked coding problems based on Data structures and Algorithms. There were questions on the projects I have put in my resume and some general HR behavioral questions.

Online Interview consisted of 3 rounds, interview on MS Teams.
Round 1: One basic DSA question and one backtracking question. Asked to explain the recursive stack.
Round 2: Project and subject questions asked. One two pointer ques and one graph question asked
Round 3: some HR questions, some subject ques and one DSA question.

2 Technical rounds - 
First-round with 1 coding question based on trees 
If you get shortlisted there was also a second-round with 1 coding question based on strings
Also, questions based on resume and projects 

1 HR round

4 different interviews. You will be assessed on your problems coping mechanisms and clients' complaints, on how to set up procedures and write documentation. 
Three out of four interviews are like having a relaxed conversation with a colleague of yours. The forth interview is technical. They will assess basic but very important concepts of traditional Machine Learning. No coding assessment.

had 2 rounds, projects were an important part, coding questions were also an important part, and questions were medium-level. Interviewer was quite friendly, one of  questions was on string 2*5-6 output in int and other was lowest common ancestor tree and futhur modifications on LCA.

Straightaway a linked list question was asked the interviewer was not helpful and no other question was asked. While there were others with hr round and only project questions not even tell me about yourself

I attended 4 hour long interviews with 2 hour long breaks during the day. I was asked only technical questions, 2 of which were system design questions. The questions were tricky, but the code required to solve them was not too challenging.

No competitive coding is needed. You can easily Crack the interview through interviewbit or leetcode. Nothing else is needed. Just focus on your basics, and CN, OS, DBMS. And start Solving all DS questions on geeksforgeeks.

While the recruiter was encouraging and engaging, the interviewers were on the opposite. The first interview was neutral, but to say to your candidate your sales are dropping... The hiring manager was not interested in me, what kind of person I am, or why I want to work for Microsoft. 
For future hiring strategy, a comment, if you require any particular methodology certifications, please save your own time and ours and drop out the applicant.

P.S. Please read the CV before you interview someone. It should be embarrassing to give a question when the answer was in front of you.

Good luck!

3 Rounds for the on-campus opportunity at Microsoft, 1 online and 2 technical interviews followed by HR Round.
The question were from topics like DP, bitmasking, graphs and trees. One should have good grasp over Data structures and algorithms and practice previously asked questions in the interviews from sites like geeksforgeeks and leetcode.
I was good for my first time as i was quite scared but they made us much comfortable for interview.Questions were medium to hard , i gained much experience for interview

One online technical interview was held after successful completion of the Microsoft Engage Mentorship Program, which is a month long development program where students had to develop a project in one month.
there were four rounds. First is coding round followed by two technical and one HR round. Interviews are of moderate level. A aAa a  a a a a aa  a  . a . aa a a aaaa .

It was a on campus drive.First round was coding round-2 Question 90 min.Then selected candidates have to appear for interviews.There are three interview rounds.In first one he asked question on binarysearch,easy-medium question on array then oops concept.2 nd round was purely technical and i was asked a question similar to LRU cache design.Third round was HR round and question based on some puzzles and based your topics mentioned in resume was asked.

Three rounds were there. The questions were straightforward easy DSA questions. Those who were selected were able to solve all the questions. The last round was AA round. We discussed my projects, and prior experience. He also asked about my courses.

I got contacted on linkedIn to share my resume and a vendor recruiter called me.
After that, I had my screening interview and then 3 more followed with 1 each week, no definite plan ahead or feedback.
It always was a question, would I be able to clear this round or not. If so, when will I hear back.
The last round was Hiring Manager round and it went good, he also said Recruiter would stay in touch. But i was never contacted. After waiting for 10 days, I called recruiter and was told that my profile was kept on hold. I know for what reasons I would have been held, but taking almost 5 hours to interact and engage candidates deserve to be updated with interview result

1st round was a coding round and it had 2 easy-medium question. After that selected candidates were called for interview after 5-6 days. In the interview i was asked some computer science fundamental questions on dbms followed by 1 coding question, I was not able to code the problem well so i was rejected.

Typical Microsoft format.  Screening call with a recruiter, call with the hiring manager and then a  5 interview loop with the standard behavioral questions focused on my design process.  The as-appropriate interview was  scheduled a few weeks later.  All were done via Teams calls as it's 2021 COVID protocols

first they asked to introduce and discuss what i have done so far and they started with their technical questions mostly on oops and trees and on dbms too.finally they asked if i have done any project till date and my answer was no

Recruiter reached out. Forwarded me a bunch of details and then ended up sending me to a hiring event with a bunch of people interviewing for similar roles. Hard to understand what exactly I was interviewing for considering it is an L5 level position.

The interview was divided into 2 parts, one part was programming questions, and the other part was a personal interview and at the end a logical riddle.
In the first part there were 3 questions mainly about strings, and in the second part addictive questions like: why Microsoft, to tell about a project I did, etc.

Aksed about the knowledge of MS products and what you plan as a marketing strategy.
It was an HR interview but the hardest HR interview ever.
All questions are very practical.
You should study a lot about MS products before the interview.
The interview was just 30 minutes.

1 phone screening interview
1 teams behavioral interview
3  person super day interview

Very nice people and a smooth interview process. They were very open and honest about what would be covered in the interview. The company sent a lot of interview prep resources too.
I applied online. At the first interview, I had to describe how I would react in some specific scenarios. Afterwards, I had 2 rounds of interviews, and in one of them I had to deliver a presentation

There were 3 rounds.
1st was a coding test basically an elimination round where 2 coding questions were there. One question was based on the graph.

2nd round was technical majorly coding was asked. it was related to dp.

3rd round was the technical round as well where question was related to data structures.
Recruiter called me and informed me about this opportunity. So after initial discussion, recruiter arrange me an interview via teams. Interviewers were friendly. The interview was about an hour long

Panel interview was about 5 hours.

1st hour portfolio presentation. (about 10 people from cross functions) All of them asked questions
2nd hour of the interview was with the Design director
3rd hour of the  interview was with of the Senior UX Designers
4th hour of the interview was with the UX research lead
5th hour was with the hiring manager

1 online coding round, 3 interviews (Technical rounds). The questions were basic and Leetcode Easy/Medium level. The Fundamentals questions were also doable. The interviews were conducive and made sure all doubts were resolved.
A recruiter contacted me on LinkedIn. Had an initial phone screening. The phone call is a basic HR conversation. After the phone interview I was given a test on algorithms and data structures.

Phone based interview. Don't stop at understanding the position you’re interviewing for. You should understand what's happening in the tech industry, what Microsoft is doing well, and how we can make ourselves stand out from the competition. Make sure to prepare questions to ask during your interview. This is also a chance for you to make sure that the opportunity is what you are looking for.
30 mins phone screens with 4 round vo in the same day(45 mins each). The 4 round interview asked about python and sql coding, behavior, project experiences, and machine learning basics

Vlotte ervaring, 2 gesprekken met verschillende managers. Het duurde wel enkele weken voor ik antwoord kreeg. Er werden enkel gesprekken afgenomen en geen testen. Vorige sales ervaringen waren belangrijk. Talenkennis is belangrijk in een internationale omgeving.

Interview process took 2.5 months with another month in administrative processes to be able to start the job, so 3.5 months from interview to starting the job. Overall, it was a pleasant experience but just seemed a bit too slow.

This begins with a phone screening where they inquire more about your resume and work experience . Then you may receive a take home assessment. After completing the assessment you'll be invited to a multi-round panel interview with various leads. YMMV

Marketers are responsible for the development and execution of a company's marketing campaigns to boost its promotional efforts. Their goal is to recognize an audience's need to purchase their company's products and to grow the business' profits by increasing sales

Mainly behavior questions surrounding how to handle various situations.  Tying the passion to the company mission is critical as well as being able to demonstrate growth mindset and embrace diversity and inclusion.

Mix of coding and design questions. Total of 6 rounds including initial screen round. The whole process took around a month. Had a good experience till the hiring manager round. The HM didn’t bother to properly introduce. Was not clear on the scope of design question that was asked. Too vague. But overall the experience was good. The process took 1 month.
Attended with virtual drive, went through 2 rounds but both of those rounds turned out to be design round which are more backend heavy. Most of the discussion was around distributed system and cloud.

It was a quite an unstructured interview with an engineering manager. Really strange technical questions that went into details were it made no sense to go into detail.
Multiple red flags (e.g. no clear plan of execution) came up that had me on the edge of just stopping the interview immediately.

My CV has not moved from action center, yet they continually post the job  - exact same detail and team - under a different code number.   Further inquiry only states they are still reviewing my application, 4 months later.

SUPER NEGATIVE experience.. don't know how Microsoft could fall down so low.
I was interviewing for Software Engineer 2 for which I applied before joining another company as a Senior Software Engineer. Before interview process I have told recruiter my compensation package expectations for this moment. He said it is okay. In a week after last interview round I received the offer which was much lower that I expected. I'd started to bargain and I have mentioned in the mail to recruiter, that according to internet resources compensation package which he provided is more corresponding to Software Engineer 1 than 2. He mentioned that "a lot of info online is not that accurate as it should be" (c).  Okay... , I asked straightforwardly: "was I suggested L61 or L62 position?" He answered: "Unfortunately, I am not authorized to talk about the Levels when discussing comp with candidates."(c).   OKAY..    We scheduled 2nd call to talk about details (we were discussing offer about a week by mail) AND EVEN BY   PHONE he was saying in the beginning: We usually just say Software Engineer in offer (c). After 5 MIN of questioning I found out that I was suggested SOFTWARE ENGINEER 1 (L60) position not Software Engineer 2.. AND IT IS FINE BY ME, BUT WHY YOU WERE HIDING IT FOR WHOLE WEEK  ????? IT REALLY LOOKED AS A CHEATING... He even were telling that I will find out my grade only after joining.... WHAT ??? SERIOUSLY ?? AM I A SLAVE ??? ..  WOW.. MICROSOFT...HOW COULD YOU...  I am not a kid and I am fine to be rejected, and also I am fine to be suggested low offer than I am expecting BUT IT IS CHEATING TO INTENTIONALLY HIDE THE POSITION ..

Some weird tricks. For example, when I finished writing up my proposed solution, the interviewer drew a line on the board and asked me if I was confident enough in my solution to sign my name to it. Very bizarre test of overconfidence...I did not sign my name but don't appreciate those types of mind games in an interview.

The administration was a bit messed up and I got the wrong interview time after the codified assessment. Yet the interview itself was a great experience — the interviewer was approachable and willing to share. The questions were a bit less technical than I thought (it could just be that I talked too much when answering the behavioral lol).
Leetcode and behavioral. Interview process has 4 rounds, each 45 minutes long, with leetcode style questions and behavioral questions. Interview was not too bad and everyone I talked to was great

Leetcode Easy/Medium, 45 minute interviews. 3 with engineers 1 with a PM. They ask some simple systems design questions - very intuitive. A few simple questions about your resume and personality in a team.
Recruiter phone interview, hiring manager phone, skip-level manager phone, then a day of on-site loop with six 1:1 interviews with team members and members of teams that I would be working with.

The overall interview process was devastating. I was depressed during and after the interview process. I am still recovering. I would never ever want to go through such a depressing stage again in my life, no matter what culture/CTC they offer.

I was interviewed with Microsoft for two positions/teams separately.

The recruiters were not transparent in the process and did not describe the interview process or the role. They are under the impression that because Microsoft is a big brand, they can get away by providing minimum information because anyways candidates will still come and give interviews whenever asked. Interviews were cancelled/rescheduled more than 10 times. The process is very slow and takes months. Until you give a call to the recruiter they do not care to schedule your next round, even if you have cleared the previous round. 

Interviewers need to understand that a candidate's whole day is wasted if you cancel the interview at the end time.

Interviewers ask detailed technical questions for the role of a product manager ex drawing the whole exact architecture, data models etc and reject the candidates even if they are excellent in the product management role. The interviewers were not sympathetic. They didn't even want to listen to your work. They judge you based on technical knowledge for non-technical roles. It is like judging a fish based on its ability to climb a tree.

PS: I am happy in my current small company. At least they respect me, my work and understand the basics like coding is for developers and not for PMs. If you are very strict on these things, please inform the candidates beforehand, so that their morale is not destroyed.

Worst interview process I have ever been apart of, the interviewers were really nice but the recruiters were a disgrace, They just stopt answer me after interview calls, I contacted the recruiter for feedback multiple times by phone and email and got zero response. AVOID.

Few step process:
1. Coding test with a few tasks (written on paper)
2. 3 back-to-back interviews with engineers from different departments. Some were more technical and had coding tasks to be done on a whiteboard, while others involved talking about system design and solving a particular imaginary problem.

Had an intro call with recruiter. Sent me few questions(Current role, comp, legal status etc) to answer. I did not hear back again. Sent followup but no response. Guess there was some issue with answers. They can at least reply with something.

The first interview was an online assessment through Codality. The assessment consisted of coding questions and multiple choice questions. Then there is a second interview which was completed virtually in person with various teams at Microsoft.

There is one recruiter round, and then there are 4 interviews for the final onsite. There are only two rounds. The recruiter round is basically behavioral. The onsite is a mix of technical, behavioral, and case.
Applied on career website first round was 60 mins phone interview with Hiring Manager on basic statistics and python coding.  Make sure you know the math behind the basic models.

It was very interesting and all the question were around job description. Scenario based 4 rounds and i could clearly understand the  role expectations. 
Unfortunately response time post interview sessions were  not as per expectation, it took almost 2 months

1. your direct report interview
2. group presentation interview
2. individual interview 360 interview with cross team  
3. 6 round in total
4. then HR interview
5. final offering

It's quite common norm in the IT industry 
most important is your culture fit for the company

The interview process with Microsoft was awesome, very nice engineers, recruiters were very responsive throughout the process. 

Definitely prepare for Medium to Hard coding interview questions. Behavioral portion was very natural and a smooth conversation.

Tons of algorithm question based on logic and in advance preparation and memorization of typical computer science problems. Most of the tasks are not that hard but require you to brush up on previous knowledge of algorithms and data structures.

Did a 30 minute interview at my college followed by an interview onsite in their Redmond office. The first interview asked a fairly standard coding question. The onsite was 2 interviews where I got asked a combination of behavioral and technical questions (some more open ended than others).

2 rounds of interviews:
1st: 1 hour
2nd: 3 x 1hour
Interviewers were very friendly. Standard leetcode questions with some interesting extensions. Also asked about some questions that they had solved previously on the job.

Full day onsite with 4 interviewers. Each interviewer focuses on a particular area: coding, design, process, etc. Breaks in between for water and lunch.  Nice experience overall. Is this thirty words?

This, according to me, was the best interview I'd ever given, yet the outcome was not what I was expecting!


Applied via their website. Heard back from the Hiring Manager within two weeks.
They set up an initial phone screen with another Engineer.
Had to follow up constantly for over a month to finally get invited for 4 rounds of virtual onsite.

Round #1 - Technical React Interview (task based) (with Senior Engineer)
Round #2 - Purely behavioural (with Director of Engineering)
Round #3 - System Design and Behavioural (with Principal Engineering Manager)
Round #4 - Technical React (task based - continuation of #1) (with Lead Engineer)

Heard back within 1 day from the recruiter. Standard 'sorry, not hired' without any feedback, even on request of the same.

First the recruiter called me. The call was for 30 minutes, Then he sent me a coding questions. it took me 2 hours to solve. Then I had a loop of 4 interviews, 45 minute each, at the same day. The interviewers were friendly and nice. Each interview had a coding question, either a system or software design question or a small method to write. The overall experience was good. Nothing to be stressed about.

It was a long iterative process. An initial interview at a  job fair, then a local interview, a phone interview, and a final multi-round interview at Microsoft's Seattle office. They were kind and informative at every step.

I applied online.

Recruiter reached me out and invited me for an virtual event.

The event was included 4 round interview.

Overall was good however I didn’t get an offer,
I placed in talent plus pool

Codility home exam, then a code exam with a team leader, then a questions exam with a group manager.
In between a recruiter is connecting you to schedule the next session.

A sadistic number of interviewers and a process not worth for someone actively looking and interviewing with different and equally competitive companies. With this lengthy and overkilled process, I was hoping the intention is to reduce biases, looking for culture add and evaluate candidates. Paradoxically,  the process felt more like looking for someone who looks like them, acts like them, and speaks like them, otherwise, not a fit. I felt little representation in the process at all with the many interviewers I had. Let alone the attitude some interviewers have because they think they work for some God.

Don't waste your time doing these many interviews, don't be part of the problem. Know your worth and go somewhere else before investing your time here. While the company can be enticing there is probably better opportunities out there to grow faster than here.

Initial Teams video pre-screen "whiteboarding" a theoretical design followed by a 6-hour interview circuit with 4 1-hour interview sessions taking place on a single day. Each interviewer decides whether you're writing code or whiteboarding the solution (sometimes they give you the flexibility to pick which). Two were clear with requirements and I thought very helpful with their hints, while the other two did not present in a clear way. As always, if I had seen the particular leetcode questions ahead of the interview I'd have done much better (partially because I wouldn't need to rely on the interviewers to clarify reqs, etc.). They were all what I would classify as "leetcode medium" questions.

I feel that doing these interviews with MSFT and AMZN and others is a decent way to prepare as I haven't really seen technical interviews that were harder than those from MSFT and AMZN, however you really have to grind for several months (after work) or a few weeks (not holding down a full time job) at least to clear enough of these potential leetcode problems to where you will have seen (ideally) all of them already when you get into the interview. That's always been my gripe with these intervews- anyone who passes them has probably completed the same basic problem on HackerRank and it's not "really" a test of coding ability so much as it's a test of memory.

The overall process was pretty simple, go through a usual support role. Interview was quick, and the process what smoothly overall. I would recommend giving a bit more time to the interviewee, as it was difficult to provide an accurate solution in the time alotted.

The interview process was standard.
This requirement was for Azure team
The first round consisted of a medium-level LC coding problem and some OS related questions. I was able to solve the problem and run through test cases but took few mins to debug for a particular test case. So the feedback was borderline. 
The second round had some project-related questions, scenario-based questions, and one medium LC problem. The feedback was good.
The third round consisted of a system design problem.  Although, I covered the all the points but the interviewer was expecting some more details especially around the services. The feedback was borderline.



- The second and third round feedback seemed fair. I still didn't understand why the first round feedback was borderline.

The process was very transparent and professional. It took less time that I expected. The interviewer was cordial. The instructions were clear and they resolve every doubt I had of the company and the questions asked.

Virtual interview with Human Resources. Fairly basic behavioral based questions, but also asked for several examples. Mostly focused on the more negative, learning experiences within past. Did not focus on experiences very much.
Phone screen then on-site with 5 interviews - product design, coding, exec screen, lunch chat, behavioral. This interview was conducted a few years ago at this point so process may have changed
2 part interview, one regarding design and the other on coding. Before in person interview was an over the phone interview where they asked more about my focuses and interests.

On teams. I had three interviews, two with developers from the place and the last one with the person who was in charge. The last interview was on C only, and he asked question related to the language.
People were kind when conducting the interview and reached out about an interview time that worked well for me. I was contacted for interview as part of their university recruiting process.
The interview was on time and casual.  The people I met with seemed knowledgeable about the company and the position.  I met with three different people over about one hour.

Three separate interviews on zoom (COVID). All were technical, one after the other, each with a different team. Who you interview with doesn’t much match what preferences you select for team you would want
The whole Hiring took three weeks. Interviews are pretty normal process, From Phone interviews to  Screen interviews to  Technical interviews to  lab interview with review on what you did. Fun.

It was okay. A bit difficult. Had to code while being monitored. Was expecting good feedback. Interviewer was friendly and nice. Would love to have another opportunity to interview with them. Prepare well before hand

The process took few weeks. 1st interview with hr, 2nd with technical expert, 3rd with managers.  the hr is just about wage, notice and expectations. The technical is very deep dive in a architectural solution. the manager part is very oriented to soft skills

The first round includes - Codility test- and skype interview. Codility test included 3 q's in different levels about data structers, algorithms etc. Skype interview was around 30 minutes and included q's about courses you've taken and other personal q's.

Took over 2 months for entire process with weeks idle in between. Interview questions are the same Data structures and alg questions that are asked in any other software companies. Medium level questions
I did not do the interview! i got the internship through military! i just applied through my school! but for other poeple i believe you have to go through this process

It was a coding interview on the codility platform. On data structures and algorithms, there was first a set of mcq questions then two coding problems. Unfortunately I didn't not pass the first phase so I can not talk about the rest.

Very scattered, changed time and interview loop several times. Standard questions. No surprises. There were four people on the interview loop, each had a unique zoom login (actually, Teams). They were professional, but not very probing. You need to work to demonstrate what YOU drove, because the interviewers did not pull it from me.
On campus interviewer was a bit rude and was condescending. The actual technical questions were not very difficult though. Ultimately, I decided not to continue the interview process with them.

I applied online. A week later, I completed an online coding assessment. 3 weeks later, I was scheduled for a virtual "on-site" interview with 4 interviewers, 45 minutes each with 15 minutes breaks in between.

Interview was about previous experience and enterprise sales experience in the cloud industry as well as background in data platforms. It was 3 interviews and then a presentation for a group of people

Straight forward first round, initial phone call and technical screeners. Same experience as other reviewers. The questions focused on cloud deployments, because that was the area of my focus. Not yet in person but up next

Two easy codility questions, that need to be completed within an hour. Followed by two technical interviews, the first is a medium-hard coding question and the latter is a design interview question, both of these take 75 minutes.

Long & extensive.  5 different rounds focusing on different aspects, from soft skills to technical capabilities.  The interview latest the full day, approx 6 hours.  Interviewers we're well prepped, they knew what they were looking for - no room for 'fillers'

It was the best interview experience for me! Recruiters have been so kind and supporting!

First Round - HR: Mainly behavioral questions like tell me about a time....
Final Round - Assessment Centre: It consists of 3 1-on-1 interviews, 1 business case, 1 group case and 2 networking session and takes half-day.

First I had one Codility Online Test which contained 2 questions to complete in about 80 mins.
One question was on numbers processing, it is on Internet & if one has seen that number question or knows that number system then solve with best performance, as I was able to get 40% in performance with my standard soln. Second question was on Text data processing which is not difficult also. So overall Codility Questions were average.
Then I had one round of discussion where the interviewer asked me to write the code to solve one problem, my approach couldn't have worked properly so he gave the hint but I was not able to complete the code in next 30 mins.
In 2nd round, I was asked to design a system, for which I made one rough & very high level kind of design & interviewer was expecting more clear & modularized design.
Though every interviewer claims that they don't expect everyone to know everything but still in interviews they expect the correct, good & production ready answers for their specific 1-2 questions. Many other things too but in short, reality of these companies will be far from what they claim, I think so.

First interview was with HR, second - with Sales manager. Very professional process, clear questions, nice communication style. The process was quite long in terms of time, big gaps between each step.

Engineering manager reached out asking me to interview for their team. 
Had a technical screen which was pretty simple.
Was then called for onsite which was 5 rounds which consisted of  3 behavioural and 2 technical rounds. The technical rounds were not difficult but the behavioural ones were very long and taxing.

Talent acquisition administrator conducted multiple online interviews with the current architects as well as the district manager. Mainly discussed about their daily responsibilities and answer the case by case problem solving question.

Held by teams and it needs two rounds interview. Each round will have 2 sections. Each sections will hold around 1 hour. The interview is hold in English or mother language depends on the interviewer.

1) Recruiter reached out on LinkedIn.
2) Scheduled online assessment of 1 hour.
3) Virtual loop interview 4 rounds with a team (4 coding rounds leetcode style).
 - First with manager, very disappointed with this round and his attitude. 
- Rest 3 rounds with team members, who were very friendly and professional.
4) Response within 3 days.

Passed the first coding interview, invested 4 hours of my day to complete the final stage that were 4 interviews in total ( system design, coding, "software design" and competencies). Didn't enjoy the process, some of the interviewers did not put much effort to make the conversations comfortable and fluid.
Finally, I was ghosted, did not get any feedback and only found out I was not selected after looking at the candidate home page 1 week later. I did not get further feedback from recruiter, not even an automated email with the final status.

I applied through Referral and my profile is entirely diversified to the SkillSet. It was a pretty positive experience in the entire interview process.

Call with Recruiter: Brief overview of my professional experience and job roles and responsibilities.
After 2 weeks, she mentioned that I was shortlisted for the next round of interviews . 2 interviews on the same day.

Technical: Troubleshooting skills, API, UI, Network and Process Troubleshooting questions, Questions based on Customer Empathy. They tested my past customer support experiences. Be careful while answering as there will be many follow-up questions. If you can answer all those right then you will be through. So prepare 4-5 good customer-based experience scenarios from your profile.

Behavioural: Hiring Manager and Department Head took my behavioral round and they made me feel comfortable. They got my inputs from the technical panel.
There were questions on Customer focus, dealing with ambiguity, and also about the feedback on the tech panel what I liked and doesn't like in the interview.

I sent Thankyou email to my recruiter the next day and shared my positive experience with panel and requested her to extend my thanks to the entire panel.
She replied that I will get an update within a week or two.

As mentioned, she called me exactly after 2 weeks and said I was through.
The only Key is to Prepare well, BE Honest in all of your answers and discussions as the panel easily identifies who can make up stories.
All the Very Best.

Insgesamt waren es 3 Schritte. Ein normales Screening vom Recruiter durchgeführt. Danach ein Gespräch mit dem Hiring Manager und am Schluss noch ein Roleplay mit der Skip Level Managerin. Nach der Zusage gab es noch die Möglichkeit das Angebot zu verhandeln.

1. Resume screening 
2. 1st round interview  
3. 2nd round interview 
4.  3rd round interview 

All interviews are conducted online. That’s only good about having been interviewed by Microsoft. The whole interview (1st round interview) felt the most DEFAMING one ever for myself. After a brief self introduction, the interviewer suddenly lost a temper and said to me ‘Can you just say it more in detail?! I have no idea what you’re going to say!!’.  …Excuse me, how can you behave rude to a person you’ve ever met for the first time?! (In Japanese culture is it considered totally OK to be rude to a person you meet for the first time?) And then, when I told him about my salary expectation, he went on to say ‘such low salary is not a standard for Microsoft, our work quality is quite high and does not deserve your low salary expectation.’ 
I’m quite turned off by the impolite, non-respectful (and childish) behavior and will never, ever consider working for this company in the future. Interviewers in any position or division should learn a tiny inch of your bad behavior will ruin the whole reputation of the company!

It was through engage mentorship program. We had to create a working prototype of a video call application. It was through engage mentorship program. We had to create a working prototype of a video call application.

First I had test on Codility which I passed with 100% then they scheduled 4 interviews one after another in one day. After one month I had the results and had another information meeting with the Project Manager. After that they gave me an offer.
The job description is incomplete and the recruiter who is processing my application is unprofessional. In fact, she was late because she was cooking according to her.  She was apologetic, however.

Brief behavioral phone interview, was supposed to be followed by a second round super day. Received notification that I advanced to the second round but never got an interview date. Weeks later I was informed that all the positions had been filled

It was a rotation of interviews with 4 different executives, each one lasting an hour.  It covered a combination of experience questions about my experience and background, my industry  expertise as well as how I approach problem solving and deal making .
There were two interviews. In the first one, I discussed a problem with the interviewer. It was a maximization problem. The second one was more concentrated on data structures and complexities.

interviewed with 4 people from different teams, questions were more related to machine learning position rather than the data science, and then there was a data structure coding, I think recruiters should let candidates know which team they're interviewing for and see what they're interested in

The interview was informal, comfortable, and very fun. It felt like a discussion and I enjoyed my time. I had 3 interviews, but because my interviews were virtual I was able to schedule them on different days.
Overall vague but quick and painless,  initially a phone screen with a sorcer - then 3, 45 minute video interviews with. 4 different people.  I was contacted by a recruiter so not actively looking

Though the process was good and fast, there was no response from the team after final round. Even after multiple follow ups, there was no conclusion. HR needs to complete the process and not hang the participants midway.

4 rounds- experience based, ad marketplace based case studies, approach to data analysis, cultural fit. Questions based on past relevant experience related to bing.  Panel was really experienced and it was a good experience where they will make you feel comfortable.

first interview behavioral interview such as questions like tell me about challenges working on a team project, a logical question: find heavy marble out of 9 while you have two weights.
2 and 3 interview are coding interview all made via skype

Few rounds were good but few rounds are not. Interviewer did not take the complete scheduled time to complete the process took only 25% of the time to complete it.

The recruitment process sucks - there are folks like Mounica, Pruthvi, Mohan Reddy who just get in touch with the Candidate to schedule the interview but never turn up with feedback post interview. It doesn't matter what the feedback is but it matters to the candidate to know the result. It awful for a company like microsoft to have this kind of behaviour.

1 code before the interview like what you heard about Microsoft, tell me a difficult you had?, why here? 
1 interview about my self with someone from new York
1 interview about skill.

A initial conversation with the recruiter then four 1 hour interviews with a peer, two managers and a director.  The interviews were spread out over 3 day contiguous days. From contact with the recruiter to final interview was 2 weeks.
HR online interview in English. This was the first stage of the process and after you pass it there are two more technical interviews with senior software engineers in Microsoft

The interview took around 1 hr. It started with introducing yourself followed by some technical questions. And a white board coding question based on single linked list. If not able to solve no need to worry they can provide you with another question related to sorting the matrix diagonally. It should pass all the test cases and you must be able to explain the time and space complexity of your program.

Very casual, 3 interviewers that switched off asking questions during the 1 hour process. Left time for me to ask questions at the end. Was completely virtual over teams. Conversational- I wasn't talking by myself for most of the time which was very nice.

The interview process was really quick itself, only one coding interview online with three different problems and then one single day of three coding interviews with three different interviewers. But the background check was painfully slow.
It was nice and i was very prepared for it, i'm glad to clear it. I love now being a part of MS in 4th year. And this isn't letting me go untill 30 words
It was extremely straight forward and clear from the start of the interview process. It was 3 rounds of interviews with 3 Interviewers who had asked me questions which  focussed on 3 different arenas
An online coding test followed by an HR interview. Then you schedule a technical interview. Medium - Hard questions on leetcode were asked. 4 rounds of a standard interviews are the usual .

There were 4 rounds, 
1. Online assessment
2. Problem solving
3. LLD
4.HM round
in online assessment and Problem solving medium level DSA questions were asked, questions topics like graph traversal, DP, stack were asked

Straight forward. On-campus interview -> super day. Super day consisted of 6 interviews, going up in seniority. 5 were technical and 1 was more of an HR interview. Although they were technical in nature, it was all white boarding and no actual coding on a computer. Overall interesting experience

1-hour + 1-hour interviews come firstly.
The next is teamleader interview.
C + AI SDE, ask some leetcode medium questions, including DFS, hashmap. They are very friendly and patient, no pressure at all.

Awesome process, quick and simple. The people who interviewed me were super friendly and open.
The process lasted for 2 months when I got the offer.
Only 2-step interview process, first and final rounds.

1. HR shortlist
2. 3 interview rounds back to back in a single day

1st round was portfolio round.
2nd round was a live problem solving round.
3rd round will be only taken if you have atleast 1 'yes' from each round.

Be well prepared, great detailed interview. Come with questions to ask the interviewer. Be yourself and keep it real. Multiple rounds of interviews and technical interviews as well. Stay engaged and focuses asking every and any question that you find interesting.

I had one phone screen 30 minutes. I was invited for an interview 3 months later. Did an initial interview with the hiring manager and afterwards a technical interview with 4 employees. I didn't get a response in 2 months. And had to reach out to the recruiter multiple times to follow up. They didn't give me an offer, they closed my application 2 months after the technical interview.

At first I had a timed exam in Codilty and after that an interview with a very nice woman, she asked about what I covered so far in my studies, in topics like data structures, OOP, Algorithms etc. 
she asked me how I would describe recursion for a ten year old.
and a problem solving riddle, if I have 9 rocks that are all in the same weight except one of them, which is a little heavier, how can i find that one rock with 2 scales on a scale

Phone:
What excites you about technology?
One fav Microsoft product?
What would you improve about it?
Did you take OS and DS and Algo class?
Threads vs processes ?
How would you explain recursion to a child?
Time you dealt with a conflict in a team?

The first interview is 15 mins with HR, quickly general check, and she will share with you how the process is, you can learn the process details with HR.
Then they will arrange another meeting for you. 
The second interview is 30 mins with the hiring manager, also general check.
The third interview is with the future team you are going to join, it's 1hr meet. 
And if you pass this one, should have 2 or 3 more interviews.
