This is about on campus interview for MS Hyderabad a couple of years ago. After clearing the OT and the first round of interviews, we were asked to wait for the second round. During the second round, they interviewed only all the girls first, and after their interviews were done, they told the rest of us that we could leave (without giving us the second interview that we were waiting for).

I feel that if they were planning on only recruiting women, then they could have been upfront about it from the start. Plenty of companies conduct diversity hiring drives and mostly nobody has problems with that. They didn't have to waste everyones time or give us any hope of getting the internship. They tried to make it seem to the rest of the college as if coincidentally all the good candidates they hired were girls, and that there was no bias. But to anyone who was there, it was quite evident that it was rigged. I don't know why they did it in this way. It literally benefitted no one involved.

Interview process consisted of 5 day data insights test, you are given a huge db and you can choose preferred language to wrangle some data. They didn't specify any problem to solve, just to demystify if there are any specific insights which you could underline

I submitted a resume through the portal, and I heard back 3 days later about a first round phone screening interview. 

First Round (Little more than a week later): 30 Minute Interview with a Recruiter. This was a phone call. I was asked questions for about 20 minutes. They were all behavioral questions and some conceptual technical questions 

I heard about the second round about 5 days later, and  got an email about a final round interview 2 weeks later.

Final Round Interview: 4 interviews (45-55 min each), with 15 minutes in between. The interviews were virtual. Some product design questions, but most of my questions were behavioral, resume based, and experience based.
It was terrible - Waited forever to get back to you, and didnt really ask good question. Seemed that they didnt want to be there. Overall it was a very ehhh experience.
Totaled 1 hour. In the first 30 minutes I talked about my previous research experience and then they went through their ongoing projects for this position. Just like a Ph.D. interview.

Son 4-5 entrevistas dependiendo del puesto con casos prácticos. La mayoría también se enfocan en tu impacto como persona y super orientado a métricas. En general quedé satisfecho con el proceso de selección.

Very simply process. Nothing too complicated. Questions pertaining to background and so on and so forth. Overall it was a great experience. I would highly recommend Microsoft for a tenured engineer as the environment is very accommodating and preferred.
The process was one HR screen followed by three remote interviews. Know your resume well and practice product design and you'll do great. They are focused on knowing you and how you think.

Mehrere Gespräche (online und offline) über einen Monat verteilt, seit Corona sind jedoch alle Gespräche ausschließlich online, da auch 100% remote gearbeitet wird. Das erste Gespräch ist mit einer HR Mitarbeiterin, die restlichen mit dem potentiell zukünftigen Team
I was a previous summer intern, so the process was more focused on finding a team I wanted to work with. HR got me to chat with a few different teams at Bing.

- The interview happens on MS team - which is a very poor tool. The app (mac) never starts up and browser client is very very bad. In one interview There were continuous drop offs and voice issues which took up 10-15 min of my interview time and created lot of misunderstanding between both the parties

- Interviewers are ,  no other word here , egoistic. Few articulated clearly and could communicate properly but most had very bad communication skills. One even kept giving feedback during the interview which derailed me a lot (and some unwelcome comments too). Common among all was the ego factor. Nothing like other US based companies I have been giving rounds with. In contrast, others dont give feedback and even if you are having the worst interview possible will hold their emotions to themselves. Microsoft, was very disappointing.

There was no feedback asked, so this goes to Glassdoor

Interview process is pretty straightforward, you meet with a panel of 4 people and you are asked about experience and scenario based questions. As a black woman you have to have all the requirements. My experience with this company is black applicants are  are held to a higher standard in terms of being able to check all the boxes before being hired! Yet the company claims to have a growth mindset. Their diversity numbers prove my point! Please see their African American  numbers compared to
 Asians and whites.  CEO will have to work on mid mangers biases who make most of the hiring decisions.

I had a phone interview, then an on site interview about 2 weeks later. The on site interview was 4 rounds, started from the morning around 8am to noon. I heard results of the interview about a week later.

online coding test at the Codility.app with three coding problems 1 easy, and two more challenging & personal phone interview via Skype with some behavioural questions about myself, some logic questions as well.

1 interview. 30 minutes. Talking about myself and some behaviour questions

Then 4 interviews during an afternoon. One interview was behaviour. The other a team session. And the last one technical.

Whiteboarding session, followed by questions and answers about personal work history & interests. I asked some questions unrelated to the engineering position about the research division, and the interviewer seem to take this as my interests being elsewhere than pure SWE; I was not called back to interview for the internship position.

1) Phone Call
2) Skype
3) Skype Round 2
4) Email

It was a pleasant and easy process. And everyone seemed super friendly. They reached out to me with an amazing opportunity and got to discuss what type of project I will be working on.

I was contacted by a recruiter who then set up a 30-minute virtual interview with the hiring manager over Microsoft Teams. The hiring manager arrived 10 minutes late so we only had 20 minutes and it wasn't enough time. It felt very rushed.

It was a technical interview process. The interviewer was trying to see which languages I was proficient in for the position. Even though he hinted that I did not get the job, he was friendly and offered some advice on not giving up on the job search.
Applied online. Got coding test. Finished the coding test. Asked a question over email. Got a rejection back. Was a fun coding test. I liked it very much. Has some details in the email.

Skype video where the recruiter asks behavioural questions . The interview was 1 hour long . That was the first round of interview . I didn’t recieve a call back from the company following the first round of interview .
Phone interview with a developer of the team I was applying to be a developer. Some knowledge-based questions and a technical assessment. All in all, took around an hour to complete.

First round was good, it was with a senior PM. Lasted 2 hours.
Second round was with a lead developer. The interviewer asked 7 SQL questions, I was able to answer 5.  I was given a "no hire" saying lacking technical skills but good program management skill set. I don't understand how can a PM be rated on how many SQL queries can be answered rather than the actual PM Skills. What is the different between a developer and a PM then.
You will have a 30 minutes prep from the recruiter team a day or two before your interview telling you what you would expect to ask and focus on, not all companies will do that - this is interesting.

Microsoft's HR directly reached out to me via LinkedIn. I made it very clear to the recruiter upfront that my choice of language is C#, secondarily Java or even C++ is OK. 
However the coding test they sent had a question for which answer should be in Python (no choices. The question itself mentioned to write the answer in Python). 
This took significantly more time as I didn't know Python so ended up giving my best answer in C#. 
The question itself was not difficult but making it compulsory in Python made it so. 
I got the rejection email later. I told my recruiter but no avail. 
This kind of interview practice is unfair and highly discouraging for candidates who hope they will get a fair chance.
They don't even seem to bother about these things. 
It's extremely disappointing to go through a process which seems determined to make you fail.

The interview process was succinct and well thought through. There were several stages to the process, including a verbal written and problem solving exercises. The process lasted one whole day and was overall an enjoyable experience.

The interviewees were very approachable and friendly. The interview was focused mainly around fundamentals of algorithms and data structures  therefore knowing the basics is essential. As well as that, behavioural questions were asked at the beginning of the interview.

A video interview with a recruiter from the European HR department. They asked me to tell more about me, why I want to work there and asked me some technical java questions, not related to the position I applied for, they just wanted to suggest me a software engineering position.

Initial interview was thoroughly thought out and was designed to review all pertinent information for the success of a future employee succeeding and doing well.  I was very impressed with their process.

it was ok. mostly just back and fourth one off questions. ya know? I could see it being a little more difficult for other positions however. If you have a decent looking portfolio then they are most likely to let you on at at least a blue badge rate.

The interview was a 1.5-hour session. It included both coding questions and discussion around my previous experiences and research projects. A big picture of their position and its project directions was also explained. I was supposed to get a second interview. I received I guess after a month or so.
Great interview. I really thought the interview went well and they were very professional. I’m not sure if I’ll get it but I enjoyed the experience. It was a good experience r

They moved fast, the interviewer was friendly and made me feel relaxed. We joked a little bit and told me about his experience with the company. I got asked if I was free  for the next round of interviews which made me think I was getting to the next round.

Home assignment + skype call + 2-3 technical interviews. You do the first two steps. Then procced to two technical interviews. And then to one final interview. I got an offer from another company after first interview. Therefore i didn't continue with Microsoft.

Tests connaissances sur l'environnement Windows / connaissances informatiques globales
Entretien à distance (teams) + entretien sur place 

Processus de recrutement sur une période de deux semaines - Réponses assez rapides

Easy phone screen to make sure my experience and the role aligned, then an initial phone interview. Easy questions, nothing technical. I withdrew my application when I realized the role wasn't the right fit I was looking for.

I participated in an interview "loop", which included a series of interviews with 7 people all in one day.  I was given an offer the day after the loop.

Mostly cultural fit and behavioral questions.  I was also asked about the industry the role focused on as well as my approach to building partnerships.

Very well done, professional and thorough. This was a three step interview and a great experience. There were peer discussions and management interviews and it gave an awesome opportunity to ask relevant questions.

Es gab einen Bewerbungsprozess auf der Website des eigenen Bewerbungsportals von Microsoft sowie auch ein online Interview. Dort wurde dann auch einiges zu früheren Jobs und anderen relevanten Erfahrungen gefragt.

Easy process with questions related to previous work experience, personal duties, skills and communication...
Focus was on organizational skills, time-management and written communication skills. 
Question about personal traits and aspirations.
 Interview lasts about 60min.

Very thorough interview which you really need to prepare for to solve complex situations. Skills like critical thinking are essential if you want to work for Microsoft. Be ready for the long process of interviews.

The process took around 2 months. I got first round phone call interview with HR, and then move to onsite. For onsite, I interviewed with four different engineers, and all of them are nice to talk with. For new grad position, most questions are data structure. Asked a lot about tree and linked list. Good experience overall.

Consisted mostly of being asked midlevel engineering questions and listening to the interviewer bragging about his past accomplishments.  I don't know why I need to enter 30 words here; hasn't anyone ever heard of brevity?

Took quite long but the interview was fair - a lot of standard questions about strength, weaknesses and previous experiences. Special emphasis on how certain situations in previous roles were handled.
Great experience very friendly overall. Seems to truly care about learning more about candidates values and how it aligns with the company values. Still awaiting if I will receive an offer

Multiple rounds of interviews 

The way you solve the product design questions are actually how you work in teams too. The interviewer is not just asking you a question and observing but also working with you on the problem.

4 Rounds - Recruiter Intro (phone call), Manager screen (phone call), Technical Screen w/ Algorithm & General Knowledge (Video), and Technical Signals (Project Feature Enhancement, Unit Tests for feature, System Design) and Behavioural Interview.
Too long of a process. Didn't get any feedback on why I didn't get the job afterwards. Interviewers were a bit weird in asking question and left it up to interpretation

Phone call 
Portfolio review (45-60 minutes) going through a research with some questions 
Presentation (30 minute and than questions all in English about 7 on call) 
2 more technical interviews with researchers and designers

Interview Process ::
1. recruiter call
2. online test in codelity tool . 
3. 2 technical rounds (Data Structures)
I was able to go through Online Test but was not able to go through first technical round .
I would suggest Microsoft to not only test candidate on DataStructures , if candidate is able to solve the problem without dataStructure you should consider that candidate . Most of the questions asked in MIcrosoft Technical interviews were already available in LEETCODE , if someone already used LEETCODE they will have higher chances of selection. 
So i would suggest you to test the candidate in all aspects , Technology , concepts can be learn in a month or two but attitude and character is very important to see in candidate .
Very interesting, it was more focused on engineering skills, ambition and will to learn more than coding a irrelevant problem that means absolutely nothing in the real world of engineering.

Codility phone screen test (number of good nodes, CS fundamentals related questions). Interviewed for a hiring event. Very rushed and disorganized.  Did not have enough time to solve the problems and interviewers joined late.
Interview process started with an HR screen followed by an interview with the hiring manager followed by 4 45 minute interviews with various people in the Research & Insights team.

6 people in total, 2 technical and 4 behavior and culture, it took 2 months as an end to end period and negotiation process was standardized as well.  I used the cracking the pm interview as study materials.

The interview followed a standard behavioral interview structure, starting with an introduction from the recruiter and myself and followed by rather standard questions. A lot of attention was put on my technical skills/experiences in the tech field as well as my enthusiasm for technology. In the end I got the chance to ask questions which was very helpful as I got to know a lot about the internal culture of Microsoft. The recruiter was very sweet and I felt comfortable at all times.

After applying, they sent an online technical test which consisted of 2 problems and a few MCQs. After passing the test, I was invited to 2 virtual technical interviews. The interviews are 45 minutes each with different mentors from different areas among ATL Cairo.

Initial interview with another CE, general chat with some technical questions.
Second round of interviews comprised of a management style interview with two managers, then a technical interview with two CEs.

I chased a number of times for feedback but was completely ignored by the Microsoft recruitment team.

Interviews that are both wonderful and challenging (in a good way). I had the opportunity to meet a broad range of people from other countries and specializations, and all of them were exceptionally pleasant.

two rounds. internship position. conducted virtually. hr was very nice and gave all candidates of the interview process walkthrough. Keep in your mind that the questions they gave you might asked during your interview. no technical questions all behaviour
The company flew me to a regional office where I met a very friendly and personable team.  I stayed 2 days and had 30 minute interviews with 5 different people.  Some were technical, most were not.

The interviewer didn't ask about any of my backgrounds and started throwing strange questions, including linear algebra, server-side concepts, front-end design. Very impatient and unfriendly person, seems wanted the interview as soon as possible hence giving me some random questions
The interview process was very professional and clear. All the questions asked are very on point and relevant, all in all it was helpful experience for me as a job searcher.

One interview with internal Recruiter. This was followed by a 3 hour interview with multiple folks split out into 3 sessions. Each session lasted 45 - 60 minutes. Also had to give a presentation where you are given a format on what to prepare. Basically, sale yourself. Why should you be hired.

The interview process is a multi-stage process for hiring new employees. The interview process typically includes the following steps: writing a job description, posting a job, scheduling interviews, conducting preliminary interviews, conducting in-person interviews, following up with candidates and making a hire.
Tough,  sales driven interview process.  All rounds were focused on how you have handled sales for an organization.  What levers you pulled to manage through the sales cycle in achieving the numbers.

Initial email request , scheduled 1hr video interview using MS team with a hiring manager, in a week. Starts with manager's introduction, then my intro info. Explanation of the process, coding using codility.com and rdrr.io online platforms.

I interviewed for a temp position so I was called in for an interview with another Lead Product Designer and Product Manager. I did a one-hour portfolio show followed by a half an hour whiteboard exercise.

There was a round of screening and I was reached out by the recruiter. They asked leetcode questions and whiteboarding.  Since this was for a junior developer position, they asked system designs to guage our technical ability.  There was a question on LRU cache.

It was a great process with great recruiters all the way. Came to the final round, but didn't through after onsite interviews. Had 4 interviews the same day virtually because of COVID. Everyone was really nice, and all of them were different managers in different teams.

I applied on their website, I received an email with a challenge code on codaility, the questions were hard. 
It wasn't from leetcode, the topics were graphs and trees,I wasn't expecting a graph problem

Applied online. Recruiter email contact. Screening interview with HM. Lots of emails for logistics. Scheduled into v-interviews couple of weeks later.  v-interviews make them too casual about scheduling, they book you with a large gaps between interviewers tying up your entire day.  Normal pm questions, but definitely felt the bias against my gender and age throughout. Made me uncomfortable and realized I wasn't going to get the role even though I was highly qualified for it. This was the usual popularity type interview process.  So it felt more like giving them free consulting.  Very disappointed with the interviewers attitudes and sad that the usual hidden biases are still being allowed/condoned.

two different roles and two different recruiters did not take the process seriously.  No organization, no follow through, no actual "recruiting" just checking boxes for minimum requirements.  For the interview that made it to the hiring team, they were unprepared, lacked the ability to formulate  interview questions and struggled to present/share screens for the assessment.  HM didn't bother to follow through either.  ZERO effort from everyone involved all around :(
Microsoft Interview via Microsoft Teams. I had two rounds of interview, and each was 30 minutes with pre-allocated time slot. Each had a mix of behavioral questions and technical questions.
Two round interview with super day. First one is on college campus. The other can be on phone. Super day is on Microsoft campus. Multi round interview with different people.

The intreview was held in Microsoft Teams. The recruiter asked me about my studies, projects that I took etc.
He ased about courses that I took already and wanted to know generel information about me.

I interviewed with 2 separate program managers in the hardware development department. The first interview was much more technical while the second was more situation based. Overall, I had a very pleasant experience although I was not chosen for the job.

codility test- 3 questions in any language you choose- 80 min.
30 min interview about yourself- personal information, why did you apply for Microsoft, fields of intrest, logic questions and professional information

first online test and after an overall online interview.
asked for technical knowlage and also logic and algorith understanding.
also asking for projects you did  and difficult you have in the projects.

Started with a 30 min phone call from hiring manager.
Then first technical interview,
after that home assignment that sould be delivered in 48 hours.
Then second interview to go over the home assignment.
Then a technical interview with team leader.
And the last one was AA interview with manager from other group in Microsoft.

Take 4 rounds of interviews and HR is asking for documents and after that nothing happens.
I am still waiting for further updates from HR. you should at least let us know that we are not selected.

It consisted of 2 sessions. The first was focused on code design, writing simple code and adding features to it.
The second one was more of a problem solving type, but it was an easy question.

A recruiter reached out to me via Linkedin to see if I would be interested in a phone screen. The phone screen lasted about 30 - 40 minutes, and covered background, potential fit for an Account Manager role and overall interest in Microsoft. 

At the end of the call the recruiter informed me that she would be passing my information along to the hiring team, and if they were interested in moving forward, I would be participating in an Interview Day of interviewing with 3 - 5 Microsoft employees across the Advertising org. 

The interviews were scheduled for the following week. The day was long, but the questions were fair and definitely test your ideation through to execution process. All in all it was an extremely enjoyable interview process and definitely sold me on wanting to work for Microsoft.

After the interviews, your profile is shared within the Microsoft org. These are employees that work across various business functions within Microsoft, ultimately making gaging whether or not you are a great fit overall.

This process took about a week. 

The week after my interview I was told the team was impressed and actually wanted me for a more advanced role. After another week, I received my final offer.

All in all, initial screen to final offer was about 4 weeks. I'll say this, really bring your best authentic self to your interviews, they aren't just filling seats, they truly are making sure they align the right talent within the most fitting roles.

Not very smooth when it came to coordination by the recruitment team, but interviews were smooth. Typical questions with coding round, design and architecture, people mgmt skills and leadership rounds.
I was quick and straight to the point. No trick questions. I really liked the interview they did with me in Microsoft. I was expecting a second interview but there was none.

first you have to do a  codility test online -which has  3 qeustionsa in some levels.
you hava 80 min to sole it.
then skype call - with on of thairs hr

Only one on-line tech interview with the hiring manager, that is following the HR's basic question about compensation and your background. But the interviewer decline me soon after this. So I could tell why the status is 'not selected' after all.

Took 6 months from applying till final decision. Overall an easy process. The team is knowledgeable and know what they are doing. Easier interview process than I thought. However, I wish that the process is faster. I accepted another offer because their reply took ages.

First technical round
Three  separate interview in 3 Hr on a day. (Technical, Team manager, Process interview)
I was asked to prepare technical presentation for one of the interview. Then on the interview day they changed the presentation to different interview. When I presented, they sais I didnt expect technical presentaion, we were expecting process presentation. I didnt argue but it was mistake from the the scheduling team but I had to pay for it. I got rejection.
It's mainly two interviews with two different engineers, and most of the interview is about problem solving, each gave me some problems (1-3 problems) and I tried to get the best solution for them.

This was for Hyderabad location.
3 Technical Rounds:

1. Medium-Hard LC question 
2. Low Level Design and coding.
3. HM Round: Design Questions.

Panel was helpful and the interviews were interactive during all the sessions.

There are a codility online judge test, two technical interviews, one interview with manager, and one system design interview. It last three months since I apply to the opening. The technical interviews are not hard, but you need good conversation with interviews.

Entrevista simples, sempre em inglês com uma parte comportamental e outra técnica. Perguntas simples e entrevistadores muito simpáticos. Muito bom ambiente na entrevista e em todo o processo de recrutamento.

I was amazed how fast Microsoft have managed to run my hiring process. I have already had another offer from a high value company, before signing there I thought to check my luck with Microsoft.
Knowing that, HR called me day after I have submitted my CV, she scheduled a back to back 3 interviews in 4 hours for the following day.
The interviews were well organized, I felt very welcome (using Teams- remote interviews with team leaders from Redmond USA).
First interview, getting to know me, talk about some technologies I worked with and my thoughts about each and my experience.
Second interview, I presented some work I did in the past in the first part and on the second part was asked to design a system in high level (networking, security, proxy, vpn, on-prem and cloud).
Third interview coding question, solve an algorithm question in the subject of stacks and queues- felt easy on first read but luckily found a catch in the middle (ended up to be harder then I thought, but still managed to solve it).
I got a call the next day letting me know we are moving to an offer.
Got the offer letter the same day, salary and benefits were way above my demand.
I was given a week to decide.

Internship in Spain.

Such a long process where HR is always helping. The European team is amazing.

You have a few interviews with them.
Then, an interview with the US team.
And finally a three our call with different managers and different dynamics. 
*After that call, HR prepare another one just to explain everything.

At the end, the person in charge of your process call you directly to give you feedback about it. Much appreciated!

Processo longo mas eficiente. Todos os entrevistadores super educados e atenciosos. Primeira etapa com recruiter. Segunda etapa com perguntas sobre algoritmos de ML (focado em unsupervised) com tempo contado. Última etapa com entrevistadores por video chamada perguntando sobre meus projetos anteriores e desafios de programação.

Friendly interviewers, easy to medium lc questions. Engaging discussions on prev work exp and projects.
Non disclosure agreement was signed hence can not disclose exact question. Overall easy to medium difficulty interview that can be cracked right effort.
OA then 3 round interviews. For the first round and second round, You just need to pass one of those two rounds. For the third round, You need to pass it.
There was 1 written test, and then there would be 2 technical interviews. The programming problems asked on the test and interviews were similar to easy ~ medium LeetCode problems.
2 rounds of interview, the first round is with the marketing director. She is very nice and talkative. The second round is with 2 IT guys, they will ask you some Azure question

The process was 3 interviews with the third being a superday were you meet with 2 interviews for 30 minutes each. Only the first and second interview had 1 technical question and the rest was behaviorals.

There were 2 rounds and the questions were related to team management and program management. There were less questions on product management though the responsibility claimed to be a manager product management.

Typical mix of technical and behavioral phone interview. However started with technical which allowed for little time for the behavioral. The technical question were long and tedious and did not pertain to software engineering, think math brain teaser. This I believe was up to the interviewers discretion so that is not a blanket statement.
Recruiter reached out through email, set up a phone interview with engineer from team. Technical question wasn't too bad. Used a coding platform that allowed interviewer to see what you were coding.

From the initial contact from the recruiter to the first call, it took 1 month. 

The first interview It was about filtering candidates to go through the process. It was quit simple discussion about my current role and what could be interesting by joining Microsoft. He told me that another recruiter will reach out to me.

3 weeks after that, I received a mail from him telling me that I'll be invited to a series of interviews : 

1- Business Case Interview (A customer facing simulation) 
2- Hiring Manager Interview
3- Technical Interview

The second interview was a simple chat with the hiring manager, she asked about my current role and if I hold Azure Solutions Architect certification....

The third interview (Technical), was really smooth, It was with a Senior Solutions Architect, we talked about my experience on Data & Analytics services available at Azure.. 

3 weeks later, no see no show, total ghosting from Microsoft. I sent them follow-up, no one there...  Simply silent.

With all efforts put into this hiring process, one was expecting more respect from a big company such Microsoft.  

To summarize, the experience was very negative. If you want to loose 3 month of your life, please do apply there. Microsoft currently has the worst unprofessional recruiters... 

Microsoft keep people waiting (and ghosting) in hopes of finding a diversity candidate for the same spot to meet their diversity quota. So in simple words, they have a designed candidate for the role, but to validate the diversity quota, they keep interviewing people and wasting their time to close the process. They have no intent to hire you from the beginning.

Recruiters were helpful. I had to answer competency based questions and had 4 separate interviews with different people. Was asked technical questions, had to do live coding test and answer some networking related theory questions as well.

Straightforward, clear communication from their end throughout process. Set clear expectations of timelines. Organized and efficient. Situational and behavioral questions. Brief summary of personal experience and background.  Was not successful in the role but would apply again.

Interview process was of 5 rounds:

First, recuriter will do the screening, find okay then the process will get initiated
Second, hiring manager will evalute your tech and soft skills, management skills
Third, code review round
Fourth, behavioural round
Fifth, system designing round

What  a waste of time for me and Microsoft!
  - Recruiter reached out to me about a role after finding me on LinkedIn and I  confirmed interest.  They looked for my resume and I sent on. Heard nothing for days and had to reach out, few days later got a response saying my CV was passed to hiring manager.  Nothing for days then a mail confirming  they'd like to start process.  Throughout the whole process I never spoke directly with the recruiter.

I heard nothing for over a week then got a mail asking was I still interested and if I could confirm availability as they were waiting on my response to a mail I never received? That was first alarm bell.
Confirmed availability and recruiting co-ordinator was very helpful and responsive and I was set up with 4 interview on 2 separate days.  Did not receive confirmation of interviews until day before.  reached out to recruiter several times for additional info on what to prep for and basic guidance on Interviewers and potential questions, got no response until day after first interviews.  Response was a copy paste from hiring manager and not helpful. Recruiter asked in mail had my interviews been scheduled...the day after I done 2 for them.  Second alarm bell!
Interviews were tough and fair to a point.  Hiring manger was extremely nice and really sold the role and team and got me really excited about joining a great team and company. General questions about background etc..  2nd round was more role related but Interviewer seemed annoyed I had not done what the previous candidate he had interviewed had done to show I was interested in such a role ( Yep , compared my achievements to another candidate, It was really nice to be ran down like that! ) 3rd Alarm bell and for me a deal breaker, Id never intentionally make little of someone and never want to work with anyone who does.  No feedback whatsoever between  day 1 interviews and day 2 which were held a few days later.    Had expected a mail to say I was not proceeding any further after my 2nd Interview, am still amazed I did not get that as was very clear to me after day 2 I was not what 2nd Interviewer was looking for and would not be a match for role.
Day 2 interviews proceeded anyway. So 3rd round was another PM Interviewer and asked basically same questions previous round had. Asked me exact same question in exact same way and my response was once again, You have read my resume I assume?  Got a very blunt yeah! :-)  Interview was ended very abruptly after about 20 mins which I did not mind as knew I was getting a no.  Last round was pretty ok. I felt it went good, another PM interviewer who seemed genuinely interested in me and my responses and happy with replies I gave. was polite and professional but I did get feeling I was also not what this guy was looking for either. Had a very good conversation however and actually enjoyed it.

After Interview I reached out to recruiter for feedback which I assumed would be an immediate no and thanks for your tome. Got no reply whatsoever and had to chase and chase and eventually copy a colleague on a mail until i got a reply that no feedback received yet.  followed up again and again and no response , eventually a shot mail, No feedback, will update when there is yada yada yada!

Status of application on careers site changed to "not selected" a few days later and still no communication from recruiter or any feedback despite following up. Oh well, least recruiter was maintaining form.

Throughout the whole process I was polite and professional. I wasn't treated the same way and Its left a bad taste with regard this company for me.
I get I wasn't a match, that's easy to take. 
But the rest, the lack of professionalism, and plain courtesy coupled  with the subtle dig about credentials and accomplishments left me a tad annoyed.
Probably could have avoided a lot of it if recruiter had a quick call with me prior to Interviews to assess role suitability and potential match.

If same recruiter ever contacted me again my response would be very unprofessional. It takes zero effort to be courteous and mannerly, it does take effort to be rude.

Lesson learned :-)

I am a cleared engineer, so I needed a certain clearance level. So this experience is probably unique, compared to experiences had by people on the public teams. This took place during COVID so it was fully online. I got follow-up from a recruiter the day after applying. I got my first screening interview within a week.  Before that took place, I had a 30 minute phone conversation with my recruiter to talk about any concerns I may have.  The screening interview was a simple chat with a team member, mixed in with a quick competency check. Something that was on the same level as FizzBuzz. If you do okay here, your recruiter follows up within a day or so and you get a series of 4 back-to-back interviews set-up. Another 30 minute conversation with my recruiter before this series of interviews. The interviews were all conducted by the actual team members I would be working with, so it was in my best effort to ask them meaningful questions about the work I would do, and get to know them personally. They were all wonderful, and speaking today, I am proud to work with such an amazing team.
Anywho, these interviews are 1 hour blocks. Typically the way they would work is the first 15 minutes would be questions they had for you (behavioral, prior experience, etc), the next 30 minutes, you would be solving a technical problem. The cool thing is, is that the interviewer doesn't want to watch you fail and burn. Some of them I had real trouble with, but the interviewer would almost always step in and offer hints or guide me in a productive direction if I was getting off course. In one case, it almost felt like the interviewer and I were discussing and solving the problem as if we were on a team together, and it was something we were assigned. It felt good. The 4th interview at Microsoft is sort of different. You only get it if I believe atleast 2 of the 3 prior interviews had gone well. The 4th interview will be conducted by someone up the chain in your org. In my case, it was my manager's manager, a principle software manager with a PhD, 2 Master's degrees, and 2 bachelor's degrees. This guy, was incredibly intellectual, and let me tell you, no amount of crunching Leetcodes out will have ever prepared me for the hour I spent with him. In the end, it was the most profoundly positive experience I had ever had interviewing with anyone. Period. The questions he had for me felt custom tailored to things he discovered I had personal interest in, and he even taught me a thing or two. It was great.
Anyways, maybe 4 days later I get a call from my recruiter with an offer. I negotiated a higher offer and received something I was happy with within 3 days.

The interviews were based around core concepts.   There were four rounds. First two technical, third with hiring manager and last with Practice Lead. The interviewers were very calm and interacts were a great learning experience

A recruiter from Harvey Nash, 1 of the non-affiliated ones who work on commission for Microsoft, asked if she could submit me to request 106353-1 a 2mo remote contract role to write their Cambridge-based Fairlearn project's web frontend. The job description was extremely vague. After a month of no updates, I got an answer that they cancelled the role.

I applied for a role online (I was prompted to apply for by the HM). I had an initial call with a recruiter, who said that she would move me on in the process, and thats where weird things started to happen.

After my next interview, I learned that it wasn't an interview for the job that I had applied for (I hadn't been given any information about the interview in advance).   It was, in fact, for a job I had never applied for and had no interest in.  When I asked the recruiter about it, and asked to hear more specifics, she flaked on the information but then said that I should apply online (I didn't).

A few weeks later, another recruiter reached out to me saying that she had been referred by recruiter #1 and wanted to chat about another role (which I also hadn't applied for).  On the call, she asked a ton of questions about me including my experience and salary requirements, and FLAT OUT refused to give me any information at all, including location or salary, etc.

I mentioned this situation to a friend who thought this might not actually be Microsoft and might be some kind of employment scam...but, when I looked them up online, the recruiters in question are actual MS employees.

I ended up deleting my MS profile because I felt very uncomfortable about the refusal to answer questions and the fact that I was being pushed around into teams and jobs that I had no interest in and yet nobody would give me a straight answer.  And I never heard a word about the actual role I applied for in the first place.

Microsoft in India, manages their hiring process quite terribly.  India hiring is managed by 3rd party vendors, and trust me, they are not justifying the brand name of Microsoft at all.

They have reached out to me for this role, stating me that, I am a good fit for this role, and then they have initiated the Interview process.

First Round, directly from Redmond, HQ with a very senior level executive. I have to agree, the US counterparts at Microsoft are very good to work with as compared to India. Interviewer was fantastic and made me comfortable for the Interview.  Interview went well, and had received very positive feedback from the Interviewer. Questions around my Product Management experience as well as early experience.

Second Round, here things got quite messy. Interviewer was from Hyderabad India, and was associated with Microsoft India since long. Since the Interviewer was purely from Technical background, he started asking me only technical questions, with a flavor of coding.  Surprisingly, he grilled me only on my coding skills (which I left 8 years ago), and not my Product Management skills. I was quite surprised, as the Job Description for this role, was not in sync with what the Interviewer was expecting from me. In the feedback, Interviewer told me that they are looking for much more versatile person with excellent coding skills. I was quite surprised, why they have convinced me earlier, as they said I was a good fit for this role, being a Product Manager.

Request to hiring team: Review the JDs before sharing it with candidates, they are ambiguous. Set clear expectations from the candidates as well.

I was contacted by the recruiter with a quick Q&A, then I was promptly provided an art test. 

I was told I'd passed with flying colors and then was quickly pushed to an informal, virtual meet and greet with the studio art director.

After the short call came a lot of prep work for the loop interview. This was virtual meet with senior members of the teams. I spent days preparing answers for the usual questions, as well as surprises, and did so in STARs format, which is common with the larger tech corps.

The loop was pretty relaxed (but I was well prepared); I was questioned quite a bit on behavioral scenarios that come with senior positions, working with a team, and contractors. The people were fun and easy to talk to, we joked and shared some common experiences.

After all this, I was told by both the studio art director, and the recruiter, that I did extremely well and they would notify me of next steps. Almost a month of back and forth with the recruiter, very positive and reassuring responses, and I found out that I'd lost the position to the other final candidate by just a hair.

While I was pretty bummed about getting so much reassurance (I was reassured to the point we were looking at homes to buy in the area), then not getting the position, I can't peg this as a bad experience. To boot, most of the parties involved personally contacted me to tell me how close it really was, and offer their apologies.

Overall process was standard- 30 min interview followed by a role play and another 30 min behavioural based interview. 

Overall contact throughout the process was lacking. As there was no recruiter or HR involved you were chasing directly with the hiring manager for feedback… having worked or interviewed for other large tech companies, this was one of the worst. They give you no time to prepare for interviews asking for interviews the next morning at 4pm the previous day and will comment if you push back on this. After the process, if you are unsuccessful you will need to chase for an answer to find out you haven’t got the role and also for any sort of feedback. In my case, I had found out a week prior to finally hearing back that someone else I knew got the role but they held off communicating this to me for a week and a half and after me chasing them for an answer and any feedback… would expect a lot more from a company like this.

I was approached on LinkedIn by their Talent Acquisition Partner, the position was University Recruiter in Japan, but the recruiter who approached me was based in Britain. He sent me the job description, I agreed to apply and sent him a copy of my CV again via LinkedIn for his reference. One day before the interview date, he mentioned that he just checked my CV and said that my Japanese level did not meet their requirement so he wanted to cancel (the job description did not specify Japanese language proficiency whatsoever, plus I had N3 - intermediate level, they required N2). No apologies were offered. When I expressed my disappointment that the screening process could have been more professional, guy even said that my LinkedIn profile did not say what test score I have, even though IT DOES (and so as my CV!). Nonetheless, it was his responsibilities to check thoroughly. I am working on my N2 but don't think I would ever want to apply to Microsoft after this experience... and he was the one to approach me to begin with.

I initially had a phone interview for a Sr. Corporate Recruiting role for which I was really excited. I had even moved to the second round and talked with the hiring manager. A few days later, the recruiter called and told me that I wasn't being hired for that role but I could interview for a less Tech role. I agreed because I am relocating and need a job and I felt that perhaps I could move up.  But to be honest, I wasn't really all the happy about a Tech role especially since I interviewed for a Sr role. The recruiter/coordinator sent over and confirmed the interview and interview team. However, although I had prepped, there was no real alignment between what I was told and what ended up happening. In the first round, I had to do a hard skills assessment, essentially remote into my recruiter's computer, edit a job posting, conduct a LinkedIn search (including Boolean) and build a pipeline. Nothing wrong with that but the computer (the recruiter's) kept messing up. Also, I haven't done boolean in a while and hoped we would talk about my skills related to this as I could have expanded and explained. The recruiter wasn't even all that friendly. I had it to the final rounds but eventually was told I wasn't going to be made an offer. Mind you that the recruiter didn't bother to call, just send some generic email through the source instead. Very impersonal!

I applied for this position at Microsoft, and later received an email from a recruiter that asked me to fill out a form for them. The form was clearly made for recruiters, not for recruitees, to see, as it contained information such as "Ask them this" or "ask them if they have done that". It seemed that the recruiter had to schedule a call to ask me those questions, but instead they found it OK to simply send me the form and let me fill it myself...

Alright, I did that and they responded me a few days later asking for a suitable time for an interview. We choose a suitable time for both and scheduled the interview. However, on the scheduled time, I had an unexpected issue that prevented me from going. I sent an email to the recruiter telling them that. I did not receive any email from the recruiter after this, ever, even after trying to contact them multiple times.

it was a little bit hard but actually, it was good and I gained some more experience from it but actually, I discovered I had an interview a little bit late because I didn't check my email(my problem) but the experience as a whole was good actually.

MS HR representative reached out through LinkedIn and suggested to apply one of their MS open role. Strangely, when I applied it was showing the final date of application but HR came back and said that they have re-posted the role to attract more candidates. 
After 3 weeks, HR approached that hiring manager liked my CV and want to invite for next round of interview. First round was technical interview/coding continued around 1,5 hours and then 30 minutes gap then second round of interview for design for 1.5 hours on same day. 
Overall was OK, but initially set 1 hour but keep asking from me can we extend 30minutes, we want to ask more questions etc. which I found quite unprofessional. Also, conducting 2 interviews at same day, exhausting process to be honest. After interviews, HR called and told me that the interview outcome will be declared after 2 weeks, do you have anything planned for so on so dates (2 dates mentioned) if you are successful. You basically have to fit in their schedule one of those 2 days, putting everything aside to do 2 interviews on same day with different interviewers. 
Selected for third round, but it was already too late that all other interviews were on final stages, completed etc. Even though, the processes were started weeks after MS application.
Couple of strange things were noted during/after interview process: HR were keep asking from me which company offer I have got whether it is as big as MS. When I said, not to disclose to her, she mentioned that she can check my status in LinkedIn which I find it quite evil mindset. 
Also, tech design interviewers were not knowledgeable enough about the answers to the questions. Overall a bit long process took 2+ months stage 1, stage 2 to complete and a lot of red flags in very early stage, as an experienced professional, personally I would be hesitant to work as such culture. I have interviewed many other big techies but never experienced such a bureaucratic process. Hopefully, this will help for others who is getting interviewed or considering offer. Thank you.
1 skype call, 2 technical intweviews. one of them was about recursion, and the other about arrays. both were pretty hard, maybe due to the fact it was in ZOOM.

Typical interview for a big company with lots of abstract questions, such how to explained cloud storage to a 5 year old, and other psychology questions
It was about 40 minutes and was all done in English as expected

Friendly and well structured. 
3 people in the loop; 1 senior PM, 1 PM and a director of the program. 
Questions were mostly behavioral questions and few based on my background/skill.

It was a super comfortable process. Interview was conversational and had a good structure. Keep examples of behavioral situations in mind while answering the questions. 
Definitely have questions for the interviewer.

Two very easy questions in the coding round (one on matrix manipulation and the other on array manipulation). Don't remember the exact questions, but they were Leetcode easy.

The interviewer was very friendly and the interview went like a discussion.  The interviewer asked a little bit about my current and past projects, why I wanted to switch, and some problem which I had enjoyed solving.

it was the first round telephonic and all about the PMBOK, Interviewer was only looking the exact definitions of the questions. 
There was no discussion on the work experience based on past or current assignment.

Relatively straightforward interview with basic questions about employment and a coding question. Coding question was in Java and covered very basic coding questions like String manipulation and sorting. No data structures covered
After applying online, They send me an online test to be done in 90 minutes. It consists of 2 medium coding questions and 6 mcq about cs fundamentals and especially data structures

- HR: was with HR from Romania
- Technical was about some topics they sent it to me, and more topics from my technical background (it was with an Escalation Engineer) 
- Managerial

Had one phone interview with the hiring manager.  Interview was all over the place - started firing off behavioral questions, then talked about the role, then asked if I had questions, then asked more behavioral questions. There was no flow or structure at all.

Interviewer visibly grimaced at a few of my responses. Received an automated rejection email about a month later. Not a pleasant experience.
it was on zoom and I was asked about previous projects, my favorite project of all of those, the biggest obstacle I faced during work with friends, and what is the latest news I heard about Microsoft

Great interview that was fun, and detailed. Had to work through 5 separate interviewers of different positions who asked me about my personal and professional experiences, Diversity and inclusion,  and what I would contribute to the team

As this role was for technical pod, there was a technical round and followed by interview with Manager.
Both the rounds were average and had good experience with interviewers. It was more like an discussion.

I was one of the first people to go through the improved and 'streamlined' interview process. So where to start other than I got a rushed email on a Sunday night asking if I could speak the next day and complete an outline for them which I did in record time. Then I was pressed towards an interview in two days! The recruiter failed to share the invite in my local time so I was online the day of my interview at 6am only to find out that they were going to start at a more reasonable time of 7. Whomp whomp. The recruiter shared they loved my background and SURELY there was a place for someone of my talents at Microsoft. They loved diversity blah blah blah. They didn't need someone super technical just technical enough even though they CHOSE the super technical candidate. The recruiter even gave me a homework assignment that I prepared in advance to present ONLY to have no one ask me to present. By the 3rd back to back interview I was worn out and tired of answering technical questions that I was told weren't relevant. If these are the people running that team, I'm glad I didn't get the job.  What a waste of time.

The interviewer was nice. He started by explaining about the team and his position. Then came the questions, 2 questions when I could have choose the language I would like to write my answers with.
The interview was 90 minutes long.

Coding round, technical interview in 3 round
, HR round. Technical interview checks the approach to a code rather than solution. 
Coding round is a bit difficult algorithm and binary tree are most frequently asked and 1 hr is the time alloted for 3 codes.

I was contacted by a recruiter to apply for the position. I went through a screening call with the recruiter. The next round of interviews with the team was set for the next week. I spoke to two team members and the hiring manager. The technical questions were not impossible to talk my through even if I could not give a straight answer right away. It was still a difficult interview. I would rate it a fair process. In the end, the team and I were not a fit for each other.

typical Technical Interview. Tree Structure and Array Structure. All prototypes can be found on leetcode. Since Suzhou Office is expanding, the Interview process is not hard. All Chinese interviewers with fluent English.
Phone call with recruiter, then a full day of interviews on-site at their office. All the candidates interviewed on the same day so got to meet them. Recruiter called with feedback the same night.
It takes around 3 months started and 4 technical interviews. The first interview was just a problem solving , second one was system design, third and fourth was asking about oop and data structure

Talk about research with the researcher. Introduce my own papers and answer some questions from the researcher about my papers. Discuss the researcher's research interested research  idea and their papers.
Lean process of 3 interview and it was a good one to know how to do a interview. Lean process of 3 interview and it was a good one to know how to do a interview.
It was fairly nice process. Involved a lot of DSA and project related questions. The interviewers were very nice and experienced.  It consisted of 2 DSA medium to hard level questions.
If they send you and interview request, they send you a initial video call to explain about teams and interview process. First round is codility, second round has 4 steps.

initial Phone call (20 - 30 min)
30 min phone call, very standard behavioral and programming concept, questions on glassdoor are pretty accurate! If you practice all the behavioral interview questions mentioned on glassdoor it should cover 90% of what will be asked.

Behavioral  (10 - 15 min)
There were no curve balls during the interview, it seems like they care about the culture fit a lot, so be sure if prepare for questions like "tell me a time when you have a conflict with a teammate. " Almost all of my interviewer asked me some variation of this question. 

Coding (30 - 35 min)
every round, they leave about 30 min to ask a leetcode medium question, the question they asked me is pretty much leetcode Microsoft interview 101, but the trick is to really understand the most optimal solution, and talk about the trade-off for each solution, for instance in one of the interviews, I was asked about space locality when visiting a 2d array. Also, be sure to talk about the input edge cases before you start solving the question. (Ex. empty, None, Invalid type...)
I did phone interview then  a technical and behavioral interview. Was above average difficulty but not too bad. I had a good time doing it. great time doing the interview

Muy tardado, Muchas horas en la entrevista.

un proceso muy largo para la entrevista y sólo recibir un no. fue un proceso de 8 horas en un día.

Alredor de 3 entrevistas para llegar a la ultima en la cual te juntan en grupos para debatir entre todos.

Interviewers were nice, friendly. Asked medium level questions from Leetcode and previous experience. It was 4 rounds each with one coding question with followups and questions related to previous projects

submitted on Microsoft Careers.
phone interview
- 1 interviewer 30 mins
- basic algos
offline interview
- 3 interviewers
- 1 hour for each
- algos and presentation
as appropriate interview
- 1 interviewer (on Microsoft Teams)
- 1.5 hour
- online interview on codility

Only finishing the OA part, the assessment is easy.

Then onsite, I canceled my onsite due to get another offer.

I participated hiring event, by emailing recruiter at Linkedin, I think it's faster than directly apply or referral.

Very long.  Initial interview was out out of Seattle for their Search, Intelligence, Assistance product.  They were encouraging and then not.  Made it to the final round only to be told no, but was passed on to another area to interview.  That guy was uninterested.  Did not get the job.

I went through three different levels of interviews.  All of them up to the hiring manager was very professional.  The Pipeline they explained for their next 5 years seemed very exciting!  Good luck to them and thank you Management team who gave me good consideration in my eyes.
Screening Round followed by 4 rounds of interviews on the big day - virtual on site. All PMs were smart and caring and focused on testing product skills, project skills and technical skills.
It was difficult. The questions were tough but it relied more on technical questions over personality. A whole day long process that took hours. Interviewed with multiple people and managers.

Got reached out by design manager - had a phone screen with them - got put in touch with recruiter for next steps. This is where things became terrible. The recruiter took forever to book a virtual onsite interview and when booked, they kept rescheduling until they didn't get back to me with a specific date. They ignored my emails for awhile and then after i sent my last email, they told me they had filled the position

This has to be one of the worst recruitment experience especially since i didn't even apply, they reached out to me. Do better Microsoft

The whole process was interesting and a bit demanding. There were three parts with three different interviewers who were so cool and it did not take them long to send us a feedback. All in all, great experience!

Pretty standard interview, 2 round interviews comprised of both technical engineering questions as well as behavioral questions that linked to past experiences of projects as well as work.  Interviewers were extremely nice.

It went pretty fast. Four 45-mins interviews. Interviewed with two teams you will work with if you receive any offers from them. Two of the interviews were with hiring managers. Coding questions and team-specific project design questions.

Phone interview: They ask you basic behavioral questions and computer science concept questions
Final round: There are 4 rounds. 3 coding, 1 system design. All 4 rounds have behavioral questions at the end.

Phone interview followed by a panel Zoom interview. The phone interview was for 30 minutes. The interviewer was direct to the point and clear with his questions. He provided expectations for the interview and the list of questions right at the beginning which was helpful to know what to expect and the flow during the 30 minutes. The panel included six executives.

Gave an introduction to the process and introduced me to different team members, very casual. This first interview was just 1-2 hours, after they wanted to invite me for a 1 day long interview session where they could see if I fit into the team. Not everyone were invited for the day long interview session. I was invited, but declined because I decided to pursue a position in a different city.

3 rounds of 1 on 1 interview with senior engineers. Each containing a general question, a technical question, and an architecture question. Try to be approachable, ask the interviewer questions as well.

1) Codility Code Test
2) First technical interview - two hours long
3) Second Technical interview - two hours long

After each step you are invited to the next step and after anHR interview you get an offer

Met a recruiter at an on campus event, had an on campus interview.  Passed that and flew to Seattle for the final round.  Had two interviews with managers from the organization they wanted me to join.

Two rounds of interviews- one technical and one behavioral. Covered Java fundamentals and leadership and project experience. Interviewers asked about language experience and familiarity and adapted questions to what I knew.

The recruitment process was the waste of time as the company withdrew the signed offer anyway (and couldn't even make this decision for months), leaving me with nothing, not even a prospect of simplified recruitment process next year. Their communication was also almost non existent, I only got back generic phrases.
30 minute phone call where they asked about my projects, hr questions, and some technical components. Overall good experience I just did not have the experience needed at the time.
This interview was a friendly conversation with a Microsoft Employee. It did not feel like an interview at all, but more like meeting someone from the company and having a chat with them.
went into the building and was greated by the emplyoyees i then went up to the interview place it was alright and the place smelled like mayonaise and the interviewers werent that good
Some technical questions, but it was mostly softskills related. Best to study up on Microsoft products and service offerings to have that base knowledge before going into the interview.

Multiple rounds from recruiter to technical to manager. Technical questions where good and tough. Additional background check by their partner. They are really flexible. There should be already 30 words.
I handed out my resume at a school event. Then was contacted to schedule an interview at school. I only did the first interview and was not selected for a second round.

zoom, 30 minutes call with a recruiter asking general questions- about studies, working in a group and math riddles. the recruiter was nice and the coversation went welll. The main purpose was to capture my way of thinking.

Interview process was intense but extremely enjoyable. The Microsoft recruitment team were very friendly and made the process smooth which allowed all candidates to perform at their highest potential. Well done Microsoft.

One-day two-interview process. The process was well organized and the problems were medium not very hard or easy. Prior to covid, it was done onsite. Two problem solving questions were provided with the solution requested to be written on a whiteboard.

Phone interview followed by onsite interview. Recruiter was super nice and the onsite interviewers as well. Had fun socializing with other candidates and getting to know the company better.  Overall a great experience.

This was a great interview. We chatted about design, product, past experience and went through some coding challenges and trivia questions. There was also a behavioral component and many opportunities to ask questions during the interview.

Tres bref mais accueillant. Et plein de questions sur la technique et sur les expériences passées. Par contre la personne chargée du recrutement ne semble pas etre au courant du poste pour lequel j'ai postulé.

First had a screening call where they asked a couple of situation-based questions and about motivation to apply for the role. After this you go straight to the final stage assessment centre which is a set of 3 interviews. The first is a presentation based on a topic they email you about a week before the interview. The second is with situation-based questions. Third is a group activity. There is no technical part in the entire interview process.

First, there were introductions between interviewee and interviewer. Then one was asked about project experiences listed on resume. Then is the coding exercise, one will have around 45 mins to solve a problem.

I had very supportive and kind interviewers. They were actually understanding what I was thinking even before I said them out loud. Provided inputs and had detailed and interesting discussion with me about the problems. The process lasted 1 month.

4 interviews in total, 1 fairly simple technical interview about Microsoft Cloud, 1 behavioral interview. It was easy because my past experiences matched their expectation for the job. Try to show technical curiosity, they are looking for technical personnality for this position. Be carefull about the salary negociation, Microsoft Dublin tends to have a low range of salary compared to other competitive company. Dublin is an expensive city. Think about your base salary and the bonus on top of it and stock options. Always negociate higher than what you expect because the job is demanding and you will regret it.

I found a referral and got an interview after a week. The man was really nice and we talked very happily. He asked me about my project first, and then a coding question. Then finally I asked him a question.
A codility assignment made out of three questions and than an online interview where the interviewer ask general questions about yourself and non related riddle at the end of the call.

skipped phone screening and got virtual onsite
folks I interviewed with are friendly and helpful during the interview 
hr follow up was pretty slow after I was told they will extend the offer (should be due my overall score was low in the candidates who get offers)

4 rounds onsite and initial round is online coding assessment, each round was 45 min and 2 system design and 2 coding challenged with behavioral, and system design were the toughest one out of all the rounds, all the best

I was contacted by recruiter. After initial screening It took 4 weeks and there were 4 onsite interview. There was a coding, system design, oops concept round along with competency questions. Interviewers were nice and friendly.
One has a number of projects on their CV and may be required to explain them. Mostly it is required that you will be able to explain the projects and the technologies behind them.

It was a three step interview process that lasted about 4 weeks in total from first point of contact

Screening with Human resource department
Meeting with executive team members
 A final interview with the Hiring Manager
Interviewed with for 4 hours, with 4 people (1 hour per person). Everyone had similar questions, they really just want to get to know you and see how you fit in with their team!

The interview was carried out via Skype, it took approximately 30 minutes and started really early at 7am. I was really nervous at first but then she made me more comfortable and I answered with the best I could

Was the HR interview. 
was normal. no tricky questions.
Just make sure to be prepared to the kind of questions of why you are good to microsoft.
was a good experience overall.

They mostly asked me to solve whiteboard coding about standard algorithm problems. They wanted to me explain edge cases and potential drawbacks to solutions. No real code was necessary, just pseudo-code.  Finished up with a detailed conversation about my background.
HR   Interview  , Codility online coding test    , 3   technical interviews.   Each interview contains around 1-3 questions, depends on the difficulty of the questions and the flow of the interview.

Pretty intense. 5 interviews back to back. Interviewed for the communications team. Met plenty of the team members and they all had pretty hard questions to answer. It was slightly overwhealming because it is very hard to have 5 interviews in one day.

The first stage of the process was to do a codility test and then an interview in skype with the HR recruiter. The interview was in English. The codility test was 3 questions one easy and two difficult , and the time frame was 80 minutes.

Standard 5 rounds with coding design and questions related to the experience, standard questions. The design round was interesting with a very open-ended discussion. The interviewers were nice and open for discussion and ideas, would recommend to anyone.

Average difficulty interview. The first 2 were technical interviews that involved coding. The interviewers were helpful in trying to push in the right direction by giving hints and set a positive atmosphere throughout. 
The interviewer in the third round could not express well  of what he wanted. He said high level design/implementation of the game of battleship. I started with a matrix implementation. Midway he said he did not communicate properly but instead wanted a different approach like a list of position objects. From there the whole discussion went downhill. There was a lot of random unconnected conversations and I could not understand what he was expecting as the final output. I got rejected after this round as expected. It would have helped if there was a clear expectation of the end result from the interview discussion. It felt like an hour of random unconnected and ever changing conversations.

Good questions to ensure strong validation basics. Mine was for full time just after graduation. Intellectual and a good learning experience. Interviewers were friendly and HR helped with the process being super smooth.

There are three rounds interviews. First round is with Recruiter. Second round with hiring manager. Final round with Marketing manager and HR. 
It is average interview. There are not difficult questions.

Was good , cleared all 4 rounds and even submitted the salary documents but did not receive any offer letter...Despite constant following up !
Later read up that Microsoft does that most of the candidates where they keep interviewing for positions and don't provide offers for most candidates

This was a phone interview with human resources, it was a 15 minutes call about my background mostly . Position was Customer engineer. Next interviews were technical ones. Applied through the website.

it was a straightforward and standard software interview process with expected questions and engaged reviewers. my overall experience was very positive and i had a fun time working through the questions.

I interviewed with Microsoft China for UX Designer (New Grad). The onsite has 6 back to back interviews include 1 hour presentation and 5 hours on 1:1. The designers were nice and I received tons of constructive feedback.  (I was turned down eventually but a happy experience)

Very nice onsite interview experience was it. this amazing interview happened many many years ago and I felt extremely excited during the interview process. Very awesome and very knowledgable interviewers was it. interview rounds were spread across 2 days. good technical discissions.

The process was smooth and consisted of three rounds. The first two being technical and project-oriented. The last round was designed to test my fit in the team. Most of the questions were around my past research and project. Some were also related to the courses that I had mentioned in my CV.

I had 4 rounds of technical interview followed by a hiring manger round.
The questions were mostly around designing solutions and the interviewers stuck to what the candidate is aware of than what was missing, which is really good.
It was a short over the phone interview. The female on the line was polite and asked general behavioral interview questions. Pretty standard and took around thirty minutes or so.

Applied through referral, passed 30 minute phone interview and had 4 rounds of virtual onsite for 45 mins each. They were typical leetcode questions based on algorithms and data structures and got an offer the next week

Good positive environ ment tough technical questions, overall enjoyable experience. Inviting offices with indepth knowl ege and development. Friendly and professional .. .. Four interviews, Hardware position, English interview. helpful and challenging

I was interviewed for a position in the Sales team. I went through 5 or 6 interviews. What impressed me was the low level of interview questions. Like, will you work hard, are you willing to spend over hours. 20 years back questions!
It took quite long time to get he interview schedule, once that happened, the whole process took around 2 weeks. Great experience. 2 x 1h interviews plus few phone calls.

1 Coding test round - Contacted by recruiter 
3 questions - solved 2.5
Got the call for onsite interviews, had 3 technical interviews. They asked OS concepts, OOPS concepts, mainly of processes and producer-consumer problem
In first interview was asked 1 question.
An initial phone call, then a written test will be conducted. If you get through it, then a couple of technical interviews will be conducted, and finally, an HR round. Thank you.

Disappointing Interview Process. Got hurried up to wait. Applied online, got contacted by a recruiter and was sent to the HM. 
I was invited to an onsite interview and was asked to do that in a couple of days. cleared my calendar and spent an entire day. 4 interviews, 3 with the team and the HM and the last one with a senior manager. Very positive and was told that they reach out in about a week. Never heard back. Recruiter did not answer emails anymore.

Décevant de la part d'une entreprise comme Microsoft.

Après avoir postulé à un poste d'Account Executive, je reçois quelques jours plus tard une invitation pour participer à une visioconférence où on me propose d'effectuer une mise en situation. J'ai reçu cette invitation un mardi à 11H30 pour participer à une visioconférence le lendemain à 11h30. On m'impose un délais très court avec donc peu de temps de préparation (24h).

Les échanges lors de la visioconférence sont agréables. La mise en situation simule un échange entre un client et un AE notamment pour juger ma capacité à mettre en avant les solutions de Bing ads.

A la fin de notre échange, j'envoie un mail pour réitérer mon intérêt. Suite à une semaine sans nouvelles, je relance les personnes qui ont participé à la visioconférence, on m'indique que mon intérêt est apprécié mais que je dois faire preuve de patiente.

Au final, je n'ai plus jamais eu de nouvelles ! Même un mail automatique aurait été plus satisfaisant / respectueux.

Quand on connaît, les ressources que possèdent une entreprise comme Microsoft, c'est dommage qu'elle ne prenne pas le temps d'informer l'ensemble des candidats qui ont postulé et passé un entretien chez eux.

3 interviews back to back to back over a 3 hour period. Everyone was very pleasant and punctual. Asked the why Microsoft question. Tell me about yourself question. Situational questions that you have to tell how you solved a problem, etc.

I had a 30 minutes Phone Call, questions about past experience, about international positions, multicultural entreprises, start up culture. Meeting lasted 25 min, probably expected more senior software engineers, that's why  I was a bit off

one two three four rounds phone video code data structure algoritham design test case next day interview software engineering entry level microsoft scared little bit scared about to clear phone call video call
It was a pretty standard process, they asked for a background on my end after reviewing my resume and later gave a more detailed description of the intern, who they're looking for.
It was very smooth and well prepared, professional and enjoyable (as enjoyable as these things are). The process was clearly outlined from the beginning and there was a good feedback loop throughout.
I interned at MS for 8 months and I had interview at end of 8 months where I was asked to present what I did at MS for 8 months, my achievements and what all I learnt.
