Online assessment (90 minutes) - 1 debug, 2 coding  questions.
Fairly straight-forward if you practice something like Leetcode.

A bit of confusing back-and-forth between the recruiter, but was invited to a virtual onsite afterwards.

Virtual Onsite (4 rounds, 45 minutes each) - Each round was with 1 person. They all asked behavioral questions as well as a coding question. Be sure to discuss through the coding questions thoroughly to eliminate any assumptions, my interviewers were looking for that.

1st round is a 30 minutes interview with a Data Scientist at Microsoft. (Background check and technical question)
The final round consists of 4 interviews and each is about 45 minutes. It covers topic like coding questions, case studies, and stats,

I passed the first interview round and was invited to the onsite. I had four technical interviews back to back. I heard back the next day. Overall the process took 3 months from my first interview to my last.

* Phone Interview with HR: Resume & Experience
* Technical & Behavioral Interview
  - OnSite * 3
  - Phone * 3

Technical & Behavioral Interviews:
- Interview with Hiring manager, team members, and related stakeholders with that team.
- Ask some problem solving question and answer it on whiteboard or coding sharing.
- Ask some questions for experience
- Ask some behavioral questions for leadership.
- Q&A

The entire process was positive; everyone was professional, intelligent, transparent and respected my time. I applied for the position online and had an initial phone screen with HR and then a few days later, a longer conversation with the hiring manager. After that, they had me take a couple of online tests (a personality test and an “IQ” style test).

Two phone calls, 5 on-site interviews, several of which were technical. Met first with recruiter, who answered any questions I had. All interviews were ~45 minutes. Overall was a good experience, focused on skills that actually matter in software engineering rather than simply quizzes and trivia.

The first round was a phone screen round (mostly behavioral). It was a 30 minute phone interview and I had an overall positive experience.  Few questions were based on my course knowledge though fairly straightforward.
It went well the interview started from a  phone interview, proceed to zoom interview then 3rd final in person. i was not accepted to the job, but it was a great experience.
met with several different people at multiple levels of management. Did most by phone and it was more like a conversation than a Q & A session.  Easy to talk to .

3 stages, phone screening , 1-1 about the overall type of job and generic personality/skill screening then an interview with 2 people from the company where one was the primary interaction doing a sales role play exercise and speaking more specifically about personality and technical knowledge for the role

I've been interviewed in Beijing for machine learning engineer. The interviewer is constantly challenging me about my non-computer science background. And she ask me some very basic computer science knowledges. To be honest, I used those techniques a lot when I was doing quant trading and building the trading system. I replied with my own understandings. But what she response is not sth she expected. What she expected is those standardized descriptions on text book. And what's more, she is not very professional on some machine learning usages, like how to leverage xgboost to implement random forest, etc. Very bad experiences.

Very through; do a lot of research on Microsoft and understand the principles of programming along with having the time to do a full day of on site interviewing. All in all, they expect candidates to possess a great deal of aptitude and the ability to work well in groups.

1. Screening of your CV after application online
2. HR phone interview about motivation, company, and the role you applied to
3. Assessment center divided into different parts, including a group assessment

The process took three weeks, first I got an invitation on LinkedIn to complete several code challenges on leetcode after passing them I was supposed to have another phone calls with Engineering team but they left me hanging on the line, never got an apologize email or phone call.

Not a pleasant experince

Loved the process and how kind, helpful and friendly the interviewers were.The environment was very encouraging.
Q.Regex expression building 
Q.Swap numbers without using temp and a design question of building a chess game api
Q.Adding two numbers as strings
Q.Validate binary search tree and inorder traversal recursively.

1 . 40 min skype call Behavioral - with someone from canada, kind of HR interview.
2 . 80 min codility test
- you can use any prog language you want.
- medium difficulty
3. 60 min coding
4, 60 min coding
-- very hard interviews. might ask you about operation systems.
5. interview with the team head

3 meetings online, they were mostly on Teams.
The last meeting was an online assessment, where I had to discuss for about  30 minutes with a different person.
The whole assessment took 4 hours.

The interview experience was seamless and absolutely brilliant. The interviewers took into account my areas of specialization. Questions were real-time live situation-based. Skills expertise was of the essence but also alignment to the company's mission and culture tenets played key a role.

2 rounds of coding interview.
The 1st round contains 1 leetcode medium 1 leetcode hard. 
The 2nd round contains 1 leetcode medium. I spent 20 minutes to come up with the solution and write the code. Then we spent 10 minutes on testing and finding the bug in my code caused by some edge cases. 
Besides, we talked about past experience and internship.

There were 3 technical rounds with a hands-on coding round. On qualifying, you'll face managerial panel round. It's one of the trickiest round as you'll not see any cliche HR questions and panel can easily spot if you're lying.
The interview process was fine, the interviewers were professionals, but at the end i didn't get any response.  There were four steps; coding skills, testing skills, system design and soft skills,

Had a phone interview, simple behavioural questions asked about my past experiences then after a week or two I got invited  for the virtual technical interview. Overall I had great experience, the recuriters were really nice as well as the interviewer

Great experience very smooth. They made the process very easy. The behavioral interview also included a few more technical questions but nothing crazy. The behavioral questions were fairly standard and focused mostly on mindset

Was invited to interview directly to the hiring team without a phone call. Had a panel interview with the team member and felt it went well and received good feedback. However, was ghosted by the team and recruiter afterwards.
Very professional and great interviewers. It was relatively easy as I had already had the experience needed for the job.  Specific questions related to technology and solving problems on a board.
1 online test having 3 problems to solve in 1.5 hours, 3 interview rounds each having 2 dsa problems to solve in 1 hour. The problems were all from gfg and pretty standard.

Technical and customer service questions are easy to answer. Interview explained the job description and environment with great detail.  Conversation with the interview flowed with ease. Recommend to be prepared to go through two interviews if you can pass the first one

I was contacted by recruiter because there was a good match between JD and y profile. I was personally happy and excited for the discussion because I had expertise in almost 80% of the job description lines. However, during interview I was asked questions which were not at all related to the job description and my skills. Interviewer did not ask me any questions in my core skills. I found interviewer quite unprofessional too.  Overall recruitment coordination was good.

There is no tech question in the first Phone Interview.
The interviewer is a recruiter, so I think she doesn't know much about the software. And she was asking me while typing something on the board, I think she is writing something about me on their system.

A one hour interview with an engineer. He had an ill defined problem about a binary tree, and got frustrated when asked for more details about the problem. 

The solution was a simple recursive function, but he wanted you to walk through what it was doing and why. No feedback, just a generic reject email.
It was an entertaining interview, there are 5 steps to get into the Microsoft, the first one is just for knowing you. Then comes the technical interviews and some tests.

I did pretty well on the phone interview but declined 3 days later. questions mostly about what I had on my resume plus they expect me to know verification and UVM with Verilog even my university didn't offer those courses.
HR phone screen, cleared. Phone screen: a mix of project dive, algorithm, coding and behavior questions, about 45 minutes. Onsite: 4 loops. Each loop is mix of project dive, algorithm and behavior.

The interview process was a great experience, the managers were highly interactive.  The follow ups were quick and got a confirmation within 2-5 days. Once, I have accepted the position, they did a background check. Standard procedure for many global companies.
Had a written test followed by several rounds of interviews conducted by the hiring team. Data structures related questions were asked. Had applied for the role of software developer intern.
Take long and position changes through the process. You have to chase the feedback and follow up , not guaranteed to get the job even if you are successful on the interviews.
Normal sales interview process. Phone screening then was processed to speakwith hiring managers next. Asked questions based on skills related to sales and how to help grow business in company.
3 round interview, with first one as phone call with a behavioral question. Rest of the interviews where leet code easy. I would study up on linked lists and trees and arrays

30 min interview in English not technical but more personal. Asked me a few simple questions to get an understanding of my personality and way of thinking. Very nice and easy way to start the process.
After passing the test I had three technical interviews with seniors from the company. First we talked about stuff from my CV and then each of them gave me an algorithmic task to solve.

There were four rounds back to back with questions related to
1) DP
2) Tree
3) Array
4) Multithreading
Also, system design questions in between and behavioral at beginning of each. Result out in one week only. friendly interviewers helps you solve the questions provide hint.
Screening phone call with technical recruiter.  Then a couple weeks later an email saying I passed the screen. Then an email to schedule 2nd round coding interviews.  Given up to 3 weeks to prepare.
It was very open and the interviewers were very communicative.  It was a three-round interview with three different people.  They were very easy to talk to and loved the work culture.

One of the wonderful interview experience.  The interviewer was friendly, knowledgeable and talented.  Asked questions that are very relevant for the position unlike other companies who ask to explain or present something with the intention of expecting for a good oratory/presentation skills.

before hr interview - codility test with 3 questions
1 - easy 2 - difficult.
HR + 2 technical interviews.
HR - With someone from US/CANADA
she were very nice, there is nothing to be worried about, come prepared with some good answares.
technical - from israel

The first interview is a telephone interview, if successful through that you then move to the next stage where you have to produce a video between 2-5 minutes talking about a product that you want or have. Then the third interview if successful with your video is a meeting with the regional manager where you are asked competency based questions and you have to produce a presentation lasting between 5-10 minutes on something that you are passionate about.

Was invited to first-round interviews - never heard back. 
The interviewer was friendly and made me feel comfortable. I thought the interview went well- would have liked to have heard back. 
Took place over skype and lasted around 30 minutes.

Applied with referral One phone interview technical round, and then Virtual Onsite, four rounds in total,  45 minutes each round with 10-15 minutes break. Asked about resume, and mostly algorithmic coding problems.

This was my first interview with the recruiter. It was behavioral, and the interviewer questioned me mostly on my resume. Apart from asking me to talk about my past experiences in the software industry, he also asked why I would like to work for Microsoft, what my favorite Microsoft product was and how I could improve it.
I was also asked some technical questions pertaining to multithreading and recursion, but that was about it for technical stuff. The interview was mostly focused on my experiences and how I would deal with hypothetical situations.

I was declined as soon as applied for the position. Despite Microsoft being actively recruiting in the area, I didn't get to the screening interview, and it's the first time it happens in 8 years of my work experience. I don't want to speculate, but somehow I feel that Tallinn office is very picky about nationality of an applicant.

I got an email for schedule round 1 via codility. 45 minutes with questions related to scheduling. 
I received an email for the final round within one week. I received an email from a recruiter that they will contact me further. Someone from their Team asked me to schedule a final round interview. 4 round 45 minutes each with leetcode questions and behavioral questions. little bit of system design questions as well.

First interview in English with a HR representative from the USA. 
Code test Test in Codility.
Professional interview with two interviewers from the relevant team.
The interviewers were very pleasant, and the HR representative accompanied the process well
There were 5 rounds in total. Interviewer in the 3 round looked highly prejudiced and was not listening to answers carefully. This was only for the 3rd round and was disappointing.
This is about the code screen, they give 3 leetcode medium questions, and each with some special test case to think about. The total process is on Codebility and you are given two hours to finish it.

Discussed the role with the HR recruiter, who talked up my resume like I was a superstar. Followed up with 3 video interviews. No further contact. I got one response that she was looking for updates and could not get any additional response. Just ghosted me

Applied online. Contacted by HR .  Generic behavioral questions by HR. This was followed by remote video call with hiring manager. Interview was easy, but did not go to next step as I don't have previous management experience .

It was through recruitment agency, I got the interview after two weeks waiting the agency to arrange it. I had the interview with two program managers. the interview was nice and easy, they asked only behavioral questions.

An initial call from HR clarifying their job requirements and asked questions on my interests in the job.  Next week was a one day interview with 4 team members via Microsoft teams. 2 interviews were 1:1 and the last interview was with 2  people from the team.  They were all friendly interviews.

Entrevista telefónica para conocer más acerca de la posición laboral y para conocer mi perfil profesional y mi situación actual.
Llamada en hora, correcta y amigable. 
Finalmente, no me interesaba la oferta por lo que la descarté.

I was recently contacted by a Microsoft recruiter to interview for a principal program manager position. Supposedly, I have been pre-screened for the position by a hiring manager within the company a fantastic role and wish I was very interested. I responded to the email which went to a queue at Microsoft. Bad sign #1. I then followed up with the phone number on the email and called the recruiter to make sure that he received my response with interview dates. He confirmed receipt. He ghosted me from that point. Never heard back from him to actually schedule the in-person interview with the "highly interested" hiring manager who had supposedly pre-screened my resume for the in-person interview.  Thankfully, I am employed so it wasn't that much of a disappointment. this is a terrible way to do business however for people who are unemployed and actively looking for work. I can only imagine how someone who does not have a job would feel if a top-tier company like Microsoft sent an email like the one I received but had no intention of actually following up. And instead we're "ghosting" people. Really bad luck, Microsoft.
Very relaxed, casual interview process. Team was very friendly. There was no set format. It started with casual conversation and question just came along. No offer has been made it.

We talked a bit, I introduced myself and my experience, projects I did, then we opened the codility and he introduced me to the first question. I thought aloud and wrote my solution, we went over it and improved it. He gave directions on where to improve

Recruiter reaches out to schedule a tech screening. 
Next week the interviewer reaches out to confirm the dates and within 2 days a Tech screening is conducted. 
SQL questions followed by data related project question followed by a business case scenario question. Overall the interview went great. 
No response on next steps for a week or two. I follow up with the recruiter twice only to see an automated reject on the career portal soon after sending the email. 

This isn’t the first time I have faced this with Microsoft. I wish they improve their recruitment system. Extremely inefficient recruiters who do not have the courtesy to follow up.

Interviewers were friendly, professional, respectful. All the interviews were virtual. The questions focus on work experience and projects done, style and of writing and any coding experience. They discuss salary negotiation at this stage.

a 30 minutes phone screening with hr for the first round, some tech questions and some question related to resume.then a virtual onsite interview for the final round, including 4 1-to-1 sessions, 45mins per session

The interview was beneficial to me because some questions I had to think out of the box and they very challenging. All in all it was a bit difficult but I managed and I was calm through out the interview and it worked out for me.

Recruiter call, hiring manager call, last round is 1-hour group presentation and a few 1:1s with hiring manager, design team member and a bar raiser. The team was nice but there was no specific feedback provided for why they moved forward with other candidates. It made you feel that they didn't care much about the candidate experience.

Final interview was virtual. Had 3 algorithm questions. The first two were easy string/array manipulation. Third question was more challenging and purposefully meant to not be finished in 45 min slot times allotted for each interviewer. Each 45 min slot was with a different person. 2 of the 3 interviewers were easy to understand via MS teams call. The 3rd interviewer had a very muffled mic, poor internet connection and a strong accent which made communication extremely hard.

The interviewers are great, they will ask some experience question in the previous company, follow by a coding (or system design) question, and they will try their best to guide me through the problem.

Dos de los 3 entrevistadores abrieron con introducciones de ellos, hablando un poco de lo que hecho en mi trayectoria para romper el hielo y despues brincamos a la resolucion de problemas. Uno de los entrevistadores solo saludo y directamente pego el problema a resolver, tuvo muy poca comunicacion y fue hasta cierto punto grosero, cuando seleccion Java como lenguaje de programacion para el problema hizo una expresion sarcastica diciendo "ah, Java.."

At first I had a short meeting with HR on motivation, salary expectations, how would the recruitment process go, then a technical discussion with 2 people involving testing my knowledge with job related examples and questions

Final onsite super day, with 4 coding questions with different people. 45 min each round with 15 min intervals to let you rest. They will ask about behavioral questions and previous projects before doing the coding.

Two separate Microsoft Team meeting with two different people. Both were very nice and honest about the company. Very clear and straight forward regarding what the program would entail. Both were extremely willing to reach out, regardless of an offer for the program

I was given a 45 minute virtual technical interview. Passed that, then I had 4 hour long blocks of mostly technical interview. All technical interviews were done with codility, and they basically just watched you solve a programming problem. It was very unnerving.

3 meetings via teams, followed by a phone call where they told me I did not get it. No constructive feedback. Overall experience based on the time invested, I think a company with that scale can have the recruiter spend 5 minutes and giving you feedback.

Hiring manager sent email directly to schedule an hour long tech screening interview with one of their principal developers. I was little nervous to being screened by their top developer, but they were very nice, talked about the team and role, gave a small brainstorming problem and very easy recursive sum coding problem, probably because there wasn’t much time left. Hiring manager emailed back asking to schedule another technical screen, this time with their senior developer. They gave a difficult probability question and asked to code the solution. At times it was little difficult to understand them, I didn’t come up with a correct solution either. It was no brainer that I won’t be moving forward in the process.

First Round interview: Go through your resume. Determining whether a tree is a BST. Implement merge sorting algorithm.
Second Round interview: Go through your resume. How to design a MapReduce program for word counting task.

On-site interview,  4 interviews  (virtual)  the process on each interview it has some easy technical questions and then coding round. One question for each round. 

After that interviewer could  ask you more technical questions or second coding question.

My advice do first 200 leetcode questions and practice them

I interviewed in March 2021.

I applied through a referral and was contacted by the hiring manager a month later for an initial screening. Following that I went through an interview loop with 5 members of the team focusing on behavioral questions. I found each interviewer to be very delightful and had great conversations, but ultimately did not receive an offer.

The recruiter in particular was awful. I spoke to him once before the interview loop and despite being told that he would share feedback with me after the loop, he ghosted me.  Repeated attempts to contact him were met in vain and made me dislike how the company could allow such a poor recruiting experience leave candidates clueless.
It has 3 rounds which was very interesting and happy to join Microsoft as software developer nice pay and helpful atmosphere and enjoying  , join the very good company and be part of growing culture

My first rounds was a phone interview scheduled to be for 30 minutes but it lasted 22 minutes. The second round was a series of 4 interviews in 1 day. First one was very hands-on: the interviewer picked up a random topic from or ongoing conversation and didn’t provide me with much details. Other 3 went well - they were about product design and the last one was more technical but a design question none the less.

4 Interviews,
1 Behavioral 1 hour
3x technical, 1 hour each first 15 minutes is small talk. 
Make sure you minimize the small talk or ask to do it at the end to give your self time for coding the solution.
First is a 70 minute coding challenge --> If passed then have an SDE interview me --> The next day manager interviewed me. He said that his opinion matters the most

The internship interviews of Microsoft China are not difficult at all, they just asked some medium coding problems on Leetcode and some questions about your resume. However, only few people have chances to take interview.

The interview process was as follows. First, you get a 30 min interview with an HR person from Microsoft that you get very general questions about youself. If you pass this step you then have in a  day 4 consecutive interviews which is a mix of personal questions and coding ones

Was pretty straightforward! two consecutive days with a total of 5 interviews between both  days.

Most of the questions were hypothetical questions around how you'd try to solve a particular scenario and why you'd take that route.

One 1st round - Chat with recruiter to know a bit about you and a few technical questions i.e explain recursion to your mother.
Two 1 hour interview- Questions on Data Structures, understanding on the langauage and behavioral.

The entire procedure was pretty chill. The hardest part os actually getting and clearing the OA round but after that its smooth sailing.  I didnt mot get selected in the end but the process was wonderful.

3 hour long interviews over zoom. 1st portion was behavioral  based questions. 2nd round is a role play scenario and the final round is product information skillsets. Feedback was provided within the following week

I applied online, and I got a first reply within 1 week. I had 3 loops with various senior leads from Microsoft, aftr which I finally went through the full loop, and then they told me I will get an offer. 
For the offer, I had 3 separate calls and numerous e-mail exchanges with the Microsoft contractor in charge, just so they can lowball me with a very poor offer.
long interview process takes a lot of time questions are not that tough but surely tricky,overall it was a good experience for me,interview was nice and makes you think of solution in different ways

I had one codility with 3 question - I was 6 month ago and more practice (style leetcode) is needed.
First question was easy, second and third med - med high.

1. HR contacted me in March
2. The interview happened on March
3. Obtained positive feedback in April and HR said it will vail for one year.
4. Received the first round evaluation again!!! 
5. Lose contact with the first HR (based in Poland), but her email address is shown it does not exist!
6. Try to contact the second HR (based in the UK) who send me the invasion link, but she is on her annual leave.
7. Still waiting for the HR team to give me a solution.
Online due to the pandemic. 2 assessment interviews with colleagues from the team, one business case for a panel audience, where senior management was included. Offer came in a few days later
It was a simple interview that basically identifies if you're a good fit for the company or not. I answered the questions truthfully and they did offer me a job but I declined.

Take home test, test #2, system design, HR test. I found the process to be quite straightforward and welcoming for the diverse software engineers. The test consisted of classical data structures and algorithms questions (Leetcode), done in Python.

1 OA. Two video interview. 
1st round, 1 medium-level coding problem, 45 min, the interviewer gave me some hints, she was very nice. 
2nd round, 1 medium-level coding problem, plus some cs basics and questions about CV, 50 min.

It was a three stage interview process, including a couple of behavioral interviews with multiple Microsoft representatives, and a session where you had to present something you were passionate about. There were no group interviews, and the whole thing happened remotely because COVID.

Behavioral and Practical two 30 mins interviews. It was not too bad but study algorithms for the practical part as they can ask you anything. They talk highly about their program which is a good program

Conversational and very open including equal time for candidate to ask questions; covered technical, commercial, and interpersonal skills and approaches to advancing ideas and solving problems.  Also asked for examples of strategic leadership achievements.
First I had a mobile interview and then I had 2 more interviews one with a senior consultant and another with a manager where I have to develop a case study for a technological company

Straightforward interview loop, technical, cultural and management style questions.  Met with a variety of colleagues and stakeholders.  approximately 5 interviews total over the course of a day. Overall it was a pleasant experience, for interviews.

I really enjoyed the interview process at Microsoft. Interviewers were very friendly and welcoming. They made sure I was comfortable during the entire interview process and were open and flexible about the timeline. I had one phone screen (1hr) and 5 rounds of onsite interview.

first I did a home test which include 3 questions at level easy to medium, then I had an interview in wich I asked about diffrent puzzles and a little bit about myself and about a project that I was doing during school.
After several interviews and low level CS puzzles, I had to solve a take home assignment within three, up to six weeks. The result of the take home then determined if they would proceed.

I had a home assignment of 1 hour with 3 questions and then phone interview that took about 20 minutes. The interview had questions about myself.  Also a question like what are the differences  between Java and Python

Standard online application, phone call with recruiter, then invitation to super-day with four back to back interviews. Very simple process; phone interview with recruiter is where they narrow it down drastically.

it was simple , and  analytical interview , depends on the way you are using for taking dissensions , be careful about your words and expressions , use easy language to describe your answers  , describe your motivations

1st round - 1.5hr DS question
2nd round - 1hr Android related design question (MVC, MVP design pattern)
Asked about current working project, Work Manager, Foreground Services, Dependency Injection. Also was given few scenarios to design application using MVC design pattern.
Design application to handle upload and download files, what if network connectivity is lost.

Standard FAANMG interview process.
1 online assessment + 4 technical rounds.
1 round - coding + career
2 round - coding
3 round - design
4 round - career + coding 

Round 4 was with a hiring manager who decides on the level and the offer

It was such a long and hectic process but my recruiter was super cool! My advice is to stay prepared and make sure that you interact with your interviewer because they are the ones that choose if you stay or go.

There was a thirty five minute phone call with a casual tone and getting to know you, then there were coding problems and you had to solve them live in front of hiring team to see your problem-solving abilities and logical thinking.
First, received an initial email, then an invitation to complete and online test, before an interview using MS teams with HR. The interview was relaxed and was asked some competency based questions.

Only made it through the first round, was told the position closed after that. The people at the company are obviously very bright and I enjoyed speaking with them. Would most likely take an offer to work there.

very friendly interview where they were getting to know me and trying to understand what i knew about the company. they made the interview seem more like a casual conversation and there was no pressure.
In stre w manager was just a single meeting and then a phone follow up I don’t know what else you want me to say it was just the one
The interview has been held remotely through Skype. The interviewer was a Senior program manager, she was really kind and open. She asked about my experiences and probed my technical knowledge
Interview process went smoothly...  no issues except for it being rescheduled last minute but not big deal since things happen.  It was quick.  Found out the outcome a few days later.

The interview process itself was seamless. Interviewers were warm and polite and made
It seem more like a conversation than an interview. Stage one was with a recruiter. Then 4 interviews with different MS people in different locations. The final interview was with the hiring manager
There are first round interviews over the phone with one semi technical question and second round interviews with easy to mid leetcode level problems. I managed to make it to second round.
it was about a month-long process, I first started the interview coding question Jan 2019 and got an offer in March of 2019. The recruiters were fair with the interview questions
It was a online interview, no video relied solely on audio. It was set up by a recruiter, I interview with at least 5 different team leads mostly consecutively with 15-30 minute breaks.

There were lot of stages in the application process. this interview was only the second stage and would still have been an assessment centre and final interview. I thought the interview went well and got on with the interviewer however was unsuccessful

1. Phone screen with recruiter
2. 4 virtual interviews. 1 hour each, touching on system design, algorithms and behavioural questions. 
3. Background checks - took about 15 days.

The whole process was seamless and the recruiter kept updating me on the progress.
Process took a total of 2 months

Interview process itself was good but 20 days after my interview I still had not heard from the recruiter. When I reached out she said they were extending an offer. I received the offer via email with no call from her. When i told her I had questions she said she was busy and asked if we could just discuss via email. Overall a terrible experience with recruiting to received and accept an offer. I am excited to join Microsoft but they don't seem to care about candidate experience.

I entered a career fair and the recruiters took interviews that day they had me answer a few coding problems and then they got back to me the same day and told me that they were going to push me to phase 2. Phase 2 was another set of coding problems and they were not super challenging.

Initial screening with a recruiter, then had a phone interview, then several video interviews with the hiring manager, team, and director. I did not receive an offer after. Quite technical and thorough interview process.

Got interviewed by 2 people on basic questions, such as arrays and linked lists. The phone interview had behavioral questions and no coding questions. Overall the process was smooth and interviewers were very understanding and nice.

Phone screening and Super day. Got the decision within 2 weeks of Super Day. 3-4 45 minute interviews  in a 3 hour long Super Day. For internship interview there wasn’t much of any technical questions all behavioral and situational.

Got an email from the recruiter for a specific job opening. As I accepted the interview offer I went through a 30-minute call with the recruiter to talk about the position, logistics, expectations, etc. And there was a phone screening interview was scheduled.

HR and first round , the hr was good , talked about my self and how to explain  stuff for kids. , such as recrussions , it was friendly  , many unrelated question to the position , I was fully prepared , didn’t think it would be this average

A series of several interviews with 2 more welcome calls at the end. Start with HR, then your future boss, his/her 3 proxies (tech and 2x product) and finally a welcome call with the office manager and a "You got the offer" call :)

Interview was done online on Microsoft teams,  I had to be prepared for the interview before time and connect with mic and camera . I was informed earlier that I might have to share screen as interviewer might want to let me do the code for some problem(s)

Phone interview with behavioral questions and based on resume. For 30 min. 2 technical questions: explain recursion and difference between thread and process. Other was based on internship experience and project experience.

The interview was about an hour
First question was tell me about yourself then had some other
questions about skills and previous experience
The coding challenge today was Data Structure string question
The coding challenge today was Data Structure string question

I interviewed with the Platform Intelligence team for a senior software engineer position. After applying I was sent a 75 minute take home test where I had to correct a small program and then write a leetcode medium style solution from scratch.

After passing that, I got scheduled for an "interview day" the next tuesday. It was a 4 interview on-site. If you look up microsoft onsite, it was exactly as described. 3 coding/systems design and one "as-appropriate". The coding problems were reasonable and I liked the interviewers. The as-appropriate went into excruciating detail on a "time you disagreed with a coworker" question.

I got an offer like 3 or 4 business days later for 62 (which levels.fyi says is SDE II, but the recruiter told me is a sr. role).

I was interviewed by Microsoft China, software engineer new grad full time position at STCA (software technology center Asia).
HR first will connect you on Wechat if you are Chinese person. Then two rounds of interview with current employee. Note that the interview are in Chinese. I didn't expect that since all job descriptions and interview confirmation are in English.
Two rounds of interview include resume digging  questions and coding questions. They don't have a collaborative coding platform, so you have to write your code on your local IDE. They expect you to code alone and quitely without discussion with them.

3round interview 
Presentation panel
Meeting with different member of CSAM leadership team 
The interviews were very nice , no tricky questions if you did your research .
The recruiter keeps you posted about every steps in the process.

Rude recruiter with a lot of "I want you to do it" "send to me", etc.

Recruiter has been pretty rude throughout the process, and not respectful toward candidates' time, by ghosting after asking candidates to fill out a very long questionnaire.

Quite unprofessional with such behavior after asking candidates to spend so much time.

Had a consultant do the interview. He asked 8 questions related to my previous experience, and why Microsoft and favorite product from microsoft and then the interview was done. No time to ask for questions from my side.
Four round interviews, behavior questions, and coding questions were asked, one of the interviewers is aggressive and the others are very good. One system design round and three coding rounds.

It consisted of one both technical and behavioral interview, one coding test and if you passed those, 4 final interviews with various questions - both technical/coding, system design and behavioral (all 4 on the same day).

TA >> 1st Interview >> Final Interview
TA said after the final interview, I'll get offer if I pass the interview.
Because of the very rude interviewer, so I quit in the middle of final interview.

First, there is a phone interview (pre-screen w/ recruiter with some behavioral and product questions). Second, there are 2-4 interview rounds during an onsite superday. Typically, about 30-40 intern/FTE interviewers during the same superday.

Went through initial phone call screening that led to one on site interview and solved problems as well as debugging. The whole process took roughly 3-4 hours and had 2 other developers interview me and assess my skills.

A short initial chat (essentially a briefing about the role, team and interview process) with a recruiter, then a chat/ casual interview with the hiring manager, and then a round of interviews with peers/ senior people. he hiring manager went into detail about the team and the role and asked a few questions about previous roles and experience. More of a discussion. The other interviews were tougher: more in-depth questions about technical knowledge and experience, response to scenarios etc
Behavior Question and go over each slot in your resume, need a detailed explanation of the resume project, after-short discussion on resume and experience, go a Leetcode practice not hard

There were online coding tests, and then they emailed m e to schedule an interview. This was followed by the virtual interview. During the interview, I was asked to solve one leetcode style question and then 2-3 behavioral questions. Pretty straightforward.
Sales associate interview was good. it asked me where I interned at, and worked at before. Responsibilities. Make sure you know your STAR method for every question - that will help you out.

First interview: Skype call talking about myself and what I have done in the past.

Second interview: On site interviews(3) mainly data structures related but can have design depending on the interviwer.

Very competitive series of meetings with various stakeholders. The team covered many  perspectives and there was ample room  for prospect questions.  There was the obvious focus on experience and technical skills. However, there was a large push to review cultural fit.

1st. testing your computer science fundamentals by about 15 MCQ 
2nd. testing your knowledge in AI-related fields 
3rd. solving 3 medium to hard coding problems (any language you want)
 
Note: the interview was completely Online Due to Covid-19

It was not that hard. I did not get the chance for the final round due to the position being filled. I found the experience very pleasing and nice. I would highly recommend studying for the "Why Microsoft" question
HR + 2 technical interview, every thing was nice, before the first i needed to past a test on codility with three quations, you can choose the languge you want to write the answers.

First round was a phone interview, second was video chat, third was 4-5 round interviews(video because of covid). Rd 1 & 2 were just questions about me and my resume. The third round was 4 or 5 back to back interviews all about STAR questions

I applied through company website. Interview process took 1 day which consisted of 3 rounds which lasted for 1.5 hours each. They scheduled microsoft team's call. Panel was extremely helpful, they were making me comfortable and helping me if i was doing anything wrong.
I had to do some programming exercises online and go through an HR interview. I thought the process was ok but a little impersonal. Overall it was a good experience.
They will contact you to schedule a meeting for a phone screen and if you pass. There will be a final round where you are going to answer coding questions with either 2 or 3 different interviewers.

4 round interview with two managers and two teammates. Hiring event with all easy questions, some database questions with sql and nosql based on the project. The entire interview process is great and all of the interviewers are friendly.
It was ok, to many questions that not really related to the job, but the people are nice and friendly very nuch. And i heard it is a good place to work in
Very laid back and technical. I have to say they made me feel very at home and were able to word questions differently to help aid the process. I would highly recommend giving this process a try.
Very quick. The PM mainly asked me about my past experience as a data Analyst and about my motivations to join this new team. He wanted to make sure I was comfortable with the requirements.

A home test that contains three code questions at different levels and then an interview with general questions like telling about yourself and why you want to work at Microsoft and professional questions in English

The interviewer was not very approachable, friendly, and didn't respond to my answers so it was difficult to tell if I was going on the right path. When I asked clarifying questions, he would just repeat the same question again. The questions were very broad. I left the interview feeling terrible and severely disappointed in myself.

- one interview with the HR
- one interview with the manager (mostly STAR questions)
- two technical interview about Azure and Cloud computing concept
the first technical interview was about general Networking and Cloud technologies.
the second covered Azure services
I sent a resume and they got back to me with a technical interview. After that there would have been a final round interview, but i dont remember what that would have involved.
it was a smooth and tension free process, though I was nervous initially, it worked well in the end. The interviewers are very nice and were giving you time enough to answer.

Interviewer asked for a resume summary and several behavioral questions. The interview was very short, as it was only for the first round.  Interviewer sounded very ambivalent before I even began to speak.

At first they asked personal information. They proceeded immediately by asking me about my understanding of position I'm applying for, and some technical questions here and there, 

at the end they gave me a scenario of a cloud service.

Casual, on-time and to the point. The interview was very well handled.  Three separate interviews were held with different managers. They were all courteous and well organized. I would interview with Microsoft again if given the opportunity.

In my experience, it was a long process, which is slightly stressful when you're (desperately) looking for a job/internship. The final interview was completely virtual because of Covid and took around 3 hours.

An interview with a person using Skype that asked questions about why do you wanna work at Microsoft, what is your passion for technology and then the interviewer used senarios and asked what I would do and how to handle it.

It was really good the perwson asked me some very good questions whcih i have very good asnwers too so it was all good. One of thiengs to be noted is that good quesitons are hard to come by so only good questions only

Interviewed for a full-time position with relevant experience of 4 to 8 years. There were 4 rounds of technical interviews and the final round was with the Manager. Overall very technical and a lot of coding questions and test cases.

Call from recruiter. With in two weeks Interview with team. Troubleshooting questions - how to narrow down to the issue. Power bi questions- live update of reports. Resume related questions like how my past experiences helps for this role.

Received an email for the coding challenge test first, asking to finish in 10 working days. Finished the test as requested in the following week. But there was no follow-up afterward. Think did well in the coding challenge since it revealed as 100% correct in the assessment.

Sono state fatte domande relative allo sviluppo software e in seguito è stato fatto un quesito di logica. L’interviewer era molto gentile e aiutava nel procedimento. Molto professionale, sono soddisfatto.

1 skype interview and two other technical interviews,
3 online tasks in 80 min that you should do before the HR interview, 
Q : explain a big O notation to a kid
Q: what the diff between good and great code?
Codility questions. All I can say brush up on debugging and data structures and algorithms. On top of that don't tense during the interview and just do what you can

There were 2 rounds. First with a TAM, second round lasted several hours and I interviewed with 3 people back to back. Great conversational interviews with behavioral questions. No technical questions

Applied directly via Microsoft's website.

Got contacted by HR to schedule the first interview, which was led by two future team members. This was a technical interview focused in SQL, reporting, and support related questions.

The final interview was with the manager, who asked me what I would do in hypothetical scenarios. Also got to present myself, my hobbies and my professional path up until the interview.

I received an offer two weeks later, went through a background check which lasted a week and finally got the confirmation that I was hired.

Contacted by a recruiter by email and asked to write back answers to a list of questions. Scheduled a phone interview in two weeks for technical screen. Completed coding challenge but did not move forward due to lack of relevant experience.

I was contacted by the hiring manager directly. Set up the final round of interviews the following week. 

Questions involved previous experience, product management concepts, some SQL hands-on.

Overall it was an average interview difficulty.

Round one consist of an hirvue video with standard behavioral questions. Then it is followed up with a panel style interview during superday. Pretty straightforward, will help to understand the main financial statemnets used in accounting

Meerdere gesprekken en een assessment dag waarop vooral gefocust werd op sociale vraagstukken. Ook moeste er een samenwerkingstaak gebeuren waarmee je (online) samenwerkte met meerdere mensen. Assessment bestond uit 4 delen waarin individuele- en onderdelen in teamverband voor kwamen.

First interview by phone, just to know your motivations and knowledge of the company. Some questions regarding your point of view in some judgements problems. Practice some soft skills and study the company missions and values

Interview was a technical interview with coding question on white board, brief behavioral conversation. On campus interview lasted around thirty minutes with a single interviewer. Overall experience was okay, not great.

Its a two step process, first with recruiter and then the actual interview with Manager and team. They want to know your dedication, how empathetic you are towards customer, critical thinking while solving problems.

Initially applied online and got a response from a recruiter within about 2 weeks of submitting my application.

Started initially with a Video Interview with a senior member of the team where we reviewed what I was currently working on and what my current job role entailed.

This then moved onto a 2nd stage interview, was given a case study about a week before the interview with a scenario inside of a typical customer I would imagine. The case study was the basis of the presentation that needed be 30-45 minutes long and then allowing for questions at the end.

The 2nd stage interviews were split into 2 parts:
1) Presentation - Technical Peers
2) Management Interview - Team manager and a peer

The Presentation was a role play to treat the peers as the customer and you in the role that you were applying for, managerial was more traditional interviews trying to match questions to the corporate values.

Took a few days to get very detailed feedback, however the feedback clashed with what the overall answer was. One of the pieces of feedback was that I was able to give good real-world examples to qualify experience and yet I wasn't hired because I was unable to provide adequate examples of real world scenarios!

I was interviewed for Software Engineer 2 position (SAP). It consisted for interviews with 4 different people, 45 min each, all remote, on the same day. This was the only interviews and decision would be made after this. The Hiring Manager was also one of the interviewers. 

I finally got an update after 4 weeks from the recruiter that the team recommended me for hire, but there was no headcount with the team so they could not extend the job offer.  It was frustrating for such a reputed company to not have a headcount but advertise the position as open. No proper updates or communication as well from the recruiter. I thankfully got a different offer in the meantime, and I understand MFST is a big company and competition is fierce, but Microsoft takes such a long time to make a decision compared to other FAANG companies. This has to improve!

I was contacted by Microsoft recruiting team , started with phone screening, followed with 4 round of technical coding mixed with behavioural questions. overally not bad, however, I realized that interviewers somehow were not professional, mostly jut trying to pass the time, like they already had made their decision

45 minute interview with some behavioral questions based off of information on my resume, projects that I have worked on and my past technical experience. There was 1 coding question asked where I had to write code and explain my work
Video chat with multiple people.  They asked me a series of questions that were related to customer service and the tasks I would be performing, as well as my experience.

I was contacted by a recruiter that they were interested in interviewing me. I spoke to him on the phone and discussed my interests to gauge my fit for the role. I then scheduled a 1 hour technical interview with a team member using MS Teams. The interview consisted of typical coding problems. I was contacted a few days later with an invitation to the second interview. This round consisted of four one hour interviews with different team members. Each interview was a mix of technical and behavioral questions. I am awaiting a response for the results of these interviews.

Two interviews, one with someone who asked me how to do something specific with File IO in C# on a whiteboard, another with a super chill person who just wanted to chat about my employment history from my resume

One phone screen followed by day of interviews. 

The interview day consisted of 3 rounds of interviews with different team members. One of those interviews including presenting a presentation on your topic of choice. You had to prepare this prior to interview day.

10 minutes about resume questions and job description clarifications. The interviewer was friendly and polite. 
50 minutes coding questions, needed to share my screen while typing the answer. The interviewer gave hints in my pauses.

Four rounds of interviews, some technical and some behavioral. Was limited to one coding question per round but we're some follow-up questions. Be prepared to answer behavioral questions related to difficult workplace situations.

First phase: you have to pass the CV check
Second phase: casual interview on more personal matters and previous experience
Third phase: Complex interview, including team work and technical questions, problem solving and one-to-one dialogue

Behavioral questions and some uncomplicated code really How would you build a kitchen for your grandparents?
And three more code questions that are not difficult but not easy to solve in 80 minutes

First there was online test with 3 questions and a quiz. It was average questions but time was 1hr. so you have to be fast. You must write comments if you want to make it. I did solved all 3 coding problem. Then was final round with 4 interview all coding related.

Behavioral and product design questions. I was asked 1 coding question but it was not difficult and I didn’t have to write the code down, just had to explain it. The recruitment process was incredibly slow though

Fair but challenging. Maybe better than other application processes that I have been through at smaller places. Coding questions, algorithms, pretty standard interview overall.  Applied as a new graduate out of school.

The interview was very detailed with multiple people. The questions were technical, but seemed more concerned about observing your ability to solve problems. They were also concerned to make sure that it was a good personal fit.

Great interview. Lots of detail for technical questions in regards to Outlook support and technical tools that would be used during troubleshooting outlook issues. Management was great to talk to and the people who interviewed me during the process.
The interview was pleasant and the team was very easy to speak with. They asked questions relevant to the role as well as questions to get a feel for how I would interact with customers.

two technical interviews using Teams webcam remotely (I used web software) and codelity (second interview had one question in jsfiddle) 

Two young guys which were very nice on video. 

Apparently the HR girl did not attach any information to the calendar meeting and it was all in the mail itself, which is highly unusual, therefore I've missed the first interview and we had to reschedule

The interview was quick and fast. There are three steps:
1. Recruiter interview
2. Technical interview (checking general technical knowledge)
3. Manager interview and presentation/role interview during the 'Interview Event'

The process was in a nice atmosphere, unfortunately, the feedback information was to make me feel like I don't know anything and I'm worthless. No positive word about me, even if the whole talk and discussion during the interview were professional.

Applied via website. Recruiter reached out about 3-4 weeks later. Went thru virtual Interview Loop within the week. Met with 3 HM over 3 hours. Included ppt on MSFT and the Modern Workplace.  All HM were extremely personable and easy to speak with. Overall it is a very lengthy process ~10 weeks in total. Recruiters definitely leave something to desire. Rarely responded to me and I only reached out a couple times. How hard is it respond with, received and working on it?

Total interview process happened over Microsoft Teams with 1 hr per round. Interviewers range from being stone faced to very friendly. I had a whole of 4 interviews span across multiple days.  I got some very good feedback on what technical areas are lacking in my career from few interviewers and no feedback and waiting for the interview to be completed kind of rounds.
One round, the interviewer was doing a pair programming since the problem statement was very lengthy and it was fun. 
Hiring manager's tone was very obvious that he found some one else and was only cross validating me with the other candidate.

No feedback from the HR so far even after 1 month and hence considering I didn't make the cut.

Process was pretty standard.
First round - Online coding challenge of 75 mins.
Second round - Onsite virtual interviews event. 4 interviews 45 min each. (2 teams interviewed 2 rounds each).

Recruiter found me on linkedin, we had a 30-min and then they sent me an invite for a 1-h talk with a hiring manager. Then there were four 1-h online interviews in one day with the representatives from different teams
I am only writing this review so they let me look at other reviews, They lock the website unless I write one review, so here you go. It's stupid in my opinion. Sorry that I picked Microsoft

1st round: 30 mins with developer on Codility doing a medium question

Final round: 4 x 45 minutes back to back on Codility (with 15 min break in between).  Each interviewer will give usually one Easy or Medium, which you're expected to complete in approximately 30 minutes with a close-to-optimal solution. They will also give you 2 - 3 behavioural questions (less about specific projects on your resume, and more "Tell me about a time when you... xyz".

4 45 minute interviews with 15 minute breaks.  Talk with four separate managers about various topics, past experience, previous projects, standard interview fare.  Each had their own different technical question(s).
Apply online, one 30 min video interview to discuss resume and coding, a virtual onsite of four 45 min interviews with the team to discuss resume, behavioral, coding and ML.

Research based. on my project, basic concept. understanding of state of art technology. Introduced my research background and previous projects. and the interviewer asked some question regarding my answer. I also asked several questions.

Very much focused on group and social interactions, it lasted 1 full day through which we have underwent various exercises from pairing up with a partner and presenting ourselves for 5 minutes to rolling over pairs of managers, group exercises for product delivery and sales pitches as to why we would recommend a product to a several managers. Technical wise, very few questions were asked ( difference between TCP and UDP for example)

3 interviews based on my experience and practical questions as if you were in this situation, what would you? 
All interviews were done in remote because of Covid situation. Smooth process and everybody was very nice

an face to face interview was the first one second one was a coding question in there offices  where you asked to implement logger with variant options (suppose to be only for seniors but I interviewed for junior position)

- I was contacted by a recruiter.
- After a casual meeting with the hiring manager, I applied for the relevant position.
- First and second round interviews
- Online interview by teams

Four interviews on zoom (during quarantine). Coding questions and some open-ended machine learning learning questions. Coding questions were not too difficult, basically standard leetcode questions. The position is in NLP, so most of the code questions were about string manipulation, and open-ended questions were about NLP.

Very smooth and comfortable interview process. It was more of a conversation about my past roles and some behavioural questions. The actual role was a bit different than what was advertised on the job position but I was told I can easily learn on the job. Left the interview feeling very confident but received a rejection email 2 business days later!
It was kind of intimating. They like for you to communicate and talk it out while coding. You sort of have to have the full idea of what you’re doing.
It was good experience, interview level is difficult. They ask coding skills even for Customer engineer role. This is some what uncomfortable that they need coding skills for this kind of role

Application, sent CV, First short-inteview. At first I  was asked very practical questions to understand my availability to work. After I was asked some questions concerning the company and my interest for the industry as well as for marketing.
A lot of steps but with very personable interviewers there was a lot of help and resources along the way. There are different skill and competency tests and a roleplay exercise also.

This was the 1st interview, it was more technical then I expected with only 1 presentation question and the rest was technical questions. Duration: 30 minutes. Semi-formal. It took longer then the expected time

I interviewed during the COVID pandemic and went through 3 different 30 minute video interviews with engineers within Microsofts One Engineering System (1ES) organisation.

The first interview gave a background on the role and the types of projects that they work on, and gave me the chance to talk about my own experience. The second interview was technical and I was asked networking and systems design questions. There was no coding problems used in the interview process. The final interview was with a senior engineer which was a general chat and discussion about Microsoft's culture.

I had the impression that each of the interviews went quite smoothly. The process seemed very relaxed and easy compared to other companies which often do intensive full day interviews. However, the communication throughout the process was almost entirely automated and not informative or personalised. After my last interview I got very little updates from the recruiter regarding timelines and feedback. Two weeks after my last interview I got an automated email from Microsoft saying they would not be moving forward with my candidacy.

Veeeery long wait. I applied at the end of October and did not receive a peep back until the middle of February. Once I got the email for an interview, the interview was scheduled the next week. 

*This if for an undergraduate research internship not normal PhD research internship.* Started with one 45-minute coding interview followed by a 15 minute break and then a one-hour interview talking about past machine learning projects.  Questions that were asked were along the lines of "Walk me through this project", "What are some of the key lessons you learned", "What are some problems you faced and how did you overcome them."

After the interview I notified my recruiter of previous offers and subsequently got a verbal offer the next day and the official written offer was given the week after. Overall everyone was friendly and it was a great experience.

I submitted my application via the portal.
it took one week for them to contact me arranging HR interview, it was good one , normal questions like introduce your self , job description,  previous experience...etc
after 3 days tech interview via teams. it took more than one hour
the q was fast and breath taking .. overall nice experience.

4 rounds of interview
Process took one week
After applying online reciter connected and further rounds were scheduled.
All d rounds were virtual over Microsoft team

2 interviews were taking interview, They were very polite and supportive. 
Most questions were asked as per the resume and JD.

30 min phone interview, 4 back 2 back interviews. 1 interviewer confuses you into thinking you're solving one type of question when its another and wastes 40 mins of 45 min to tell you otherwise. Also another interviewer asked question that cannot be solved the way they wanted in a programming language of your choice. Basically 2/4 interviewers were bad don't give up keep trying. Also doesn't care how resourceful you are or your critical thinking only cares about getting question correct  from leetcode.
They reached out to me, had a prescreen call to discuss overall position and interest, was promised to hear back after 1,5 week. Never got an answer, followed up but got ghosted by the recruiter.

Tenia pactadas 3 entrevistas con los Directores a los que tenia que asistir
La 1er entrevista fue con una Directora bastante agresiva en su manera de hablar sinceramente me hizo sentir muy incomoda
La segunda fue con un Director, la misma duro 10 minutos y la persona bostezo 3 veces mientras yo le hablaba
La 3era fue cancelada el mismo dia y no tuve mas novedades posterior a eso ni de la empresa ni de la Consultora Manpower que fue quien me acerco la oferta laboral

I was contacted via LinkedIn. The interview process was pretty standard. Nothing overbearing or dramatic. Fortunately, all of my interviews were remote and split over multiple days as they were trying to find someone quickly.

Casual Interview in times of Covid-19.  Using Teams to for individual interviews is working nicely. The people interviewing also know their role and clearly they are agreeing the topics everyone of them is going to discuss with you.

I would have been happy with the process even not getting an offer but how the closure was done was pretty disappointing. I was pulled through a series of inteviews (6 separate calls) and afterwards nothing told how the process would go. After 2,5 weeks I was just sent an automated email saying that "Thank you for applying, better luck next time". I would have assumed to be getting some level of personalised comms, even in for of an email. No reason given what happened.

Please Microsoft think your recruiting process through as the closure part is really important for the candidates and also for you. I would assume you would like to get people staying interested applying still for new positions.

After applying, you will have a phone screen that was mainly resume based, behavioral and maybe one technical question. They want to see your passion for technology!

If successful, you will move on to the final rounds with at least two interviews (back to back) with a mix of PM and technical questions.

I saw a Technical Specialist role in Linkedin and applied from Microsoft's website.
The process has the steps below:
1) Email from a Microsoft's recruiter
2) Call with a Microsoft's recruiter
3) Screening with a Technical Specialist in the same role of application (30 mins)
4) Interview with a Hiring Manager

One HR phone screen.  After the phone screen, HR scheduled 5 different video interviews.  One interview with the hiring manager and the others with four members of the team and stakeholders.   No feedback or rejection.  Crickets.

The Process was dragged for more than a month , there were 2 Technical Rounds and 2 Managerial Rounds .

Each technical round exceeded for more than 1.5Hours and it was purely technical , Microsoft doesn't compromise on the depth of Technical knowledge with respect to Security concept that one possess .

The 2nd Technical Round  Was not a comfortable one , The interviewer was mechanical and asked text book based questions and expected answers according to the same. The interviewer had technical issues with her front cam yet she insisted that I had connectivity issues and to restart my network. It was quite contrasting to the first round which happened more or like a discussion.

I rejected the offer since the role I opted for Senior security analyst and the position Microsoft sanctioned was of Security Analyst.

I applied 8 Times for the position of Threat researcher and Senior security analyst over the year and it went through only for this time.

The Resume screening process with respect to Microsoft does not justify it's Global fame.

Online assessment that has 1 general CS MSQ questions and 4 problem-solving questions, 2 of them are find the bug in the code

After the online assessment I did interviews loop of 4 interviews virtually due to Covid-19

there were three problem solving and last one of them I didn't code

It was just a problem that needs to ask clarifying questions and dive deep with the interviewer till reaching a valid approach and that was the hardest interview

Continue Reading

There were 2 rounds.
First phone screen. Basic behavioral questions (Why do you want to work here etc.)
Second round was a super day.
Super day was scheduled for a couple of months later. Interviewers asked pretty standard LC mediums.

HR interview, followed by online coding test (3 tasks, leet code alike, medium difficulty). Final round is 4 interviews in one day - System design interview, soft skills interview, OOP concepts interview, algorithms / data structures interview

The worst interviewing process, they contact me in LinkedIn, I respond that I was interested, they reply me with 10 questions on my inbox, so I answered them and later on the week they send me an invitation for the OTS (Online Technical Screening). I show up 5 minutes early and no one attended the meeting. I wait for an hour, and sent a couple of mails, and nothing happened. One week later they show up tellingbme that the position was closed for LATAM, that he could transfer me to a job position in other team that could hire someone from LATAM, and that he would send me the OTS next day. I'm still waiting, I sent emails but no response, a complete waste of time and the discouragement of being stood up

Straightforward. Done in one day.  Long waiting period to get any answer back. Polite interview panel. Recruiters need to be more up to speed with questions. Would recommend to interview for Microsoft to anyone.
First round phone screen for about 30 minutes. I made it to the final round which was four 45 minute virtual interviews. First 3 were technical/behavioral and the last one was behavioral.

I applied and Hiring Manager (Director) reached out quickly, directly via email. She seemed excited and positive when we met on VC. There was no recruiter involved which seemed a bit strange. She said that she would follow up in a week, with a decision on whether or not I would be invited to full loop. Never heard from her again, was ghosted by Microsoft! To add to this, this week a recruiter reached out on LI re: a similar role. When I asked him was it the same team, and told him I didnt hear back from the Director above, he came back to say "We are currently in process for other candidates but I'll come back to you should we be interested in progressing you further and then we can discuss the role in more detail." He sourced me on LI, so I was pretty surprised with his response simply for letting him know about my recent experience.

Screening round. Question can be rated as LC M, dynamic programming. Interviewer forced me to use java even though I said that I preferred to use python3.

Interviewer was very nice, but question was more of an onsite question.

I applied for a position "Security Researcher" in Microsoft, Vancouver.
First I had a discussion meeting with program manager regarding my application. After a week, HR scheduled 3 back-to-back interview, each 1 hour, with 3 different interview panelist. Interviews were so smooth, I had answered almost all questions and didn't answer a few. But none of them belittled me for not giving right answers. I would highly recommend everyone to experience technical interview process with Microsoft.
I got a mail from HR next week saying, I will be having final interview with research manager. It was cancelled on the last day. HR re-scheduled the final interview with another research manager. And on the day of my final interview, I received an automation mail from Microsoft that "we will not be moving forward with your candidacy for the position of Security Researcher". I dropped a mail to HR and he too responded back saying he never received any note that the interview has been cancelled.Later HR told they will get back with more information but no response from them even after I mailed them twice asking for an update.

The whole interview process took one complete month.All I needed was one response from HR team on the closure.It is not good to keep candidates hanging like this. 
It would have been better if HR had some basic manners of informing the candidate on the situation.
Please attend MS technical interviews for good interview process experience. But do not have hopes on getting conclusion mails from HR (even if you performed well).

I applied online and I was contacted by a Microsoft engineer. He explained the process in the email. The interview was remotely and took an hour. The guy was easy going, but answered mostly "up to you" to my questions making it hard to decide what's important to focus in the coding challenge I got. I didn't have a clear goal to aim for and although he explained is to see how I code and approach things I still think I could be more efficeint ih we colaborated more. 

I was told it will take a week to get feedback or I should contact a hiring manager. I didn't get any email for 2 weeks, so I sent one. The hiring manager replied with generic message after 2 weeks, but when I asked for feedback I got no response. I realize they have many candidates but it's disrespectful and unprofesional to leave people like that when they spent time to prepare for the interview.

Codility- answer 3 coding questions in 80 minutes.
Interview - Skype interview with someone from overseas.
Interview: technical questions on a project, why do you want to work for Microsoft, algorithm question.

I went through 4 stages. The first was a call with the hiring manager to review my background. It was mostly behavioral questions. Then I had two one-on-one technical interviews with engineers in the department. My last interview was with the hiring manager and was entirely technical. I received an update 2 weeks after the 4th interview.

The interview lasted for 1.5 hours.  

There are several technical questions followed by a short presentation of my own project. Several questions were asked about my specific project. The interview ended with several HR questions like my personality and the benefits I expect from the company
Had 4 technical interviews in total. Overall it was very organized but took a while to hear back. The loop was kind of fun but also very nerve wrecking. I suspect they over interviewed.

Interview process started with recruiting team reaching out to me. But for some reason HR doesn't call candidate to explain any details. 
Interview was two step process, a scheduler scheduled interview with Manager and a technical resource as preliminary and subsequently 4 more interviewers.

I received result within a week.

The process is not as daunting as some of the more technical roles, but still come prepared to interview with 3+ people. The roles are competitive so bring your A game even if you feel very qualified.

Interview with 3 people from the department that was looking to hire a new software developer which took place at the Redmond campus. All 3 people had several questions relating to both past experience and hypothetical situations for which different problems were posed and your answers were challenged by each panel member.

The process included a coding test followed by 3 rounds of interview. First round of interview was technical, next was behavioral and the last interview was managerial/technical with the tech lead of the division.

Technical interview using 2 different technical code questions with talking inbetween. The technical coding question was on a website with a Visual Studio like environment that was very helpful to use.
Structured but no follow up: I have to proactively ping the recruiter for status.  Process  takes four months abs then new HM takes REQ and starts over. I liked the team and the role.

Very straight forward and good. I had two meetings, one with the team and one with the manager. First interview was very technical and checking the knowledge about the product, they asked very basic to advanced questions. Manager ask a lot of questions regarding how I manage the cases in previous experiences.

Online assessment that has 1 general CS MSQ questions and 4 problem-solving questions, 2 of them are find the bug in the code

After the online assessment I did interviews loop of 4 interviews virtually due to Covid-19

there were three problem solving and last one of them I didn't code 

It was just a problem that needs to ask clarifying questions and dive deep with the interviewer till reaching a valid approach and that was the hardest interview

Online assessment has 1 general CS MCQs, two problems solving and two find the wrong in problem solution
The last interview was the hardest and was about a real-life problem and you have to dive deep with the interviewer to solve it

There is no fixed interview process or format, I was told that it varies between product groups and teams. The process that I went through consisted of 4 rounds focused on testing the analytical, problem-solving, and management skills.

half an hour interview on skype with a recruiter from the USA. most of the questions were personal, and the last one was more technical.  I was asked about a challenge I had in my former job, and how did I overcome it. I was also asked I would I explain a little kid the term recursion.

First I did an HR review with american interviewer, after that 3 technical interviews which were data structure questions,.... 
The process take to much time almost two months and in the end have many candidates and they choose one from us. 
And it's unsane how much the Interview Process long.
