It was a good process I can complain. The interview was average difficulty with challenging design questions. Overall great. There was only one coding session the others were design and customer focused. Went through one 30 min interview and then four others that were conducted in one day. Heard from them the next day.

I have applied for the role in January 2020 from Melbourne.
-Cleared the HR round
- Had my technical round with Team in China -Cleared the round "All of my facts about the SCCM were super accurate"
- Interview with the Team manager -Cleared
-interview with two of the director of Asia pacific. cleared.

Then after HR called me and told me that Director  advised me to apply for the Azure support which i had no experience about. But they kind of persuaded me. Had the interview and rejected.

This whole scenario made me never want apply for the job in Microsoft and no one to complain about!

Worst interview experience I have ever had. Attitude of the interviewer was horrible and dismissive. One interviewer gave feedback of the sales simulation opposite to what other interviewer gave information to HR. The whole process was a complete mess and very unprofessionally handled.

Phone screen was fairly simple.  Very general questions about skills, experience and education.   Other questions  about various software programs, how  do I  handle difficult personalities at work, how do I go about anticipating the needs of an executive, etc.

A generic job description shared. 
Random set of interviewers who do not know for which role they are interviewing and interviewee background.
I was shocked to see Engineering Managerial drives conducted similar to campus placement drives.
A combination of contract recruiting staff and HR coordination made whole process even more painful.

Since it is the "Microsoft" I went ahead here is what followed:

I was able to clear the coding round. Interviewer is knowledgable and pleasant.
For the second round - Design round, they did not have interviewer ready. Hence they set some one up after taking a long time who dozed off during the interview. Biggest farce is he said he thoroughly enjoyed conversation :D
Could not make it to third round :)

I think Microsoft Recruiting need to review their strategy. When hiring experienced professionals, it is important specific job description and evaluation strategy needs to  be planned not a generic one. This way they can help themselves and give a positive experience to candidates irrespective of the result.

The process was very professional and I was very satisfied with it
they start to prepare white board and I has been asked about some data structures like searching algorithms, graphs and tress

2 hours interview. An easy assignment, fibonacci code with recursion and loop. Afterwards a more difficult efficient algorith writing of a math riddle. Both of them using codility. The interviewr was really nice and cooperative.

*Te contactan por email, 
*Nunca toman la llamada, 
*No te dicen en que estatus esta tu proceso, 
*Recibes correos automatizados de que vas avanzando en el proceso, pero no tienes retroalimentación alguna. 
*Al final recibes un correo automatizado, que indica que no fuiste seleccionado, pero nunca tienes el derecho a conocer tu retroalimentación

The process went very smoothly. The interviewer was very polite and also tried to help me when i got stuck in between sometime. The overall Experience was good. The major thing to focus on is the basics related to the language that you have chosen and also the role.

Hackerrank live session. Didn't pass the question. They asked for the two sum and the interviewer was very helpful. There was a variety of languages to choose from. Didn't hear back from them for a long time though.

Interviewed for total of three rounds, each took about a week to proceed and received offer two weeks after final interview. Recruiter is kind to tell you your performance on interviews too. Unofficial email from recruiter saying positive first then offer.

The process begins with an aptitude test. You do a series of tests to measure your competency and understanding of Data structures.  You're then invited for a physical interview where you're interviewed by one of the senior developers
They ask me to solve  2 problems. I explained the solution and it was done. I had a pretty good solution so they were all impressed at me.  So they welcomed me with a generous offer.

There are several interviews but you need to pass each one to go to the next one. The first interview is about your background in software engineering. I didnt pass this first interview. They asked a few questions about why microsoft, what I did in college, preferred languages and several questions like this. They also asked me a puzzle question and 3 code questions to do in an hour outside of the interview.

There were 2 rounds , both technical. Basic data structures - median in a stream of integers, topological sort, tree traversals, graph traversals. 

Also some questions on projects mentioned in resume
codelity then 3 interviews  then hr questions after that the hr told me about my opinion in the salary then i declined it because its so far to work there as you know

totally there are 4 interviews after phone screening. Interviewers were very kind. Before each interview, 1 or 2 behavior questions were asked.
Very common questions, like most challenging project, colleagues who are hard to deal with, conflict with team members, etc.

1/ J'ai postulé sur le site Internet des carrières Microsoft
2/ J'ai ensuite eu un screening RH (appel de 15 minutes)
3/ Invitation à un assessment centre avec différentes épreuves tout au long de la journée
El proceso de entrevistas fue interesante y muy completo. Sin embargo, el feedback recibido deja mucho que desear y no me contactaron para comunicarme que no había sido el candidato seleccionado.

After passing the CV screening and the online programming assessment test, I was interviewed by 4 researchers from Microsoft Research Redmond. The last interview was conducted by the leader of the research team.

All interviewers were very polite and easy going. The questions were mostly "design questions" but with a focus in NLP research problems. I think I did very poorly in all these questions. I'm not sure why but I couldn't ask the right questions to clarify the under specified problem. I tried to "solve" the problem using only the very broad information piece given at the beginning.

In the end, I didn't got an offer. That's ok. It happens. But the most annoying thing is that they just got silent. After FOUR INTERVIEWS! I think I passed through the whole process! And they just didn't bother to tell me I wasn't getting an offer. I insisted a lot with the recruiter before coming to a friend that works at MS so that he could contact the team leader directly. Almost immediately the recruiter called me to tell the bad news. I think it was more than a month since my last interview and their return.

So that was very disappointing. Specially because I have hear so many good things about MS process.

- HR phone interview to assess the skillset
- round 1 - technical - questions were mostly around react and javascript
- round 2 - technical - ticky and indepth questions regarding react, redux and javascript

Leider habe ich keine Rückmeldung nach dem Vorstellungsgespräch bekommen. Insgesamt war der Prozess nicht so gut, generell gab es eine fehlende Transparenz und ich war überrascht im Interview zu sitzen. Nachdem Gespräch gab es keine weitere Kommunikation von der Personalerin. Das Vorstellungsgespräch war insgesamt okay.
No sé comunicaron para decir si o no después de un año, me imagino que fue un no, pero me hubiera gustado que lo comentaran, es un buen detalle para la persona ya que gasto algo de su tiempo

There were two people interview me. The interview went well with questions. 
It was not very hard. I interviewed with two team members.  
They asked question about hardware test and some questions in my resume

It was a very strange experience. First I got an email from the Creative Director, then I talked to the hiring manager, it was an awesome conversation. But then the recruiter stepped in the process itself and everything went awry. I had a rather weird call with an HR, she said rather unpleasant words that it’s not clear at all how I could reach this stage, etc.

Did an interview. The person conducting my interview was very nice and professional. Although I did not get the position they have me good feedback at the end and I was happy with the overall experience.

Questions about Microsoft and Educational background. Also about any mistake on compony website?

Questions about Microsoft and Educational background. Also about any mistake on compony website? Questions about Microsoft and Educational background. Also about any mistake on compony website?
First-round was 30 minute Microsoft Teams call. Interviewer showed up 15 minutes late and only left time for me to ask one question at the end. Behavioral and design questions.

Applied in May 2020 for new grad 2021 role. Received interview invitation in May. Did a HR interview phone call in May. Was informed in June that I am moving to final round. Did a final round interview in September which consisted of 3 back to back interview. Got offer in October. The role starts in February 2021
The process was Fair and to the point, Had a Technical Sales play and a sales interview to show my skills and let them know more about me and my skills and what can i add to the team.

Took about 1 month, 2 rounds of interviews. First a phone screening, followed by final  rounds with 3-4 interviewers. Interview was mostly behavioral and job fit questions. Using STAR method really helpful

Three rounds: (1) screening, (2) research interview, (3) problem-solving interview. 1 - simple codding puzzles and shared screen codding over Skype; 2 - overview of my current research with all follow-up questions; 3 - two problems, no codding - just explain the algorithm/approach.
The hiring process is too long. It took more than 2 months for me. Also they release offer after completion of background check. I received my offer after 40 days of concluding my interviews.

The interviewers were kind and interested and very personable. Quite a time-consuming process but valuable feedback. Went through multiple meetings before I was told my application process wouldn't go any further.
Applied online and got invation by email,four rounds 45mins video interview. Had a good discussion but got rejected.Had a good discussion but got rejected.Had a good discussion but got rejected.
It was a relaxed 30 minute interview with an employee based in America despite the placement being in Reading. It was with an interviewer who was very nice and considerate.

After a two phone interviews I was flown out to the Reno office where I had 4 interviews back to back. The conversations were pretty casual and were more about getting to know you rather than grilling your knowledge. They had questions relating to personal experiences and how you have learned or changed from them. It gave you an opportunity to gauge how different employees think and what the company culture was like.

Very good. High pace, relevant questions. Good company overview, exciting workplace, excellent benefits. Hope to hear soon. Flexible work hours and great facility for the employees to work in. Lots of support and development

Very smooth  The interviews will include competency-based questions, as well as questions about your resume. Keep the core competencies in mind. Think of examples you can share or incorporate into your conversation.

Four interview in a row with four others in a round robin style, for a new grad engineering position on Azure. There was one really hard one, one kinda hard one, and two that I thought were pretty fair.
I had 5 1-on-1 hour-long interviews. Each one was a series of whiteboard coding questions. Difficulty ranged from Very Easy to Hard. Overall it felt like a fair range of questions.

Had an initial phone screening. Followed by 3 in person interviews, which each lasted about 45 minutes. I was left alone for 15-20 minutes at a time time in between each interview in a small room. No one ever reached out to me following the interviews.
It was good. nice learning experience. had 2 rounds. 1 cp the other one more of generic round where some questions along with hr questions were there. round 3 got postponed cause of lack of time

Recruiter reached out about a hiring event. Applied for it,  got invited. The only confusing aspect was that i had no idea what team I was applying for, so it was kind of hard to research. They gave me an invite link the day before the interview and i joined without knowing who I would be speaking with from what team. Otherwise, the conversations were great, and the interview was entirely product/behavioural.
first step is code test sent to mail and short phone interview and then video interview of about 90 minutes.  Asked to implemment a pazzel, as for pieces and all the needed classes and functions.

Interviewed via the phone as the firs step and had two other follow up interviews.  They reached out again to see if I was interested in the position.

Interviewed via the phone as the firs step and had two other follow up interviews.  They reached out again to see if I was interested in the position.

The interview process was very straightforward. The interview process was very straightforward. First go through headhunter, then hiring manager, then someone in the peer level. All oral interviews... whole thing took only 2 weeks ....

I applied for an internship a long time ago and didn't get a response. Then out of the blue a year later a recruiter did a phone screen. Then I went to an onsite interview. There was a whole group of us.
Interview process was easy and quick. However, no feedback was given. Hence, this should be changed in order for talent to be attracted.  Otherwise, the company image will be tarnished.

Did online coding test to get past to the first interview. Got through to the interview - got asked questions about previous experience, explain programming concept to a child, design question. Said they would hear back in a week, but had to send a reminder e-mail and got rejection e-mail approx 3 weeks afterwards.

I apllied online mainly questions were from ds and algo. If you solve leetcode and hackerrank can easly pass the process.
I apllied online mainly questions were from ds and algo. If you solve leetcode and hackerrank can easly pass the process.
Brief whiteboarding session followed by explanation of the answer I put down. Very reasonable examination and didn't get a response after passing my first interview due to already full slots
I had one phone interview. If you get past that you have one morning of interviews in the Redmond office. It is 4 interviews that are about 45 minutes each.

I was an intern there. One of my boss gave the interview. He asked about my experience and then let me code in another platform. He muted himself while I was coding. I described my thoughts at first, which is a bfs and barpartite problem. He confirmed and I designed the api and start coding. While finished he reviewed my code and gave positive feedback.

Overall good interview. They make you feel rather useless as they interview you in blocks so they throw you in a Microsoft Teams call with 20+ other applicants. Questions were pretty much on par with Leetcode medium. The interview process included 45-minute sections with different interviewers. Most interviewers were involved and helpful but some definitely stared blankly and did not provide any help or comments.

I had a good experience with the human resources hunter, and with the future team colleagues and direct manager. there were kind and understanding about the whole process. I had questions about leadership, time management, operations, and customer experience handling
reached out from Linkedin for hiring event, total is OA + 4 rounds of vo. got the offer, but TC is not as expected so I rejected it. Interview progress feels comfortable,  people are nice.

The first round was chill, just behavioral questions with the recruiter. Then the next round was the final round which was also mainly behavioral interview questions with a 10 min presentation on any topic. Process took months and the communication with the recruiter was a little off so it was confusing at times.

Very professional, friendly and welcoming . The schedule was very clearly communicated beforehand. So no surprises. Interviewers are friendly and truly passionate about their work. The questions are moderately difficult.

first HR international interview then 2 technical interviews each interview on hour, first you talk about yourself, previous projects then one question on each interview, the questions help the interviewer to know how you think and how much you know

recruiter reached out to me and set me up with an initial phone screen
after i passed that i went to seattle for onsite 
nice people in the loop, shame i couldn't pass

Five interview loop. If you did bad in one they will ask you to do a six loop.
If you are aiming for the team it would be the managers or seniors in the team interviewing . If not then the it will be all random

I had to make a one-to-one screening call, and They used Hackerank for the coding part. The call had questions about my background and had a few technical questions about projects I did and some logic quizzes.

-Phone screening (via Teams around 45 minutes) mostly behavioral question and clarify the role of the position a candidate would like to apply for
-Interview (supposed to be onsite but on Teams instead due to covid) with 4 interviewers each around 45 minutes.
I only had one round of phone interview and another round of onsite interview. The phone interview was just a behavior round. The onsite interview included programming and mechanic aptitude test.
you get an email, you get a call, you get ghosted and then you don't get the job, overall not a very good experience. Perhaps it's too large of a company?

First Round interview was a 30 minute phone call discussing my skills and why I want to work at Microsoft. 
Final Round was a super day where I spoke with multiple people. Overall it was a mostly behavioral along with me speaking on my technical skills.

Received message from recruiter on LinkedIn to arrange a call. Followed by a brief call (around 15 mins) asking to formally apply.
Attended “hiring event” which consisted of back-to-back technical and management interview .

Had a technical screen with one member of the team I was interviewing for. He asked one question and we spent some time going over logical reasoning regarding solutions, and then code. Then I did a virtual onsite with five interviews, including an "as appropriate" interview with someone higher up. Most of the questions were easy/medium, and the interviewers varied from friendly to mildly angry. I was told afterward that my feedback was great, but the position had been filled, and I declined to look for other positions, as it was really just that one I wanted.

Had a phone screen for the first round. A 30-minute call with the recruiter who asked me some basic technical questions as well as behavioral ones.  Know your story well, and know why you want to work there.

1 Phone + 4 in person. The phone interview will be setup by person in contact. He will give his feedback too. Then for on campus they invite for a day. Though some of the engineers were uselessly difficult. However, the hospitality was good.

I did my phone screen ~a month after applying, and got invited to the final round the next day. The interview was chill and pleasant. They reuse questions in my case so do some google before interview.

It was okay. The interviewer was kind and tried calming me before the interview, trying to phrase questions in such a manner that it is easier to understand. I enjoyed the process but the problem itself was a bit difficult for me

Gone through three technical and one Director round.
Technical questions are moderate in difficulty and mostly based on malware research.
Director round contain questions like, why Microsoft? You may face very dumb questions here.
Hiring process of Microsoft is more pathetic then  startups. The hiring team will not contact or respond to your queries once, even if you get selected.
In my case, I got the confirmation email that I got selected for the role, but then never received any further call or offer letter.

Was asked to solve a maze in the fastest way. Solved via DFS.
Was asked to talk about myself, me experience and what I am looking for.
Had the ability to ask the interviewer about the team
I interviewed for a role  through my universities co-op program. This was a 45 minute interview with two senior team members that made the entire process comfortable, there were no surprises.

People oriented rather than oriented on skills. First round CVs, second round online interview, last round assessment day (normally in person, now digital). Assessment included a group assignment and personal assignment (presentation).
negative and first time worst experience with MS. In general MS interviews and process is always good and inspiring and benchmark. but seem a little unprofessional this time and predecided.

30 mins virtual 1st round interview. Interview was on microsoft team. It was about whether I fit Microsoft as a company so the questions were geared towards my background, and behavioural questions.  

Since there was only 30 mins, so the interviewer was rushing to ask all the questions she prepared to get signals. At the last 5 mins, there were Q&As sections.

Screen with recruiter, asked about experience level in BGP, OSPF, MPLS, ISIS, python, automated testing tools, scripting.  The screen asked:
 1--Do you have experience in the skill?
 2-- Is your experience educational or professional and how many years of each?
3-- Any examples/specifics you can give me on your experience in the skill set that will help me convince your hiring teams to move forward?

1 coding screening + Onsite (2 coding + 1 system design + 1 behavioral)
You can split the interview over a period of 2 days. The level of the interview is easy

Went through recruiter call and then 4 rounds of technical interview. All the coding question were of medium difficulty level. Basic data structure knowledge will be really helpful. Make sure you go through all the details of a data structure.
It was much easier and less technical than I expected. I was asked a lot of behavioral questions and the technical questions are very easy, not even leetcode easy questions.

Applied for a frontend position but was interviewed by a backend only developer and asked data structure questions. Only one of the questions pertained to the frontend which was odd since it was a frontend position and my background is frontend. The interview did not pertain to the skills listed on the job description. It was more focused on how recently the applicant has done leetcode problems rather than the skills in the job description.
Was that bad it was a phone call interview with non-technical questions. Involving with projects, personal challenges. They did provide a few sources for us to view before the interveiw

Contacted by a recruiter, phone call with recruiter, then interview with hiring manager and one other. Recruiter was communicative throughout. I got the questions before the interview to prepare. I was respected by all.

I was sent an invitation to a first-round interview and a link to a Codility challenge that I needed to complete before the interview date.

The Codility challenge included 3 problems that you could solve in your preferred language. I definitely suggest doing some leetcode exercises beforehand but the problems were overall very fair and I had no time issues.

The interview consisted of mostly behavioural questions and some Microsoft related questions.
In the very end, I had 5 minutes to solve a little thinking puzzle.

Overall the process was very transparent and the recruiter was very friendly.

I was invited to a final interview round which I have not yet completed but will consist of 4 interviews with different coding challenges.

First-round phone screening, HR Phone interview, 30 minutes,  ask questions about your experience, behavior questions, your preferred programming languages, no coding required. At last, I asked 2 questions, then the interview ended.

First, an on campus interview with a business operations / analytics manager, in person interview with lots of engineering managers.

Second, onsite interview with engineering and program managers. The team i was interviewing for seemed super engineering oriented (their product is kinda like a microsoft engineering consultancy) so I had more engineering/cs questions that the average interview

Pretty good, 4 45-minute interviews and they all included design exercises. The only thing I have a complaint about is that my recruiter didn't tell me ahead of time which org I'd be interviewing with so that came as a surprise

Interview process involved an initial pre screening with basic questions from cryptography, penetration testing and threat modelling followed by a series of virtual interviews on teams which they call as interview loop. There were 4 interviews in this stage with team members, hiring manager and director, all with very positive attitude, making me want to work in this team.

2 stage.
1st stage:
30 min interview
Adked to code height of binary tree. 
Complexity, test cases
2 nd stage:

2 hour
1st hour
Behavioral + tech
Asked about projects in my resume,  challenges, contribution, team work.
Tech: asked to design and code a game giving the demo, grid coloring game.

Behavioral + tech

Tech:reverse a string backward word by word, not letter by letter., test cases etc

Coding round followed by written test followed by interview. Coding round was easy able to do all the questions. Despite doing all questions in coding round and clearing written test they rejected in the interview after 3 rounds. It looks like the interview process is completely random and they were hiring good looking people.

Just the normal interview process conducted online due to Covid-19. 
Before the interview, you are required to provide some writing samples and a brief introduction of the project you did before.
Phone screen
Interview
Very casual, a simple video call. They asked personality questions and asked about your contribution to team projects in the past. They were very nice through the three round interview
Super day can be long and they will ask you a bunch of questions back to back. It is a whole day-long process and they usually will fly you out to their headquarters.

Casual chat with a grad at our university recruiting fair. 30min on-campus interview with a veteran engineer where he asked about my interests and then we solved a small problem. On-site interview was an entire morning, 4 interviews back-to-back. Did one coding question per interview with little time for soft questions. Last interviewer was a manager who had more time and had questions tailored to product management and my prior curricular/internship experience.

Phone screen and then full day in office interviewing with six or so interviewers. Mostly technical algorithm generation and coding in whatever language you want. Lunch with both hiring manager and his manager.
The interview went well - I did the phone screen and they asked me the questions I mentioned, and the technical wasn't so bad. 3 interviews all 45 minutes long.

Solved question correctly, rejected 2 weeks later. Not sure what went wrong, but it is possible that they just simply had too many applicants and didn't make it through. Could have been a better experience if there was more communication throughout the process.

I submitted an application online after emailing a researcher at Microsoft about an internship. The application included two reference letters. I went through three rounds of 30-minute interviews talking about my research and the potential intern projects they'll have this summer. The interviewers were all very nice, the conversations were really enjoyable, and there weren't any algorithms/data structures programming questions. Instead, the questions focused on how I would solve different research problems. A recruiter reached out to me with an offer around a week and a half after interviewing.

I interviewed with three people they were all very professional except one gentleman was rude and condescending. I respect Microsoft and have supported the products and certifications for years but this was not a positive experience. I would not interview with them again if this is the culture. professional except one gentleman was rude and condescending. Total 5 interview sessions. 

The first interview process started with hiring manager, followed by 2 peer business group managers and then skip level BU lead. 

HR held the final interview.

I had applied for a Support enginee role in the Exchange/Office 365 domain. The interview was core technical and very detailed. They mainly focus on the basic concepts and if you have them you should be good.
I had a phone interview first. it's mostly about your previous work and automation skills, verifying if you are a right candidate. Then, I was brought to the on-site interview.

Typical screen with behavioral questions that align with your background but extremely long process and lack of clear timeline. Need to wait to be placed in final round interviews. Good communication with recruiter.

Very fast and seamless interview process. The whole process took less than two weeks. There was an intial phone screening which was followed by two technical and two managerial interviews. All interviewers were very friendly and open.

First phone interview for screening. 
Had to solve a puzzle and explain the solution verbally. Not that hard to solve with a paper in front of you. 

Second interview was on sight. 3 whiteboard coding interviews with 3 different engineering managers.

Phone interview, in-person interview after that. The in-person interview and that has probably changed with COVID. Phone interview was 30 minutes. The interviewer was very kind and understanding. Asked very typical behavioral questions.

Two interviewer ask me to complete two coding questions then lead me to optimalize it. There are two interviews and any of them lasts one hour. Also the interviews include self introductions and few questions about cv

Applied with referral. Recruiter reached out for phone screen. Completed phone screen then digital onsite with two interviews. Onsite interviews had a combination of technical and personal questions. Positive experience.
Standard interview process. I was rejected initially but then a spot opened up in another team and I did a quick interview. Ended up getting an offer and I accepted.

Applied online First on campus first round, through school. Was 1:1. They flew  me out for the final round. I had three interview rounds and each had a mix of PM/SWE questions that were asked. Overall, it was a solid interview process.

It was good and the interview went smoothly. I felt stressed in the beginning but through the interview, I felt comfortable.
The questions were:
What is your salary expectation?
what are your strengths and weaknesses?
I had to go through some assignments.

One on site school interview and a final interview in Seattle. The school one was 1 45 min interview. The Seattle was 3 45 min interviews with different people. I also had to give a 10 min presentation.
It was a good interview for me, and they do ask what you have provided in the resume, and they will not make you hurry, it was a neat and peaceful interview.

1- first "phase" technical interview (aprox 30')
2- three interviews in one afternoon, 45' each, 15 minutes rest in between with coffee and food

The problems were average/easy but the questions made by interviewers and "next step" in the problems where interesting and made a lot of sense.

The intreview was held online through Teams due to COVID-19. 

The first interview was a short 20 minutes screening call with a senior PM in the team.

The next steps were classic PM interviews (3 interviews).

Really easy and chill. Phone call followed by two onsite interviews.  Phone interview is super trivial, hardest part is probably getting selected for it.  The onsite interviews are lit because they give you a sick food allowance to get room service at the hotel, so you can grab a handle and get busy with the other interviewees over a steak dinner

A recruiter reached out on LinkedIn and sent all details about the position and the interview process, including a link for a coding challenge on codility that should be finished in the next 72 hours.

Was sent a Codility test, after maxing it out was invited for 4 interviews, 45 minutes each. Questions ranged from behavioral, concurrency related stuff, classic algorithmic problems, system design. I interviewed remotely.

Gutes professionelles Gespräch 
Wertschätzung der Bewerbung gezeigt 
Einblick in Strukturen bekommen 
HR Team sehr nett 
Hat Lust gemacht, das Unternehmen kennen zu lernen 
Viele Fragen zur Motivation und Erfahrung

Applied through a recruiter, the process took about 6 weeks. My interview was pushed back, it would have been a 4 weeks process. I had the same interview the previous year but there were not a lot of interview spots left for final rounds so decided to try again.
Given a binary tree and a number, return true if the tree has a root-to-leaf path such that adding up all the values along the path equals the given number. Return false if no such path can be found

The process started with phone interviews about portfolio questions and past experiences, really the standardized procedures. The process was smooth and HR followed up really fast. The onboarding process was easy to manage.

No coding challenge. Had to do two technical questions back to back, one on binary trees and how to create and check for balance, and another on reversing a sentence string. the second was straight from leetcode

HR check
1st step: Technical interview
2ns step: (waited for a looooong time)
3rd step: Onsite: 4 technical interviews (no system design)
all 4 were algorithmic + behavioural; aprox 10-15 minutes at the beginning behavavioural questions, then a problem, then more questions if you have time;

Nothing much general SDE questions  based on DP, graphs HashMaps, heaps. It was followed by an HR round in which they asked behavioural questions like why do you want to be in this company, and why should we hire you

Meet with hiring manager, then select partners, then perhaps a senior leader. Each person responsible for evaluating a specific competency.  Questions are behavioral interview based, and those who are skilled really just make it seem like a conversation.

A recruiter reached out to me and I got scheduled for a technical interview. The interview was done online using codility and I was asked to solve a coding question. The interviewer was very kind during the interview.
First round is getting to know you and the process is quite good. Recruiters are well aware of your preferences and they are willing to help you become better.  Good experience

Had 5 virtual interviews (due to COVID). I met with the hiring manager, two members of their team, someone from a parallel department, and the manager's manager. Most questions were behavioral, asking about difficult experiences, collaboration, adaptability, and how I would structure content. Everyone was friendly,  and it was fairly straightforward.

Single first round interview with one person, followed by two second round interviews both with two people, all of which done via Microsoft Teams. Was asked to give two presentations and submit to a Q&A on both, answer scenario based questions, and questioned on knowledge of the technology. Had two technical intervirews and a line management interview.

I’ve interviewed twice with microsoft in the past 2 years and both experiences were woeful. The recruitment team were great but the next stage of meeting the Hiring Manager was lacklustre. Each time the HM was disinterested and had an air of “I got the job at Microsoft so therefore I am superior”....  the last interviewer didn’t even know when I was asking a question and would just nod. Or cut me off half way for another question. These interviewers are the same people the market has to deal with. Clients, partners and sub contractors see, feel and hear this same arrogance in commercial conversations with Microsoft and roll our eyes swapping narratives. I wouldn’t apply again based on recruitment experience and the poor feedback I get from the market. Wake up, guys - there are other cloud and platform providers dominating the market that treat people a lot better than you.
The interview mainly was on a coding problem, the problem was somewhat difficult for the given time frame, but not impossible to complete. Overall the process was smooth and went well.
Very challenging but the interviewer was very nice. The questions were a bit tricky but seemed fair at the end of the day. Great company so I didn’t expect any less

45 minute on campus interview followed by a round-robin on-site interview, with everything payed for and even opportunities to explore the city. You should be very familiar with computer architecture, low-level software, computer systems, digital design, and design verification. Also, be prepared for behavioral questions and questions about your resume.

1. Submit application
2. Take phone interview
3. On site interview (5 rounds)

One of the worst recruitment experiences I've ever had.

The story:

A global talent recruiter reached out to me on LinkedIn and wanted to put in time to discuss Microsoft's consulting ambitions. "Sure", I said, and we had a call. This initial chat was actually quite pleasant. The recruiter, however, was based in a different country. This meant he would need to pass me to a local recruiter if I were interested in proceeding. I said this was fine, and off we went.

This is where it all starts going awry.

We schedule a call for the new year given that there wasn't much time left in the year. The recruiter proposed a few options and I selected one.

The time comes for the call and the recruiter is nowhere to be seen. I email him. I get an OOO message as a response. I love plot twists, but this one seemed a lot like some pretty lazy writing.

The next day he apologises and we reschedule.

The day of the call comes, and we chat. He tells me about the role and I ask a few probing questions to make sure it sounds right to me. At the end of the call, we agree that the next steps are for him to send me some more details on the role and I will respond with my full resume (he had already looked at my LinkedIn).

After the call, he sends an email (at 9:00pm - Microsoft certainly seems to have some strange working hours these days) with some more details about the role. I respond that it sounds good and I'm comfortable to proceed. I attach my resume.
No response.

A few days later I follow up to see whether there's anything to be done.
No response.

A week later, I follow up to ask whether this is still going ahead.
No response.

At this point, it has been two weeks following the last contact with the recruiter. I can only assume that one of the following is true:
- he learnt all of his communication skills from Tinder and has become a professional ghoster;
- the fate of the world hinges on my not getting this job; or
- he's just a terrible recruiter.

Not sure which.

-Second call was less why did you apply or why are you qualified and more, what do you bring to the role as well as them sending me a technical product powerpoint to review and then discussing the product I'd be managing on the call (the powerpoint doesn't include an actual product but an example, and then they want you to take that example product and talk about lifecycles, managing teams, customer relations, etc)
-Third call was with managers

-Got an offer

The program leverages the expertise of APN Partners and AWS best practices to create repeatable and scalable migration models.

The interview was ok. Mostly about my resume and mutual. The interviewer was nice and friendly. He also described the works they were doing and showed interest in proceeding. However the second level interviewer did not follow up.

got an interview when attending a conference but I was not prepared for the interview question so I did not pass the first round interview. Make sure you prepare for the technical interview so apply when you feel ready to nail the technical interview

4 rounds of interviews, each 1 hour long, no test, just talking about previous experiences. Motivational part was the biggest grilling, I guess they were looking for the most passionate person towards data management.

They asked me about projects I had done and what was difficult about them. And then algorithmic questions. After I suggested a solution they gave me a few minutes alone to write the code that implements it.
I knew the solution but after two days I received an email that I was rejected.

The interview process was smooth. The first round manager asked me questions mostly from my resume and some security related basic questions and they said the second level manager would contact me and did not get back after sending multiple follow up emails.

Got selected for the phone screen which went well, got selected for the interview loop, but because I was not exactly an industry hire, got dropped from the process. I was still completing my graduate studies at the time and was set to graduate and in my mind, I was looking for a full time opportunity. But unfortunately, I could not move forward as they were looking for someone with more experience.

Very standardized process in which: 1) someone that does not know anything about the position calls you and in 30 min asks you a bunch of stuff including some brainer exercise; 2) you have another call to know how awesome ms is; 3) you have 5 interviews in a row (in place or online during COVID) where they ask you basic but detailed stuff coming from the bachelor, even if you are a Master or a PhD. The manager does not even listen to you (confirmed by other two intervieeved)

It was multiple one on one interviews.   Only one of the interviewers had one of the famous "microsoft questions"; which I found kind of interesting.  It took me a minute to figure it out.  Apparently, he was more interested in how I went about figuring it out than the answer itself.
Fui a sus oficinas y en un grupo de 4 personas me presentaron con un problema cada uno. Estuvo cordial pero no son flexibles en cuanto a como se explica o el tiempo que le dan a cada problema.

Interview was aligned by a recruiter, process took 3 weeks. Cleared 3 rounds, interviewers were friendly, understanding however there was a fitment issue.  Post interviews, there was radio silence from recruitment team. Post checking with them there was very terse response on not being selected with no feedback.

The guy was late for the interview and then we was hurrying me up to do things, terrible interview experience. I did not have time to ask question or to even finish my reasoning because he was late to the next interview.

Good interview process. 

After applying to the college recruiter it started with a link to a Codility challenge. There were three problems that weren't too difficult.  Second round was a 30 minute phone call with a recruiter where I was asked behavioral questions and one programming question to check if a linked list had a loop in it. 

Final round was four 45 minute interviews with four different interviewers all happening with 15 minute breaks between each one. Initial questions asked weren't too difficult but then they would add constraints to the original problem e.g. solve it this time without using any arrays or other storage.

Recruiter got back quickly saying they wouldn't be moving forward.

The first-round includes some data wrangling questions and a stat question. All coding requires lots of comments on why you did what. I finished both questions but they still said that there's a bug with my code even though it passes all the test and that they don't undetstand why I calculate my stat question even though I explain the whole reasons behind the calculation. Vague feedback.
phone interview and code test,  as a home assignment, later there was a video interview with a local worker. It was a technical interview with leetcode style questions, medium level.
Was contacted on Linkedin by an external recruiter and the process took less than a month. I was invited to the first round of interviews for a position in Oslo

the interviewer asked basic questions about stat, ML, and coding problems, also details on the projects listed in resume

not a hard interview itself, but didn't receive many feedbacks from the interviewer

I had a set of 4 interviews each lasting 45 minutes with 15 minutes breaks in between . It was both technical and soft skills (people management skills)
The technical part was more on system design and DSA.

I interviewed with Microsoft in India, the process was about 4 weeks long- in the last round I was supposed to speak to Service Practice Director, a lady based out of Microsoft Mumbai!

First off, this was 5th round, I was cleared with phenomenally positive feedback in all past rounds.

The lady to start with did not even show up in the interview! After waiting 10 minutes, recruiting coordinator calls and says can we reschedule to next day? I agree.

Next day, for what was suppossed to be a 45 minutes discussion, this director lady joins the call- no response to my courtesies- asks me 1 question: explain what your usual day looks like! And thats it... in 15 minutes just wraps up the interview!! It was almost like she joined for the sake of it, and dropped off. 
She didnt even acknowledge any of my courtesies at the start or end of the call, it was beyond insulting!

It was almost like she was least interested, and extremely rude, I wad beyond aghast, not to mention extremely dissappointed, because 4 weeks of my effort went down the drain in like 15 minutes, just because this woman is least interested!

While the recruiter herself hasn’t been in touch for the entire 4 weeks process, I dont even know who to share this with? The recruiter hasnt been even responding to emails throughout the process, only the interview scheduler used to call, and that scheduling coordinator also isnt picking up the phone now!

So senior level professionals, especially in India, who invest their time and efforts into Microsoft beware, this is how uncouth and unprofessional their management is!

30 Min skype call, mostly behavioural questions.
 3 Codility Tasks, tasks are challenging and have many possible solutions. Overall was a good experience,  learnt alot  a aa a a a a a a a a

The interview process consisted of 1 phone interview which followed, several week later with 3 in person interviews, however these were conducted view Microsoft teams video chat due to the current pandemic

1 written + 3 technical interview
Questions related to data structure and algorithm+ resume + projects.
Intro+ questions related to work experience then asked 3 coding questions was code. He wanted the full code to be written on an editor.

Reached out to by recruiter, was not told what the role was.
Had a brief introductory phone interview with another recruiter. 
Super-day scheduled within a week.
Whole process was about a month.

Very positive and smooth process. Interviewers asked brilliant questions. Although highly competitive, very positive experience. Very respectful interview styles of the interviewers. Three to four interview series (rounds). Very diverse re. interviewer profiles and roles.

I had different 9 interviews that lasted over a number of months for a contract role.  Most people asked the same types of questions. The process could have been cut in half had they spoke to each other.

The process was long and arduous but everyone was kind.  There are quite a few rounds of interviews. The questions were difficult but expected.  If you want to prepare for an interview algorithms and data structures are paramount.  Practice tasks at leetcode.com
Had 1 Phone Screener and a virtual Final Round that acted like a super day. Overall experience was good and interviewers were great. The whole process took a few months

One of the worse interview I have ever experienced. Here are some red flags.
The interviewer was full of ego and totally ignore my self introductions. I literally saw the interviewer type her email.

The interviewer was so direct while being rude as she condemned me of being “not sharp” and she said she was lost half way the interview.

From the interview experience, I believe that Microsoft culture is quite toxic. I am glad that I did not get the offer.
Be careful y’all.

The process consisted of various  one on one interviews such that you are given the space to showcase who you are as an individual and your professional skills that demonstrate you are fitted for the job.

Interviews themselves were fine but working with recruiting was a nightmare. No clear recruiter you work with, often the FTE recruiter on the chain would never even acknowledge receipt of an email, vendor recruiters turned over constantly, communication after the loop was non-existent.

reasonable process. knowledgable employees. The interviewer was very kind. I had some trouble answering questions. I should study more and be ready next time. Dont be scared to do an interview based on my review

Asked  a lot of questions, including: tell me about yourself, go through the resume, why Microsoft, why this position, view  on the industry, live case analysis (cooperated with the interviewer), etc.

Was over ms teams, the interviewers didn't have answers to my questions related to the role, but was a quick behavioural interview. Overall neutral experience, wish there was more communication though

Some questions and OA, followed by a technical interview over the phone.    Asked about algos and data strcutures, roughly 30 minutes per round.  Then there were some screening questions.  I did not make it past that

Went onsite and talked to some low level PMs about their work.  Was left guessing about what the context and content was about the role they were hiring for as they seemed to be waiting for me to pitch a STAR story FANGstyle tailored to the role that was not described.

It seemed like this was gatekeeping for someone who was not me.  I've had principal offers at MS before.

The principal interview was interesting as all people who've been at the firm for twenty years are.  They were the only one that was at all engaging.  It was unclear what they were looking for in our chat, but that was expected from suave executives who deal with skip and LCA continually.
Fairly easy questions, some question regarding ethics, agile team environment etc. questions regarding azure knowledge base. Be confident and you will do great in the interview. Be prepared for it

I had an interview with the recruiter who explained about the general process and in the second round  (next week) with the senior principal researcher in cambridge, united kingdom. He asked about the research and development experience that I have done.

submit my resume without a referral
hr reach out a week later
30 min phone interview at the end of November
I felt okay and interviewer says the result will come out 3-5weeks
but I did not hear back. I think I was rejected but do not no why

Online codility test and then an interview of HR behavioural questions. Brainteaser was a bit unexpected and had 5 min to complete. 
Recruiter was super friendly and overall was a very pleasant experience!!

Primero debes subir tu CV a la plataforma de Microsoft Careers, se ponen en contacto contigo y después te agendan una entrevista, esta entrevista es de código. Se enfoca en resolver un problema de programación utilizando cualquier lenguaje de programación
professional, very helpful human resources team, enjoyed everything about it - great company. i am sad i did not get accepted but what can you do. better luck next time.
I was referred by a friend. Had the HR call me and explain about the process, then had 2 professional interviews with senior group members and then with the group manager

The company comes to my institute for the campus drive. The campus drive includes online coding round, followed by 2 technical rounds, followed by HR round. Clearing all the rounds gets you the offer from the company.

The process consists of 5 rounds. 

The first round was codility test and the phone interview with the recruiter. The recruiter was asking behavioral questions and codility test consisted of three coding tasks.

The other 3 rounds were more focused on technical questions but there were also behavioral questions.

The last interview was behavioral.

The recruiter reached out and scheduled an interview. During the interview, I answered one programmer problem. I was asked if my solution could be optimized and how I would go about it.  The interviewer asked about my background and I asked how soon they would get back to me.

Due colloqui, uni singolo l'altro con due intervistatori. Tra il primo e il secondo una HR ci ha aiutati a prepararci. Il secondo era poi tecnico, ma non troppo. Non mi sono candidata per una posizione specifica ma loro mi hanno guidata
Dopo aver inviato la candidatura online, sono stata chiamata per un colloquio tecnico con un consulente tecnico e per un colloquio con il manager sia su contenuti tecnici che conoscitivo.

The assessment center consisted of 3 parts: 
1) Pre-prepared presentation 
2) 45 minutes scenario-based interview 
3) Team exercise (they evaluate candidates on the grounds of teamwork, so you may almost ignore the task itself)

One phone interview, one super-day with three separate, consecutive interviews. Lasted about 3 hours. Basic behavioral questions. Need to know about industry and what’s happening in the space. Very important to know about Microsoft products.

The interview process took about a month. I applied online and received an offer for a phone screen within a week. I had 4hrs worth of final round interviews, and at least 3 other phone screens or video calls. The team was very friendly and engaging throughout the interview process.

At the end, I did not received a phone call or even a formal rejection email, just a response to my follow up email from the recruiter. Pretty disappointed in having dedicated roughly 6-8hrs of interview time to get such an impersonal response.

The interview had 2 rounds. Both were coding based and simple. If you have practiced top 50 interview problems on leetcode then you'll crack it. The interviewers were friendly and always helped when the candidate needed.

The  interview was  in 2 parts:
1. Coding test at home in Codility-contains 3 questions in intro computer science style. 1 easy question and 2 hard questions
2. personal interview through skype in English

First round DS Algo. They scheduled zoom call. Diagonal level sum took me 30 minutes to build algo and code. Second question was difficult as he asked me design optimal strategy to reach to hagman solution.

The interview process was very organized and the interviewers were pleasant. I think there was a mismatch of the role itself and my experience which affected the outcome. I guess there should be better matches done.

I applied through their portal for the MBA Aspire Program (Technical Consulting and Client Success). I was invited for a 30min Skype Interview. The interview went well to my knowledge but obviously, the interviewer had a different opinion.

4 back to back interviews (Microsoft Teams).
The 3 of them were mixed (behavioral & technical) and the 4th was behavioral only.
Interviewers were very friendly and provided help when required.
Overall very positive experience!

1 phone interview with HR. 2 1 hour interviews with experienced engineers. I found it casual and non-threatening. Interviewers had a combined 20 years at Microsoft and really worked to promote their teams.

Had 4 rounds of interviews with a particular team (did not get to choose the team) and each lasted for one hour.

There was some kind of connection problem so it took about 5 minutes to solve. The first interviewer gave a small introduction and started with two behavior questions. He was very interested in getting to know my answer, so he asked a lot of follow-up questions before finally gave the coding question.

The second interviewer started with the coding question and we had about 5 minutes for behavior.

The third interviewer was pretty chill compared to the first two. We went through behavior questions like chit chat and then a coding question.

The fourth interviewer is the director of the team. He was interested in knowing why I was interviewing with the team, which I actually did not have a choice. There are other teams I would love to join, so I hope in the future, the coordination between HRs and Engineering Teams could be better.

Made it to first-round interview for PM intern. The interviewer, unfortunately, sounded like he could not care less throughout the entire call. He just wanted to ask the mandatory questions and get out ASAP. Tried my best to get a conversation flowing but he refused to budge and just wanted to move on to the next. The main design question was pretty weird considering it was more architectural than software of tech.

First round
->  Phone / video interview -> Palindrome. Still waiting on results for the next round. It was more of a collaborative experience. It didn't feel at all intimidating as I expected. I felt extremely nervous initially but as we went on I was calm nerves and then went on to solve problem.
The interview comprises of four stages. 2 of the stages are with the hiring managers which were done online via teams. Sample questions include: Explain why you would be great at this role?

Robust, thorough and daunting.  Interview panel consisted of four people (Sr Director and higher) held virtually over a four hour timeframe.  Scheduling took approximately 30 days from time of application submission.

Zoom interviews.
First interview with a team leader and a team member.
Was asked to describe a feature i worked on, and how to solve different issues that may occure.
Second interview with a team leader about home assignment..

Worst process ever.  Asked talent recruiter what the position entails and where.  Weak answers!  Also asked if I could speak to the hiring manager.  Answer was no, as the hiring manager will be the first interview in the “loop”.   Also had to put together a 30 min technical presentation for the technical interview. That person will tell you.

1- Hiring manager never showed
2- Technical interview happened unknown to me until the last interview when I asked the question is this where you’d like to see the presentation?
3- As I was trying to get feedback the recruiter blocked my email address based on the Microsoft outlook diagnostics code.
4- The Microsoft job portal still shows “good luck on your interviews”. That was Dec 11th 2020 it’s now Feb 7th 2021

Microsoft I expect better from you guys

The interview process was really great. You could tell Microsoft really wants you to succeed and all my interviewers were amazing. They were very understanding about some technical difficulties I had.

Had 4 rounds of technical interviews, all required coding. One was a bit higher level design but I still had to pseudo code. 

The interviewers vary, luck of the draw. First guy looked bored and lacked energy. The next guy was was arrogan and when offering help it seemed more like he just wanted to get the interview over. The question was also very hard.  The next two interviewers were more laid back and friendly. I enjoyed the last 2 sessions the most. 

All male interviewers

All male interviewers.

Microsfot Interview Process
Round 1: Problem Solving Algos and DS
Round 2: Low level design Round
Round 3: Problem Solving Algos and DS - called Fly no Fly Round
Round 4: Hiring Manager Round

the interview started with general background about my studies and experience, after that part the interviewer started asking technical questions about software design and data structures. that was the entire process

Final Round:
I had a very difficult interviewer (I don't think most will be like mine)

Had an interview with a recruiter first, then went to final rounds where I had two rounds of behavioral and coding questions.

First I had a 30 minute phone call with a very young and nice recruiter, he only asked behavioral questions. Then I was called for the second and final interview round where I met with two interviewers one hour each, they asked behavioral and technical questions.

Phone screened with hiring manager, spoke with the recruiter, and then did an interview loop with 4 people. Overall much of the conversation was very relaxed just discussing projects and how I had managed everything from proposal to common challenges, and deployment. Was not very technical for the most part.
The first stage was a one hour phone call with a current data scientist. The second stage was a three hour interview with four current data scientists. This second stage was the final stage.

After getting a referral from one of my friends, first, I solved an online test including three problems which require general knowledge of algorithms. Then, I had an online interview where a system design question was asked.

El proceso lo llevaban desde Londres. Primero hubo un filtro telefónico y posteriormente una entrevista de una hora por Teams. Durante la entrevista revisamos la trayectoria y el curriculum y luego comenzó a hacer entrevistas por competencias/ incidentes críticos/STAR. La siguiente entrevista era con el responsable de la posición mas general.

I received an email referring me to a Codility test, and to schedule a skype interview. 
Afterward, I got an email says they are no longer not considering candidates for their graduate opportunities, even though I did well.

Recruited through university campus placement process. The first round was competitive coding over a third party platform, very simple questions, on the easier side of leetcode medium. There were two interview rounds in total, but some of my peers had three. The decision was given by the end of the day.

Very good - Quick and clear steps - Requirements were clearly explained, the general atmosphere of the interviews was great - It was a very positive experience and it was especially really constructive.

The questions were mostly from Machine Learning and Statistics. The interviewer picked up a clustering algorithm and then went really deep into this topic. I was expecting some deep learning questions but they weren't asked.

The process consisted of 3 rounds of interviews each focusing on different skills. The first round tested programming and problem solving skills, followed by a design problem round and finally another technical round evaluating programming concepts.

1 round phone took 1 hour and 4 rounds back-to-back in total about 5 hours. No online code assessment. Coding questions were directly asked during interviews. Several behavior questions. All interviews were virtual.

Phone interview with 3 more in person interview (in zoom). Very harsh comments. Last interview was with 6 ppl in one zoom meeting. For last interview, u do presentation then U get time to do one-on-ones.

It was a video interview. The interviewer did not turn on his camera but asked me to open mine.

The worst part was that the interviewer did not even have a copy of my resume even though I have attached it in my application.

It was great. I had 2 in-person interviews, both had whiteboarding (writing code) but one of them was less technical than the other. I highly suggest using leetcode as practice. I practiced easy and medium questions.
Interview 3 turns and each turn an algorithm program challenge. If one fails a turn, he will be passed. I think only people who pass all 3 turns get the offer.

First of all, they have an online test
After that, if the test has been passed, you will be called for an interview
And then, if you pass the interview you will get the job
I was contacted about setting up an interview. Was asked questions ranging from experience to behaviors in certain situations. The interview lasted around 45 minutes. This was done through webcam.

This was the interview process:
Online Application 
HR Interview (Skype Connection) - 30-minute call with HR
Assessment Day (2 weeks after the HR call if you're successful)
Manager Interview

In the HR interview, it is a 30-minute video call where they will ask for logistics/housekeeping questions such as the right to work, when to start, etc.  The questions below was from the HR call.

After being contacted by a third party recruiter through LinkedIn, my resume was submitted for a few positions. I received a notification that my resume was pushed through to the hiring manager and they wanted to schedule an interview with me. Everything moved along very quickly, which was great!
The first interview took roughly 30 minutes and the interviewer asked very relevant questions about my experience and did not focus on traditional "basic" questions which helped with a more organic conversation. Overall, it was a great experience while still being challenging!

Setting up the first round interview was quick, and the interview went well. Interviewer was nice enough to provide helpful hints on the posed coding question. Interviewer also asked questions about my resumé and recent projects.

There was one phone interview before the three final round interviews in person. Sat down with members of the team as well as the hiring manager. It was a super day, and I got to meet a lot of other people interviewing for the same position. Questions were structured, but it was still a very relaxed competition.

Several Interviews from RH / Profile match to several tehnical interviews.
The Process included an interview with roleplay to simulate cx engagement.
Long feedback loop between interviews wich adds a lot of anxiety
Pretty painless for a explore internship interview. I had 3 45-minute interviews back to back. One interview had a technical question, the other two were mostly behavioral.  Overall great experience.
There was a coding question at the start of the virtual interview. This was followed by a very short 5 minute behavioral interview section.  The interview was only thirty minutes long.
Overall it is very good, the interview experience is nice . The interviewee was treated fairly and the discussion went smoothly. The interview is highly intensive with limited break time.

They had requested some repetitive informational inputs after I had already submitted my resume.  Behavioral interview included questions like, what was my hardest challenge and how did I overcome it.

It consisted of applying online, phone interview, then 4 back to back virtual interviews. The phone interview was a mix of technical and behavior questions while the virtual interviews were product design. sense, and behavioral questions.

Candidature envoyée en Septembre - Retour à la mi Octobre du Senior recruiting manager Nick Procter -
Tres bonne expérience un entretien de 30 min.

Questions de motivation, sur mes expériences, ma capacité à comprendre le produit (Cloud Azure) et à le vendre.

Un retour la semaine d’après, malgré recale aux entretiens, un feedback complet sur mon entretien, des conseils et vœux de réussite chaleureux. 

Process en anglais. Sur Teams.

The timeline was not as quick as I had anticipated. Had a phone interview with 3 coding questions and a few behavioral questions. Then moved forward with final rounds. Final round was four 45 minute interviews with a mix of technical and behavioral questions.
The first step of interview process was an online test on platform like codility. It covers a basic algorithm and data structure problems. Next step is tehnical interview, but i wasnt invited.

Technical With a DS aquestion and resume related questions
Then 4 onsite rounds all DS related and few design questions
I was also asked some behavioral and cultural questions which is pretty common these days

I am a Masters student and applied to a few roles in Microsoft (project management, operations and sales). I received an e-mail around 3 weeks later, which stated that a Microsoft recruiter took interest in my application and would like to invite me to a first-round 30-minute interview. The role which I would be interviewing for was not mentioned, and neither was the location. This was a little odd to me, as my classmates who went through the same process had first-round interviews that lasted 2 hours long and the location and role they were interviewing for were made crystal clear to them before their interview. I chalked it off to a procedural change due to COVID, since my interview was remote but theirs were on-site. 

The interviewer I had was late to the interview, was highly distracted and paused the interview on a few occasions to reply to work e-mails for at least 2 minutes each time. All part of remote work, I thought to myself, and tried to show my understanding and empathy. The interview thus lasted way less than 30 minutes. We did not get to go through my resume completely, even though I have 3 years of PM experience, 3 years of Operations experience as a Manager and 2 years of Sales experience, all in tech companies. I was not asked any behavioural or technical questions either. Not even asked about what I know about Microsoft and what the responsibilities of those roles entailed and how I saw myself fitting into those roles (I have previously chatted with several Microsoft staff to understand what those roles required). Received an e-mail from another recruiter (not my original one) 5 weeks later saying that I would not be made an offer.

Started with telephonic interview , followed my manager's round. Most of the questions were scenario based. Overall challenging and interviewer was overall very good in making me comforatble . Waiting for the next round of the interviews

Applied online and a month later got an email asking to schedule an interview. I responded and then didn’t hear back from the recruiter until following up again. We scheduled a time for the next day. The recruiter was late to the call, but was able to talk a little bit past the scheduled end time. He walked me through the timeline for next steps and then completely ghosted me.  I sent a couple of emails, a thank you, a follow up a week after, and then a final email a week after that basically assuming they'd gone another way with the role but that I'd love to keep in touch. Bummed because I thought it went well and seemed like a good fit, but it is what it is.

Edit (30 Nov)- Recruiter did end up calling, saying they extended an offer to another candidate. I appreciated them closing the loop, but would have appreciated an earlier response to my emails.

I applied in mid-August 2020 and was contacted at the end of September for an interview. It was very simple, just asking about my background. Then, I was contacted at the end of October for my final round, which was 3 virtual interviews back to back. The morning of, one interview was canceled, but I continued with the two other scheduled interviews (with different PMs on Azure teams). The first one was behavioral, asking about experiences on my resume. The second one was a case, where I was asked questions about how I would make an app better (I chose to talk about Yelp). Two weeks after this "final round", I scheduled my final interview, which was a simple case study about elevators. I received my full time offer in mid-November.
There were 2 interviews, one of them is the Human Resources interview, other one is the technical interview. Both of them were okay to pass. They were kind, and helpful

Over the phone - coding module; If passed, you will go through another over the phone coding module. If successful, you will be invited for In person interviews at the Microsoft HQ in Seattle which consist of at least 3 separate interviews

Got contacted per email, behavioural interview  was set up per Skype. The interviewer was very nice and calm. She didn't really look at me while I was talking because she was writing stuff down, but it was mostly OK.
Very encouraging interviewer and mostly behavioral questions with a few data structures and PM questions. One of the main focuses was to know how to explain everything on your resume.

Il colloquio è iniziato con la solita presentazione, descrizione del percorso di studi, progetti accademici e esperienze. Alla fine sono state fatte domande più generiche, atte a saggiare l’interesse del l nel settore della tecnologia.

I was questioned on Skype and I was asked questions about my work ethics and what I've studied in my uni.
Also I was questioned about what do I know about Microsoft, and on what projects I worked before.

Behavioral  interview with an HR guy, the first after completing the docility code test. 
 just be yourself,  normal questions about yourself and your professional experience and your teamwork expiericne, etc.

One 30 minute screen call with a software engineer where they ask about what you like/dislike in programming and your basic knowledge of software principles. Final round is two 45 minute whiteboarding interviews with SWEs where they have you work through basic problems and ask you to reason your thought processes.

First round was phone screening interview for about an hour. They ask you variety of questions involving behavioral, problem-solving, and technical. I didn't get an opportunity to move into next round! :(

Initial phone screen with one technical question and the remainder of time to talk with recruiter. Two technical interviews in final round. Pretty good conversation with all team members, and was pretty enjoyable throughout.

I did not end up getting the job but it was honestly life changing. I went in expecting to only answer questions but I learned an extreme amount of technical information and they helped me figure out what I need to work on in the future. It was an amazing experience.

Process seemed to drag unnecessarily long. In addition, there seemed to be information inconsistencies between the recruiter and the scheduler. Questions about the process either went unanswered or would take several days for a response. It appears that recruitment/scheduling is handled by 3rd party companies, so that might contribute to the disorganization.

Interview itself pretty vanilla and consisted of four one-hour Teams interviews spread out over a 10 week period. Screening interview with recruiter, meeting with hiring manager, and then two technical panels. After that was a follow up with recruiter. 

My experience was somewhat negative due to the disorganization. One of the CSAs on the technical panel talked a lot and took up an awful lot of air time. Another was late. Everyone else was incredibly friendly and knowledgeable, so it's hard to really judge. Seemed like folks were more interested in talking about themselves/chatting than getting to know the candidate, so it could be they had already made their hire and were just going through the motions.
It was an easy interview, I even got to sit down with Bill Gates and a gentleman named Soros (could be wrong) I basically told explained how I could benefit Microsoft as a whole and they liked me.

Had a phone screen that went extremely well. 

Then moved on to the four hour long interview with 3 engineers and hiring manager. Asked basic coding questions and things about my background. Thought it went well but ultimately was rejected. Not sure what they were looking for. Hope you get lucky.

The interviewers were very nice and encouraging. I really enjoyed the process.
There were 3 stages:
- first stage was online coding, 3 problems about arrays and strings
- second stage was with a software engineer. it involved coding and some questions based on the CV
- last stage, was a series of 4 interviews, each 45 mins long with a different software engineer

Interview with HR from New York.
Codillity test.
Two technical interviews with group managers.
If I would have passed them - there would be another final interview.
I did not pass the second technical interview - it did not feel as if I had the chance to show my true skills

I received an email from Aerotek that Microsoft wanted to interview me so a week after I received the email I got on a Microsoft teams with one of the recruiters. The interview process consisted of introduction, coding challenge and any questions you want to ask the interviewer.  After the first interview I had an hour break and the same procedure as the first one. I thought I did well but unfortunately did not receive an offer.
Took about 4 months from first interview to written offer. Two rounds of interviews. First was a screener via Teams. Second was 4 interviews back-to-back. All these interviews were technical.
I had one technical interview that lasted for an hour and then an onsite with four interviews that were a mix of  technical and behavioral questions, each an hour long.

First was a phone screening where there were some technical questions.

Next they flew me out to Seattle where I had 6 interviews throughout the day. Lots of hard problems and whiteboard coding.

Was a very familiar and typical process for big tech companies. Relatively friendly. Started with a broad interview with many people. 4 1on1 interview (for about an hour) and then a final round interview with 3 people.

Good experience. Interviewers were friendly but the process was quite long. Took a number of weeks. Lots of the interviews seemed more informative about the role than actually assessing the candidate ability.

It is ok. All practical questions, no tricks. Write small functions and sql statement, most of them are scenarios will be used in real work. Keep talking about your thoughts, those count too. There are also design questions, they are looking for your design principles, consider performance and extensibility.

It was quick and I was kept well informed throughout the processs. The interviews themselves were enjoyable as the interviewers were relaxed and were keen to get to know me and not just how well I could code

The onset interview has 5 sessions, including:
1. Presentation
2. Research Questions
3. Machine Learning Questions
4. Coding Questions
5. Others

The research questions cover all my publications in PhD, where I need to give a brief introduction to each of them. Machine Learning questions are quite random, based on what we are talking about before.
Totally 4 rounds. Three coding and one system design. They are very nice and good people. The coding was not very hard but need the candidate to specify the input and think of corner cases.
