Applied via referral from a Microsoft employee (would recommend using this process when applying). The process started with a phone call from a Microsoft recruiter followed by 4 x 1hr Interviews over the space of a 2 weeks (via teams due to COVID) with different Microsoft employees.

Once the interview process had been completed the recruiter made a formal offer by the end of next working day.

One phone call and a great conversation. The recruiter called me and found I'm not applicable since I wanted a part-time and they demanded a full-time employee. But he described to me very impressive tricks for job hunting.

Very streamline standard process, phone interview then virtual onsite interview with two engineers. Phone was behavioral with one question thats a pretty open ended algorithm question. Onsite interviews were a little behavioral and mostly technical. One technical question per interviewer. Received decision a couple days after interview.

Technical screening phone call after the recruiter reached out via email.

After the technical screening, we scheduled a round of interviews with each team member.

Each team member then asked questions pertaining to their own role.

It was a smooth process. First a call with the recruiter, then the whole day with 3 interviews including hiring manager and a colleague moving away from the role to the promotion and regional manager interview with the case study
Awesome, amazing people and amazing work environment. I love the team and the learning experience. Would love to retire here. I learnt a lot and worked with an amazing team
Remote online interview with scenario based questions. Behavioral questions - what would you do in given situations + knowledge based questions related to the cloud. Length was about 1 hour.

New Grad Role, Easy Interview leetcode easy-medium lot of testing questions. No offer. Onsite 4 hours over teams and Codility. Good interviewers although the questions were very vague and did not have proper format.

I applied for another graduate role but was called by a recruiter and offered to interview for a customer engineer in the aspire programme. I had one Skype interview that was around 30 minutes long, questions about the culture and about me but mostly behavioural. Then they invited me to the virtual assessment centre that consisted of a preprepared presentation, a group activity (also presentation), another interview with only behavioural questions.

Online assessment, phone screen, questions already mentioned here on glassdoor. Didn't get to onsite, should've prepared harder questions. Most questions are also on leetcode, do some LC hard questions too.

Got to their virtual onsite. One of the interviewers was not engaged in seeing my solution to the technical problem. We agreed on the algorithm before I went to actually code it, and he wasn't aware of what/how my code was doing things. I finished the coding he quickly looked at it and accepted the code.

Rejected without feedback, I literally have no idea how to improve for next time, thanks for wasting my time in the interviews Microsoft!
Codility test didn't go well. HR interview was good, the interviewer was nice and calming, asked good questions and a quite easy riddle. Still didn't recieve a mail about the next rounds.
Got a call from the hiring manager first because the recruiter must have been too busy - 3 rounds of interviews with a panel at the end - overall pretty daunting but wasn’t too bad

Entrevista preliminar com recrutador.  Entrevista técnica.  Entrevista em vídeo com várias pessoas o que pode incluir fazer testes práticos de código, e responder perguntas sobre seu histórico e suas experiências profissionais.

Long. Took about two months. Met the hiring manager and  the team. I was done remotely due to COVID. Video interviews. The people were friendly. It took longer due to the holidays. But I had check in with the recruiter after not hearing anything for over 2 weeks.

It was a short 30 min first-round interview where the questions were mostly based on getting to understand your technical capacity and your experiences. At the end you are given a question and given 5 mins to come up with a solution which you will explain to the interviewer. 
The interviewer told me that at this phase they don't really look at the coding ability because that is something that can be taught while on the job but instead they usually look for interpersonal and problem-solving skills without forgetting teamwork of course. Overall it is not as hard as everyone on the internet makes it seem but it is best you be prepared.

Very well organised and professional. The interviewers make the candidate feel good and comfortable before asking the interview questions. The candidates should be punctual and join before 5 minutes as they also look at about your time management skills.

Behavioral-based questions were asked to see how you have handled situations in past experiences. It seems the idea behind this is simple - past behavior is the best indicator of future behavior. Overall, I would say the interview process was great, and not as stressful as I had anticipated. Great interview experience.
Very professional and well constructed. Interviewers were very positive. They value diversity. Company culture is very important and they are looking for some qualities that prove you are a good fit.

The most common process consists of 4-5 rounds focused on testing the analytical, problem-solving, and technical skills .
Use of codility to code and dashboard on white board
Use of codility to code and dashboard on white board
Use of codility to code and dashboard on white board
Horrible was done through a third party . No feedback was offered just a really bad experience for a company I wish I could work for.  I plan on reapplying and going through the process again.

Terrible experience, went through multiple rounds of interviews for a sales mba program, told I made the final round and never heard back from recruiter or interviewers and they would not respond to my emails. Worst experience and very unprofessional.

Applied to the role and was asked to fill out a survey of my skills. Set up a phone interview that was rescheduled by them literally last minute. Interviewer was nice, no behavioral/technical questions but it was just them basically repeating the survey and retyping my answers.  Redescribed my experiences using all the tech in the job posting and said info will be passed to hiring manager. It was also clear they did not look at my resume whatsoever, by asking if I have experience with the technology when all my projects use it. Over in less than 10 minutes, hour later rejection email. I assume it's because of my lack of 1 yr experience. Was this not an entry level role? Seriously, why bothering going through the whole process in the first place. Disappointing

- Screening CV
- Entretien RH (questions assez basiques de motivation, de connaissance des produits Microsoft, mise au point sur des éléments administratifs)
- Assessment Center (Ice breaker avec pitch d'une minute, puis 4 entretiens: mise en situation avec cas concret de présentation à un client, exercice de groupe sur les opportunités technologiques de Microsoft, entretien avec 5-10 questions de mises en situation professionnelle, entretien informel avec un manager)
Online Assessment as a prequalification for onsite interview. The recuriter sent a codility link to me  which has 3 questions for 2.5 hours. Questions in Long distance problem, sum of sub-array

I had about 4 interviews with 4 different persons.

- Screener Interview (60 min)
- OOP Programming Interview (60 min)
- Behavioural Interview with Team Manager (60 min)
- Design Interview with Principle Engineer (60 min)

Had a screening interview with some data structure questions + online coding test.
Then had 4 interviews for assessment centre with a mix of behavioural and technical qs
The technical qs were mixed in difficulty, I feel they were more interested in my communication skills and approach then the actual solution itself.

First-round interview was pretty standard, didn't ask any technical questions and had 5 behavioral questions where the interviewer asked to talk about my internship experience.

For final round interviews, I had 3 virtual interviews each ranging 45 mins. I had one interview where I presented a 10 min presentation about what I'm passionate about.  I heard back in 1 business day and got my offer.

Engaged by recruiter, professional, thorough, efficient, set the process expectations clearly and stuck to the plan.  
Introduced to the hiring manager, then placed into formal loop with 5 other senior managers.  Did 5 video calls on Teams in 1.5 week period.

very fast and efficient, background check ready in 5 days. Consists of interview with direct manager, regional manager and HR department. The content depends on their knowledge of your career, as I was reffered to this position, they did not ask many questions
The interview process was very pleasant and quick. The interview was very relevant to the position. Although I didn’t pass the interview, they called to tell me which I very much appreciated.
Relatively standard, but was surprised and pleased to receive feedback directly in the interview itself on areas I'd be a good fit for the position, and areas that I would need to develop.

Primo colloquio di 30 min circa in inglese puramente attitudinale, colloquio di 1h per spiegarci come prepararci e cosa portare al terzo colloquio e infine colloquio di 4h circa (5*40 min + pause) divisio in: presentazione, impact, attitudine, attitudine, lavoro di gruppo

The interview is technical. I was interviewed by one of the team members through Teams.  You introduce yourself and there are some short questions about basic technical knowledge. Then they will give you algorithm problems to solve.

Recruiter contacted me by email and scheduled a 30 min interview meeting. At the interview day she joined a little bit later but apologised for that. It was a 20 min conversation until she realized I was not a fit for that position. She was very kind and recommended me on keeping applying for other type of positions.
First round phone interview. It went pretty well and I had a mix of behavioral and a coding question in 30 min, so they didn't expect a fully worded result

I applied through the sociaty of women engineers for the summer internship. I got contacted by a recruiter after a month to sxhedule a first round interview. I scheduled my time for the following week.  I didn't have much time to prepare for the interview. Recomendation, apply when you feel ready with your data structures and algorithms knowledge so you dont miss your interview opportunity

After I sent my resume, I got an email for a phone interview which is the first round. I selected my interview date and time.  On interview day, I got a call from the interviewer.  She called me sharp at the time. So if someone having the interview, you better be ready before 10 minutes and relax yourself.
1st it was phone call screening that took 30 minutes, followed by Microsoft teams interview thst took an hour. The interviewers were very friendly and accommodating and questions were very easy.

Scheduling was a pain--the people I worked with seemed confused about the process. I had a 30 minute phone screen with the hiring manager and 4 one-hour interviews with members of the team. The recruiter never returned my e-mails (even to pass along thank you notes), and never notified me that I wasn't selected to move forward. Ghosted.

The interview process includes 3-4 different rounds with senior cloud solution architects and business leaders. Technical interview feedback takes at least a week to come back to you. At the end the final feedback takes again 2-3 weeks. Very long and tiring process without proper feedback and updates
They two 2 round of interview and never respond back. Not even letting me if I did good or bad. No HR contacted me and it was not very good experience.

Case interview 
1. A team discussion of about 4 hours. In this discussion, your team should give a proposal regarding the case that MS provided. 
2. After the team discussion, your team need to give a presentation of about 30 mins with Q&A.

1st round: phone screening, 15 mins basic questions 
2nd round: 3 rounds of interviews, one of which was a presentation on a topic of my choice (10 mins). Overall was not too difficult. Almost no technical questions asked.
Received an email from a recruiter to apply for the position. I applied online and the recruiter sent me an email to schedule my interview. Gave my first round of interview with another recruiter.

It was mostly a fun process to get to know the team and learn about the role. The only frustrating thing was the lack of communication from the hiring manager and recruiter. It didn’t seem like they were on the same page. The role ended up getting pulled after the lengthy process.

Recruiter was very helpful with resources, first round phone call was very simple with basic computer science concepts and about personal projects you've done. The loop was about 4 interviews that were okay (two interviewers kind of had an attitude but I didn't look that much into it). Overall, it was a great experience, learned a lot from it.

I submitted my resume online, and a recruiter reached out to me directly and was enthusiastic to speak with me. I scheduled a phone call with her and we spoke for an hour, covering my resume and specific points related to the Director role. The interview was very pleasant and positive, and the recruiter said she expected the team would want to speak with me for the next round. Unfortunately, she reached out a few weeks later to say the hiring team went in a different direction for their loop of interviews.

Quick phone interview - asked personal questions and some design questions. 
Afterwards I had two interviews back to back with software engineers from the company. They asked coding questions that were in the medium-high difficulty range.

Video interview with technical interviewer with mostly behavioral and past experiences. Hard because they want in depth thoughtful answers, but very good and calm interviewing atmosphere. Don't say fluff, when asked why you want to work at Microsoft have thoughtful answer.

30 min long. Start with a Self introduction and go through resume a little bit.  Then start coding questions, interviewer was nice and gave hint when you got stuck,  then follow up with additional some condition.

I had 3 online interviews that lasted 45 min. The interviewers were very professional and friendly, guided me to the correct solution. Even though I didn't get the internship, they called me and said on what to improve. I will apply again the next time.

had a 2 interviews in 1 day. Each 45 mins, with senior developer and hiring manager. With manager we started with behavioral question, with senior with challenges and last few min had behavioral question

Consisted of a phone interview then a virtual interview with 2 separate people. The phone call was behavioral and the virtual ones were both technical SWE questions. Everyone involved in the process was super nice and definitely wanted to see me succeed.

Very unprofessional throughout, I was contacted by one of their 'Technical Talent Sourcers' through LinkedIn. In the beginning it was good, decent communication and had some phone interviews. At the time I was also interviewing for other positions and had made it to some of the final rounds. The talent sourcer said that she wanted me to do some type of technical interview or assessment to help her place a job for me. I naively thought that this would mean that I would be given a shot to take it and perhaps get an opportunity to work at MS. 

So I decided to bow out of the other interview process to pursue the MS opportunity. This was my big mistake, as the talent sourcer turned out to be entirely unreliable, unwilling to communicate to basic questions, and straight up ignored my multiple attempts at emailing her to see what the next steps to take the assessment were. 

Ill  never make the same mistake again with any recruiters or talent sourcers from MS and assume that theyre about as reliable as a chocolate teapot when it comes to moving through their interview process. It would be one thing if I completely failed an assessment and missed my shot, but the treatment I received was unprofessional at best.

* Applied through referral
* Then got invitation to codility. Codility had medium questions, but you could find them on leetcode and you had 90 minutes to complete them, so not a big deal
* then invitation to a call with a recruiter. some behavioural questions, nothing too fancy
* then onsite interviews. 4 interviewers, leetcode+some behavioural questions
* offer through an email in the next couple of days
Great interview process. Did an intro call with recruiter before getting screened into interviews.  First call with Security expert and the second with the manager on the team I would be working on.

first of all they let me do 3 questions in 80 minute and then there is 30 minute phone interview most the questions are personal and in the last 5 minute they ask a riddle to solve and after that i waited 2 weeks to get an answer that i moved to the next step (2 technical interviews each 1 hour) but i didnt bass the second

Went through one initial screening, got asked a question about trees and didn't really pass it. The interviewer ended up helping me through it.

For the final 2 rounds, I had one technical interview and one behavioral interview.

Had one initial 30 min interview with some Microsoft-specific questions, then another round of three 30 min long interviews with behavioral questions about past work experience and relevant skills. Interviewers were very friendly and welcoming.
1 hour talk with hiring manager followed by virtual onsite consisting of 5 rounds. The onesite had 1 design round, 2 coding rounds and 1 domain knowledge  / coding round.

The role is for MSFT STCA in the Beijing Office 

The interview round is 3 rounds 
with PM & Principle PM 

It's usually 1 hour 


Lots of questions on your experience

The entire process took 2 months total after a referral, very disorganized process from start to finish
One 30 minute HR call, one 45 minute technical interview, final round consisting of two hour long interviews (mostly technical). There was 5 weeks between my first technical interview and final around.
I applied online to a Software engineering position  in Microsoft in California at the SWE conference inter position.  Then 1 interview with human resources  after 1 month since I applied,

Two rounds. The first round was about 40 minutes via Teams. She asked me to introduce myself, asked some follow up questions about my background, and finished by asking a product design question. The second round consisted of four 45-minute interviews in a row. Almost all were behavioral questions, i.e. "tell me about a time when you...".

Live coding question was asked
The interviewer asked Me to share the approach and then code it in the notepad
a few hr questions were asked too. In the end, the interviewer asked if I wanted to ask him anything.

Sehr lockerer Ablauf, das Vorstellungsgespräch ist mehr auf Persönlichkeit als fachliches Know How ausgelegt. Zuerst Vorstellungsrunde, sowie von früheren Erfahrungen gesprochen, danach habe ich Informationen zur Rolle bekommen sowie Fragen zur Arbeitsweise und Personal Fit

Very straightforward and organized process.  The final loop stages take up to 4 hours with up to 5 rounds of interviews depending on the department you interview with. Afterwards you get a gift voucher for your time with them regardless of the decision.

The first interview round 30 min over the phone. He asked some personal questions along with some design questions. The interviewer was approachable and very pleasant to speak with.  The next round is two interviews with software engineers part of the team I am a candidate for.

Initial phone call screen that was pretty much all behavioral. After that, it was a simple coding challenge question. Then, about a week later I was contacted to attend an onsite with about 4 rounds of coding questions.

There were several rounds with all members of the functional team. Started with HR function and phone screens, and then moved to in-person interviews. The final round was a blitz of several back to back interviews on campus, some of which were 30 minutes and others were 60 minutes. The last interview of the day was with the head of the group - he didn't ask many technical questions, was more testing general knowledge.

The process was very smooth and the interviewers did a great job of making me feel comfortable. The response came back in around 3 weeks, which was a bit later than expected. Overall, they made sure all interviewees were able to perform optimally.
One campus interview, and one onsite interview with two interviews. The engineers who interviewed me were part of the organization that I was being interviewed for, so that was a nice caveat.

Searched internships online. Then applied online for a couple of  internships, contacted to schedule virtual interview month later, then virtual interview through Microsoft teams. I am still waiting to hear.

Had a few interviews onsite with different people from the team. Pretty easy questions overall, some behavioral and some technical. Day was over after three or four interviews and got the offer a week later

first stage- home test of 80 minutes , contains 3 coding questions over codility. and than conversation over skype with HR for 30 minutes with personal questions. asking about project you have done, why microsoft

Interview process was very simple and clean. Had the interview with HR, then a long interview with 3-4 different people. My only issue was they did not inform me about decisions quickly. I had to refresh the site for a month to find out i was not selected.
they sent me an exam from codility.com and then we scheduled an interview, it was 30 minutes conducted in english, and then there is another round of interviews still waiting

Mainly to discuss with mentor. Several medium level leetcode coding problems plus some math problems. As a research intern interview, it is natural that different supervisors would have different preference for his/her  candidates.

First call my Microsoft recruiter to understand experience. Then a sleep of a month. Followed by urgent request for interview with hiring manager who did was visiting from Europe. Face  to face interview with hiring manger and sales lead. 
Next round was a 30 min telephonic discussion with hiring managers manager. Questions were direct and at the end a direct feedback. Overall positive experience of this interview. 
Recruiter Quickly followed up and provided feedback. The feedback is very positive. Next, a long wait.... no feedback for over a month. 

After few follow up the response was - thanks but the team decided not to move forward with your candidature.

3 rounds with the design task. First-round general in-depth portfolio review. Second round problem solving and design task. Third round HR questions.
3 rounds with the design task. First-round general in-depth portfolio review. Second round problem solving and design task. Third round HR questions.
Fast and easy process. It was pretty difficult because I had to do it remote (before everything was remote). But they were super accommodating since I was studying abroad at the time

I was called on the phone by a current Microsoft software developer who gave me a brief review of this career there and then asked technical questions. They were very specific things that you must remember from your intro classes when they seem unimportant. Must know the basics of computer architecture.

Great !
The requirements are fair. You need to practice your basic data structure and algorithm. I think the most important for the interview is that you fit in their culture. Look up culture at Microsoft on their website to learn more.

Very well structured, engaging managers and quick responses. High quality process with lots of relevant information about the role. Never felt unclear about expectations or the timeline of interviews. Would recommend applying

5 rounds, 3 technical, 1 design, 1 behavioral. 
technical questions were leetcode medium. Interviewers are usually nice and help you through. Interview process can vary team to team. This was in person (few years back) and included lunch.
4 interviews, all non technical/product oriented. Several phone screens and then an onside in Washington with 4 interviews. Not much more I can add here. Good experience over all, easy interviews.

Behavioral interview easy questions only went through first round interview had an internal referral thought it went well but it is competitive as it is a two year program that transitions into a full time job.

Premier entretien RH par téléphone, ensuite invité à une journée d'assessment qui permet de discuter avec différents managers, mise en situation par groupe pour évaluer manière de communiquer, préparation d'une mini presentation au préalable, à faire à 1 des managers

I have a screening 30 minute phone call. The worst interview I ever had. I feel like the interviewer had unrealistic expectations. I am a POC in CS and I know the bar is high, but the practices at Microsoft make it clear for me that they don't care about us being present in the room to make decisions that have an impact on my community. The way they recruit is designed to get almost perfect engineers, which are often white and asian.  Congrats of not moving forward with a better system that accounts for different backgrounds and different experiences during your process.

a skype conversion and a codility test with 3 question. 
the codility qustions are not easy and its hatd to make it on time.
the sype is interview with hr.

Only had 1 stage until now, interview through zoom. mostly behavioural questions. very nice interviewer.
I am waiting for stage two and then i can share the whole experience. overall the process takes some time but it is woth it.

Onsite interview. One algorithm question. One production design question. One soft skills question. There were four interview blocks. They lied and said that getting three of four was random. It was not.

one phone round and two virtual onsite rounds, both with coding questions on leetcode. The questions are not hard, but they require a lot of thinking and talking. They also ask about projects that I have been working on.

The first one is HR behavior questions, about 30 minutes. The last round is the super day interview, four 45 minutes interview.  All questions are most behavior questions.  Just prepare well for that.
in the 30 min phone call round with 3 days slots appointment most of the questions are bq questions and they are normal, it really depends on who you met
codility test- 3 questions in 80 minutes. then you have a skype interview with HR, then 2-4 more interviews with hiring manager. didn't finish the process yet. will update later.
All technical in the first round. It was pretty hard, it asked pretty complex coding questions. The interviewer was really nice and helpful though. Learnt a lot from the experience.
First you get registered on their website then you get notified of the interview. On the day of the interview you show up. Interviews usually with interviewer having a PC in front of them.

(August 2020) Submitted application online without referral.

(September 2020) Normally on-campus, but due to Covid was virtual. One phone screen with mostly behavioral questions and a couple conceptual technical questions (about standard CS concepts). Really practice talking about your projects and the teamwork within your projects. Within the next week (usually takes longer but only took me a week) they contacted me scheduling a virtual on-site.

(October 2020) Interviewed at the very start of October with the (seemingly) randomly decided team in Azure. 4 interviews: 1. A Software Manager asking about projects and technical decisions within projects. Technical question was variation of common BST-related problem asked by Microsoft. 2. SWE asking about projects and teamwork. Technical question was Meeting Rooms 2. 3. Software Manager asking system design question. Fairly lax since New Grad, so just talk about things you would consider when building the system (how to make things scalable, what databases to have, important features). Question was about cloud services product design. 4. Normally called the AA meeting, only for people who did well, but for virtual interviews they seem to give this to everyone no matter what. With Senior manager who likely makes the ultimate decision based on feedback prior. Asked about your interests and past experience. Checks if you are match for the team. Technical question was along the lines of longest palindrome substring. 

Received offer several weeks later due to delays (late October). Was great experience. Make sure to quickly understand what team you are interviewing for in the AA interview, and match your project responses to that.

First round interview was a 1 on 1 with a recruiter. Second round interview consisted of 3 1 on 1 interviews. It was mainly behavioral questions with a few questions about project management. None of my interviewers have responded to my emails despite saying they wanted to connect regardless of the decision on my offer. It was disappointing since we seemed to have genuine conversations and connections.

1. HR call, quick chat about my resume and the roles available
2. online coding assessment, 2 coding questions in 90 minutes. Time is usually an issue, manage it wisely. Questions are all around fundamental algorithms and data structures, nothing crazy!!
I did an interview on my school's campus instead of a phone screen, then I had 2 back-to-back final round interviews. The interviewers were kind and willing to talk through the problems.

virtual interview with three managers. 
The first one,  general behavior question.
The second one, open code platform for coding HTML, CSS, javascript.
The third one,  all about javascript interviews question. 
I don't think all process is a high standard for selecting a good candidate.

at first they contacted me via email, sent me a codility coding questions to solve, after that we had a skype interview with an HR , then  had a technical interview, it was an hour and a half, asked me two questions, one I had to code and one to answer and explain verbally.

I had a interview with nice person from Romania, it was half HR interview and half technical one. 
he asked me a few riddles and asked me to describe myself and my History.

Really friendly, overall good experience. It was over Microsoft teams.  The interviewer asked questions such as "describe a time when you had to resolve a conflict", "describe a time when you ran into an issue working with a team", "describe a time when you had to problem solve", "describe a time when you had to learn a new technical skill on the job".

I got an invitation for interview after 1-2 weeks after I applied and the interview was via Skype. The interviewer was kind and it took max. 30 min. She didn't asked me many questions but it was around how do you do as a team mate.

I did a first round interview by skype, I was asked mostly behavioral and situational questions. I was required to talk a bit about my previous experiences and mostly how I woul react in some situations, then I was asked competency based questions.

1. Screening call: the call with the recruiter was very engaging and she was very nice and open. 
Eg questions: Tell me how you landed your last job. What was the hardest customer situation you faced?

2. After the first interview, I had to wait a week to have feedback. I was then invited for an interview round with 3 managers:
- !!! This step required more preparation. Be ready to be bombed with questions and do not even think of lying. They will go really deep into your experiences and lying won't help you.
Eg questions: You say you are a fast learner, give me an example and how long did it take you?

3. After a week I received a rejection email. Unfortunately, although personalized, they did not give me any detail or any constructive feedback.

Although I did not get the job, I believe I had a really positive experience. All the people involved really want to make you understand how it is working at Microsoft.

Pro tips: 
- get informed about how Microsoft shifted to the cloud and modified its business model (company background check)
- get informed about the people you are going to be interviewed. Also, to avoid surprises, check the team lead profile
- cross-check the job position and your experience. What do they have in common? 
- get to know well the products they offer
- BE YOURSELF
First round is a phone screen. Very nice interviewer and really just wanted to get to know me. Applied in august (end) and heard back mid September. Interview was about a week later.

Quick and fast paced, consisted of 3 smaller interviews which zoomed through various programming tasks. It bared most resemblance to various programming competitions. Prepare a little, and the interview is supposed to be easy.

Positives:
Interview with the hiring manager and another colleague went smoothly.  They were open, candid and very professional.  I was impressed with them.

Negatives:
1) I was not invited to have the customary interview with the Microsoft recruiter prior to the interview with the hiring manager. Hence I was not able to check if the level of the role and compensation were appropriate for me, prior to my interview with the hiring manager.  
2)  Lack of any useful feedback after the interview, just a boilerplate email from an unmonitored inbox saying I will not be progressing.  I contacted the hiring manager on LinkedIn after and did not hear back.  A shame because I felt the interview went really well and I will never know what I could have done differently or where I should focus to improve.

Generally, very smooth interview process with lots of behavioral questions instead of technical ones. Seems like they care more about people than skills. Highly recommended to anyone who are interested in joining the company.   Basic programming skill required

The hiring process in Microsoft is pathetic. They took 4 rounds of interview for over a month and asked to submit my current organization's payslips at the end and again after 2 weeks of multiple follow ups, they said "Hiring is on hold now"! All my time and the interviewer's time is wasted! Microsoft is no different when compared to other companies now, gone are the days you would think Microsoft as a dream company! They do give reason like this when they cannot match your current pay. Think before you join this company guys.

I applied online (submitted resume).  I was invited to a phone interview with HR person (screening). After passing that, I was invited to final round interview (one day with 3 separate interviews with three executives on the same team).

Sehr angenehm, Senior Leadership auch im Gespräch involviert. Fragen auf menschliches Verhalten fokussiert mit direktem Feedback und Einblick in die Perspektive der Mitarbeiter. Sehr "menschliches" Gespräch. Auch Essen serviert bekommen und Gespräch mit anderen Trainees und Interns in der Kaffee Pause

Processo muito, mas muito longo e falta de informações, não houve devolutiva por parte do RH ou de algum entrevistador, nenhum feedback. Desgastante e estressante. Me senti triste por não receber nem ao menos um e-mail agradecendo pelo empenho nos muitos meses de processo seletivo.

I applied online and received an email from recruiter 4 days later for a screening. Had 2 Panel interviews the following week; first panel was Sr Engineers with technical questions, 2nd panel was hiring manager interview (behavioral). Received an offer about a month later.
Was good  but was not sure about the coding. Was okay overall.  Not sure if I will get to second round. Interviewer was friendly and was able to help me through
four interviews about MS culture the questions are on the behavioral interview questions to figure out if you are a fit of MS culture you need to give examples of your experience

Asked questions from Data Structures and Algorithms. They came to our campus, 8 candidates were shortlisted from 180 candidates, Although I answered correctly I was rejected maybe due to lack of confidence
With this team, the process was wonderful. The people were engaging, respectful, and we even got to joke around a bit. Don't forget to show your personality in interviews. It matters.

4 rounds of interview with some design included .
In the latter one was asked some network related questions.
Then they asked hoe to optimize a code snippet.
The code snippet is not hard to read

Contacted by the recruitment for a interview 
1 step 
All good
2 nd step
All good 
3 rd step
Went to the office they offer a coffee and food before interview and all was nice
Appreciate the effort of them
Got the job

First there were 3 codility questions, as a home assignment, and then two online interviews with two interviewers that requires you to write code online in codility. the process itself was very professional.

It was a good experience. Coding Questions were asked in HR round as well. If u know coding things will be on your side. Best of luck for the interview. Nail it by practising coding questions before hand

Very conversational and informal. The STAR story format was useful for being able to relay my experiences in a  concise way, but there was no preconceived expectations that I follow a rigid format in my responses. It felt like I was on a coffee chat with a colleague. Very cool interview experience.
The interview process of Microsoft for the PM Intern role consists of multiple rounds. The first round is a phone call screen interview and the second round is actual interviews.
I felt it very tough for the role as it was junior role I did not expect it that hard. The first round was telephonic and the questions were on sql, c sharp, testing, html, xml.
Positive interview experience! First round on college campus, they flew us out for final round interviews in Redmond (two short interviews with engineers), emailed with the offer about a week later.

the interview was well organized , and it included an overall evaluation of both the technical and the interpersonal skills . questions ranged from computer science related problems , to ability to detect and solve  communication problems

Final interviews were 2x45 minutes of conversation about me and my background, then a small programming challenge, and finally open questions. The interviews were back-to-back sessions on Microsoft Teams. The interviewers were friendly and encouraging.

Several basic information asking, behavior question and One easy tech question. Only 30 min but I got actually only 25min because of some issues. Very nice interviewer with hints and guidance provided.

There are about 3-4 separate technical interviews in the coding language of your choice. You must first apply through the jobs and careers page in the company site and then check the action center periodically before you receive an email.

Send the resume through application portal, then the first interview is a 1 on 1 with technical questions. After this,  4 interviews in final round. Normally the final round interviews are on site but currently everything is online.

1: Recruiter Screening
2: Virtual interviews 3-4 interviews back to back.

Thought I did well, Microsoft seems like they "care" about diversity, but I think thats just a show. Indians stay hiring Indians and Chinese stay hiring Chinese.

Recruiter contacted me in LinkedIn. Did a online coding round in Codility, after that, I was invited for the virtual interviews.

Virtual interview consisted of 3 rounds (1 behavioral, 2 coding/design)

Positive:
I enjoyed the 3 virtual interview rounds, the interviewers are very nice and I had a really interesting conversation with all of them.

Negative:
The communication/interaction with the recruiters was very bad, most of the emails where automatic messages and it seems that the didn't even care.  After the virtual interviews, I received a email saying that there were going to make me an offer and that the offer could take form 1-3 weeks. I was completely ghosted after that email, I even tried to get in touch with the recruiters and even cc everyone I could but didn't get any response.

Had an initial technical screen followed by a virtual onsite.
A few days later I got an email from a business recruiter that Microsoft had an offer for me and requested availability to discuss the offer.  After I sent the availability they did not reply to any of my emails for two weeks. After that they sent me an email that all positions were filled and they are sorry. 
I reached out to the talent sourcer and they said I had cleared the interview but all positions were filled before they got to me. Then they completely ghosted me.

I did not expect this from a company like Microsoft.

The interviewers were all super nice (except one guy who was semi-rude). The interviews were intense. I studied tons of LeetCode problems, but all of my interview questions were questions I didn't practice (bad luck). However, my knowledge of DS&A is what allowed me to find the solutions. Seriously, study your DS&A. Also, be social and make them laugh, it works.

I applied for the Ability Hiring Event because I'm Autistic. The final round of interviews were virtual. However the interview was still like that for a normal person, because my interviewers still expected me to be "normal". It was no different from all my previous interviews. I could not be myself the entire time. Ability Hiring Event? More like a scam.

Applied online. Had a first phone interview with a manager. Deep dive into my resume. Then, a medium recursion question.

Then, had an (virtual)onsite about a month later. 4 rounds of interviews with engineers and managers. Very professional. If I was stuck, they nudged me slightly towards the solution.  Had at least two questions in 3 interviews. Leetcode easy/medium. The fourth was a difficult one.  It was more of a collaborative thinking interview. I was presented with a very vague question. And throughout our conversation, we were both untangling the question. It was fun. It was an open ended question and I believe the interviewer just wanted to see how I think.

I don't think there is any use in doing specific questions. Practice all data structures. I was asked Linked list, array, string, matrix.

Three interviews, each 45 minutes, first is behavioral, second was a 10 minute presentation, and third was conversational. Each interviewer asked about relevant problem-solving and resume experiences.  Overall a super positive experience!
They gave me a 30 minute coding challenge where I had to show my coding process to an interviewer on screen. I had to explain my code to the interviewer about why I wrote my code in that way.

It was a 3 rounds process.In first round I was given 2 coding problems to solve.You had to complete both of them to proceed.Secondly the  interviewer in the 2nd round was calm and collected and he asked me about my projects in cv and also some system design related questions.The final round was the HR round where he asked me about my ambitions and expectations from the company.

1 Screening
Followed by 3 rounds of interviews
This was all during corona. Hence everything was virtual.
The interview was more technical that other product management interviews that I have given. Having said that, there were no coding questions

Application and then video interview where I was asked personally based questions, then after a very long period I received an update on the outcome of the interview. Used Skype for the video interview.

A recruiter reached out to me for my availability for interviews with the team, and then never scheduled anything or followed up. I followed up THREE times over several weeks, and finally got a simple reply of "the team no longer wants to speak with you." Not a great experience.

Very quick process. Awesome Interviewers. 
 
I started the process in October and 4 weeks later I had an answer from a recruiter. The interviewers were very smart and kind persons. Great interview experience

1) hr phone call to set up skype meeting
2) codility test - 3 technical questions in 80 mins (easy to medium level)
3) interview via skype with hr from Microsoft US.

I had 3 virtual interviews that were 45 minutes each for the final round. There were 15 minute breaks in between in case you and your interviewer run over the 45 minutes or if you need to 'recharge' before the next round.

For the first interview, I was asked a lot of S.T.AR.(S.) based questions aka 'Tell me about a time you did xyz', 'How did you react to that scenario' , etc. The interview did a good job of making it less stressful and gave a lot of positive affirmations when I said what they wanted to hear.

For the second interview wasn't really an 'interview'. I had to give a presentation on a topic of my choice for about 10 minutes and after that, it was just a conversation with the interviewer. I was free to ask them about MS as a company, their experience there, the different jobs I was under consideration for.

The third interview was more like the first. I was asked things like 'tell me about yourself' and more S.T.A.R. based questions. I was also asked to redo my presentation but do a condensed version of it (so for instance, if my original presentation was 12 minutes, I now needed to do it in 8 minutes).

I really liked all my interviewers and they helped make an interview process that initially seems difficult and intimidating more manageable. Good luck to anyone applying!
There was an on-campus interview then an onsite interview with 5 technical rounds which lasted 1 hour each. The turn around between the on-campus interview and onsite was about 2 weeks.

Applied online and heard back about a month later. Did a 30min interview on Microsoft teams it was mostly situational.  Thought it went really well but a week later received an automated email saying they were going with other candidates.

Interview with the hiring manager and then was told to expect another call. No news from the recruitment team for a couple of weeks and then no feedback as to why I didn't make the cut. The amount of prep someone does for an interview and then not getting any feedback is very disheartening.

3 behavioral questions back to back. Questions got more abstract as the interview went on. Be ready to talk about your experience and how it connects to the role. The company culture (which is amazing) definitely radiated through the interview
The interviewer asked a lot of technical questions, so be prepared. They would ask you to share your screen (Teams interview) and have you write/draw your answers and share your work.

The process took about 6 weeks from my first initial screening with a recruiter to my final interview with the hiring manager. I had 4 interviews in total.

1. Initial screening with the recruiter 
2. Interview with peer director
3. Interview with peer director
4. Interview with peer director
5. Interview with hiring manager

I was emailed by a recruiter around 2 weeks after applying for a first interview. That went pretty well, only one LC easy and background questions. I was called back for a second round which was supposed to be a day with 4 interviews. They canceled the last one and told me only after I emailed them during the supposed time. The three other interviews were pretty bad, interviewers didn't have their cameras on and didn't seem interested in what I have to say at all.  
I also haven't heard back from them yet.
Applied online in August. Got a phone interview in late september. 2 LC easy. Heard back next day for onsite in late october. 2 LC Medium, 45 min each. 2 Days later got the offer.
First tech round. Introduced myself and was asked for some questions about my resume experience. Then went to the coding session.  I was asked to code for two coding questions.

The interview was a hiring event:
- 3 Coding Questions to complete in 40 minutes
- 4 Virtual Round Interview

Was very disappointed with the recruiters from Microsoft. They send me useful resources for the onsite a day before my actual interview.

After I completed the interviews, the company mentioned that they are interested in giving me an offer and that I should provide my availability. I scheduled the meeting with the recruiter, however, they were a no show.  I sent them an email to understand what is going on, at which point the recruiter stopped answering me. 

If the offer was a mistake in the first place, I would have preferred them to say so, disappointed that this is how the company operates.

The interview process started with an online assessment in Codility. There were three tasks to solve, one easy and two more challenging.

After the online test there was a behavioral interview on Skype, where i chatted with an engineer from MS.

Still waiting to hear back

The interview process was pretty straight-forward. Mine was a bit unique as a recruiter reached out to me personally on LinkedIn. I sent him my resume as well as a confirmation that I had applied for the job. Pretty soon, I had a phone screen, and then went directly to a final round interview a couple months later.

Very hard, lots of questions. Mix of math and behavioral questions. Nonetheless, they were very polite during the entire process, which is something that i really enjoyed. In essence, it was a short and hard process

There was an interview, after some talking, and well you know I think I did good. That's up for debate I guess. Many answers where provided to the many questions, who know what they thought? A dollar in the forest is never as valuable as the dollar in the pocket of the queen.

Had a 45 min phone interview with the recruiter. The behavioural part lasted for about 15min-20min, and the technical question about 30mins. After that I got called to the onsite interview, which consisted of 2 rounds.

two rounds, first round with direct manager, test bq and sql. a typical Microsoft interview, ask about basic behavior questions, project case questions and whiteboard SQL questions
second round with senior manager, basic bq

An online coding test with three questions, 
One related to number digit-manipulation (classic division) , one of string manipulation using recursion and the last one with dynamic  programming of 2dim array, not too complicated but a long implementation proportionally

The first-round interview at Microsoft is a basic phone screen interview. I asked only HR interview questions and no technical questions. I think I was asked about 11-12 questions and the whole interview lasted about 20 minutes. You should come prepared, tho (and not wing it as I did)

Great interview  process 
1. enough time to prepare
2. Steps of list for interview
3. Ask Presentation sample for demonstrating the  marketing tools and strategies.
4. Questions about how much experience 
5. References

Phone screen 1:1 - very smooth, and very nice interviewer but did not pass the interview round. Went over resume first, and moved onto the technical question immediately. Got leetcode easy problem, and finished the interview early.

Applied online no referral. First round was a phone interview. Was told to expect a mix of technical and behavioral questions. The interviewer was very pleasant and friendly. Was notified of final round invitation a week later. 

Final round came around and the coldness of the interviewers caught me off guard. The first interviewer was late and did not introduce himself to me.  He could not figure out how to share his codility link with me. I had to answer all of his questions verbally without sharing any screen. The second final round interviewer talked about himself and then my resume and questions about myself for the first 80% of what was supposed to be a technical interview. At the end he only allowed me around 5 minutes to work on the technical problem through codility. I verbally solved it and said what I would do if I had more time.
Phone Interview went well, asked behavioral and resume questions, the recruiter was very kind and we had a lot in common. Felt great about the call, even if some of the questions made me pause a bit.

The first half of the interview was behavioral (conversation about interests, experience, challenges faced, and parts of resume). The second half was a coding question (a medium). I was to solve it and talk through my understanding of the question.

The process was very clear and nice
They made sure understand the position and responsibility. Told.me about their experience
Tried to do the best to let me to prove my self and also to make sure i want it as well

The interview process was smooth, the questions were mostly based on past experiences, and school/university projects. They wanted someone who had a software background. The questions were mostly based on leadership qualities, strengths, weakness, how did you handle a tough situation, etc.

After 12 interviews, they didn't bother leaving me feedback. They asked me to do case studies and present to them to a total of 5 people.I hopethey can change their for format to make it more pleasant.

Good. Some behavioral questions and some background questions. Mostly the interviewer sounded like they wanted to just get to the technical part quickly. You can tell that that part is the one that determines whether you move on to the next round.

Quite straightforward. Interviewer is nice but application is lost in the pipeline as recruiter (outsourced) left the job or got fired from the job. 
1 phone interview followed by 4-5 onsite (or remote due to COVID)

Contacted by recruiter to do first round of interview. After first round, I had to schedule my final round three weeks out and they wouldn't schedule it earlier for me, plus recruiter wasn't responding to any of my emails. Final round had two interviews, one went ok and one went super well (really liked the second interviewer who possibly will be my manager). Got offer on Monday after interviewing on Friday due to offer deadline.

First round was a phone screen, just general behavioral questions and fairly easy. Second round was three interviews back to back with two managers and one associate. I would recommend understanding everything Microsoft does and their values. Also, don't be intimidated.

Had a phone interview, technical but no algo questions.
Moved on to the final round. had two back to back interviews. The first one went really well. was a leetcode easy. The second one was a leetcode hard. I came up with the solution but didn't have enough time to write it down in code, so I'm guessing that's why I didn't get the offer.

Interview was set up centrally via an automated booking system - fairly impersonal, but understandable given the number of applicants they must have. This was for a 30 minute HR screening over Skype, with standard questions about experience and the tech industry. I then heard nothing until an automated rejection 3 months later, by which point I'd actually forgotten I even applied.  I had expected a more people-focussed approach from somewhere like Microsoft.

Phone Interview for the first round which is a mix of behavioural and technical.

The second round is the final round which contains 2 back to back technical interviews with 2 engineers from your potential org.

The processes wasn't that bad. Although Microsoft took a while to get back to me for a decision, the interview was not that bad. They asked simple questions and want to know more about your experience, which they focused on my resume.
The first step was a phone interview , the recruiter asked me some questions about my resume'.  Also I was asked a simple programming question and also some team work experience.

the interviewers were really understanding and they helped me understand my role if I got accepted really well, The interview's first part was 1 hour long, I didn't do quiet well, on the second part I felt that I did well, but unfortunately I wasn't accepted.

I interviewed for a similar position twice. Every time, the whole process from the HR reach-out or application to making the decision took me over 2 months. The interview was nice though, talking directly to the hiring manager is a lot about who are you, why you special, and if you will win this job. If you are an international applicant, they will do you a visa evaluation, taking about 1 month, by their law team.

Very well organized with clear communications and thoughtful questions and smart interviewers.  Everyone was on time and the interviews were more conversational in nature. They happened over two days which is not uncommon.

1st Round - Phone Behavioral, simple questions about myself, experiences, situational ones
Final Round - 3 back-to-back interviews, problem-solving, behavioral, personal character ones. Was tiring considering three one-hour interviews back to back to back.
I took an online coding test through www.codility.com and then had a skype interview. The internship post was in Israel but the interview was in English with an American interviewer.

Two 45 minute interviews. Started with self-introduction by interviewer and interviewee, and one or two behavioral questions (10-15 minutes). Followed by 20-30 minutes for a technical whiteboarding question. Opportunity to ask questions during remaining time.

First round was online coding test and interview with recruiter. This interview was mainly introductions but I was also asked a brain teaser. 
Four on site technical interviews which focused on different aspects of the role.
Overall It was a good experience as it was my first interview to attend. Questions were tough and i was not well prepared for it. GO PREPARED before any interview. Get to know about the company.
It was my first technical interview and I was anxious. The interviewer was very condescending, and their tone implied that they thought I was stupid. I wanted it to end so badly the entire time.

The interview consisted of one behavioral and three design questions. All three design questions were simple design questions such as designing a parking app for a concert venue, designing a kitchen application for the elderly, etc
The interview included brief questions about my background, and a technical coding question which involved sorting an array in an efficient distributed manner. The length of the interview was 1 hour.

One 30 minute phone call with a screener. Interview was like a casual conversation and the questions were mostly behavioral with 2 design questions. I've heard some people are asked technical questions but I wasn't asked to do any.

1. Apply online through company website
2. Phone screening with a recruiter, included behavioral and design questions. much emphasis around passion for technology
3. Technical interviews - 2 rounds back-to-back, held virtually on Zoom
It was a call interview with problems of sort and linkedlist, also questions about what you need check for a correct function of an ATM. The interview had a duration of 45 min.

HR interview in teams app about 30 min
after that homework 3 questions in 3 levels in 1 hour and 30 minutes.
the students that succeed the exam will get an 2 interviews with team leaders in the office and then HR interview

The interview was unexpected, problems were from Codility, they were not direct as normal interview questions on sites like Leetcode and Geeksforgeeks.
They sounded more like Codeforces problems where you need to read the problem carefully to understand what is needed.

Very professional yet casual interview and engagement process.  The appointment setting is done by another group but they can work with you and find a convenient time.  Good selection process but updates can still be improved and feedback can be provided to candidates.
one phone screen interview no coding general questions like tell me about a project you did  and the hardships you faced.. also why microsoft and how woud you describe recursion to a child

There was a two step interview process.  One technical and the other managerial.  Both heavily focused on interpersonal skills and cultural fit.  And the technical interview added a focus on troubleshooting methodology.

applied through the website. they returned to me after about 2 months and scheduled a video interview with a recruiter from England (not where I live). the interview was 30 minutes and included very dull questions, nothing specific to me or my resume. the interviewer was very nice, but no one updated me after until 3 weeks later when i decided to ask them, then i was told i'm rejected.

A home test followed by an interview with someone from the US, followed by 2 interviews: one about coding and another about design. The coding was about binary trees. The interviewers were friendly and helpful

Interviewer was very nice and straightforward. We talked briefly about my background and quickly worked n the coding assessment. Interviewer gave assistance, such as asking guiding questions when I struggled at some parts. I was allowed to look up documentation.

Interview was long and complex (broken up into 3 parts/45 mins each), but they encourage you to be yourself which made the overall process smooth. By far, the best interview experience I've ever had. Ensure to articulate a growth mindset.

1 - Appel et premiere evaluation de la RH 
2 - 4 entretiens de 45 minutes qui se déroulent sur une demi journée, avec plusieurs managers / pairs. 
3 - Retour positif/negatif apres 1 semaine de delai

Standard process. Phone screen covering CS fundamentals followed by a virtual onsite that included system design and a behavioral round as well. At the end received an offer that was a bit on the lower side for the locale.

I had two back-to-back phone interviews with video calls on Teams.  The first interviewer was more conversational, while the second went straight to the technical question. There was some live coding involved and time to discuss optimizations.

I applied online and heard back from a recruiter to set up a behavioural/coding interview time.
The question was more data structure and optimization rather than arriving at the right answer

Didn't get an offer but it was a great experience overall.  All people I came in contact with were very nice. The recruiter was very supportive throughout the process and let me know of the feedbacks the day after the interview.
I got a call, answered and he talked about what we were going to be doing. After that, we talked about how we are, general ice-breaking, and then the interview questions.

Asked about difficult situations that happened in the past that wanted to know how I overcame it and what did I learn from it. Valuable learning experience was asked over phone before in person jnterview

A recruiter from Europe approached me in LinkedIn and suggested me to apply for the position. The first round was through Skype and I've got a congratulation letter but Microsoft wanted to continue screening the other applicants. In three weeks I've got a message that the other ones better matched the requirements.
The interview was directly with Washington, but the connection in Skype was just terrible and we barely heard each other, we had to repeat answers to each other two or three times. It was very frustrating.

I was given a difficult 3 question assessment which I was able to finish and did very well. The only issue is the recruiter who ghosted on me and its been more than 3 weeks and I have not received any response regarding next step.

Went smooth and the interviewer was quite encouraging. He understood that there is fear and nervousness, so he made sure I was calm and explained the interview question in detail. If you get stuck, they will also help you! great environment

One initial phone screen interview. Then 2 video interviews, could be PM, system design or technical interview questions. I got one system design interview and one PM interview. Interviewers were super nice!!

1. Online coding challenge -- don't remember it too well but it was fairly typical leetcode-type questions
2. Phone screening -- very quick and chill
3. Microsoft Teams video interview -- 3 total interviews, each 1 hour long. One behavioral and two product design.

Very smooth and friendly interview process for college low-level programming job. Well organized, especially during Covid-19. Two step interview, phone screen and then final rounds. Phone screen was a simple behavioral and logical screening, and final round was behavioral with a few programming interview questions.

1. Applied online mid August 2020
2. 1:1 First round interview early September 2020 consisting of 1 30 minute interview over Codility coding
3. Final round interview early October 2020 consisting of 2 45 minute 1:1 interviews over Microsoft Teams coding with some resume questions

Quick turnaround after interviews. Experience with 2 interviewers and HR was pleasant. However, my last interviewer was quite rude (criticized my understanding of the question, explained how other candidates would have coded the question, hung up immediately after answering one of my questions).

In-person interview with executives across the business, focused on sales and technical skills. Scenario based questions to assess sales skills, as well as architecture interviews for the technical aspect. The interviews last a day long, with a chance to meet future colleagues.

long process many interviews, they had a lot of interviews
two 30 minute interviews then "final round"
final round consisted of 4 interviews back to back, technical and behavioural
technical interviews included leetcode type questions and design questions
Lengthy and not according to expectations , asked to join earlier than scheduled time and not responding when joined. Question was of expert level which should not be asked for sde intern profile.
The interviewer was very personable! I very honestly did not expect the interview process to be so smooth and relaxing. The interview was made to be as calm as possible.

I received the interview two days after I applied. I then scheduled for an interview 10 days from that, and it was on microsoft teams. They send me a link while I have to log off to use it. It was pretty hard since the accent wasn't clear and it's hard me to understand the questions.

Codility test followed by HR interview.
passed both, After that they invited me to interview day that included 2 consecutive interviews, and if you path both you get third interview.
the first was codility style questions in your preferred programming language.
the second was  OOP interview, you need to plan and program Battleship game.

2 interviews, first one half fit half coding problem. Second one was a conversation with 2 brainteasers.  Overall enjoyable experience but difficult. Brainteaser was apparently a famous one used by Musk.

After 65 days without any updates and waiting for the result of the technical interview, I receive a reply to my email in half a line that I did not pass.
Horrible experience.
I had my first round as a phone screening round. It was for 30 mins and was with someone from the HR team. Asked me general questions from my resume and digged a bit deep into my previous projects.

The interview itself was great - low stress, casual, and conversational. The overall process, however, was a huge disappointment. My interviewer stated a different follow-up timeline than my recruiter. I figured not a big deal, I’ll patiently wait out both periods, but when I didn’t hear back, I was a bit worried. I reached out the following week to receive a bounce back that my recruiter had left the company. Fortunately, a new contact, I believe the recruiting director, was listed. I contacted her and she said she would get the ball moving. A week later, no word. I decided to follow up once more and was told the recruiting platform should now be updated. Microsoft was one of my top “hopefuls” so it was disheartening to see my application suddenly close.

Informal, questions focused on application design. Choose an app you interact with on a regular basis, and outline its core functionality.  Draw a relationship diagram between features. Will be challenged on what are core features.

codility one easy question
。and bq as well。question is about recursion。。。and design question he said it is bonus 。i did not open the camera， 30 mins， and also a few bq question
The first round is a hr call. It was a 30 minutes long talk to ask about basic background of deep learning and machine learning, as well as several behavior questions.

Only one process until now, zoom interviews ( corona ...)
The next will be coding by codility website  (3 questions in 80 minutes)
And then more three interviews with the team

Fun interview! Did my final round "on-site" remotely because of COVID-19 and talked to 4 PMs. I thought the discussion I had with my interviewers was great and they were very kind people :) Definitely informed my decision to join Microsoft!

I applied online and received an invitation for a phone screen a few days later. 
The  screen call with a recruiter was about 30 minutes and I was asked a mostly behavioral questions (team conflict) as well as a couple of design questions (ex. design a phonebook). 

The final round, which took place about a month after the phone screen,  was two remote 45 minute interviews through a platform similar to Leetcode. I had two technical interviews where I was asked to tell about myself, about projects on my CV and to solve a coding question.

Took about 3-4 Weeks. First interview 45 minutes over Teams. Few technical but mostly behavioral. Be able to tell your story and be yourself. They want to see that you are a team player and a collaborative worker, the knowledge will come with time.

It took forever, 5 months. I lost track of how many people I interviewed with, half of which were over the phone. I think I interviewed with at least 10 people. Then they low-balled me with the salary offer, paying less than I was already making at my current job. Extremely frustrating to say the least.

Scheduled a 30 minute behavioral interview. HR representative called me (late) and asked me a few questions. I answered all of them and thought the interview went fairly well. It was more of a question and answer type of situation and not a conversation. I was not sure whether they understood the technical terms I used as they never asked to clarify when I spoke to about my projects.

The phone screen should be easy enough but the on site was pretty hard. There were two interviews and both interviews was tasking. I was gotten back to the next day though which I think is pretty fast. I got the offer but still acknowledge the interviews were difficult

It was a phone call from a HR representative. She had no real knowledge about the role and department I was applying for, so she couldn't really answer any of my questions and i believe couldn't help her evaluate if I was qualified. She wasn't great at answering culture questions, either.
I applied on the site and 1 week later I got an email in order to schedule my first round interview. The interview was 2 weeks later on Skype and it lasted for 30 minutes.

Applied for the position with a referral, got a phone screen, and got one onsite (virtual) interview. The onsite was the last step of the process. Phone screen was more casual with some guided questions.

At the beginning there are coding exercise and human resources interview (indepedently). If you pass them, there are 3 interviews, first lasts 1.5-2 hours, second 3 hours with coding exercise and 3rd 1.5-2 hours . The topics of the questions in the 1st and 3rd interviews are data structures and algorithms. An interview includes 3-4 questions and the interviewers were nice people.
Normal interview with a few technical questions. Nothing out the ordinary, if you've done these before you will be fine.  Some of them were quite hard and I couldn't answer all  of them.

Applied Online and contacted by recruiter within a week. The process took 2 weeks. It was an easy interview if you come from support background. 2 interviews (1 with technical lead and 1 with Hiring Manager)
Was good had a phone interview first and then moved on to the face to face interview. This was a while back so it may have changed but I'm not too sure.

I was called on with ~40 other students to attend on campus interviews with Microsoft around April. The interview was a pretty straightforward Leetcode question. I didn’t receive an internship for that summer but in about July I was invited to final rounds in Seattle. Over there it was 2 medium level coding questions with a bit of the general “Why do you want to work here” type questions at the beginning. Each interview was 45 minutes.

It was a 10 step process - we learned quite abit about ourselves as well as the company so that was nice I was looking to be more involved in the decision but it wasnt able to showcase the talents of the management searching where I could fit in.

short and quick to the point, they really tested your soft skills rather than hard technical skills t

it was quite easy to connect and the lady throughout the process was very friendly even helping me when I stumbled
It was a good process. I met lots of people. They asked lots of finance-related questions. We had lunch. I met lots of other candidates. It was a good experience.

Hiring manager called me and we talked twice. Never received any feedback, seems like they are interviewing dozens of ppl for each role and don’t even have clear job descriptions. The managers I’ve talked to seemed very drone-like, lacking any personality. I had to contact them to learn that I was not moving forward in the process, let alone they had no feedback whatsoever.

They will Send interview link if they like your portfolio and cover letter. Remote questioning and answering. Very relaxed and interviewer was very kind. I really enjoyed process and would do it again

Informal phone call with the hiring manager. After they called, it was primarily behavioral questions, and then questions specific to research on my resume. Overall very straightforward and low pressure.
Was good I liked how personalised it was. It was just amazing. The interviewers were kind. And friendly. Thats it. I was able to learn a lot. And I appreciated. Now that was it.

Pre-Interview 3 Coding Questions
Interview 1 Coding question, approach mattered not arriving at the correct solution. Was tougher than the preinterview questions. Just keep explaining solutions to the interviewer, he will appreciate your thought process

Extremely unprofessional management. They schedule interview and never on time. You need to wait for 30 mins to be onboarded. They mention that there will be product thinking and design rounds. But the hiring manager will ask tell about yourself and why Microsoft. The round is just to shortlist the profiles only for people who are from north of Vindhyas. Just an eyewash for others. A person who clears 3 rounds of apple and 4 rounds of google interviews can’t clear first round itself due to hiring managers biases. Extremely unprofessional and unethical management. Never ever give interview for Microsoft Bangalore spineless management

Simple and straight forward. A lot of the questions can be answered if you have knowledge of user data and scaleable projects. I don't think anyone with a PM background would do bad on these questions.

There were 5 rounds. First round was an online test with 3 coding questions. We had 90 mins for this round. More than the test cases, it seemed like they look at the code efficiency, for selections. The next round was a pen and paper technical interview. After which was a normal tech and hr round.

Straightforward and transparent. Good communication and scheduling. I spoke with a manager and an employee, both of which were able to answer specific questions about the job and asked good thought provoking questions

Was referred to the role by a friend who was also working as a program manager. All other positions that I had applied to online were not considered. 

Due to Covid, the process was virtual. The interview process lasted a full day with 3 rounds of an hour each primarily focussing on product thinking and customer empathy. In case the 3 rounds went well, a final round with the hiring manager would be scheduled later in the day. 

Each round of the process was taken by senior people in Product Management, with the HM being a director. The process was well organised with clear expectation setting at the beginning of each round. Rather than a series of questions followed by answers, the interviewers made it more conversational and gave me a sense that I was also evaluating Microsoft while Microsoft was evaluating me.
One thing that was clear from the process was that if I got the job, I would be working with really smart people and that excited me the most.

I applied for the program over the summer with the help of a referral. I heard back two months after I applied to do an on campus interview. Normally those would be behavorial but with referrals, we dove to the technical round

It started from 11 AM with the pre-placement talk and continued till 7/8 PM. at first there was a group fly round then two technical rounds and finally the HR round. It was on campus internship interview.

On campus screening technical+behavioral, then onsite final interviews. The onsite interview consisted of only 2 rounds. The first round was purely technical, and the second round was a system design question.

An online round followed by 2-3 technical rounds and a hr round. The online round fairly easy with 3 questions which were pretty basic and the technical rounds were overall of medium difficulty. This was an oncampus interview.

A bunch of rounds with a million people applying for small number of positions . The interviewers seem like they are barely interested in what you have to say. It was also obvious that managers had already picked who they wanted and was just going through the motions.

Was good had a behavioral interview then a final interview. The final interview was two 45 min interviews. The second interviewer I got was extremely disengaged and was even grinning the whole time which create a bad experience. Also, he answered my questions with two word answers. First interviewer was good.

Not difficult, Basic leetcode questions involving trees and mostly string manipulation. No offer most likely because my behavioral answers were abmyssal and i need to work on them, just basic questions which i was not prepared for at all.

There was an online coding round, after clearing that it was followed by the interview rounds (X3), two were technical rounds and one was HR round. In few hours results were declared. Their technical rounds were to check for the basics of Data Structure and algorithms.
