Had a first round phone interview that was approximately 30 minutes, then an on-site behavior and coding mixed interview a few months later in Redmond, Washington. The on-site consisted of two 45 minute interviews with a short break in between.

Smooth and organized. 1 phone with 4 rounds for onsite taking 2 months from application to offer. For my onsite it's an hiring event and you will meet a lot of peers, so good chance for networking also.

Description of my resumé, slowly analyzing and describing my solution to the problem as I went, and some ways to optimize my original solution. At the end you get an opportunity to ask a question or two about the company or the work that the interviewer does.
A test in mttle which consists of english, Aptitude and Questions of CS Fundamentals, followed by a GD round then a technical interview, after that a techno mangerial round then a Director round.

Round 1 .Online test(MCQ) Consisted of 3 parts:English,Aptitude,Technical(OS DSA CN DBMS)
Round 2.Technical Round(Start with a comfortable subject ,mine started with DSA,Java,Coding ),then DBMS and SQL as it was in my Resume,OS and CN were their point of interest .
Round 3. Managerial
Round 4.Managerial
Full day interview with lunch and dinner. They paid for the hotel and meals. They set up 1:1s with all key personnel all day. I gave a 1 hr talk.

Chill Process. Behavioral screen first round. Great interviewer waiting to hear back how it went. Good luck to all of you out there applying to Microsoft! It's a nice process, so hopefully, I get a callback
1-hour phone tech interview. First, we introduced to each other about the background then comes with 1 algorithm problem. During the solving process there's a lot of questions was asked.

An online test round with 3 programming questions.
This was followed by 3 interview rounds .  In each rounds increasing difficulty of algorithm and data structure questions were asked like Heap Sort, Merge  Sort, Quick Sort, Graph algorithm questions,etc . We had to tell algo complexity too along with approach

I was interviewed as part of on campus hiring. First an in person interview on campus, then was asked to fly for a second interview. I didn’t go to the second because I accepted a different job offer.

Everything started very well, but at some point I feel like the interviewer was more interested in terminology than actual knowledge about the area.

No feedback was given, not even that I didn't get the position.

I've been through the phone screen so far, and that was a 30 minutes conversation; first five minutes was introductions, then next 20 minutes were behavioral questions (fairly typical ones just worded a little differently), but they were also targeted to the role product launch, dealing with failure, challenges, etc. The interviewer was a current full time Operations PM, really nice and approachable. I had plenty of time to ask questions and get more direction.

First round was coding round with 3 questions. Time was about 1.5 hrs and those who done all three in good time were selected.

After that was two technical and one HR round.

Online round on mettl. It had 3 easy coding problems. Then virtual interviews on MS teams. There were 2 technical rounds and 1 HR round. Technical rounds asked questions on DSA, OOPS, OS, DBMS. HR round was normal HR questions.

i was selected from microsoft mars colonization program . then we had an interview where i got rejected. Actually after the interview there was direct hiring i guess. The program was quite a great fun , and we didnt make it but

The interview process was held after a coding round. After coding round there were two technical rounds. The intern salary is 80k/month and I sat in the first technical round. I was rejected in that technical round

First I was given a questionnaire to fill out, then several weeks later an phone interview was scheduled. The interviewer sounded uninterested and mentioned that there was an internal candidate currently performing the tasks.

The interview process was long but I enjoyed it.
A total of 5 interviews 2 technical and 2 behavioral and 1 with the HR.
I received the offer and accepts  it  but due to some Visa limitation I was not able to join.

There were 4 rounds in total: 
Coding round - 1 Hr
Online interview - 30 min
Offline test - 1 Hr
HR round - 15 min

Questions asked were of easy to medium level

On campus recruitment
The first round was a online coding test.
After this round certain students were selected for the further rounds.
The next interview round involved writing the code on a piece of paper and explaning the logic to the invigilator. 4-5 people were assigned one invigilator

It was very well conducted. There were 2 technical rounds and 1 hr round. There was the online coding test and a fly round before that. The interviewer was very friendly. One has to be very thorough with their resume

There was one interview with someone from HR, followed by 4 back to back interviews with your possibly future managers. All of them were focused primarily on solving case scenarios. Amazing experience, really nice people.
Straight forward and required some preparation. Would just try your best because they want to see you have a passion for technology and that you'll be a good fit for them.

1st Round. – Online – 30 mins
The first round was an online round which was hosted on cocubes.com. There were 20 MCQ questions. Questions were from a variety of topics like Algorithms, Data structures, C, C++, OOPs, Memory Management, Computer Architecture, etc.

2nd Round. – Online – 1 hour
This was a coding round in which two problems were given.

Problem – 1: Given a word and a text, return the count of the occurrences of anagrams of the word in the text.
For eg. word is “for” and the text is “forxxorfxdofr”, anagrams of “for” will be “ofr”, “orf”,”fro”, etc. So the answer would be 3 for this particular example
Problem – 2: Given a binary tree with parent pointers, find the right sibling of a given node(pointer to the node will be given), if it doesn’t exist return null. Do it in O(1) space and O(n) time.
3rd Round – Group Test – Code on paper – 45 mins
First, we had to discuss the solution with the assigned mentor and then we had to code it on paper(no pseudo code)

Problem 1: Given a BST, one of the nodes violates the BST property( left-child < parent < right child ), return the pointer to that node.
Problem 2: Two no.s having equal no. of digits were given in the form of singly linklist. (For eg.- 102 will be given as 1 -> 0 -> 2 ). Add these no.s and return the answer in the form of a singly linkllist. Do it in O(n) time, given n digit numbers
G
4th Round – Interview
I had to implement a T9 dictionary . insertWord function and populateWords were the two functions which I had to implement on paper(again no pseudo code).
First I have to discuss the approach with the interviewer and then he asked me to code.

5th Round – Interview

He dicussed the work that I did in my last summer internship and after that he asked me to code the maximum subarray problem in one pass.

Lots of 1-1s with hiring manager followed by a panel of managers and scientists onsite. Very friendly and two way interviews.

During covid all was held either by phone or Teams. Fairly easy interview questions, but had a lot of time to ask my questions which was useful in choosing Microsoft.

teams meeting was set up for an interview and they have asked for all the  information about the personal and project details we have to give all the information about the technology we have worked and what the my role in  team all the information

It is quite long, after 2 months after the first interview I got an email that I am not going to the second interview. It was a HR type of interview with questions about myself and my response to some situations that may appear.

3 back-to-back interviews with higher-ups at Microsoft (none of whom I would end up directly working with); they were all behavioral and asked fairly generic interview questions. That being said, all three were highly conversational and felt almost casual – probably one of my favorite companies to interview with

Very polite and prompt recruiter, smooth and quick interview process. 

Hiring team explained the organization and the role clearly, and gave candidate good amount of time to ask questions. The interviewers were also polite and they made sure that candidate feel comfortable during the entire process.

I received an email requesting a virtual interview about 3-4 weeks after I applied for the position. It was conducted over MS Teams and went by fairly quickly. The interviewer was nice and seemed interested in my projects and explanations.

It had one online test and more 3 technical interviews. The first online test was of four parts. The first part consisted of aptitude quantitative and reasoning questions . The second part consists of two coding questions. The third part contained technical mcqs and the last part contained wat.

Applied through their new grad online application in August, no referral. ~ a month later, I did the first interview which as a 1:1 behavioral. From the beginning I let them know of a competing offer. 
2 weeks later I'm notified that I'm moving onto the final round. Though I previously communicated that I had a pending deadline, my interview was never scheduled and my recruiter didn't respond to any of my emails asking for when it was/communicating that this was all time sensitive for me. 
After reaching out to my university recruiter weeks later, the Technical Consulting & Client Success recruiter responded that my final interview would be after my offer deadline and suggested I somehow get a month (!) extension.
A week later, my recruiter emails me again saying that she is unable find an interview time in the next month. She recommended that consider accepting my other offers because she couldn't guarantee that I would even end up interviewing for the position at all.
I never expected this lack of communication and organization from Microsoft, and I am disappointed in the entire process. Why move me to the next round but proceed to not respond or even schedule me into that process?

Applied after attending NSBE conference . Recruiter reached out and asked me to schedule  a 30 minute interview to be conducted via codility.  Interview was pretty smooth.  I was unable to finish the coding question due to time . I got rejected 4  weeks later.

It was alright, not really challenging, they asked just very basic questions  about what i had stidud and what i know of the activites thay re running. 
Basically they wanted to know if o knew the sujbects they wanted to reserch on and if i had any industrial experience

Starts with HR contacting you. If a good fit, then it moves to a conversation with the hiring manager. If all goes well, then you will be moved to speaking with team members. The process is very well organized and structured and fast.

Starts with introduction and went directly to coding question on whiteboard. 3 questions were asked and the interviewer will occasionally help when in difficulty. After question asked, I had a little chat with the interviewer of the task and team that they are going to do.  Ended up not getting the job because the interviewer decided that the task is not in align with my interest.
Got a coding test and an automated email reply. Didn't pass the test but I wish I did so I could write a better review. So here are a few things to know. Hard test good people nice.

Asked a few behavioral questions about work/school experience on my resume.  Also how to store a list of phone numbers, names, and addresses and how to explain a computer to a 5-year-old. The interview was mostly behavioral.

In a word, wonderful. The recruiter was proactive and super communicative. All of the folks I met were picked smart, asked thoughtful questions, and listened to the answers. Overall I was left with the impression that the team truly had each other's backs, and that the company is a remarkable place to work.

Discussion with Hiring Manager on call; discussed the impacts of pandemic and how it will change the way we sell. Focus on territory management and technical capabilities. Esp concern on whether the person can manage architecture level discussion at an exec level

First, a skype interview mainly checking your personality and a coding test with 3 questions.
Then, two separate interviews each is an hour and you are being asked to solve a coding problem as long as some personal questions.
At last, there is an interview with the team manager, which also asks you to answer one coding question - also about an hour.
I was reached out to by a HR manager. I got the interview after 3 weeks. It was simple and had an interview assigned with the team lead within the week.

Four rounds of interviews with direct manager, senior team member and key biz stakeholder thru teams meeting. Total process until offer confirmed takes about 1.5 months. Interviews are all in conversation—no quiz/assignment

Recruiter reached out to me on LinkedIn telling me to apply for role as my experience was a good fit. I applied then messaged them back with a few question which they said they would answer in my first interview. I

First interview didn’t happen till about a month later and it was with a random employee not  even in the role that had apparently volunteered to do first round interviews with candidates. I was told that I had progressed into  the second round and would be contacted soon for a second interview. This was where I was kept in limbo for about two plus months. 

According to recruiter they were interviewing people for second round in the order they had done the first round interviews and due to COVID their timeline has shifted. Got an official update almost three months  that the postions had been filled and their hiring was done for the role. 

Big waste of time

Scheduled a phone interview where I was asked behavioral questions mainly, we talked about  my resume and a research project that I currently work on. It took about 3 months for them to reach back to me to notify me that I will be having a final round interview.

First 1 hour screening interview on Microsoft Teams, with a programming question to solve in a text editor. Then 4 1 hour interviews with four members of the Hololens team, one of program design, 3 of technical programming question.

Online coding  challenge consisting of a few easy problems ,then an online technical interview with 3 different engineers where they give you a problem and you have to solve it on an online code editor while discussing your approach.

Straightforward and largely dependant on the Interviewer. The Coding round was easy enough, The first round interviewer was cheerful and supportive, But the next interviewer took 6 hours to show up, was cranky and did not indicate the correctness of the solution,

The interview is a bit too much for a low-class opportunity in Egypt. 
This is a non-known lab it is not really "Microsoft". However, they will go through a lot of processes, and in the end, you will only be contingent staffed? 
It is silly and the process is too much for a no-name lab., that hires people as a contingent staff while making use of the "Microsoft" name.

Interview process is very informal and almost nothing was clear to me throughout the process, even after asking and complaining. You are always at the mercy of Hiring manager to give you no details. Despite having good interview rounds , heard nothing. Seems like they hire only the folks they know prior the job opening.
It was good. Just a few tell me about yourself questions. Asked about stacks and trees. Asked few Oop questions. Then asked why I wanted to join Microsoft, coming from electronics background.

After initial screening interview, I was invited to a full day of interviews on spot. It took place on a working day. I was interviewed by 5 people. I found this all being way too much for one hiring process. The interviewers were very nice though and I had a lunch with local manager. Most of interviews were standard engineering questions. Last interview I personally completely disliked, because it was not so much of a technical one, but obscure task that had no right or wrong answer.
Nothing special the process is standard you need referral for an interview but if you afe ideal you better study cs or engineering otherwise no suitable job in Microsoft china

There are 4 stages in total including a pitch presentation of a case study about Microsoft's product. Questions are around Microsoft's culture and the job description. Everyone was very professional and friendly!

The process was HR interview + codility test. after that there's two more technical interviews. 
The HR interview was in English with an HR lady from UK. Codility test was 90 min

1st stage: Technical interview to demonstrate search techniques such as Boolean an X-ray. 
2nd stage: Competency interview to demonstrate MS growth mindset.

Interview process took 1 week in total and feedback was delivered within 24hrs.

Pre-contract verification process includes background check (career history) and criminal record check.

1. 30-min phone call with hiring engineer on Codility. Question was related to string manipulation. Followed up with 1-2 behavioral questions, what is your team preference.
2. 3 final interviews. Each round consists of both technical and behavioral questions. I was asked about BST to which I'm not very good at. I could feel that I already failed the interview.
3. Got rejected after 1 day.

Interviewer with a friendly and comfortable manner, general questions about my aspirations and a couple of problem-solving scenarios regarding technical sales. Overall a pleasant experience, even if I wasn't chosen.

Microsoft Interview Experience: Simple traversing binary tree question, followed by questions one would expect like "Why do you want to work at Microsoft?", "What is your tech experience/background", "What excites you about tech?", ect.
The interviews were rescheduled multiple times and then HR does not bother to inform about the same on time. This should be improved. Interviews are fine though and the people are good.
Em geral, considerei bem justo com o job description. As perguntas sao bem voltadas pela experiencia que voce descreve em seu curriculo. Sao normalmente 3 entrevistas tecnicas uma seguida da outra.

written exam
technical round
managerial round
hr round
Where do you see yourself in next 5 years, 15 years and 25 years?
Questions on family background.
Strengths and Weaknesses.
Questions on the facts mentioned in the CV.
One phone interview with recruiter. Did not hear back for 3 months after that. The recruiter would not respond to email followups. Finally, received an automated rejection. Did not like the process.

I had my interview over a programming based chat software. It was pretty much only technical and no behavioral for the first round. My interviewer would help me out a little bit if I was stuck but didn't really guide me towards a solution.

The interview process is straightforward. You would expect an uptight attitude, but their staff was really great, and friendly, minus the new, freshly joined manager. Initial rounds were more turned towards the personality match.

I interviewed in Oct 2020. The interview process was pretty standard. It has 1 technical OTA and a virtual onsite round. The questions were all similar to Leetcode. The recruiting process was smooth. 
Questions:
3 Leetcode
1 System Design

Amazing and very 'easy'. It was all behavioural and basically they want to make sure that you have a growth mindset. I definitely suggest reading Satya's book because it gives a great overview of the company's culture

Recruiter reached out via LinkedIn.
Scheduled initial telephonic round with a developer within 1 week. Didn't allow any preparation time.
It was a coding round over codility for 45 mins. Asked Medium difficulty leetcode question and some Android questions in the last 15 mins.

After that scheduled virtual onsite round after 2 weeks, consisting of four 1-hr interviews.

All questions were medium difficulty leetcode problems.

Received offer within a week.

First got in HR interview. The interviewer had NO idea about the position!!
Then they sent me online test and for me this is so disrespecting to the candidate, give us people to talk to and share ideas with!

I was reached out by a recruiter through LinkedIn. The first round of interviews was with a Director of Communications. The final round consisted of three 45 minute interviews with members on the marketing teams.

Conversation facile et intéressante avec différents tours et tests sur mes capacités à faire évoluer et à développer l'entreprise, ainsi que des questions techniques.
Processus différent et facile à suivre, la redaction d'une présentation assez complete sur son parcours Prut également être demandée

Two rounds, both remote because of COVID. First was leet code easy 30 minutes with one behavioral question. Second was 2 x 45 minute interviews.  The two interviewers were really nice, asked me about my extracurriculars and technical questions.

Online coding test - easy, three questions. Three technical interviews. HR Round. DSA Questions were of moderate difficulty. Little to no discussion on CS fundamentals. Interviewers were friendly and helpful during the entire process.

The interviewer asked me to introduce myself followed by which she asked to be to explain one of my projects.Then, 
I was asked a DSA Question. I had to explain my approach and write the question in any code editor

Amazing experience - loved the interview set up and meeting talented members of the team. Everyone was really kind, and made me feel heard. 

I did 3 separate interviews, each an hour long, and was able to ask my own questions at the end to get a better feel for the companies culture.

30 min first round -> Onsite (2x 45 min technical)
overall easy interviews but it depends on your interviewers to be honest...you may even get more design pm style questions than technical LC

Behavior phone screen. Simple 30 minute conversation regarding past projects and why I am pursuing software engineering. Was also asked about why I wanted to work at Microsoft and my favorite Microsoft product.  The interview wasn't very technical was the exception of a few questions related to CS fundamentals.
I applied and heard back after 2 weeks. I found most of the interview questions on Glassdoor. The interview was really straight forward. The recruiter was very helpful with the process.

The interview process included first, a phone call and then a single day of three back to back interviews averaging 45 minutes each. It wasn't all the stressful and I had been doing prep for big consulting firms simultaneously so I was very prepared for what turned out to be just a number of behavioral interviews.

Fairly easy, first round was phone interview what you would expect in a PM interview. second round was technical and it was on a group call...I got my question wrong but because I was vocal I got the role

basic dsa, DBMS, and easy-medium interview. I cleared the interview. It was an on-campus opportunity. There were 3 rounds 2 tech rounds and one tech+managerial round. Each round was of 40-45 mins of time.

The process contains at least three different stages.
The first one in a test: the test conatins 3 questions and has to answered within 1.5 hrs.

the questions were sorted from the easy (q1) to the hard (q3). 
At least one of the questions was about strings.

Didn't finish the proccess.

First I had a phone call with HR for behavioral questions and some design questions. Then the final round had two interviews, one behavioral/projects and the second was technical/coding. They gave me an  easy leetcode problem and asked me some questions about the problem to solve.

Highly intensive, over 6 months long, multiple interviews including coding tests, HR reviews etc. to screen candidates. Got a reject initially but I mailed them and asked them for an additional coding test. Made it finally. Persistence pays!
1st round was at NBMBA, 30 minutes of behavioral questions. 2nd round was on site 7 weeks later with 3 back to back interviews. Got the offer 3 days after.

- A zoom interview with someone from around the world, interview in English 
- A zoom interview with someone from the team that I was interviewing for with technical questions
After the second interview there is another technical interview with the head team, but I didn't pass the first one.

Much less technical than I had expected, they were more focused on finding out how you think rather than what you already know. Mostly behavioral questions with some technical questions scattered throughout.

The interview had 3 rounds of technical questions. In the first round, they asked a question about strings. In the second round, they asked a question on the maximum sliding window. In the third round they asked questions from operating questions.
One coding test, two technical rounds and one HR round each round took place virtually and the coding round was taken on mettl and the others on teams. the interviewers were great.

The interview is okay. Make sure you communicate your thoughts properly and most importantly stay calm. I answered all questions related to Algo and DS but fumbled 1 easy math question. So just stay calm.

I sat for on-campus internship for SDE role at Microsoft.
The Preliminary Round consisted of a online coding test which had 3 questions to be solved in 90 minutes. They were pretty easy  (kadane's algorithm, easy-medium leetcode.).

I was selected for 1:1 interviews. Round 1 was just to check whether the candidate can code and explain the time complexity and be able optimize the code. I was given a easy problem on string manipulation.

Round 2 was when things got serious. I was questioned on my resume, previous internships, projects for about 20-25 minutes. After that I was given a grid path finding algorithm(application of BFS, DFS). There were a few extra conditions and also required to print the path etc. I wrote a BFS approach, the interviewer asked for some runs on hypothetical data. I was also asked time complexities of BFS and DFS approaches and if one of them was better than the other. The Interviewer seemed satisfied. 
I was offered the SDE Intern role some hours later (yeah, just 2 rounds).

1 coding round - 3 questons to be completed in 90 min
3 technical rounds-Ask about your projects(if any), general introduction and optimized solution to coding questions, go through your resume thoroughly

It was a very casual remote interview. The interviewer was in a different country which made the interview unique in a good way. The interviewer made it more like a conversation and mixed in some easy questions along with the big questions.

the first round was an online coding roundwhere we had to solve 3 questions related to competetive coding which was followed by technical interview and finally a hr round for an on campus internship as a software engineer.
We had a coding round first and the interview process had 3 rounds via Microsoft Teams. The first 2 rounds were based on Data Structures and Algorithms and the last one was an HR round
The first round was 30 minutes interview with Microsoft teams with one of their UX developers. It was great but mostly in rush. I did not get the internship position.

An internal recruiter contacted me regarding a position, and we scheduled a phone interview.

The specific role that she contacted me about required experience with Azure, which I don't have, so it wasn't a good fit.  Neither my resume or Linkedin profile mentions Azure, so I don't know why she contacted me for this position in the first place.  I guess my profile popped up in a keyword search and she was too lazy to read it in detail.  Or maybe she has an activity quota to meet.

However,she did say that there are other AE positions that I would be a good fit for, and she asked me to complete  pre-screen  questions that she forwarded to my email.  There were 17 questions that covered topics related to technology and sales experience and expertise, as well as HR questions related to travel expectations, citizenship, etc.  It took about an hour to complete.

I submitted my responses and haven't heard a thing about the positions that are supposedly a good fit.  The recruiter hasn't responded to a follow up email. 

This recruiter is very pleasant, positive, and raises expectations.  But like most recruiters, this is phony and she is a time waster. Common courtesy and professionalism is a one street. Expected from you, but not reciprocated by them.

The process was quite long, phone interview, AC, and then an interview with the manager.  The phone interview was about some behavioral questions and some questions about the technology at Microsoft. Make sure to know about Microsoft's mission and its goals.

The first round was supposed to be in 30 mins and to be behavioral plus case interview but nothing similar happened. They asked me 2 coding questions in 30 mins, what I was not prepared for at that time.

A recruiter actually reached out to me about this position months before the application came out. I had a phone interview in late July/early August with the recruiter I was corresponding with, primarily discussing the role and my past work experience to see if I'd be a good fit. About a month later, I participated in a Microsoft Teams meeting where several prospective interns (for varying roles) came together to ask current employees questions about the process and other details we wanted more clarity on.  Soon afterwards were the final round interviews. For the specific internship I was applying to, I had three 45-60 minute interviews with  individuals who were the decision makers of whether I'd be hired or not.

I applied online, the process took about a month
1. Speak with the recruiter about your background 
2. Speak with the hiring manager and walk through some of your projects 
3. Portfolio Panel (1hr) and 4-5 1:1 Interviews (1hr each) and a 1hr break

Great process that has clear communication, interview set up and feedback. Everything worked as communicated and all interviewers were really professional and asked great questions. You can also access the MS portal to track steps and upload your information.

Submitted the application online and requested a former colleague refer me. Recruiter reached out to set up a screening with a recruiter. 

Future interviews included:

second step: hiring manager, 

the third step: loop with four 1:1 interviews, including hiring manager.

participated only in the first interview of the process: phone screen interview and online test.
the interviewer was very nice and it was a good experience.
the online test had 3 questions. One is easy and the rest of them were easy-medium.

1st interview only:
It was a quite smooth and good experience, the interviewer made the questions feel different from any other questions I ever had by mixing my interest, for example, I was asked about how to manage a team if one of the members was Tony Stark (A fictional character from MARVEL).  This interview was behavioral. Still waiting for the second interview
The interview was quick and done virtually. They asked me a little bit about my past and asked me to code a quick piece of data structures. The process was fluid and felt quick and a little rushed.
i has 2 interviews, first one was with the team i might join, second one was with Support Manager (EMEA), both interviews were not deeply technical as the job itself did not require this

The process was very fast; I heard about the results within a few days after the 1st and 2nd(final) interview. Recruiters were very helpful in answering questions about what to expect and the interviewers were all fantastic.

Had three rounds. All the rounds were technical and had questions where we were asked to write a code and a few questions about projects done. The interviewers were friendly and tried to maintain a casual atmosphere.

The interviewer was very nice. I got an initial email, then had a phone interview. The phone interview was 1 hour, and consisted of 3 general behavioural questions, followed by questions regarding the role and the company. I did not proceed to the next round.
I applied using a referral I got. Recruter reached out to set up an appointment for the first initial phone screen and now am at the final round of the interview.

Intern Conversion with 1 Lead and 1 AA.
Lead: About 1 hr 20 min, LeetCode 1 medium + 1 hard + system design.
AA: About 50 min, mostly talked about career path, school projects, and intern experiences.

I was contacted directly by a recruiter after they had seen my resume at a conference that Microsoft attended to schedule a first-round interview! I submitted my application to their portal and then was prompted to schedule the interview through their website. 

The interview took place over 30 minutes with someone within a Product Marketing team at Microsoft over Microsoft Teams.

Very simple process. After applying, they will contact you for a phone call interview (first round) which lasts about 30 minutes. Fully behavioral. I waited five weeks to hear back from them, for them to tell me that I have moved on to the next round. I waited another 4 weeks for them to give me an interview date. Then, out of nowhere, they tell me that I have been rejected because the role has been filled. I just accepted another job offer because Microsoft recruiting is the most unnecessary waiting time I have ever experienced for campus recruiting. What a joke of a process.

Interview experience was excellent:
I went through all the rounds of interview and all the interviewers were extremely happy and even said “we look forward to have you in our team”

However, I didn’t get any reply from recruiter after following up multiple times.
I found it extremely unprofessional, specially when i am interviewing with a company like Microsoft.

Contato por linked in, conversa breve com RH, depois entrevista com o manager da posição e um(a) diretor(a) par do(a) mesmo(a). No final, um email automático dando a negativa, sem argumentos, nenhum contato da recrutadora, mesmo após eu ter tentado contato com a mesma. Um grade descaso

1) Online Coding Round which consists of 3 coding questions for 90 minutes

3) Technical - 2 Interview A similar round which could include a system design question and some theory questions.
4) HR Interview Round
I think it was perfect. Microsoft asked from me theee prograaming questions via Codility. I did all of three. I think, this was the first stage. There will be another interview.

Series of questions about how you would respond to certain situations, your view on certain technology-related things, etc. Not a lot of interest in your background or experience; the decision is based on your answer to those questions

une grande bienveillance tout au long de la journée

Interview loop consisted of going from office to office, talking to 5+ engineers, and mostly solving coding problems on the whiteboard, in real time.   Additionally, some "brain teaser" type questions were asked.
First home test,  after Skype interview (English),  and after two or three technical interviews. In the first one they asked questions like in leetcode(medium level). The interviewer was impatient.

Un premier entretien téléphonique RH suivi d'une journée d'entretiens lors de laquelle on rencontre différents managers pour un entretien avec consigne et support à préparer et présenter, un entretien technique et un entretien en groupe. Il est possible d'avoir un entretien supplémentaire si notre profil intéresse une autre personne.

It was good, interviewer was friendly. They had two online rounds followed by onsite rounds. Onsite had a group coding round and then two interviews before the final HR process. Need good coding skills.
The process showed that they are looking for a very homogeneous environment. Almost no questions were geared toward the non-analytical aspects of the job, like contributions to company culture.
2 rounds: first round and final round, first round was a phone technical interview. I didn’t get past the first interview but if you’ve taken data structures and algorithms you definitely can.

I went through a phone screen which consisted of LC med and LC hard, the next step was the interview, the first interviewer asked 4-5 LC questions in quick succession, ranging from Med to hard, for some I had to write the code, others they just wanted to check for the approach. 
I was asked system design questions on finding the bottlenecks in a system with a given parameters and had to come up with a solution to mitigate the answers

I applied online in September 2018. In  February 2019,  I received an email from a recruiter asking for additional information to set up a phone interview. I talked to a FTE who basically asked about what I study, why Microsoft, etc. I made it through to the next round for in person interviews. I flew out to Redmond where I did a presentation of my portfolio to a group of FTEs and then after lunch I had 3 interviews, each 45 minutes with the people who saw my presentation. I answered questions about my work ethic, my experience, and how I approach problem solving. Less than a week after that, I received my internship offer.

Initial short talk with follow up on location with group interview. 5 people collaborating, finding solutions. Full day with a couple 1-on-1 talks in addition to the group tasks. A bit difficult to know exactly how you should stand out during the day, I didn't feel like I managed to prove my skills.

Needed to create a MS Sway introducing myself. Who pass the Sway around will proceed to interview round. Two phone interviews in the same day. One with the team manager and another with a team member. Those who pass the interview round will be offered a place in the internship.

Glassdoor's description of the first round is pretty much right -- questions might be worded more uniquely, but pretty standard. Expect more unique questions in the final round. They'll fly you out to Seattle and the teams choose their own questions.
Interview process was really fine. Nice people very respectful and kind. I was asked some questions and i gave some answers like any other interview i guess. That is it i think.

Applied through referral, i was based our of hyderabad at that time, two rounds of phone screens were there before calling for F2F, there were 5 rounds of in-person interviews, majority of them based on resume and experience and couple of case questions.
It was okayish. There were 3 rounds - 2 coding rounds and one HR round. The interviewer of the second round was friendly but first and third round's were strict . Overall it was a good experience.
The interview process is them getting to know you. Once you have done your research, all you need to do is be confident and friendly and you’re in good shape.
It was good. Definitely fair. I'd say good. I do not have much else to say other than the fact that it was quite good and definitely fair.  Thus, to summarize, it was both good and fair.

Had an initial call/screen. Then had interviews with various managers. It was nearly a day of interviewing but was very enjoyable. The process actually taught me a lot about the company and they even had suggestions to help me improve in the future.
I submitted my resume and one week later I got an interview. It's a virtual interview with 3 managers because of Covid 19. They asked five to eight questions. Thing is going normally.

First call is usually with a Pre screening recruiter to review your resume, general fit and interest in the position as well as a check on salary range expected. Then passed to hiring manager for over-the-phone followed by in-person interview with job stakeholders (5 to 6 interviews in one day).
On-campus 30-min technical interview followed by an onsite consisting of three back-to-back interviews. One of my interviewers became my manager and another one was a SWE II on the same team.

A phone interview,  Online coding assignment and a Microsoft Teams interview with a team leader.
on the phone interview i was asked about my favorite coding languages and simikar questions.

first round was 3 questions you have to get atleast 2.5 correct to qualify into next round.next round is group fly round . I got rejected there and I was not able to go to next round

Gut und professionell. Kurze Wartezeiten und reichlich Verfplegung. Schwierige Fragen zu technischen Details des Software Engineering. Mehrere Interviewer im Laufe eines Nachmittages. Ich musste auch eine Whiteboard Coding Übung zu Algorithmen machen.

coding test,                               telephonic round,3                     onsite  interviews

Simple but long-drawn. There was a total of 3 interviews to get the sales position. Everyone was extremely kind and understanding; they made the process a lot more manageable. The interviews themselves were simple, but the process of serving them up & going through them all took about a month+

They were all meant to test different skills so that they could make a better decision. Overall, it was a fun but stressful process.

I was reached out to by recruiter for a phone interview. I was then connected with the hiring manager for a phone interview and general connect before moving to interview loop.

Applied online through my university, had the first round interview, and did not qualify for the second round. Others qualified for the second round and were flown out to Seattle, Washington.

I am not in the market or looking for employment as I am a private consultant and have been for more than 5 years. The interview did not seem serious from the start. 3 people each between 20 and 35 minutes each with not much questions. No interview by hiring manager. I sensed this was a waste of time. This is shameful as it plays on people's emotions and expectations and shows no respect or regard!

one phone screen, invited to superday that consisted of 4 interviews each lasting around 30-40 minutes. mostly testing culture fit with some basic finance questions. Overall, was very laid back and would not stress if you know your basics and are a good conversationalist.

Started a internship then I Back my feedback firstly I conduct my interview then talk everything so what about your opinion fir this internship good or bad .

The first interview is a 30 minute call where a recruiter asks you behavioral type questions. I was offered the final interview, however I have not had it yet. I believe you meet with two recruiters for 45 minutes each.

The interview process was very smooth and I felt well informed along the way. First there was an online coding challange (consisting of 3 leasy/medium eetcode algo questions). Next there was an HR video call, mostly behavioral and a logical problem to solve. Following was the final round of interviews which consisted of 4 back to back interviews with 4 different people. 1 was mainly behavioural, 2 system design, 1 algo & data structures. 

All in all, all the interviewers were very nice and friendly, trying to help you as much as they could and answer any questions. 

I interviewed for a position to Prague.

It was a conversational style interview, with not many surprises.  I thought it was going to be more HR stuff, as the recruiter told me the loop would be with global talent, but it was all technical.  Once I got through the shock of the change, I was good.

First you get an email asking you to solve a Codility test (with 3 coding questions, Leetcode style) and inviting you to a 30 min interview in English with a recruiter from abroad.

first one was with a nice interviewer he was helpful and patient, asked two leetcode question:

30  min - 1 hr phone call. Asked questions very similar to posts that others have shared here. My recruiter made the interview process feel like a conversation more than an interview. Phone call first round interview.

While this team doesn't have a location preference, other parts of the MS org do prefer to have candidates relocate to the Seattle area. 

While the hiring team was lovely, my negative experience stems from interaction with the recruiter.
She called me on Sunday night during the Thanksgiving weekend to schedule an interview for the next day. And then ghosted me after the final round. The hiring manager mentioned that the outcome will be decided before the year end break.  I felt disrespected and undervalued.
my friend from university recommended me for the job. they called me and then scheduled an interview.  the interviewer was late and in a rush and he asked me about subjects that i never learned
Test conducted at mettl platform. 3 questions to be solved in  90 minutes.First 2 were string manipulation questions and third was a 2*2 grid problem. The difficulty level was easy easy hard.

it took three weeks. one phone call, one online tests, and two interviews. (both of them using Microsoft teams due to covid.  the first one was with a developer from the team, the second with the team leader.

Very well managed interview in Seattle. Helped me improve as a developer. Stay at the hotel was really nice and the lobby was great. The interviewers were stern faced at first but after going back home I realized they were trying to help me.

It was great. Initially involved updating videos on various questions. After that I went through an interview process with general passion and interest questions. After the interview process, I was informed about the result. Easy and quick process.

An external recruiter, to which Microsoft seem to have offloaded all recruitment work approached me with the SRE role opportunity. I showed disinterest as I'm a backend developer looking for backend role. He insisted that I should try as the role is backend centric and not to be misled by the title. I agreed to take it up.

Within a week I got a call informing about the interview to be scheduled in next 3-4 days. Dates are not changeable. No other way but to go ahead with it.

I had 2 round over the "Microsoft teams". I was asked to keep my video and screen sharing on (to ensure that I'm not cheating) whereas the panels didn't have their video on. I was specifically asked to share the whole screen and not just one window.

Contrary to what recruiter made me believe, both the rounds were SRE centric Trivia and to most of the questions I kept responding that I didn't have enough knowledge on those topics. Interviews ended soon enough after some basic programming questions.

Overall experience: 
1. The recruiter's info was misleading. Representing Microsoft it'd be the poorest professionals I've come across.
2. One of the panel on the call itself informed me that I'd be better suited for Backend role than SRE. When I said I was hoping for it to Backend centric role, the panel said he'll inform about this to the recruiter. Generally it's not wise to communicate the feedback by the panel. The panels were not trained for interview process.
3. Both the panels as mentioned in another Glassdoor post: were at the same level they were hiring for. Which creates prejudice. Most of the time panels overlapped and cut me off while I was speaking. Picked one word from my response and asked next questions without even letting me finish.
e.g: 
Q. How does redis Ensure persistence?
A. Data is kept in-primary memory but it allows snapshots to be taken at...
Q. What is a snapshot?

The Process was well organized and started on time and the interviewers were very calm and professional. First, there were two rounds in the beginning and after clearing it there as  another round which I did not clear

did not got selected due to Eligibility. Applied online and after somedays recieved mail that i was ineligible for the job. did not got selected due to Eligibility. Applied online and after somedays recieved mail that i was ineligible for the job.

I got a phone screen (basic background), then a technical interview.  It all happened online due to COVID-19, over Microsoft Teams. The technical screening was there to gauge your knowledge level before moving on, it was quite challenging and then there is another stage afterwards.

Total Rounds: 4

Round 1:  An online programming test on mettl.com  consisting of 2 easy questions and 1 medium question.
Q1. Solve a postfix expression.
Q2. A straightforward question to sort the array and find the difference between certain elements.
Q3. Calculate the mean, median, and mode of a given array of numbers with precision.

Round 2: A technical interview where I discussed my projects and a question based on the application of data structures.

Round 3: A technical round with questions on strings and different variations of the "buy-sell stock" problem.

Round 4: A technical and behavioral round. There weren't programming questions but we had a discussion on encryption(in messaging apps and video streaming platforms). 

Note: I do not have any hardcore knowledge of encryption rather, I only knew what is encryption and where and why it is used. Later, he explained to me a few topics on encryption and then asked me questions based on it.

I interviewed during the pandemic for a Software Engineer position at the Atlanta office.

The process took 2-3 weeks.

The initial talk with the recruiter went well and was mostly focused on my background.

The next step was a phone screen with a Senior Engineer in Redmond. This interview was very different from what I was used to. Essentially I was asked to describe my solutions to 2  semi-easy coding questions. 

After surviving that I had a virtual on-site interview with 5 different interviewers.  The first 3 sub-interviews were coding based (with a few behavioral questions thrown in) and  I did pretty well on 2 of them.  The 4th interview was the typical developer behavioral interview. My 5th and final interview of that session was with the Hiring Manager, and this is probably where I ended up falling short. This particular manager was the head of a team that was particularly focused on customer satisfaction.

The rejection email said this:

"...you performed well like coding and problem solving, but didn’t meet expectations in areas like adaptability and customer focus which are critical competencies for our engineering teams to be successful"

Not entirely sure what that means but I guess that's why I'm not Microsoft material.
Great interviews; they are more interested in people rather than the background. 3 rounds, and all of them focus on me, my purpose, and my abilities to pursue all my goals.

It was virtual interview for software developer role, I was socked to see the question he asked, the reason being it was Google's interview question. For 6+ years of experience who don't have Leet code practice asking such type of question is really tells that Microsoft India don't have any guidelines for interviewers. I checked his linkedIn profile and found out that he was from ordinary background and most probably interviewer was itself preparing  google.
There were mainly 3 rounds , 2 tech and 1 hr, but there was a lot of variance in the interview process as the interviews were not very helpful and were not able to understand the replies.

It consist of 3 rounds 
1st  Round was the coding round whuch has 3 questions and the other 2 rounds were technical . All the question were easy. I did all the three question and selected for the next round

The interviewers were not friendly: In one of the interviews, the interviewer was very arrogant and was not clarifying the questions properly. After starting to discuss my approach to the question, he was asking too many unnecessary cross-questions and was not letting me proceed to code. 
Even after coding the solutions to the problems properly, I was not sure why I was rejected. Instead, some of my friends who were stuck in standard questions in one round were selected.
Gender Bias: A lot of preference was given to female candidates. Most of the selected candidates were female candidates.

Had a phone interview. Passed it easily. However, during the onsite interview, the interviewers were unclear and one of them gave me a second problem when time was almost over. So I felt they were not considerate.
The interview process was quite nice. I only had one interview of around 30 minutes in which he asked me about the program I applied for and some basic coding questions. It was a fun experience

There was an initial phone screening, and then 4 rounds of interviews (ranging from behavioral to technical questions). The interviewers asked questions to get to know you and your interests in the company.

Overall It was good experience. I went through total 4 rounds but didn't hear anything after last round. Last round was mostly  design and coding. I was asked to design a multiplayer online game and them implement one class.

did a virtual interview and went through 2 questions. only got through one. I applied through recommendations from fellow students early in the process before major career fairs which were nice. The interviewer was nice but problem difficult.
Initial phone Screen followed by take home exercise. Given five days to complete the take home excercise. The interview was casual in nature and conducted in a  professional nature. Prompt.

3 days of interviews, mostly behavioral and how you perform in work situations. Some people has to prepare presentations but I did not. I mostly answered questions about my desire to work for social justice projects.

There were several (6) stages to the interview process. The recruitment team could do a better job of managing candidates expectations throughout the process as too often they failed to update candidates or provided feedback.

Sadly the process lacked structure.

One coding round and after getting short listed , few coding interviews (Along with CP questions ,they ask about resume , the projects u have written and the courses u have studied , ask questions on basic C++ language and OOPS concept , the CP questions are from easy to medium level )

Interviewing at Microsoft has been one of the worst experiences of my career. You will typically get a screening interview with a recruiter and maybe one other person. Then, you will be put into a “loop day” where you go through several interviews in one day. You will then get a decision. Each of these are supposed to happen quickly, and if you are not chosen during the loop day BUT they like you, then you are supposedly put into a queue for the next position.

Preguntas acordes al puesto. Experiencias previas en atención al cliente corporativo, experiencia en tecnologías de la infromación. Evaluación de conocimientos acerca de los productos de la compañia. Se realizaon varias entrevistas y el proceso es llevadero y con un gran acompañamiento del candidato.

The total process consisted of 4  rounds where the first one was a coding test which consisted of 3 easy-medium questions .
And post this round result, there were 3 rounds conducted of which 2 were technical and 1 hr round..

Round-1(Online Coding Round):

The recruiter sent me the link for the test on Monday and asked me to complete it by Tuesday if I wanted to get an invite for the drive on Friday.
Codility Platform, 2 Coding Questions, 70 minutes
It was just an eligibility round. Anyone who scored more than 50% was invited for the placement drive.
Placement Drive

The interviews started at 9AM on a Friday. Each round was an elimination round.
After each round, I got a call from the Recruiter with the details of the next round.
Each Interviewer will give some time in the end to ask questions. Try to be prepared with some questions.

Very much technical, deep probing on business aspects and relating it back to CRM functionalities. most of the questions were on crm customizations, data porting, integration with crm api, scheduling tasks, etc.

Coding round(3 questions)
Technical rounds-2
Hr round-1
Was mostly focussed on DSA , OOPS, aptitude- not so difficult to crack but do focus on basic concepts they can be twisted and asked indirectly.

Asked a balanced bst question. 
- Given few numbers put them in a balanced bst.
- Interviewer was friendly.
- Hints were given if struck.
- At last a small talk about resume.

Open Source contribution to a GitHub repository with a minimum of 100 stars. Only coding contribution not cleaning/ changing documentation. Then after the submission you get called for an interview to present your solution to the open source problem and in turn explain how you did it under whose mentorship in how much time.

Easy interview. only one 45 minute conversation with the hiring manager or someone of the same level at Microsoft. Go through Aerotek if you contract. They pay the best. They hire many people straight out of college for contract positions. Everyone is very nice and training is great. However, they do not convert contractors very often, if ever. They do offer 18 month contracts with good pay and you will have lovely Microsoft managers. It is great experience a resume and they always hire pervious contractors for 2nd and 3rd contracts. You are more likely to be considered for full time after a few contracts or after full time experience elsewhere.
