The entire process took about 1 month with a series of interviews. Most of them focused on behavioral and situational questions

Three rounds of technical interviews were conducted. I was expected to write a working function and give optimizations in terms of space and time complexity. It was a great learning experience for me. Always keep in mind, your interviewer is your friend and will help you through the problem if you ask the correct questions.

Received call from recruiter to complete a series of tasks for the initial process of hiring on the codility platform. The tasks themselves where of average difficulty with the exception of one debugging task.
It all happened in one day only. We were called out at 10AM and it ended at 3AM the next day. There were 40 candidates in total out of which 25 were selected at the very end.

There was an online test on "mettl" platform and consisted of 3 questions. They were just concept based. Then there were 2 technical rounds and 1 HR round. 
In the first round, the interviewer asked me a question based on depth first search and told me to implement it. He asked me what were the edge cases and how your code is able to handle them.
In the second round, I was asked a question based on map and he kept asking me for different approaches and optimizing the code.
Third round was casual, he asked me few questions about my project.

Note: All of them asked me to introduce myself and describe the projects that I had done.

I went through about 7 total interviews over about 2 weeks virtually. The process was very thorough and a wide range of questions were asked from basic technical questions pertaining to troubleshooting to  more advanced people management skills and ideology.

One coding round  consisted of 3 questions 
Three technical interview rounds
One HR Round

Coding round was easy.S  o were Techn  ical ones. They hir  ed in big number.It was good experience overall

Online test, Group discussion followed by three interview rounds which hand questions from Networking, troubleshooting, operating systems, and basic linux and Unix commands were asked. The difficulty level was medium to high. They were trying to test the basic knowledge

I had two rounds of interview - one technical and another HR, in a span of 15 days. In the technical interview, I was asked questions of data structures and algorithms. I was constantly asked to optimize my code interms of time or space or both. The interviewers were helpful, humble and sweet.

It was nice. Consisted of around 5 elimination rounds. The first one was filtering through the CVs and percentage. The second one was a written test. The third one was a GD. Fourth was technical and 5th was of HR.

fist round -
3 coding questions .. very easy .. sorting , maximum contiguous sum and mean median mode 
2nd round - project description was asked and futer explanation of what i did in it and how i overcame a big hurdle etc. 
coding question -  and convert string to float

The interview process had an online round which consisted of 3 questions. The questions were quite easy. The next round was a technical round which consisted of questions on Ds algo and core concepts, and a discussion on projects.

Very pleasant. I first spoke to a recruiter who contacted me via LinkedIn after I selected Open to new opportunities. Then spoke to studio recruiter followed by 1:1 with hiring manager. After that I did a full panel of interviews with 6 people over Microsoft Teams. After 2 weeks I heard back with offer. Then I had to wait 1.5 weeks while background check was run and verified by Microsoft. Once that was done we negotiated start dates and relocation timeline.

First is online round. It has three coding questions. 2nd round is technical coding round. I was asked one array question. 3rd round is also technical based on OOPs and DBMS concepts. Last is HR round.

There was an online test conducted on mettl platform. The questions were very simple. We have to solve 3 questions in 90 mins. The first two were normal data structure algorithm questions like infix to postfix and postfix evaluation. The third one involved using dynamic programming and kadane algorithm. About 30 people were selected for the interview round
An Online Programming round held on campus, followed by two technical interviews and one HR interview. The interviews were held a week after the initial programming test. It was stressful but fun.
One online coding round conducted on Mettl consisting of three data structures and algorithm questions  followed by three technical round where I was asked to write codes for the problems presented

It was an on-campus opportunity.
There was a short coding round, in which about 25 students were shortlisted.
Following this, there were 2 technical interviews and an HR interview. The interview process, tested the problem solving abilities and the personality, overall.

the first round  was a coding round which consisted of 3 questions. The level of the questions was easy-medium . Then I was called for the interview in which their were questions regarding my projects and an algorithm based question.

First, there will be one phone interview asking your project(thesis), work experience, behavior  question.
After phone interview, there will be three on-site interview. first one include short code test and project question. Second one mainly focus on my project. Final one is the most difficult. They will ask about model design and some insight of their on-going project.
It happened over Microsoft teams and was good. First round consisted of ds algo, next consisted of system design and further ahead. Last round was the project discussion and hr round.

Firstly you have to pass the initial coding segment of the interview which is done online. The actual interview is conducted in 3 parts, all of which include some coding and problem solving. Each part is conducted with a different person.

I applied online in June and was selected for a 30-minute phone screen. From the phone screen, I was then selected for a Super Day (virtual) in the middle of August. The Super Day was 4 45-minute interviews. The interviewers were Finance managers/directors, all very personable and genuinely wanted to get to know me. All behavioral questions.

I applied for the position at Microsoft's career website. The recruiter reached out to me and scheduled the initial screening round.
1) Round 1: Phone interview (30mins)
Asked about my job background 
Solved a string problem in 15mins

2)Virtual Round of interviews(3 interviews)
I got a response from recruiter within few days saying the team is interested in interviewing you further.
This was scheduled for 23rd July. I got an email from recruiter on 20th saying they have   cancelling my interview as team has elected to move forward with another candidate.
This is very weird situation and I feel is not appropriate for the team to make a decision on your capability even without the interview.
It was well arranged. Had an online objective test and then 4 technical rounds spread over a month. Out of the 4, 3 were on site, and 1 was on video conference.

It was conducted online on Microsoft Teams. The interviewer was friendly and gave enough time for the questions asked. Questions on array, linked list and DBMS were asked. Had to write my code in the chat section of Microsoft Teams

Asked about projects and relevant experience, then gave one binary search problem for coding test, which was pretty simple. In the next round, something similar happened, with the same employee taking the interview.

I am writing this to describe the absolutely nightmarish time I had during the Microsoft student recruitment process. I was assaulted three times, the first two times were in the space of me being in the Microsoft building for just 20 seconds.

I passed the online stages for the Microsoft student recruitment as I was looking for a paid industry placement during my sandwich year, and what happened to this day has left me shaken. I have worked at Deloitte which is known for a rough culture, startups, and even governmental organisations but nothing compares to the scum I encountered that day.

Having just rejected a job with Apple and a startup company, along with having had employment in the past, I entered their offices for the assessment day. As other candidates were talking I walked over, except everyone immediately stopped talking and began staring at me as if I was responsible for having committed some atrocity to their families. It was at this moment that an Indian gentleman squeezed between people to get to me, tripping me up to the extent that I hit the floor and struggled to get back up from the impact. I was both shocked and confused by what had just happened, I was only in the Microsoft offices for 20 seconds, but thought perhaps it had been an accident. 

The other candidates had resumed their conversation on video games, but blocked me out of their circle and refused to interact with me. I saw a girl just outside of the circle that appeared also left out, and probably unable to contribute to the conversation as it was on video games (not trying to be sexist). I tried to make conversation with me, to which she replied “OH MY GOSH ARE YOU TALKING TO ME?! YOU ARE A PEASANT” in an extremely loud scream, with a face that looked like she had just accidentally bitten on a sour lemon thinking it was an apple, and gave the impression that she was the Queen of India and I was the peasant garden boy. With her hand movements my face and arms received some mild cuts from her nails. I tried to calm the situation down but I was completely and utterly ignored, she was too self-important.

By this point my temper had begun to flare, from the shock I swore pretty loudly in front of Microsoft recruitment people, however this girl did not react in the slightest. We all ended up walking into an office where we would be interviewed as a group.

Foolishly I decided to go first and present an object that I had brought in, when I should have let myself recompose after the trauma of what I had just experienced outside. After my presentation I lost my temper. Fortunately, Microsoft did not kick me out as they had guessed something had just happened outside, and told me to go again.

At one point I explained that there was a difference between Java and JavaScript, however a candidate (the one that tripped me up outside) encouraged everybody to laugh at me saying that they were the same thing. After I politely tried to explain the difference, stating that Java is a strongly typed language compared to JavaScript which is loosely typed, I was laughed at again. I told the candidate that he had just got a car confused with a carpet, to which everyone rolled on the ground laughing.

Despite everything, I ended up talking for almost four hours, showing off my knowledge and essentially cleaning the floor with everyone else. Many lacked even the most basic computer science knowledge, such as what a pointer was used for. This made the gentleman who had assaulted me mad, whereas the girl that assaulted me just looked out of the window the whole time as she was too self-important (except one occasion when she spoke to me as she strangely did not know that a hex editor could edit text within a .EXE file).

The candidates through everything at me testing my knowledge, however in the end one “lawyer trick” was used against me and I unfortunately took the bait and lost all credibility with Microsoft. The gentleman that assaulted me earlier did a trick to bamboozle me, where he would explain a scenario in a long, complex, and complicated manner so only myself and perhaps two other people could understand. He would then ask a simple question, such as the colour of the sky, but given his scenario I would be backed into a corner and forced to say purple, instead of blue. This destroyed the entire day, as the candidates began fighting one another, and Microsoft thought we were all stupid.

After, when we were outside playing ping pong all of the candidates tried to gang up on me, and the one that assaulted me earlier punched me in the face. They were butt hurt that I had made them look stupid when they could not answer simple Computer Science questions, such as what a PE file was.
intense. be prepared for your subject. if you don't know any answer tell I don't know. they will give a chance to recover. i couldn't answer couple of questions still I was selected

submitted online application, the resume screening team reached out after two weeks to for phone call about my background experience. the meeting was set and a recruiter called with what sounds like ready questions or checklist

Process was encouraging and exciting rather than strenuous and daunting. Team leads were friendly. Some hard IT-related questions were asked, but other than that everything ran pretty smoothly. It really helped that I knew what the unit was about, so doing prior research showed to be important.

First round, white board. The interviewer asked me to stop talking and just write my code on the white board so I was a little discouraged then. I was recommended to go to final round, but I wasn't actually selected, or something went wrong on their end.

The interviewer was very rude and was not interested in taking the interview. He asked me one programming question. I explained the logic and approach to tackling that program. He said yes,  and asked me to write the code. I took around 15 minutes to write the code on white paper and after that, he did not check the code and told me that the approach is wrong and stopped the interview. I had attempted the interviews with Amazon & Google before and was unable to crack those interviews as well. But I was happy by the way that the company treats the candidates.
Got a call from the recruiter. Gave the initial phone call. And later was called onsite. The interview was difficult.  There were 6 rounds of the interview process, including whiteboard coding.

Multiple phases, all virtual, really good and really require you to do your research! Had a briefing before the interview where I was given the names of this who would be interviewing me so I could research them on LinkedIn etc
Short application. Short skype interview with coding questions and general questions about my career. Was quite abrupt and clearly I was on the end of a whole day of asking the same questions.

get ready for a loooooong ride. Entire process from interview to offer took 3 months. Interviewed via an hiring event. My god. This has to be the most frustrating interview experience ever.

First step: online assessment. Fairly easy. But this is where the frustration started. It took 1+ week to get back to me with the results. I mean, I passed every test case and such, why was I not automatically passed to the next round? After following up with the recruiter multiple times for a week got an email saying I'm moving to onsite.

Since this was a hiring event, date was already set. However, I didn't get confirmed for the event until ONE DAY before. ONE DAY. I had to take a leap of faith in taking time off for the interview with recruiter completely unresponsive. So unprofessional.

Onsite consisted of 4 interviews, 45 mins each with 15 min break in between. All virtual via Teams. Oh they had this kickoff call at 7:30 in the morning. And it was just a Teams meeting with all interviewees in the room. Lol just awkward. No one knew what the hell they were doing there. I left after 10 mins. To this day I have no clue what that was supposed to be, and why I had to get up and ready by 7:30am. Mind you timezone was same as I was a local candidate. Actual interviews were great, interviewers professional and courteous. Had a good interview experience.

Got email 1 week after that I passed the interview and was moving forward with the offer. This is where another fun begins. Lots of emails back and forth, which could have been 1 single email, tossed between multiple recruiters (why? I don't know. I dealt with total of 6 recruiters for the entire process), long story short it took 3 weeks to get a verbal offer.

Oh and then, once I sign it, background check. So, for some reason, we are not allowed to know the results nor the progress of our own background check due to confidentiality.  What? Ok. They use HireRight to carry out this work, and they are downright incompetent. They took 3 weeks to tryverifying my education and work history. And the best part is, they still couldn't do it so I did it for them by reaching out and getting paychecks to verify it myself. All this took me 2 hours. They took 3 weeks.

When I joined, I really had to try hard and separate all this BS from the actual opportunity. I mean Microsoft, you really have to work on your interview experience. It.... just sucks.
It was a great Interview, people nice and questions all in the area of work and study. Whole process took around 3 months by this is just an entry-level so I can understand

All virtual interviews. Initial phone screen round consisted of 2 questions. Next Round One hard question from leetcode followed by 2 design interviews and one hiring manager round. All are average difficulty level.

Very easy. They asked easy-medium questions. Don't stress too much, be clear with your words.
Be concise in your explanations. Always discuss your approach with the interviewer first. They don't ask hard questions.

Firstly, it's unclear what type of job you will perform. It takes forever to get the HR interview, the whole process is too much waiting for me. The interview was very general, you could basically just say anything. Very standard, about confort zone, challenges, how to solve a problem.

It's got initiated with a couple of calls from a technical recruiter, this was an opening for SAP GTS. During an interview, I had given almost all the answers correct, the interviewer was at the same designation for which I have been interviewing for, I realised the Question was not at the level I was expecting maybe the person who interviewing is not skilled up in the level he is supposed to take an interview and guess what he rejected me where I answered all most all answers right. I still wondering why I got rejected, just a suggestion to recruiting team don't put a panel of the same designation for which you are recruiting it creates a conflict of interest and maybe a bit of insecurity while taking the decision.
This was part of hiring event. Recruiter reached out on Linkedin. Recruiter asked technical questions as part of phone screen. Onsite interview was straight 4 rounds and it was very hectic.
First Round Microsoft Teams Call, which lasted about 30 minutes, and then a month later, 3 back to back calls with different people from the team, and they ask several technical questions.

There were two tech interviews, both were fairly easy. In one they asked coding questions and in the other, I was asked to tell more about my previous work at the company given it was an interview for intern to Full time conversion

Was smooth and the interviewers were really polite. There were 3 rounds - the first two being Tech Rounds followed by an HR Round. Each round lasted about 45 mins. The tech round involved questions from algorithms and databases and the difficulty was from medium to hard.

Start with a phone interview with a recruiter, which is about your personality. If you make it through that round, you'll be invited for an assessment center, which is about 5 rounds long and includes motivational questions, cases and a presentation.

I interviewed in the summer of 2021 - the interviews all took place remotely. Started with a screening with a recruiter who immediately passed me onto the hiring manager and set-up a call with them for the same day. I advanced to the loop with Directors and VPs from the MSSA program. Met with 4 individuals separately and they all asked similar questions.
Recruiter reach out first. Set up phone screen interview, it was a typical algorithm question . After that a virtual on site interview. The interview process is normal, people are kind.

It was asked to be prepared to talk about Teams and Azure. Microsoft provided the links. The interviews lasted one morning, with roleplays and questions about your background. Also be prepared for some technical questions.

Screened by outside recruiter (working as a Microsoft vendor) in brief phone call. Then advanced to subsequent rounds where I completed 30 minute interviews on Teams calls. Process is straightforward and communication is good from the recruiter.

Call for 30 mins he asked Basic questions. It was internship position. It was Easy going Very conversational and Interviewer was very nice and attentive.
I am waiting on the final interview

Microsoft has very smooth interview process. Their HR is best in scheduling and following up on the interview. The interviewer was not so good. My job title at current company mad him prejudiced against me.

It was three steps process. HR, technical and problem-solving. 
It was on-site and takes about one hour for each step.
They did a great job explaining the next step and setting expectations.

interview approx 2 hours.  With 2 or 3 different managers.  Asked questions about resume and some "riddle" problems.  Plus some questions about past experience.  Wasn't too much technical coding problem solving questions involved.

Interview happened as scheduled. The behavior is good. Started with a self introduction. A live coding test was given to understand the logic and approach.  The interview was very supportive to convey the limitations of the approach.
The process includes a code test and two interviews with one interviewer for each one. The process is smooth and the interviewers are kind. The code test is somehow long and difficult.

This was the first interview for a Software Engineer for a Graduate Role. The interview did not even ask my name and the first question was if I have any job offers at the moment. I felt that this was very rude not to ask a person to introduce at the beginning of an interview.

Applied online with referral.
1 screening round focussing mostly on statistics.
4 Round interview loop: 1 ML Coding, 2 ML and DL (basics and math and stats) and 1 case study/ ML System Design round.
Couldn't clear the loop but was supposed to give a behavioral round if I cleared it.
It was a good interactive heartly session with both the interviewers. We had a chat before the interview just so that I can be comfortable and I also received good feedback.
great! really nice person asking simple questions.  it was great i am filling up words so i can use this app. this first interview s really light. omg how is this not 30 words.

5 interviews. 4 technical, 1 cultural. Each was 1 hour, one after the other. At least one of the questions was way over my head, but I felt no shame in asking questions and admitting what I didn’t know. Prepare for the technical questions as you would prepare for a systems engineer interview.
All of the interviewers were men. They are the people I work with regularly today since I’ve accepted the job.

The interview process is a multi-stage process for hiring new employees. The interview process typically includes the following steps: writing a job description, posting a job, scheduling interviews, conducting preliminary interviews, conducting in-person interviews, following up with candidates and making a hire.

One round for contract, its easy for contract, basic questions will be asked its not tough to crack interview for contract roles, be confident and answer. I had only one round of interview with client, one screening with payroll

Technical and role based interviews went great. When speaking with the hiring manager in the final round he questioned my reasoning for wanting to switch jobs and questioned my motivation to come to Microsoft. He said he didn't understand and felt like my motivations were wrong.
One call, next to schedule coding session. Then a session with very arogant young russion guy. He has started with "I was impressed by your CV...". Then the hell started.

Interview process is long, exhausting and exciting at the same time. There were 5 rounds of interview each with different stakeholders. Generic questions about experience, sales process and technical capabilities.

I had to pass a written test, a mcq test.
I was later shortlisted for the interview.
In the interview I was told to introduce my self.
I was later given a problem to solve.
The interview was conducted on MS teams.

Challenging yet the interviewers does not make you feel nervous but rather comfortable about it. Prepare for technical and scenario based questions, do not be nervous, and try to answer the question to your best logically even if you face difficulty.

First virtual interview, in comparison to other companies, was a lot more laid back - it was a very easy going conversation. I had a great feeling about the interview, but was called back with the news that they went ahead with an internal employee. Almost felt like they did the interview just to do it and have a record one their end.

interview was for sde full time offer..they asked mainly about basic data structures and algorithms like stacks implementation and linkedlists. the experience was very bad as the interviewer was more interested in the final code correctness rather than the approach

Applied online and received an email to schedule a 1st round a week later. Very unorganized, interviewer was confused on the interview process and didn’t expect to be interviewing that day. Radio silence for 3 months and my emails to the recruiters went unanswered. Had to find out from others in the process that they filled their class and were pushing start dates back to 2022.

My advice is to get better recruiters that are responsive and human enough to deliver a rejection instead of giving radio silence...

Two Rounds -
Round 1:  Behavioral Questions for 30 minutes
Round 2: 3 hours and  3 rounds and 3 different interviewers - 1 hour each
                     Mix of behavioral questions, case questions, and conversation.

Couple phone screening calls, the interviewer was nice and engaging. Gave a good description of the role and what is expected from the individual hired. He asked some basic questions relate to my work history, background, and the reasoning for my interest in this role.

1. On campus interview
2. Final round online

final round had 4 interviews back to back testing algorithm questions
if you do leetcode mostly you should be fine

try to practice because they will look at your speed and thought process as well 
the experience also depends on interviewer but overall not bad at all

It's the worst interview experience ever (with 343 studio).  After the hiring manager phone interview, the recruiter scheduled 2 days/7 session virtual interviews but incorrect interview panel info/time was provided. 

Without any heads-up, the interview sessions were canceled in the middle of day 1 sessions, not to mention Day 2. As a candidate, I feel terribly disrespected and traumatized. Some interviewers gave me a very negative impression- it’s virtual interview, but the interviewers didn’t turn on the camera nor provided any response. I literally talked to myself and stared at the empty screen the whole times.

While I was waiting for my last session interview in Day 1, which was 15 mins late already, and this was when I noticed an email sending from the recruiter during the last session interview --- with the email title "Can I call you?"   the recruiter couldn’t have seriously expected me to check my email during an interview and answered her call?!!   I closed my interview software and called the recruiter immediately. Then she told me "The interviewers decided not to continue the interview, not to waste time." YES, THEY WASTED MY TIME!”

The recruiter didn’t handle the whole situation and I had to find out on my own, because she was in a hurry to get out of the work.  Show some respect to the candidates!
Phone interview with HR to see if you fit the profile in terms if work experience and characteristics. After that they sent me a Codility test with 3 questions in 2 hour.

Video interview and answered questions online. 
Many of Java’s object-oriented features are motivated by problems with previ- ous languages, and their implementations are influenced by this history. Some of these features are hard to explain when people aren’t familiar with the problems they solve.
We get to object-oriented programming as quickly as possible, limited by the requirement that we introduce concepts one at a time, as clearly as possible, in a way that allows readers to practice each idea in isolation before moving on. So it takes some time to get there.

I received an email after I applied asking for some clarifying experience questions. I was then contacted about scheduling an interview. I was interviewed by a panel of 3 Datacenter Leads and was asked about my experience and some basic technical questions.

I applied for an internship last year and never heard back. They reached out this year because they knew from my CV I was graduating soon. Had a phone screen and then 3 (virtual) "on-site" interviews. They were very nice and made sure I was comfortable during the whole process.

HRs  from microsoft are nothing but unprofessional and impossible, not that they are enough to  be careless(for not informing that we have one more round  and the panel is already waiting for us)during the interview, after clearing 3 rounds, the next person is oblivious to the solution you are giving and simply asks "i want a DP solution" and  says wrap it up as i need to run off to a meeting . You are supposed to atleast discuss with candidate, this is not a one word answer question . Please be professional

Got in contact with a recruiter through a friend, which led to a casual phone call just to get to know each other. Later had a technical phone screen. I was then invited to a virtual onsite which was 4, 45 minute interviews via Teams with 15 minute breaks in between. 

Each interview started with an introduction by the interviewer followed by a ‘tell me about yourself’. Some interviewers delved deeper into my previous experience while others went straight to the technical problem. At the end you have time to ask questions. 

The technical questions were on the easy/medium side. Make sure to know the basic algorithms/data structures and be able to explain how/why you would use them. I was expected to explain my solution thoroughly before I was able to write code. All of the interviewers were extremely nice and helpful. The interviews were very collaborative and gave me a good idea what the interviewers would be like to work with which I really liked.

 My advice would be to just be yourself! If you don’t know an answer be honest and treat it as you would if you were working through a problem with a coworker or teammate.

2 rounds of interview. Initial interview was an hour Skype call with HR and on premise loop followed for about half day with Development manager for Bing, Test Manager for Skype, Senior Engineer for Skype and 2 other leads

I highly recommend people applying for jobs at Microsoft to attend their Virtual seminars. It helps a lot connect directly with recruiters. I am still in the middle of the interview process. Very well structured 60 minutes phone interview. Started with my intro and projects that I have been working on followed by a coding question and then a small design discussion.

An English telephone interview with someone from Bucharest, asks logical questions -There are three boxes, one contains only apples, one  contains only oranges, and one contains both apples and oranges. The boxes have been incorrectly labeled such that no label identifies the actual contents of the box it labels. Opening just one box, and without looking in the box, you take out one piece of fruit. By looking at the fruit, how can you immediately label all of the boxes correctly?

6 interviews, done over 2 days. 3 interviews each day, all conducted virtually.
Few weeks of gap in between day-1 and day-2.

Recruiter further shared the feedback more than 3-weeks after the last interview.

Recruiter discussion to qualify and validate, followed by a loop of interviews (4 total) with working peers and hiring manager. The recruiter was very poorly informed about the role and was somewhat arrogant ("you should feel luck to be getting an interview"!). The other interviews were mostly soft and not followed any structure. The people were nice but it seemed they were not focused or prepared.

He asked 2 coding questions in AA round answered both correctly. I wasn't shortlisted because of my branch.some behavioural questions were also asked too. That's all I remember they only judge people based on branch and cgpa and not on the basis of knowledge🙂
I had a brief phone interview, then I had to complete a coding test online (wasn't so difficult ), and then another phone interview. I failed in the second interview. Don't know why.
It was fun and easy going. The HR round was the simplest. The technical rounds were a bit tough to crack but was fun and challenging at the same time.

I applied in the early summer. I did not receive any information for 4 months. However, in december of 2020, I received a rejection from Microsoft. They also asked if I was eligible to work in the United States and if I was a person of disability. Also if I was a veteran.

I applied online.
first I do technical test and skype interview (general questions)
and in the second level I have another technical interview with manager. 
the Interview Questions is below. aa aa

It was online interview with the Software Engineer Lead. Position was in Herzliyya, Israel. I got two tasks to my email which I must do in 5 minutes. Unfortunetly I couldn't do it because I missunderstood the task. I didn't find like overview here and I hope it would be help someone else.

Got call from hiring manger followed by recruiter.  Collected all requirements and documents.  Final interview was on Teams with 3 team members . Conversational and nice technical interview.  All interview team members seemed intrested and metioned that I seems good fit. Recruiter told me that I will know outcome after 2 days. Nothing till next 1 week. Pinged again, I got an update that they will make decision in a day . Nothing even after another week. Pinged again after a week. No answer. Finally I got another offer , I asked recruiter to tell me now given I had other offer,  feedback was that I am good fit but they are moving forward with other candidates.  Seriously,  I was supposed to know answer in 2 days after interview, nothing even after a month even after interview went really good. After a month I had to force them to tell me an answer and I got NO. Nice interview but horrible hiring process.

the first interview was HR one, but the next interview was technical. If I passed that interview I would probably were invited to another one with a senior manager. 
I presented myself and talked about my degree, achievements , and different projects I held during the degree.

It was a Skype interview. There were a few details asked initially about my right to work, which I feel should have been a separate process. I could not see my interviewer even though we were using Skype and I had to disable my camera too so that my voice would not buffer.

I had an all day interview with various people including Human Resources and Exchange Client lead support. This included testing my skills on Mac OS and Microsoft Office/Exchange Client application software

question of job requirement , question of job experience, question of submitted resume, and contents, question of another company interview experience, explain why i applied this position, when can i work

Two technical interviews - the first with a team member and the second with the group leader. They didn't really read my resume so asked some question about my experience.  The team leader decided to cut the interview because of my specific experience (Even though I wrote everything on my CV and they invited me to the interview!). This was one of the most weird and annoying processes I had.

Focus on basic concepts in OOP, programming languages, algorithms and problem solving abilities. Asked questions regarding the projects that I had. Future plans. Why I chose microsoft? Am I ready to relocate to another city?

First-round consisted of a very easy test on Codility (3 tasks, 15-20 minutes are far enough to solve them) and quick non-technical interview. After it, I received very quickly negative response with no option to ask about any detailed feedback due to Microsoft's policy.

phone call regarding why microsoft and skills I had regarding adapting to change and solving problems 
the interviewer was nice and made feel calm and the questions were more general

Recruiter contacted me on LinkedIn about a position at Microsoft in their legal department. Called me for a quick phone chat but was told Microsoft would not be interested in interviewing me because I do not come from a technology background. I don't see why this is an automatic disqualification. I felt the recruiter should have done a bit more research on my resume before wasting both of our time. 

(A few weeks before this I had a recruiter at Aerotek contact me about a few job postings at Microsoft. Unlike the previous recruiter, this one didn't mention that I had to have a technology background and was happy to put my resume forward for any considerations)

it was straight 4 rounds of interviews on same day. Due to Covid19, rounds happened online.  Timings of rounds were not sceduled. On every round, they go forward, only after positive response from previous round.

In First round, I was asked to build image slider. Choice was given on technology. Since during briefing, they said React is main tech. I used same. I implemented CSS as well. But weirdly found the interviewer got confused on how React works.  Also asked a DSA question.

Second round was full DSA and couple of React questions. I felt again that the interviewer didn't have good grip on React.


Third round was more of generic frontend and problem solving. Same here. Frontend knowledge of interviewer was not upto mark to question me.


Fourth round interviewer seems to have good knowledge based on his introduction. But didn't ask me a single frontend question. And I screwed up DSA question he asked.


Could have done better from my side in fourth round but probably first 3 rounds made me loose interest in Microsoft regarding Frontend role.

first step - coding test online and skype with an HR from abroad. second step is an hour and a half coding interview. the third step is sepose to be also an hour and a half coding test with a team leader.

I started with an on campus technical interview, and then I was invited out to Seattle to complete 5 consecutive technical interviews. I felt like they were only interested in testing me on the spot, I definitely suffer under high pressure situations like that. I didn’t feel that this was a good environment to show what I can do code wise, and they barely asked me questions about extensive industry experience. They also really didn’t care to get to know me at all.

The interview process was online due to the covid-19 situation. First, I had been interviewed by an HR person regarding my background skills.  Then, I had an interview with the manager and team members. I was afraid of the process because work at Microsoft is my dream and I couldn't fail, but the interview steps were amazing and I had a great experience with everyone from Microsoft.

OA with Easy/Medium questions. 
Then I have to onsite/online interview with 3 persons. 
First was a Ph.D. holder and discussed my resume and many topics on Machine learning 
The second was the team lead. I was asked a system design question (data sciences related), and then two problem-solving questions Easy/Medium.
The third was a software engineer and asked me graph problems, string manipulation, and many deep learning questions to discuss.

I applied to an ad for Berlin, and I have learned later that this ad was for multiple locations in Europe and there were no open positions for Berlin. 
They contacted me with an email to have a quick phone screen almost a month later. Then after that they've sent a codility test. Which I've passed easily.
After the codility test they set up 4 interviews as a "hiring event". And due to COVID-19 all was to be done online. The day before one of the interviews were cancelled. And I had completed other three interviews. But didn't get a feedback for 10 days.
After that I have emailed to the recruiter about feedback on the interview. She told me that she has moved to other projects and another person will contact me about it. 
After another week I was called by another recruiter and he said that feedback from that 3 interview was positive and they want to have a replacement interview for the cancelled one. And I will be contacted for that interview in a couple of days. 
Two weeks passed and there were no contact. And I did not remember the name of the new recruiter and did not have his email but used the contact recruiter button on the Microsoft Action Center and asked them about this interview. That was almost a month ago and MS did not contact me since. 
It's been almost 5 months since I applied and almost a month and a half since last contact I have received from MS. And I am really dissapointed how unprofessionally handled my process.

Interview took place during COVID-19 quarantine. First stage was a conversational interview via video chat on Microsoft Teams with the hiring manager and another engineer. Second stage was a coding challenge in which a product specification is given and the candidate is tasked with building a frontend interface to match the specification.

The challenge task was simple and straightforward. I felt very confident in my submission but did not receive an offer, nor clear feedback as to what was lacking in my submission. Would have appreciated a direct follow-up with the hiring manager after reviewing the code challenge instead of relaying vague feedback via remote HR recruiter.

the interview was mainly a task I was given and afterward I was ask to go through my code and explain it. then the interviewer asked me some questions about the reasons I chose specific elements in my code.

Skype interview, technial interview with a potential coworker and then with manager (that i didnt pass). All the interviews were remote because of covid 19. If you pass all of them there will be 4 total.

i am talking about the Skype interview with an interviewer named Olivia (English interview)
in this interview there are lot op question about yourself...
the main goal for this interview is to see if the candidant is aproximatly the type of people that Microsoft wants (try to reflect that your nice to work with,pation,want to learn new things, want to solv the best way could.
*Plesse note this is only the FIRST interview from 4 interview row.

Long story short, I applied for the MBA Operations internship, interviewed at a convention with a Microsoft employee that worked in engineering, the first interview is mainly just for culture fit. Was invited 2 weeks later to be flown out to Redmond to a super day. Super day started at 7 am you interview 3 different people within the department. About 60 people there in the morning. Interviews are really conversational but they dig deep and some small case questions. I ended up not getting the operations internship but 2 weeks later was called to interview for the marketing internship for MBA’s (I applied to both and was told my operations interview rounds were good). Process is pretty much the same except this was an over the phone interview. Was flown out again and did the 3 round interview. Make sure you have you stories down for the interview the mainly want to know about you and your professional experiences and what makes you unique. I was only asked 2-3 heavy marketing related questions through all 3 45 minute interviews on the super day. Also was asked 1 marketing related question on the phone interview. Other than those it was just questions about me.

Contacted by a recruiter on LinkedIn. The first screening test was on codility, two technical interviews (with tech lead and manager respectively) to be followed by an AA interview, the manager of the group I interviewed for. All three interviewers shown great interest in my previous work, in my background, and in me in general.
Unlike processes in other FAANGM companies, the atmosphere was laid back and supportive.
The interviewers (all three of them) were modest, and I always felt they're talking to me in a great amount of respect. Each interview ended with a *fair* amount of time pitching me in to the team. 
I Felt very welcomed and respected throughout the process. 

When that fell on the right side, an HR representative contacted me to start dealing with the details of the offer.

In May 2020, I was contacted on LinkedIn with some basic questions about my experience. Soon a screening test was scheduled, if cleared, I then had to go through 5 interviews with the team members. 
The screening test was on codility with 3 mid leveled search trees and string manipulation questions. 

Soon I received a mail from the recruiter that I cleared the screening test and now my first face-to-face screening interview was set up with a team member. The interviewer was very friendly and was able to provide me info on how Microsoft works and what it means to work at Microsoft.  He asked me to solve a problem and talk about the solution I derived. 
Post that soon I was informed that I cleared the round and in few days my final 4 interviews we setup. They comprise tech coding challenges & system design with a bunch of questions on my past experience. My final interview was with the hiring manager who asked me some behavioral questions. 

I was able to provide a solution for all of the questions put in front of me except the last tech round where I took more time and could not finish my solution in the given time. 

All these were virtual interviews because of COVID.
Overall the experience was good and interviewers were friendly except one case where the interviewer didn't even turn on his webcam and spoke too little. Most of the time I felt like I'm talking to a bot. It did shake up my confidence a bit but rest all was very professional.

After all the interviews I was told that I will be contacted by my recruiter with feedback, which really never happened. After 2 weeks of no news, I contacted my recruiter and then received a notification from the portal that I didn't make it. 

My overall experience was really nice except that fact in the case of rejection the company does even bother to let the person (with whom they have spent so much of time) know that he didn't make it. Maybe it's the way it works.

I was informed I was moving forward to interview and, shortly after, a coordinator sent a request for my available times.  He then scheduled a series of 4 interviews with members of the department - each an hour in length and held over Microsoft Teams.  Accessing teams was not an issue, however there were repeated technology interruptions during the interviews that made things challenging and forced stop/start.  Feedback from interviewers was that it was something they had experienced earlier in the day.

It was an oncampus opportunity and I had 3 total rounds in the whole process. First one was an Online Coding test on cocubes. Next was a Group Fly Round (Pen paper based round) followed by Technical + HR interviews. I had 2 technical and 1 HR interview.

Interview questions were easy

I applied for a position posted on the employers career website. A recruiter reached out three weeks later for an initial interview on Teams where I was asked to walk through my resume. The day after I received an email from a second receuiter to schedule an interview with the hiring manager. That interview took place a couple of days later and I was told the recruiter would get back to me but he/she never did.
I only did one interview but the interviewer was really nice and took into consideration that I come from a Computer Science background and not from a Program Management one.
There was a quick online survey, then there was an interview scheduled for 30+ after first being contacted. The interview was 10 min and mostly focused on proficiency in skills.

It was nice. testing your knowledge about the cloud computing and your understanding of Microsoft Azure. going to M365 to dynamics 365 and your full understanding of Microsoft's todays services that helps businesses
The interview had 2 parts. Part 1 was a technical online, 3 questions. The second part was a face to face Skype chat with a recruiter, a bit less technical, more theoretical questions.

First-round phone interview. Questions about background and project work which lasted for about 20 mins. This was followed by a relatively tricky coding question in an HDL of your choice (30 mins). Very nice and respectful interviewer. Pleasant experience.
The interviewing HR person was incredibly rude and demeaning, effectively telling you to grovel at her feet to get the job. Once I got to the engineers there were somewhat human.

The worse interview process I have had ever. Applied online. two positions got contacted by recruiter, and replied the questions they had, then no response and disappeared. send multiple emaild for the follow up, never heard back from them.  One position, got to final round, no follow up from them. I know MS is big company, but they should learn be respectful to the candidates.  The worst interview experience ever!

Having interviewed for a SDE role in the US prior I expected a similar level of professionalism especially from the likes of Microsoft, however this was not the case. 
I was approached to take a online interview/technical screening which went well, I correctly answered two coding challenge questions no problem. However there was a network related question which I found quite odd as the job description didn't call for any of that type of knowledge, I was upfront but answered as best I could (and in all honestly I checked the question against my answers later and I wasn't actually that far off). 
After the interview there was basically no contact from the recruiter(Philippines based) unless I prodded constantly for feedback/result of the interview, and even then he would only try offload to someone else. 
I finally got some feedback after clicking the "Contact Recruiter" button on the Action Center page and surprise surprise it went to someone local who told me I failed due to the network question (again, not on the JD).

The interview process was way too large. I was interviewed remotely by Microsoft on March 2020 at the first stage, second stage on May and they answered me at late June.

Regarding the interviewers, they were all friendly and kind, and took the time to explain me some examples on the coding interview before I started going through the problem.

First they sent to me an online assessment contain 2 problems I can solve only one of them, and there are also some of MCQs, I pass it, and they set the 2 interviews after each other, the interviews was focused on just problem solving, Unfortuanlty I didn't pass it

I was really disappointed after my initial interview for the position. The interviewer seemed professional and impressed, added me even on linkedin and told me he will get back to me within 2 weeks.

I receive nothing on my mailbox, I contact him on linkedin for some feedback he completely ignores me. 

It has been 3 months now with no positive/negative feedback which I think is really unprofessional bearing in mind that it is such a big company.

The interviewer asked a question which is more of a system design question for product design. The developer in me got me to take that route but they were looking for more broader, customer-focus approach.
There are three rounds on-site, and two rounds of phone interviews. Each interviewer asks questions about the algorithm and kinds of stuff on the resume, the difficulty is between easy and medium.
An online interview. A week later I participated in a virtual assessment centre featuring a 10 minute online presentation with Q and A at the end. After that a 30 min interview.

Applied through a microsoft employee. Invited for Skype interview  which I passed. Waiting for my first technical interview.  The Skypw interview was fairly quick, not hard. Was not so plesant since it felt like the interviewer was not interested even though I passed

I had a phone call with HR, asked questions about a project that I did, how I work in team, also I had to complete a coding test before the call, 3 easy questions, after that I had a technical interview

Really nice progress. Everything was clear and straight forward. This is probably due to the fact that everything is remote. It made things a bit easy going. Using COVID 19 to my advantage, i hope you do the same.

I had a phone interview and an online test not very hard.
The telephone interview was in English. From what I understand, I spoke with a representative from an international manpower company

i had a Skype interview with someone from the recuiting staff. 
the intervier was from abroad.
it was an introducing interview.
she was asking a general carasteristic quations.
it was nice and frierndly interview.

The interview was 45min long. The interviewer asked me to introduce myself and asked some behavoural questions. We then moved to the technical problem. 
The question wasn't very difficult and I quickly coded the brute force solution, but I couldn't think of the optimal one and answer the follow up questions.

One android discussion followed by a Data structure round of discussion.
Android - Bitmap question. He was only looking for the bitmap API but was not clear on the question.
MVVM and recycler view questions- Again not very clear questions. 
Binary Search and Tree questions.

The interviewer quickly told me about himself, and how the interview would be conducted:

Intro
Questions from the interviewer
Questions from me

It was painless and the interviewer was gracious.  I may apply here in the future.

at first the asked me to do Codility test, about 3 questions, with 65 minutes to solve them , after that i got a Skype interview in English with HR, asked me personal questions and some other technical questions,
A recruiter contacted me on LinkedIn and I did a phone interview that was around 45 minutes long. Was offered a final round interview but declined due to location.

Recruiter contacted me over linkedin and scheduled an interview within a week. It was all telephonic due to the lockdown period.

The interview panel consisted of two rounds and each round had two people. Usually one was actively asking questions and another was passive.

First round went for 1 hour. They joined a bit late. First 15 mins was about typical "tell me about yourself" and then a few technical questions on performance, approach etc. And then there was a layout problem to be solved. All that they asked was approach. Not the working code. It went well. He said the recruiter will share the feedback on what went well and what didn't.

Second round also went on for 20 mins where they introduced themselves and asked for my introduction. A couple of questions on technologies used and how comfortable I am with those frameworks etc. Only one of them was interactive all through and the other was not. He asked me to open redbus.in and develop the calendar that is visible there. I asked questions on, should the leap year be considered, alternative month days etc. After I coded for 20 mins he said to concentrate on the logic part. Till then I was coding different templates for days/row/week row etc. I was not even aware that there was time limit, they didn't tell me. I completed the logic part. The active interviewer was answering the questions and following the logic that I was writing. But as the one hour got over, the other interviewer who was silent till then pitched in and said execute the code because it is time up as they have other interviews to be taken. I hadn't even linked my .js files, .css file to html file. I am comfortable in local ide rather than repl. Obviously it didn't work. So he asked the active interviewer who was interacting, "ain't you leaving the call? I am leaving" I left the call immediately before even they left. It took 5 mins for me after the interview to make it work perfectly.

Then on the next day, recruiter sent me a mail saying they are discontinuing the process with my profile. No elaborated feedback on to what went wrong. So, it was a kind of disappointment for me to spend so much effort and time to not recieve a proper feedback.

To guys who have read this before your microsoft front end interview, one concentrate on completing the problem. Probably they are not looking for the code quality because no one can develop a calendar in 40 mins with good quality. And good luck!

Overall good experience. Prepare for a full day of interviews. 1 hour portfolio review of at least 3 different projects showcasing design fundamentals, research strengths, critical thinking, problem solving, business partner/stakeholder expectation management. Afterward there was 5 1-on-1 interviews.

The experience was very positive. First, you get 3 tasks in the Codility platform, which is very similar to the questions found in LeetCode (easy-medium). this part takes an hour. Second, I had a phone interview in English with behavioral questions. After 2 days I got invited to a second interview.

4 rounds of interviews. All Technical Designing and data structures questions.
Since it was a covid situation. All 4 rounds are on team meeting. interview process took over 1+ months. It was for Front End Full Stack Dev.

1st round - Data structures and Design a Pagination Component and some general programming questions. Interviewer was good and patiently hearing out.

2nd Round - Data structures and Design a Bing Search bar and some general programming questions. Interviewer was good and patiently hearing out.

3rd Round - Design a LUDO snake ladder.Interviewer was manager and patiently hearing out but she was arrogant but giving some valuable feedback.

4th Round - Interviewer was fully from the front end side no knowledge of back end. He was , arrogant and too much of patience less. Design a google calendar layout and Print the top view of the binary tree and how streaming works.

Even though i answered all the questions in all the round i got a rejected mail in 4th round.It was heart breaking and unbelievable why they have rejected me even though i answered each and every question. I still not able to accept my rejection.

The interview process - particularly some interviewers are knowledge less . they are just aware about there side of technology.

Suggestion - If you are hiring a full stack with general skill don't try to evaluate it in only one tech focused designing.

Process took longer than usual. Started off with an on campus interview, where I was asked 3 questions in 30 minutes. I was told that I had passed the interview but the final round spots were full, so I waited 5 months to hear about a final round spot. The final round was all virtual due to COVID-19; I had 3 interviews back to back, with each one being 45 minutes of implementing code.

Recruitment drive, filtering out candidate at very fast pace. Have to call hr again and again to get feedback. Design part was tricky. not explained what features of application. Interviewer wants answer whats there in his mind

You have IQ exam, talk to HR. You need to solve logic, verbal and exam with pictures. HR and director from department ask you questions about your, your preferences, about your faculty, where can you see yourself in ten years...

From first contact to organise the technical interview took 8 weeks. However the non technical interview was organised after 6 weeks. it was very relax and friendly interview. Also, it was Microsoft Teams interview.

one casual chat
2 video interviews

during the interviews, nothing technical was  asked, most questions are about your experience, your motivation and how you would like to contribute to the company. Microsoft focus a lot on whether you are agree with the company strategies and mission.

Recruiter phone call, then 2 technical interviews. The technical interviews took place in Microsoft Teams video call, and the coding questions were answered in Codility. All of the communication was done via phone calls and emails.

firstly I have 1 hire manager interview ask some OOD questions. And then I have 4 loops final interview is about system design and programming questions. I have been asked behaviour questions as well.

Interviewer does not gave look to my resume & even does not introduced himself. Busy with mobile during video call.
Look like he is not interested to take interview or confused with something.  
Precisely interview took 57:30 Min (as joined 2:30 min late) and 21 questions were asked.

Majorly they will ask SQL, although in my case , interviewer itself confused with his own examples. Mixing OLAP and OLTP in same questions and forcing his own solution over candidate solutions.

There are 5 rounds
First two round will be technical and then HR and managerial round.

Tech difficulty level will be more in round two.
They will more focus on VPN, BGP and TCP/IP

Application -> First Round Interview -> Final Round Interviews -> Offer

First Round is just an intro, then if you do well you advance to the 4 final rounds. This can take between 2 weeks to 2 months.

1. Phone call: outlines what will be expected in the interview process (first is said phone call, second is a codility assessment that is a medium-hard question, then the third is the couple rounds comprised of a technical interview and a behavioral)
2. Codility: you get a sixty percent or higher and you might pass 
3. Technical interview: personally, did not reach this stage. The interviewer said a lot of candidates weren't considered if they didn't ask a lot of questions during the technical interview because the coding questions were meant to be vague. Your thought process matters to them, so ask a lot of questions.

Microsoft that is based in China. 2 round interview. you only have to pass one of the first two interviews then you can do the lead interview. The first interview asked you two easy questions finished in 20mins and then the second interview asked two medium questions that I did not finish.

First round was a phone call with the recruiter then next round is with hiring manager and last round is the interview loop. Both the hiring manager and recruiter were really unprofessional in my opinion, joined meeting 15 mins after the scheduled time and were rushing me through the process. i had my interview with the hiring manager and she wanted me to go through the loop the following day without giving time to prepare. Also the loop was a bunch of Data Science questions (even though thats not what i was interviewing for ) and  a exact copy of hard leetcode questions
Takes long time but everything is clear and structured. First HR meeting is about values and aptitudes, then a meeting with your next Manager and then finally a meting with manager of the manager

Interview took place in airport setting as this was the only available place possible. Interview was cordial and informative on both sides. I believe that it gave me a good impression of the business and the company. The product area was well known to me so that was not a challenge whereas the product area was new to MS.

There were a set of four interviewer. They asked a range of questions during the interview process. Various kind of questions that  went from Technical to fit in the culture to communication to specific knowledge in specific area
It was thoughtful process, protracted hiring decision though. I had a good experience and appreciated meeting with the hiring manager and team. I learned a lot from the the interview.

Entretien RH de 30 minutes
Assessment Center d'une journée complète avec plusieurs épreuves (chacune vaut un certain nombre de points et les candidats qui ont le plus de points en fin de journée ont une offre)

Had a phone screen and passed to second round. Was told would receive interview date only to find out 6 months later that they have filled up position. Would have appreciated being told sooner rather than being led on by the recruiter.

during the first interview in microsoft 
the interview was on skype
some of the questions were:
how would you explain a recursion for a 5 years 
the apple/orange riddle 
what you know about microsoft 
tell me about challenge you faced while building one of your projects

I didn't interview with recruiter or hiring manager separately.  They brought me in for full virtual interview loop.  I did some networking with this group over several months and was told by the recruiter I was their #1 candidate from the beginning.

Screening iniziale del cv e poi, dopo qualche mese, mail con richiesta del colloquio. Questo è stato molto veloce (30 minuti), per lo più conoscitivo. Mi hanno chiesto principalmente le mie motivazioni e cosa mi interessasse dell'azienda. Il tutto in inglese.

Applies through their job website and got an email a week later to set up a skype interview in English with one  of their European interviewers which was really nice. 
I also had to take a 65 minute coding test online on Codility.

First interview - half on hour in english. only background, no technical.
Second interview - 3 technical interview question, 1.5 hours.
After that, you should have a two part interview, and then an HR interview.

in the first review was in English, they asked general questions about me, projects I did and situations I was in.
in the second interview they gave a code sample to find the bug in it and try to improve it.
overall was very nice and fun, through the skype in a very good and respectful atmosphere,  i dont know if i got an offer.  need to wait a little longer
SW test on university level, nothing first about experience, it was entering test for further steps, but still I have expected more about my previous work. That can change maybe slightly

interview in english with recruiter from  Romania, behavioral questions, nothing serious.
3 question in codelity, not hard
1st  technical interview  in microsoft teams with software engineer in the group of cortana
Nice interview questions, fun process, fast responses from HR as long as everything goes well, but no response for a long time if you are not selected, which is very annoying

1)Skype interview.
2) 3 more interviews .
took me like a month to finish , rejected on last interview ....a a a a a a a a a a a aa  aa a

Long and tedious. They ask you to do some tests and few phone interviews. The last one was in groups of 7 people. Hard to get.
I recommend to study the company and be ready to answer with the STAR style.

There were 2 rounds of interviews, one technical, and one group. The technical interview had general string-based and resume-based questions, along with possible future goals. The group discussion involved researching and pitching a project idea with several other people, it checked delegation and team work.

It was interactive and mostly about what I had done in my career so far. Even though the role did not require that I have all the technical knowledge, I was still quizzed a little about the solution area.

First technical interview with one code challenge. Two interviewers asked about some history abd projects I did. The interview was about an hour and was not very difficult. Interesting jobs and very nice people

Proceso rápido, eran claras cada una de las etapas del proceso, primero es una entrevista donde evalúan la capacidad de vender algo, luego tu capacidad para comunicarte en ingles (realmente fácil si se tiene un conocimiento básico del mismo) y finalmente el por qué quisiera trabajar para Microsoft en ese puesto.

The process went very well. Recruiters vere were nice and responsive throughout the whole process. 
Interviewers were nice and interesting people. In the beginning I did an online test that had 3 problems for 65 minutes. Phone screen was 30 minutes out of which 20 were to solve and algorithmic problem. During virtual onsite there were 4 interviews 45 minutes each which were more focusing on different technical questions ( database, DevOps, etc) and behavioral questions. Had to code only 3 problems where 2 were not really related to algorithms.
2 stages (so far) - first was a simple HR stage with simple logic question, the second was the following question on microsoft teams. the interviewer was a team member

first interview, a 30 minute talk on a skype call. I was mostly asked about my CV, previous projects, classes im taking and experience i have.  
Before the interview there is a coding test from home: three questions in one hour.

First I had an easy phone interview.
Secondly I had a 2.5 hour long interview, quite tough.
Thirdly I had an home assigment which was pretty easy and I'm sure it went good but they decided to go with somebody else.

So it is a total of 4 interviews first one being HR online on skype which is typical hr questions plus a little puzzle (in English doesnt matter if you are going to work at the company hq which isnt in English speaking country) and then other 2 professional interviews usually 2 on 1 and ends with another HR

The interview was very relaxed, it was more of a presentation for an initial scanning. They ask some questions regarding your problem solving process and capabilities and somethings about your background and personality traits.

1 phone interview, mostly HR. some questions about a project i did and at the end a riddle. then a cody test with some random question and than another zoom interview with more advanced coding questions. came back to me very fast each time/

2-3 technical interviews, probably with junior and then senior in the specific team.  After those interviews, you'll have to pass an HR interview as well.

After completing the process, you'll negotiate your global salary and rights

The phone screen interview was pretty relaxed. I was asked questions like why Microsoft, why I chose my major, and what I did in my current position as well as customer service questions which also seemed behavioral.

A coding test was sent via email at first, and after passing it, i got interviewed by 2 software engineers at microsoft as a live coding interview session. The first one asked about a dynamic programming problem while the other asked about a simple hashing problem

One Leetcode Medium, Interviewer asked about background and proceeded to technical question. Interview was not so difficult, but at the time I was not familiarized with Leetcode so I hope I can do better next time,.
It went on for 30 mins. I was asked to write a program on white board. I did while I was on the call with the recruiter. He was asking me about validations in the program apart from the main logic.

I applied at April , then I received an email that I passed the screening phase after that I had an online coding quiz , and the last phase I interviewed onsite two interviews one technical and another HR

fluiu super bem, não nada a reclamar. RH sempre em contato, senti que o processo foi justo, direto, respeitoso, gestores bem preparados. 
Sem dúvida está entre os melhores processos que participei

Super professional and friendly recruiters. I felt taken care of at any time of the 1 month recruitment process. Two recruiters called me time to time and were prepared to answer any questions I had. They explained coming events/interviews in detail and made sure I knew what was going to happen next. They also informed about next steps always in 1 to 2 days, so there was no waste of time.

- 30 mins phone screen interview with the hiring manager 
- got back after 3 weeks with on site virtual interview 
- day long process on Microsoft teams 
- did not proceed any further

An hour-long portfolio review followed by an all-day interview process with 6 people. One of the interviews was heavily based around testing research skills and methods knowledge. The rest were more behavioral and evaluative of the fit. A lot of questions on research processes/logistics/stakeholder communication.

First round: Skype interview with university recruiter. 2 parts: one about logistics (if you can work in the country...) and one to know the canditate's motivation for working with Microsoft and his/her attitude in working in teams
It is a long process with minimum with three interviews.. the process took 4 months to finalize and whenever you think it is over, a new request for a new interview i scheduled

I had two interviews overall. the process was virtual, nice prosses they were very kind. 
the first interview was with a senior PM and the second one was with the manager of the position

Easy and rather short . Two technical phone interviews. The second was more behavioral than technical. Worked through the solution with my interviewer and worked through testing. That was really helpful as far as communication goes. Really liked the experience overall

Initial recruiter outreach and screening call, followed by video conference call with hiring manager. 

I chose to exit the process as I accepted another offer. 

The process was far to slow. It took 1 month from their initial outreach to having the video call with the hiring manager. This stage went well and we both agreed to proceed, however if then took a further 2 weeks for the recruiter to respond to schedule the a green next step.

Had a first round interview at my university, resume walk through and coding/design questions. A few months later had my on site final round. Final round was 4 interviews back to back, an hour+ each. Mix of behavioral and technical questions based on my resume (e.g. system architecture, cloud computing, security questions).  A few weeks after my recruiter told me I go the offer.

Applied online while in college. Phone screen with recruiter, followed by an initial phone screen with Senior PM responsible for hiring. Pretty informal, discussing your experience, your understanding of the PM role, why you like MS and then some design questions, such as "design a smart clock". Basically looking for your design thinking and thought process.

Invited to onsite about two weeks later. 4 interviews, each with current PM's of varying seniority. They'll say its 3 interviews initially, but if you do well in the first 3 they'll add the 4th with the hiring manager PM. Each interview followed very much the same pattern, start with small talk and questions about your background, your experience, behavioral questions like 'tell me about a time when you showed leadership/worked in a team/ resolved a conflict/solved a technical challenge'. That would take about 5-10 minutes, and then the remaining 30+ would be designing something. "Design a smart cupboard/ an app for the elderly to encourage increased physical movement in nursing homes/ a smart car entertainment system."

They're really just looking for a process, that you're methodical in how you solve problems and understand the importance of asking questions first and identifying the parameters/constraints of what your product should and shouldn't include. Don't dive straight in, ask clarifying questions, listen to their feedback as you're talking through the process out loud, and make sure you use the whiteboard. Wire framing is your friend. Ask questions of the interviewer as you think of them, right throughout the process.

Overall process was fine, repetitive if anything. Younger interviewers were pleasant and enthusiastic, more senior ones seems hard to impress and very much like they'd better things to be doing, very stoic and standoffish. Just depends on who you get.

It's a long tiring day, so eat before hand and hydrate well during it, you're doing most of the talking so your voice could get hoarse.
Clearly filling an interview quota. No feedback except "not up to par". They attempted to get me to apply for another position, I wouldn't unless they gave feedback. No contact after that.

After working with a msft recruiter for a month or two, they forwarded a job description and asked if I was interested. I'm a publicly recognized leader in my field - the job description was almost a 100% match - so close, I asked the recruiter if it had been written with me in mind. With the "Partner" designation, of course I was interested.

After an initial M&G and a round of interviews, there was a clear fit and obvious interest on both sides. I had worked with and had a good relationship with people on the interview panel. The hiring manager gave me a list of books to read that "I usually only give after we've made the offer." This was all but done. And then everybody went silent.

After a week or so I pinged the recruiter to see what was going on. On a catch-up call I was informed that an internal candidate had been selected. He didn't have my skills, but he knew how Microsoft worked. This is what you should prepare yourself for - especially over level 67. I've since talked to many, and watched other execs deal with senior level politics at msft. The backstabbing, reorgs, and land grabs are constant and olympic-level jackassery. That the top 5 or so execs in the company haven't put a stop to this, while Satya grins publicly and talks about all the change that's happened in his book - this should tell you something.

If you're happy joining at a lower level and climbing the ladder, sitting in your cube and keeping your head down - yes, Microsoft is a great company to work for. If you're a go-getter who's hungry, wants to make massive changes and not deal with cancer that senior execs desperately need to cut out of the company, avoid this company.

Yes - I'm extremely bitter. I was massively excited to join. In hindsight I dodged a bullet but I'd love to help others avoid that experience if at all possible. I've stayed in touch with many inside the company, and paid more attention to the inner workings than I had previously. If I knew a year ago what I know now, I wouldn't return the recruiters call.

Before you interview - but definitely before you take a position - befriend a L67 or higher who's been there at least 18 months. There's lots of positives at Microsoft - but make sure they tell you a few stories in the trenches, as well.
