The whole process felt really rushed and mismanaged. After passing the online assignment I got offered an onsite in Redmond 10 days later, I was not offered the option to reschedule since recruiter claimed it was the only hiring event for that team (later I learned this events happen pretty often). I accepted, microsoft took a week to send me the travel arrangements and my flights where confirmed less than 3 days before the onsite, making it hard to plan ahead and get days off my current job. I emailed the recruiter the day after passing the online assignment asking for some guidance on materials to prepare for the onsites, no answer, I got an email from him with some prep material the evening before the interview! 5 days after the onsite I got a call from the recruiter saying that I wasn't selected for this role but that they had another opening that might fit me better and encouraged me to re-interview right away, I declined the offer and asked to get some feedback from my onsites on areas to improve, recruiter didn't have the feedback at the time but said I should be receiving it by email in the next day. That was 3 weeks ago, still waiting...

As for the onsites, I had 4 hours of technical interviews, 3 on DS and Algs 1 on Systems Design, interviewers where really nice and helpful, the problems where about medium leetcode difficulty. One of the interviewers seemed a bit shocked when I said I was gonna do the challenge in python, ( this was already determined since day 1 when I spoke with the recruiter) and seemed to be improvising the challenge as we went, which made the whole thing pretty confusing, so that didn't feel great.

Overall the onsite experience was positive, but recruiting process was one of the worst I ever experienced

All of my interviewers were dead inside. I asked one interviewer how his day was going and he said “stressful”. None of them took notes and I think one of them came up with the questions on the spot. Was contacted by a recruiter in January to have a phone call to describe the role, and to see if I am interested. Once I confirmed interest, I was moved onto the next stage which was the phone screen interview. In this interview I was asked to do 2 coding questions (first one was Easy, second would be Medium leetcode question), then I was asked a number of SRE oriented questions (some networking, linux, and troubleshooting questions).  The phone screen interview was very pleasant and relaxed, the interviewer was super nice. After this,  I was contacted a few days later from the recruiter saying I am being moved onto onsite in Microsofts office in Dublin. This was a full day onsite, I had 6 interviews in total. 1: Systems Design, 2: Troubleshooting, 3: Lunch, 4: Coding challenge, 5: Software Design (very difficult), 6: AA.

Each of these interviews were intense in difficulty, but each of the interviewers were polite and very helpful in guiding me.
I was then contacted a week later to say I had gotten the offer.

I attended the initial phone screen which I came to know I cleared after two weeks. Then they called me for one full day interview after two months. On interview day, I had seven back to back rounds of interviews. Almost everyone asked the same questions except the last managerial and first managerial round.  All the interviewing panel carried the pride of the company brand and they clearly showed off that they are smarter by asking a lot of coding algorithms. It appeared that they never used those algorithms in their day to day tasks. And of course, all the interview panel were desi guys. Obviously, they acted over smart by showing their extra preparation for the interview.  They do not even know the basic concept of giving breaks between interview rounds. In the end, the manager interview clearly showed that their work culture is bureaucratic. They don't like someone who asks too many questions.

Pre screening interviews and then a recruiting day in the company where I was interview with some managers with different backgrounds. In general the process was easy, what you have to do is to know yourself and find key aspects of the job description that matches with you.
You start with the interviews on university campus and, if you do well, they fly you to Seattle for 2nd round interviews. The 2nd round interviews take about half a day.

I initially submitted my application for the Microsoft Explorer role around August/September of 2019, and had an in-person interview at my university for first rounds in October. It was half behavioral, half technical, and I honestly think I choked on the technical part. However, I received an invitation to fly out for final rounds a month later, but my only options for dates were far off, which worried me because Explorer spots run out fast and it's better to do final rounds as early as possible. I flew out early February and interviewed on-site (pretty sure I was in the last group of interviews of the year for Explorer- yikes). I had two interviews- one PM and one technical, and for both interviews, half of the time was spent on behavioral/resume, and the other half on a question. I thought I did really well on the PM interview and alright on the SWE one (I don't want to reveal my interview questions, but I will say that when I searched up my SWE question on Leetcode, it was a Leetcode hard question- so even though I didn't think I did that well on that problem, I think they just asked me it to see how I think, not if I could solve it given the time constraint). I told them about my offer deadline for another company that was coming up and they promised to get back to me before then. They emailed me the day of the deadline letting me know that they were extending an offer to me, but the formal offer was not prepared yet, so they were just letting me know ASAP so I could deal with my other deadline. The formal offer letter arrived a couple of days later. Overall, I had a great experience- the Microsoft interviewers were hands down the nicest interviewers I've ever had, and I could tell they genuinely cared about getting to know me and sharing our work with each other. Microsoft isn't looking for the strongest coders ever for this role- they're looking for people passionate about what they're working on and who know what they are working towards in the future. I'm definitely not the best coder, but I am passionate about my work and about empowering other women in the field, and I think my expressiveness about this made the interviewers like me more and think I could be a good fit for the team.
thirty -minute phone interview followed by on-site interview (they paid for everything - plane, hotel, food, sightseeing), got back within three to five days. the recruiter i spoke to was very nice

Microsoft Ireland has a serious issue either with the HR or the management team, I read a lot of bad reviews on the company on the recruiting platforms such as LinkedIn, indeed, and glassdoor, but I wanted to apply anyway and try my luck.

The first unprofessional incident happened with me was 8 months ago, when I applied for the role of Cloud Solutions Architect, the HR called me and informed that I will have an interview with the company and she will send me the interview details, but instead I received a rejection mail from them claiming that my qualifications are not good for the role, despite the fact that I had all the needed and preferred skills they asked for.

It was really bad to make a big effort and prepare for the interview then they reject me even without having an interview with me.

The second time was 2 month ago, I applied for the role of Customer Success Manager - Azure, Hebrew Speaker.

The HR sent me an e-mail that someone will call me to assess my language then if succeeded they will proceed with the actual interviews.

Someone called me just for 1 minute and half, and once she knew I'm Egyptian she was shocked and hanged up the call very quickly and said she has to go as it is her break time.

Just 1 hour after I got the rejection mail from the HR team as they claim my language is not good enough, which is not correct at all, as I have more than 10 years working in customer service with Hebrew language.

I sent the HR to inform him about what happened, and she replied me 1 month after that the management decided to give me the chance and make the interviews with me.

She said that first I will have the technical interview, then if succeeded I will have the rest of the interviews.

I passed the technical interview and she invited me to have 2 other interviews and asked me to prepare a presentation for the role play.

I did very well in the role play interview and also at the competency one.

Yesterday the HR called me and informed me that after all of that, I haven't been selected because of the language assessment, which is really awkward.

If you guys decide not to select me from the beginning so why did you asked me to have the other interviews which took me a lot of time and effort to prepare for them ?

This is very ridiculous and racist, you first didn't have a proper language assessment to judge if I speak Hebrew good or not, and second it was totally unprofessional to reject me after all of that because of the language test that you decided after that to proceed with the rest of the interviews.

HR contact me via email, tell me they are hiring service engineer, then the phone interview,  but the one over the phone asked if I'm applying software engineer (I was applied that but as I said in front, they are finding service engineer, I'm new grad and I'm not quite sure) (since that confusion, I don't know what should I show to them, that may lead to the failure)
There was one technical phone screen and three rounds of onsite interviews. Interviewees take the candidates to the room and there may be three to five rounds for each one.

Recruiter contacted through LinkedIn. First round over phone and then onsite for final round where they have 4 back to back interviews. 

It was one of the worst interview experience for me. The recruiter said my name wrong the whole time we were on call and everytime I corrected her but she was not interested in recruitment it seems.

First there's a phone call with an interview that asks about experience and a couple of technical questions. Next was round of 4 interviews with different team members who asked about past experience and a couple of technical questions with 15 minutes breaks between.
Had an on campus interview, one on one in a classroom on my campus. Interviewer asked one technical question, and the rest was just a quick conversation about work-life at Microsoft.

Contract role:
3 rounds of interview.
Design an app that displays a list of users from the database
Last round with the manager. Asked about my project and previous work exp and coding question.

Skype interview - a recruiter from Poland reached to me and I had the behavioural questions taken by her. There were 8 questions, some of which were linked to the other. It was super easy and teh recruiter super friendly

I applied and got interviewed in Microsoft Bangalore , HR was very polite and handled well , first interviewer also was very polite and most of the questions asked were related to trees and stuff first interview went well , the second interview was with a scum he showed up very late on top of if he didnt respond to my greeting instead he started as if  its a war , the problem with this guy is he had a fixed  implementation in his mind and he wasnt willing to listen or go through n understand my code, instead of giving an effort to understand the code he said,  I dont think it will work n stuff , its not worth to work in such teams where people are not willing to listen and expect fixed answers ,   anyways I have an offer with AMAZON and google process is going on

I had multiple interviews at the Redmond HQ with Program Managers and Engineering Manager. The interview process was chaotic and was not streamlined. The interview was also more difficult than expected.

This interview was for AI cognitive science org at Microsoft in Sunnyvale. One recruiter reached out to me and the recruiter recommended AI cognitive science org for me based on my background. I cleared the online assessment and I was told that I will be moving to onsite interviews next. But that did not happen. First recruiter (recruiter 1) handed off the process to another recruiter (recruiter 2) who told me that hiring manager wants to do a phone screen first. The hiring manager kept procrastinating for 2-3 weeks and finally agreed to interview me. The phone screen interview with hiring manager went well and they immediately told me that they want to move to onsite rounds. They cancelled my onsite rounds 2 days before for some random reason which they did not disclose and told me that they want me to come to Bellevue and interview for there. I agreed and went to Bellevue for the onsite interviews. On the day of onsite interviews, I met my 2nd interviewer initially and my 2nd interviewer (who was gonna conduct the lunch interivew) told me that they had not booked conference rooms for 2 interviews. This was weird. I did my first interview in some temporary conference room. It went well. I had a break in between my 1st round and 2nd round. In this break, they told me that I am supposed to sit in that conference and not roam around. I sat in that conference room for 5-10 minutes and suddenly 10 people showed up with for scrum meeting. Apparently the team which I was interviewing for did not book the conference rooms at all. They kicked me out of the conference room. I had to spend my break time in the kitchen area. After my break, I told the 2nd interviewer about what happened. The 2nd interviewer was smiling and I felt that he knew about this but he was trying his best to hide it. The 2nd interview was supposed to be the lunch interview but he completely forgot about "lunch" part and took me to his workstation and started asking me whiteboard coding questions. I solved the question and gave him optimal solution. When 20 minutes were left, he suddenly remembered the "lunch" part and basically told me to finish my lunch in about 20 minutes. My last interview was a system design interview with hiring manager. The hiring manager works from Sunnyvale but they called me for onsite interviews in Bellevue. They do not have any team members in Bellevue then why invite me there. This was extremely strange. Moreover, the hiring manager joined the interview session via audio call and did not even show me his face. I solved the design question and the hiring manager said that I did a great job overall. I received an automated reject 1 day after. Funniest part of this process was recruiter 2 was hiding under the name of "conference" and basically did not even care to join the prep call. So, I never got a chance to talk to recruiter 2 in the entire process. Even the amount the expenses that they have reimbursed (which is less than the approved amount) does not match the amount that they have approved. Clearly they set me up with some fake interviewing process when they were not even interested. Such a waste of time! Rude people! On the other hand, I am glad because I do not want to be a part of such a  team/org where they do not respect people.

I applied through online portal. After that got a call from Microsoft Team and scheduled an interview two weeks after. Being average throughout my life, getting call from Microsoft itself was big deal. 
I prepared heavily for two weeks. The interview day came.
1) First Technical Round went for 1.5 hours. It started from basic questions like CLR, GIT, code execution to a bit high level. At the end of the interview the interviewer told,  the job would not just for .net support, .net would just be less than 5%, so be prepared for the second round. I cleared first round.
2) Second round was scheduled after few days, I prepared again for a week. The interview was really of high level. Did not clear the second round.
Full day process broken into multiple individual one on one interviews which can include time at the blackboard writing snippets of code or scripting. Not for the faint of heart or the unprepared.

I was referral by a member from their group. 
1 on 1 phone interview. I went on a detailed interview about my research about 30 mins. Then I got a programming interview for the rest of 30 mins.

First an online assessment, then a behavioural phone interview and after that the final round interview.  The last interview was technical, 5 rounds with different interviewers (45min each). Leetcode style questions.

4 interviews, 
1. technical with a team member
2. AA interview with group manager
3. design with team member
4. technical  with team leader

depending on when the interviews are held, you might not do all of them (as in ,failing the first 1-2 will terminate the process)
me contacto recursos humanos desde Brasil y coordino las entrevistas, unas fueron remotas y otras presenciales, en ese momento se podía presencial pero entiendo que ahora ya todo es virtual

Was good. The interviewer was very friendly. I could not get the offer only because I was not prepared well. The interview process was held completely online. I was asked to find the area of intersection of two rectangles.

The process started with a personal interview on zoom and a test on codility, the questions were not hard,
but the codility interface was terrible.
after that i got invited to a second interview that was mainly telling me about the company with technical coding questions, i had  the question of printing out alll the permutations of a string, and had no idea how to do it
3 interviews, all 3 technical. Asked questions around strings , stack and trees. Other than that there is one screening round where interviewer asks about current role and 1 coding question

Applied online, only using the CV (no cover letter). I had my first phone interview after 3 weeks, not more than 5-6 questions, very relaxed. I have been invited to an assessment center a few days after, which was virtual and I had to prepare a 10 min presentation, then a strength-based interview and then a Microsoft challenge. Great experience, all the interviewers were very positive and made me feel confident.
A long process of built of many sessions.  Started with zoom talk that was more HR like,  than It moved on to three more technical interviews, the last one was the longest and more challenging one.

My interview was held remotely at the beginning of the pandemic. Some of the steps were weird, as they were still figuring out how to interview remotely. But it covered a range of topics that I would expect to cover in a Software Engineering interview

Could have been goog but in beginning of covid period, never heard of them after first interview due to cancelling the physical interviews and other process this year. The lady that interviewed me was however really kind and told me that had should go to the next step. Did not happen.

It started with an initial 1 HR screening interview and then 2 CBI (Competency Based Interviews) with my direct managers  and finally a Technical interview with a case study showcasing to a customer the capabilities of the product

You apply via Microsoft portal and then university recruiters reach out in case there is a fit with your resume and the role they are looking for. Make sure to have your resume tailored to the role you apply.

Three interviews around Microsoft teams, one more technical, the next was more personality and the last was a presentation and some questions around that. Each Interview was over Microsoft Teams with one person on each session.
Very slow, made to wait, had to follow up, in the end was told it was filled and that I was overqualified??? I will not apply again. Waste of time.

1 recruiter interview, 1 algorithm question face to face, and site interview with 4 people for 1 hour each. The site interview has 1 behavioral and 3 technical parts. First Question is design a whats up system, second question is transformation of data from legacy system to new system when both of them in live environment.

Had a behavioral phone screen and then final round in person in Boston which consisted of 4 rounds. 2 behavioral interviews and 2 technical ones. The technical interview was not that hard but I was personally not ready for it at the time.

Starts with One coding round written having 2 questions. One DS Algorithm F2F round having 2 moderate questions. One HLD/LLD round. Hiring manager round. All rounds took place om the same day as it was a drive. I was told that Iw as hired on the same day. But the offer rollouts happend in 2 weeks

Their interview was conducted in a very personable and friendly manner. Don't professionally and straight to the point, but was extremely encouraging at the same time. Some times I have an interview and the interviewer turns me off from the position, but not this one.
30 min Teams call. Basic resume question and one technical question but overall very doable if you prepare a bit. Focus is on why you want to work for them and what makes you a good fit.
The process will be held on zoom application at 10:30 wat, and two or more interviewer will participate in this interview and only one interviewee will interviewed this is all the process
Awesome experience. Two rounds of technical + behavioral interviews. Get to stay at a nice inn and food you eat are reimbursed. The offices are really nice, people are welcoming, and always smiling.

The hiring process went well. Very helpful recruiters assisting you in being successful, and the everyone I communicated with was very welcoming and passionate about what they do.  I was very nervous, but the interviewers gave any information they had about the internship and went from one in-person interview to the next, and were thoughtful enough to even think about breaks for coffee. Thoroughly enjoyed it.
4 hour 4 round one to one interviews in the afternoon.  Coding questions on white board. About 2 questions or one questions with follow up questions within 45 mins. also tell about yourself.
I interviewed for SWE summer intern. First there was an on-campus interview which was half an hour. Later they flied me to Redmond for onsite interviews. My interview consisted of two rounds.

One round with a peer who has the same profile as the position I was getting interviewed for. Once i cleared it, another round with director. After clearing it, another round with HR business partner. Last it was a salary discussion.

I applied on their website, and was contacted in a month for a phone screen. The hiring manager asked a fairly basics design question, and ended the interview stating interest in having me come for an on-site. The on-site consisted of 5 interviews and a lunch in the team's offices.

Apply through the careers section on Microsoft’s own website. 
Short phone interview with recruiter to ensure you are applying for the correct role. 
“Hiring day” consisting of presentations and standard interview questions further determine fit in the role and company culture.

I have applied through a referral. I received a mail after a week asking me to provide time slots for a phone interview. I was interviewed virtually for nearly 45 minutes.
The interviewer asked details about my resume, behavioral questions and some technical questions . Overall experience was good and i found the interviewer very friendly. 
After a couple of days, i received a mail stating that i was selected for the final round of interviews and was invited for an  onsite interview at Microsoft Office in Seattle. 
On the interview day, they conducted 4 back to back interviews each taken by a different interviewer. Each interview lasted from 45-60 minutes where they asked questions related to Machine Learning, Probability and Statistics, Programming and questions based on your projects and research papers if you have any in your resume.
 I don't exactly remember the questions they have asked . Overall, the interview experience was good. Unfortunately, three days after the interview i got an email stating that i was not selected.

Two online interviews and One assesment day at the end that lasted for a full day at the msft offices. The people there were really friendly ,we had lunch and generally it lasted from 9 to 5 that day. It was an enjoyable day.
I had previously had an internship so I went straight to final round, stardard coding questions. They flew me to Dublin and paid for 2 nights at a great hotel.

Interview process contained one online test which contaned four programming tasks. People who passed the test got a chance for the internship with three onsite interviews. Programming tasks which were included in test were mostly data and algorithms related problems.

The interviewer was very friendly, she asked me about myself, my preferences if I start to work for Microsoft. Then she asked me about previous projects, but nothing too technical. Overall she wanted to know what areas I have worked in, after the call I have gotten a confirmation that she has forwarded my application to the area I have experience in, however, did not get an offer.

The interview process consisted of a call with the recruiter about your past experience and why you want to work for Microsoft. Once you get past that they send you an online coding test and if you pass that then 4 in person interviews at the Microsoft office.

The interviewers were nice and very willing to answer questions about culture, work, other activities at Microsoft. The questions were average difficulty, once solved they focused on getting an optimal answered with lowest time/space complexity. Each interviewer asked one problem solving question along with some behavioural questions.

The recruiter was a bit sketchy and follow up is not very good even after getting an offer. After signing the contract becomes even worse. Also for some reason salary ranges at Microsoft, Dublin are far lower than their other locations as well as salary ranges of other companies in Dublin.
Good but it could have gone better. I would say, make sure to know your DS&A fundamentals and you should be good. They asked me to reverse a linked list. I did it iteratively. It was alright overall.

Overall was pleasant - behavior interview went well but technical interview was difficult. Ultimately did not get an offer but the process itself was good. The interviewers were nice and pleasant to me, and had taken time to listen and talk back and forth past the interview times on ice breakers.

Primero fue una entrevista con una persona del outsourcing muy general, preguntas de mi experiencia anterior, pretenciones de sueldo, si hablaba inglés y me dijo la descripción de sueldo. La segunda entrevista fue presencial con la manager y me preguntó detalladamente algún proceso que llevara a cabo en mi empleo anterior, alguna vez que hubiera tratado con un manager difícil ypreguntas en inglés

(Student position): The interview started with the interviewer explaining a bit about the team I was interviewing for. He then questioned me a bit about a recent large-scale programming project I did for college, presented me with two coding exercises, and finally let me ask my own questions.

Preguntas y respuestas, con diversos tópicos técnicos de los cuales había que conocer muy bien y que es difícil de explicar a grandes rasgos . Más que nada se centra en el tema programación, algo muy amplio y aún más en 2020 dónde la información es tan confusa por tanta distracción

The process itself consisted of two parts: the online coding and the interview. Online coding part consisted of 4 questions on a platform to be done in 3 hours. Interviews consisted of 3 one hour long interviews, focusing on the knowledge of algorithms and data structures.

I was scheduled a short phone interview in October, mostly behavioral questions and logic. It took a while for them to get back to me. I was originally rejected due to space, but kept checking back with recruiter and she eventually offered me an on site interview for early February. On-site consisted of two 45-minute interviews back to back.

First id did an Home test. Its a test with three questions in codility. 
then, I did an interview with technical recruiter that asked me easy logical questions.
And lastly, I did a technical interview whitch I didnt pass. I answerd all currectly but I didnt pass.

Bad experience.They ask us to build meeting calendar invite and time duration for an 1:30 hour and they expect us to write neat and create component based in vanilla javascript.Once the time is over, they call us individually to show what we build.They didn't see the code how clean we write, they expect we would completed almost 80% functionality.Atleast in microsoft Bangalore, they are not hiring smart people, it just like you know how to complete the task.Come and we will hire you.Bar of quality people is degraded in Bangalore as I got to know by assignment no professionalism and I got the same feedback from couple of my friends.Atleast some other companies are really good and know what they can expect from candidate.

Very well organized, and smooth. The whole process was very well planned and everything went very smoothly. There was little downtime in the four hours of interviews, interviewing with program managers, hiring managers, and technical employees.

Il colloquio consisteva in un assessment di gruppo per una posizione di intern. Ho sostenuto due colloquio, uno con hr e uno con un ingegnere, sebbene entrambi non fossero tecnici, più un esercizio di gruppo. Tralasciando la qualità delle domande, dove forse volevano sentirsi dire discorsi di Satya Nadella ripetuti come un pappagallo, avevano detto che ciascun candidato avrebbe ricevuto dalla recruiter un feedback positivo o negativo che fosse entro una certa data.  Passate un paio di settimane rispetto a questa data ho scritto per ben due volte alla recruiter per chiedere molto educatamente quantomeno un feedback per migliorarmi, ha visualizzato i messaggi senza rispondermi. Non è un comportamento corretto e serio nei confronti di chi si impegna e dimostra magari di non aver le qualità che cercavano, ma quantomeno serietà ed educazione.

processus en 3 phases : sélection sur cv, entretien skype et journée dans les locaux. Le processus est globalement bienveillant et on est bien guidé tout au long. Les questions sont axées sur nos projets personnels et associatifs, comme ce serait dans d'autres entreprises comparables
good, best, better, it's all good. I like it.  I loved it. It's my dream job. I recommend everyone. Go for it. Just do it. Yes, it's worth it. I wish you all the best

First round interview
Behaviour based (mostly competency questions)
30 minutes in total conducted on Microsoft Teams
The interview will be based on your motivation and the skills we feel are required for the role you have applied for. You will get the opportunity to express who you are, your passion for Microsoft and technology.

First-round was an online coding assessment, there were 2 questions based on arrays.

The second round was again mentioned as the coding round but it was a mix of coding, design and technical questions

The third round was again mentioned as a coding round but again here it was a mix of coding and technical questions.

Did not make it through to the last two rounds.

Microsoft has outsourced recruiters and these people are not so helpful in the interview process, all they do is send emails and create meetings.

Before the interviews there was a document shared describing the interview process, but it did not mention clearly what each round will look like. I was fully prepared for problem-solving and system design, but there were many framework related questions asked and I managed to solve all the problems in all the rounds, so I feel my rejection is because of the framework and language-related questions. So it's better if they inform the candidate how the interview rounds are going to look like so that one can prepare accordingly. Most of the questions were known to me but was not able to answer because of not concentrating or revising on these aspects before the interview.

There were 2 total interviews, Each interview was a total of 45 minutes. Both interviews were similarly broken down. 15 minutes for introduction, 25 minutes to solve technical questions, and 5 minutes for questions. The behavioral questions were the most difficult in my opinion. They asked behavioral questions I did not expect. I did research on Glassdoor and connect with previous Leap members.

I had three interviews spread within the time frame of a week. 
The first interview was more like feeling out waters. The senior researcher gave a brief introduction regarding the work they were doing. I briefly explained my research interests.

Second interview was more focused on me and my research topic.

The third interview is scheduled for tomorrow.

It was good. 
1. But the interviewer was having a bad internet connection which led to only an audio call on Teams. A video call would be better.
2. The interviewer asked me NOT to say out loud my thoughts while solving the given problem, contrary to which I read.

Took my interview virtually and they used Codility. They make you use Codility's whiteboard feature to let you sketch out your design, but it feels much more time consuming compared to using an actual whiteboard. Also expect to run your code depending on the problem.

There were four (one hour) interviews in one day and an hour break after the second interview. The interviewers were pretty friendly and the questions were LeetCode medium.
got an instruction about the role for 40 minutes, and you asked a couple of questions. casual meeting. still some people  fail, so be careful. If you pass, you will be notified about the next step.

Recruiter reached me on LinkedIn, and then applied for SDE I position and the received codility test to complte in 2 weeks.

Two steps
1. Online assessment
2. Virtual onsite with 4 rounds consists of coding and behavioral questions. 
3. result/feedback shared in 3days after final round.
Overall, its  a great expereince.
Coding assessment, you had to solve coding problems as part of a coding test, which was the second part of the interview process and the last part is an interview with the team (loop interview)
Interview process takes time, they will do a background check prior to releasing the offer. There will be 5 rounds in total, 2-3 technical rounds, 1 HM round and a GM Round.

phone, onsite, all the standard processes. easy overall, coding and behavioral questions, love the team and people. very positive and many cool technologies, love the team, love the people and everything I see

I was invited by a recruiter through a friend's referral. The interview process began with a presentation of one of my project in front of ~4 employees. After the presentation, I went through a few rounds of in-person meetings that included personal questions and quick design challenges that tested my problem solving skills.

There was an initial phone screen by recruiters that are contracted by Microsoft. It went well and was very friendly. Primary questions were about security clearance, why I was leaving my prior employer, and a run down of my skills and work work experience. Moving forward I was selected for 3 back to back virtual interviews via Skype. The recruiter called me the night before and we went over some of the points that she knew they were looking for. Overall the 3 interviews went well, friendly, and mix of behavioral and skill based questions. At the end of the day, I was not selected for the position and the recruiter never followed up with me like she said she would.

Skype interview talking about past experiences both technical and non-technical followed by an AI-related question. Talked about the length of past programming experiences, the different groups i had worked with and how i felt this related to the position i was applying for.
Skipped first rounds due to referral. Final round interview with two technical questions, each leetcode easy. They are very vague with their questions on purpose, so you should ask more questions.
Initial on campus interview followed by four on-site interviews. For the on-site interviews everyone was flown out to Seattle. It was overall a positive experience and included a short tour.

I applied through university and received an invite to interview on campus. Then around one weeks later I heard that I was waitlisted for interview spots, but eventually (maybe two more weeks later) they offered to fly me out to a final interview in Washington.
1. The Campus Interview
The campus interview was fairly straight forward. They asked me a something that tested data structures. I didn't actually catch on the the interviewer wanted me to use a hash table for a bit but he was really patient with me and encouraging. He then asked me how I felt about the Tesla touchscreen displays in the cars and asked me to why touchscreen or traditional knobs might be better or worse.

2. The Final Round
The final round consisted of four interviews each around 45 minutes. There were no coding questions unless you were coming from a non-computing major (I chatted with a bunch of the other interviewees and that's the conclusion we'd come to since the only two non-computing were the only two who got technical questions).
My first round asked me about any projects I've worked on. I mentioned one from a previous job and he grilled me on my design choices in the project (though it was a basic intern project with the design choices already made for me so he asked me how I would have designed it). He then asked me some general questions about if I were given a product and a team what would I do. He narrowed the question down as I asked clarifying questions.
My second round interviewer began by pointing out the same project on my resume from my previous job and asked about the design choices again.
My third round began by saying she spoke to my previous interviewer and wanted to hear about my project from my previous job (tbh at this point I really wish I could have talked about something else). Luckily, this interviewer decided to go off the original problem my project was solving and asked for a larger scope how would I solve the problems.
My fourth round was the most fun. He asked about an app I use a lot. I mentioned Spotify. He had me try to improve the product coming up with three new features. He then asked for a big new change for Spotify.

Did a phone interview, very brief, only about 30 minutes and it seemed to me that the interviewer had  a list of questions to go through. Mostly behavioral looking to see your passion   for tech and how you think of technology. Not even asked to tell me about yourself

Was one phone call with a director in product marketing. Completely behavioral questions, a lot of them were testing your marketing knowledge. Took extremely long to get back to me- that was probably the sign I didn’t make it to the next round.

The person was not at all interested in the work that I did, even belittled the projects I worked on. It seemed like he had come to a conclusion before conducting the interview. Asked me what I knew about recommendation systems (something I barely knew about), and then proceeded to ask me in-depth questions on it.

The process was disordered. Recruiters did not arranged well. The boss round is not professional. Too difficult to concur the flight and hotels. The process was disordered. Recruiters did not arranged well. The boss round is not professional. Too difficult to concur the flight and hotels.

3 technical rounds.
first was group fly round then followed technical rounds.
you should be strong with problem-solving and communicating your ideas as you think with your interviewer.
it was for 2 months summer internships so they didn't ask much about core subjects, although basic OS questions  was asked.

Casual interview. The interviewers are the mentors I will work with. First they asked me to do a brief self-introduction and then start technical questions. The questions are easy. Overall a happy experience.

45 minutes phone interview. The interviewer was helpful and asked questions mainly on resume, computer architecture, SV, UVM and verification scenarios. It was my first interview so I was nervous and unprepared.

The position was phd data science position at Microsoft. I applied online got a phone call at the end of December about the datasets I have worked with and some behavioral questions. A week later I invited to have an onsite interview.

The interviewers are very courteous and are genuinely interested in you. There were 5 interview rounds scheduled for me and had a gap of 10 mins between them.  They also had a person accompany me for lunch and it was wonderful experience.

I applied online to Microsoft ATL in Cairo.
First a codility test is sent to be completed in 90 minutes, the test consists of three questions one mcq and two algorithms/ data structures problems.
If the candidate passes the technical online test, he will be asked to attend an online interview, which is nearly of 6~7 rounds.

Super quick and smooth: the whole process is very quick and the hiring committee inform me in a timely manner. The interviewers are professional. The questions are fair and very related. All professional

There was an intial onsite interview in San Francisco. It was fairly straight forward, a leetcode easy problem. The interviewer was not great, as they were on their phone for the majority of the interview. I then got flown out to Microsoft where I had a final round interview.
It was a nice experience, the interviewer was very friendly, and I got to know more about the company and the tasks for my role. It is a nice company to join.

Interview process has 4 rounds involved. first two were technical and other two were manager rounds.
each round was about 40 - 45 minutes.
After al4 rounds were cleared, HR intimated that they would get back

Found the job opportunity and asked for a referral from one MSFT friend. One HR phone interview for basic questions and then one onsite interview with the hiring team. The onsite one was with 5 interviewers includes hire manager, team peers and the their director.

I first applied to Microsoft online during my last month of seasonal employment at my last job. I tested the system with an attempt at the gaming position (because I’ve only been playing video games for almost 20 years) and they had a question about whether I worked professionally with video game troubleshooting for over a year. I guess not so maybe I would have had to work at GameStop? Anyway I got an automated rejection email a day later just to see how the system worked.

So I received an email about a week after my application for the Part Time Product Advisor position from a recruiter with a “phone screen” questionnaire. Here’s the kicker, I thought it was fake! The email was full of typos and the email looked different from the ones directly from Microsoft. I never got a phone call yet either. I did loads of research for the questions and to test if it was all legitimate. I tried calling the Microsoft Store I applied to and got stuck with the automated assistant and Google was no help. Even job sites like this one lacked people in my situation. I typed out the questions in the table format she sent me and sent them off just to see what happened. I waited a week and got no response. I found her on LinkedIn instead just to update her on my employment availability which became open later in the month after my seasonal job ended. 

Lo and behold, I actually received a call though because I was still hesitant, I truly did not know it was her until it was too late and I got the voicemail. She was calling from California I think which spooked me. The call was unanswered and now that I think about it, perhaps it could have helped me get the job.

That weekend I actually got a missed call and voicemail from the Microsoft Store I applied to but it was a different number than what I called initially. Luckily, I got a follow up email immediately and it turned out the Assistant Manager was trying to schedule an interview for next week. 

A team member greeted me and welcomed me into the store on the interview day. He offered me a bottle of water after I told him I was here for an interview. I then waited for a few minutes at a nice gaming PC station until the Assistant Manager greeted me. I was startled but he seemed like a nice guy. He also offered me a bottle of water. The back room looked a bit like the Apple Store. I was pleasantly surprised that I was in a 1-on-1 interview and not a panel as described by most people who reported interviews for Microsoft.

I felt that things were going well again until the interview. I think even though I studied for a month for this position, because I was late and in a panic to get there thanks to unreliable transportation, I forgot much of everything. I didn’t even show him my questionnaire or harp on about Microsoft and Xbox like I have initially. He didn’t really ask me to elaborate on my skills and what qualifications I have outside of that pesky retail and past job experience. I ended the interview early without closure. I went home worried and confused as well as tired but I had to come up with a thank you email ASAP.

Now I waited about 10 days just like the job sites recommended which was silly because by the time it reached day 10, in the middle of my follow up email with the recruiter, I was already denied the job before the automated email told me as I checked the career site and I expressed that in my message. I wasn’t sure if it was because I really didn’t qualify or if I should have replied earlier. I can say though it must have gone well enough because it took nearly half a month for them to deny me as opposed to just over the weekend. I could always try again down the line.

One First Round interview. If selected for final round then 3 back to back interviews. First round is behavioral+case. One of the three final round interview focus on why microsoft and is behavioral. One interview is with your hiring manager and is behavioral+case. The third interview in final round is a fit+why marketing role interview and is behavioral.

Easy and very know questions asked. Interview was friendly.
GFG questions and some related to my recent projects.
know questions asked. Questions were asked from linked list, Operating systems, networking,graph,dynamic programming.
Questions were asked from linked list,DP,graph,puzzle,maths

1 hour phone screen with general DS/ML questions followed with full day on site loop. 5 1 hour interviews in total. I didn't really know what to expect going in and got a pretty wide range of questions. Topics involved data structures & algos, experimentation, dealing with dirty data, & lots of statistics/machine learning questions. Overall everyone was really friendly sharp & smart. I also had a few curveball questions thrown my way where the interviewer was trying to see if they could catch me off guard.

121 interview with hiring manager which took place at their headquarters in Reading.  The interview was relaxed and relatively informal.  HR were not present so the interview focussed on previous work experience.

Surprised that it was actually comprised of mostly qualitative questions rather than diving deeper into proof of quantitative / analytic abilities. Everyone I interacted with was enthusiastic and seemed genuine.

Simple phone interview, DP questions--all the usual for any CS related company now a days. It was not very special in terms of an interview. the DP was not too hard and was approximately at the difficult of leetcode medium.

Was interviewed for the role last year. Technical interview  1 round: Object oriented programming questions were asked. Also, initially questions were based on the resume and projects done. Interviewer was nice.

1 hour interview  with the Lead Executive assistant with main focus on your previous experience, softskills,  ability to deal with multiple executives and managing complex calendars for several executives. Ability to self manage and work with global teams. A quite intensive interview.

The whole interview process was very smooth in general. Given break time between two rounds - that helped to restore breath. The interviewers were very supportive and helped to get to the solution together.
I applied online then received an e-mail. It was pretty straight forward. The questions were the typical questions you would receive during interviews. Do not stress out! You will be fine

Suboptimal experience for a corporate organisation.  Contradicting criteria for the job role and poor communication. Interviews cancelled at last minute. On one occasion the interviewer thought I was an internal candidate, and obviously didn't review my CV prior to the call.
Lengthy and in depth just for a person that is looking to apply for a position in facilities management. The process went smooth but yet it was lengthy. The interviewer was thorough yet inquisitive.
1st part of the process is passing a general interview in english, telling about your self and answering questions about your studies, difficulties you have had with partners. then the technical part

Phone Interview (5-6 questions with some design questions - tests more of critical thinking and design strategies). 
Technical Interview (2 coding problems with any language of your choosing). Much more challenging than initial interview
Heard back from Microsoft regarding acceptance the following day.
The interview was not hard and it was very much behavioral. They want to see if you are a learner and if you can adapt quickly. Overall, it was not very difficult.

The interview was on their main campus. At first the recruiter gave a brief introduction and their contact. And then they called a campus shuttle car to take me to the office building. All interviews happened in this building. Four rounds, plus one lunch chat.
Tough but fair.  They are looking for a good two way fit. They will also tell you what they expect out of the position and the metrics by which your performance will be reviewed.

Got a an interview that lasted about an hour. Was called first then did the interview over the computer. Was asked basic behavioural questions and asked to code some solutions to data structure problems. Was fairly straight forward.

At Microsoft, there is no fixed interview process or format-- it varies between product groups and teams. However, the most common process consists of 4-5 rounds focused on testing the analytical, problem-solving, and technical skills of the candidate.

The whole process is smooth and good. Honestly speaking I didn't go for the interview, but Glassdoor is forcing me to fill up something so :/ But let me just type some random stuff, so I can continue to do my own research
I was given an interview after handing in my resume at University job fair. Later on, they flew me into California for a in person interview. The interview was very technical.
There are five round , 2 Technical , 2 management and 1 HR behavioral round and it took 3 months to get the offer letter. HR team generally don't do much negations.

difficult process that was hard to understand 
difficult process that was hard to understand 
difficult process that was hard to understand 
difficult process that was hard to understand 
difficult process that was hard to understand difficult process that was hard to understand

the first round is an online assessment and then 45 min phone screeen with hiring manager and then you move on virutal onsite, which consist of three round of technical question from your peer, manager, and so on

It was fairly straightforward. There was first a phone interview with behavioral and basic coding relating questions (i.e. differences between ArrayList and LinkedList, etc.) The next round was a technical "whiteboard" interview (I did it virtually) with two technical coding questions.

You have a phone screen that is mostly behavioral and just asks you a few questions to see how you think. Second interview I was flown out to Redmond; whole trip was paid for, super fun experience. Two technical interviews in a row. Medium/easy level questions.

Third party recruiter really struggled to coordinate with tons of meeting invites and frequent changes.

On the day of the interview, nobody showed up and had to call up the recruiter.

They coordinated and someone showed up after almost 20 minutes of interview start time.

That delayed the next interview which was right after the first with no buffer in between.

Did not expect Microsoft people to be so unprofessional and lack coordination.

Final round was 4 back to back interviews. Product design and in depth resume questions. All with different program managers in Microsoft and was quite difficult. Estimation, behavioral, and other questions as well.
HR talk for 40 min. Then going for an onsite 2 months later. Have not gone to the on-site yet. The on-site will be in February. Have to write 30 words.
I had a feeling like I was screened by a person who doesn't fully understand the technology.  Also, it was very impersonate and cynical. Like all I care what check-boxes I have to put in my form.

Although every individual will have a different experience. Many factors come into play when it comes to the interviewing process however it is important to closely work with the recruiter and also make your own research prior to the interview.

Very easy and very nice interviewers. The response was quick. You have to be checking your action center on a weekly basis. At first, it is a phone interview and then if selected, you interview in Redmond on the Microsoft campus

Very informational and thorough. They had many good questions to ask me and fortunately I answered them well to my knowledge. Unfortunately, I was unable to receive the internship.  It is okay though, I found another place.

Technical quiz, asked me many hard questions related to software development and project management.  The call kept losing connection, but luckily the lady was friendly about it and we continued the interview where we left off.  Overall, it was a difficult interview, but I made it to the next round despite not feeling like it had gone well.
Interview was 4 hours with a break scheduled between the first two interviews.  During one of the hours I had two people interviewing me at one time but the others were one on one.

We connected on skype, she asked me few questions that   I felt like I can't really express myself in the answers, and we finished after about 10 minutes. I really felt like she want to be other with it, and it stressed me out a bit, although the questions were personal and not professional

I was passed around 3 HRs just to schedule a phone screen and the process took 1.5 months!! This is ridiculous considering the fact that MS has such great reputation. NO CODING questions at all. Interviewer needs to wake up!! Ended supposed-to-be 30 minute talk in just 17.

Applied online through Microsoft Careers and got a phone interview about a month later. Phone interview was not technical and they asked annoying curveball questions. I was invited for an onsite about 3 weeks later. I chose the January date which in retrospect was not smart; I heard that the acceptance rate is much higher for the earlier cohorts. The final round for me was all behavioural which is not normal. I got my rejection 3 weeks later. Overall, it was a good interview experience and the recruiters responded very quickly to any questions I had. The one weird thing is in the final round they said they would make their decisions today (the day of the interview) so I should expect to hear from them in 3 weeks.

The person seemed rigid and he asked me for the reason of change to start with after respective intros. Maybe I said something that I should not have, so even after answering and implementing the code, I dint get through.

Mehrere telefonische Interviews. Alle sehr angenehm und in diverse Richtungen. 
Ich empfand dass man sich intensiv um neue Mitarbeiter bemüht und dabei auch auf die Erfahrung besonders Wert legt. Die technischen Fragen sind tatsächlich realitätsnah

Long and and a lot of talking. Asked a lot of questions including a lot about my history and my college education as well as my experience. They emphasized on how they have teamwork and expect their employees to be a team

A 30-minute phone call/ short discussion on Skype. With several situational questions and opinion related questions. For a role in placement with Microsoft. Felt very brief yet was not selected to progress. Felt impossible to get wrong and was more a way of filtering candidates rather than assessing them.

It was an hiring event held by MS. I saw around 50 interviewers candidates during the onsite event.
Before onsite, there's 1 round of OA.
There are 3 rounds during the onsite interview.

I got the recruitment information from one professor's email. I applied online and got back in one week. Scheduled a 30 min phone interview in 2 weeks. Then I waited for 3 weeks and got decline email from the recruiter. If it goes well, you would be contacted in around 2 weeks.

Initial contact from recruitment teams and scheduling teams was superb. First telephone interview seamless. First face to face interview fantastic, second face to face interview brilliant. Then the problems started. I was told I would hear decision about the job in three working days. A week went by, chased, recruiter couldn't get replies from interviewer / hiring manager. Waited another few days, still was unable to give answer but feedback was the interview went superbly, as did one other. Waited a total of almost 3 weeks, VM to say I hadn't got job. No issue with that but any feedback since I've waited 3 weeks? Nothing. Not even a reply.

Interview process consists of 1)phone screen and 2) first round of tech interview over the phone. If you do well, you get to called for an F2F at Microsoft (Onsite interview at Redmond, WA office). There would be 4-5 rounds each of approximately 45 mins - 1 hr.  
Questions will be around Tech fundamentals, major projects you recently worked on, key skills you mentioned. Good understanding of communication, teamwork and support roles is a plus. Interviewers are very friendly and even drop hints while asking questions. They are more interested in finding out your approach to solve a problem, than solution. 
Being at Microsoft Redmond campus itself is an experience. Be sure to visit Microsoft Visitors Center.

3 vorstellungsgespraeche 
- firs one : HR
- second: hiring manager
-third: case presentation and 4 people present

the first HR round is quick and basic questions and by the phone
second one and third u need to really prepare ! the case is very important. they will check your presentation skills therefore train before

Interviews were standard electrical engineering interviews with technical and behavioral questions. Interviewers were knowledgeable in their fields and interviews sessions were interactive. 

The negative experience came from Microsoft travel schedulers and their lack of communication and organization within the group and also with external vendors like the Fort Collins Marriott. I was charged for the hotel and multiple phone calls/emails to both organizations for over 4 months have still not resolved the expenses, even after acknowledgement from the travel agency and Marriott that the charges should be refunded. 

Interview candidates should be aware when they checkout of hotels reserved by MS travel and ensure that they are not charged to avoid getting into situations like this.

Recruiter reached out on LinkedIn 
Phone interview 
Onsite interview consisted of three rounds .
One issue is that they interview differently for the same software engineering role . So do charcoal with recruiter in detail what team they are recruiting you for as that decides what kind of question you will get

Recruitment process. 
1-Dynamic test group
2-Mathematic test
3-English test
4-Spanish test
5-Personal Branding
To put in a nutshell, it was easy but you have to structure your ideas clearly.

You do not need any king of computer knowledge. I meand C++, Python, etc

Telephonic interview. Very easy- translating sentence and words in German from English. Basic Introduction in German. Education and why studying German? Resource used.
Only consulting company can recruit you for the position. No online application is valid.

It was a weekend drive, and managed by vendors. Right from not calling the right candidates to massive gap in panel's expectation and JD, it was a very mismanaged event. The interviews were delayed, and looked like the panel was not very much interested in taking the interviews post lunch. They had called non-engineers too but wanted them to code on the job, if required. This was neither mentioned nor spoken about, in screening phone calls.
Contacted by a recruiter from my college and then had an onsite interview in Seattle area. They paid for car, hotel, etc. I had 5 rounds of interviews each asking mostly technical questions.

Total 6 rounds, first round is hiring manager. The second round is more technical. The following rounds are from peers or people from other teams. If the result is positive, the recruiter will contact you.

It was very cool but I also found it to be kind of a bit difficult.  I initially applied online but was then later asked to partake in a hireview.  The hireview asked pretty standard questions about business development and my interest in this field.  They also inquired about my background.

Got contacted by recruiter. One phone interview and then flew in for onsite. Onsite was 5 rounds with one engineer each from the team.  All were very technical. Included references to past projects/experiences as well.

Microsoft has highest integrity, runs on trust, cares about their employees, works w/ you to get work/life balance, provides a work environment that is highest Microsoft has highest integrity, runs on trust, cares about their employees, works w/ you to get work/life balance, provides a work environment that is highest

first interview was a computer test 
the second was technical interview knowledge
the third was interview technical questions 
the process was not very quick and it was virtual on all of it parts
Kids were in the background during the interview so it was very distracting. I had a hard time figuring out the code since there were noise.  Overall, I did not like the interview

Initial screening call with HR followed by a discussion with a hiring manager, there were a number of other stages following that. Discussion with hiring manager was primarily a CV review and standard questions, nothing complex.

My University had a Microsoft rep come to campus and interview in person. He asked a basic DFS question, and I was then ghosted by the University recruiter. I pinged them 4 times over the span of several months before abruptly offered an onsite.

Interviewed at NSBE through referral by a previous intern and got call for an onsite interview. During onsite interview, I was interviewed by about 4 persons. included a lunch interview as well as met with the hiring manager. This was for an internship.
It was a great experience . I was suppose to ans every que, but I was not able to. They did select another candidate fr=or this job >> that was sad

So the first part of my interview contained online test after clearing which I got a mail from university recruitment team telling I had cleared the interview and they had given me dates of my next round i.e. virtual interview which was for about 50mins . About a week later I got a mail mentioned that I had cleared technical round and I had to fly to hyderabad for my next round which was mannegerial round  which was for about 45mins. After an Hour they annouced the result and we were asked to have another round that is HR round. I had cleared HR round too.... And the the results were announced !

BUT ! I WAS THE ONLY ONE WHO WAS ASKED TO HAVE ONE MORE ROUND OF INTERVIEW ! WHICH WAD DELAYED AND THEN THE COVID HAPPENED. DUE TO WHICH MY JOB FOR FRESHER WENT ON HOLD AND THE HR HAS NOT BEEN RESPONDING EVEN AFTER CONTINOUS MAILS AND CALLS.......

Online test
Virtual interview
1:1 interview (mannegerial round)
1:1 HR round

Ich habe mich über LinkedIn beworben und habe zwei Wochen später eine Einladung zu einem Vorstellungsgespräch mit der Personalabteilung bekommen. Das Gespräch fand über Skype statt, da die Personalabteilung in Dublin war. Das Gespräch verlief sehr gut und ich hatte eine gute Chance meine Fähigkeiten und Kenntnisse zu zeigen.
On site, 4 round interview. One technical interview with the rest a mix of behavioral and cases. There was a large group of students that were all there for the same set of roles.

About one week after submitting my application, I got an email to schedule a phone screening for the following week. The call was very brief and the interviewer did not seem to know about the position. He just went through all of the listed requirements in the job posting and asked if I had experience with each of them.

Lengthy interview process. Took more than 1.5 hours. The interviewer went through all the previous experiences. Discussed career goals. Explained the current position and its responsibilities. The position has 5 people reporting to the finance manager.

Skype HR interview (a little about professional experience as well as classic HR questions) and two technical interviews (mostly algorithms and data structures, write in any programming language you know).

Usually 3 rounds
All technical
Two coding and one design discussion.
Coding is focused on data structures and algorithms and problem solving. More focus was on approach and way of thinking rather then final solution. Try to give multiple solutions to a problem.
Lastly a hiering manager round which is mostly discussion about projects and some technical questions.

there was one 30 minute technical interview over the phone. They call you and then give you a technical question and then ask you random stuff about your resume. If you pass that they send you to microsoft for a real interview.

Intern to full time transfer. 2 technical interviews (after OA and HR phone screen etc) for the internship then one interview after completing my internship. Entire process was fairly standard throughout.

Series of technical discussions and sales methods within domain area. Discussion with the current sales team. Final round was a example sales questions / presentations. Structure was very dynamic, unlikely other candidates would see similar

Long, but very fair and with a lot of help from the company. Technical and behavioral interviews mixed after an online assessment. Mainly algorithmic and data structure question with some system design as well
1 Phone screen and 3 virtual onsite interview and also a recuriter screen. The questions were from the leetcode Microsoft tagged questions. All of the interviews are 1 hour interview.

it went well and the employer was very friendly and eased out the process for the ones who were very anxious about the interview. Overall the experience boosted my confidence and gave me strength for further interviews
Met recruiter on college campus. I had one phone screen which was more background. Then they flew me out and I also one 4 interview block with coding on campus in Redmond.

Interview with two team members, lasted about 30 minutes. Very friendly environment, it was a rather short interview. The panel was very hurried and looked to finish the interviews quickly. As I was already experienced in giving interviews, I was calm and confident.

5 rounds of interview. First 3 are manager rounds. One director and the last is HR round. Manager rounds are scenario and experience based Questions. They had set 2 more interviews but the interviewer did not show up.

Came in through the college program. Interviewers made me feel very comfortable and mostly asked situational questions. It’s definitely a plus to have experience with the products, but it was clear they judged based on your ability to learn

1 hour Interview which was half Coding Challenge and half Resume Questions/Behavioral Interview. Followed by 5 hour Onsite which consisted of 4 coding challenges and 1 behavioral Interview. All the coding challenges started simple and built toward increasing complexity.

The interview lasted 30 mins. The recruiter was very nice and tried to make me feel comfortable. It was the first round, so there were no technical questions. The questions were concerning my way of thinking and also some scenario-based ones.

I met with two pairs of people over Microsoft Teams, one interview was technical, and the other was culture fit. Both interviews were on the same day, about an hour apart, and I received feedback within a week.

I applied through LinkedIn, got an email back a couple of days later. In the email they asked me to answer all sorts of questions....in a table...in an email. Kind of weird they don't have a form link or an automated process for this. Based on the answers to the questions, they decided to move forward and book a phone screener the following week. I thought the interview went well, apparently it didn't. I was told they wouldn't be moving forward with the interview process and when I asked for feedback so that I could improve my performance for the future, they told me they couldn't give me "formal" feedback as it's against their policy. Honestly both bummed and a little relieved about this one.

I had HR reached out by email but then he started ghosting after I provided availability. Somehow after following up many times, I got to interview with the HM. She was pretty easy and impressed and put me in final round. Again ghosting by the recruiter! After following up couple of times I finally got the final round scheduled for after 2 weeks. It went pretty great. The HM showed so much interest as if she is going to hire me on the spot. She was so impressed. My other 3 rounds of final loop also went great. Don't know what happened but the HR has been ghosting me since past 2 weeks. I tried reaching out to HM as well but no response.

I was contacted by a recruiter and asked a few questions. She then recommended me and scheduled me for a technical interview and then an interview with a hiring manager. Technical interview was neutral. Hiring manager interview was a no show until I contacted the recruiter. Interview with HM got rescheduled multiple times but went well after speaking. Microsoft was a dream company to work for but the hiring process did not leave a good impression at all for such a reputable company.

I got referred for this job, and as a first-round someone from the team called me for initial discussion then I had the second-round technical discussion that also went well as the interviewer is quite good. Then in the third-round everything gets changed, The person who is taking the interview is having no absolute idea what he gonna ask in an interview. That interviewer was not even able to ask a question in complete sentences. I have to ask the question multiple times to just clear it out. He himself is confused.  I do not know how they are being hired in Microsoft and taking interviews. He asked me about RTL and I have not worked on that part. So he jumped to the conclusion that I am not a good fit. Great isn't? Judge people on the basis of one question. This is Microsoft.

There were 4 rounds. First 3 were technical and last was with Hiring Manager. 
Different rounds focused on different technical skills. Though the opening was for Program manager, focus was more on technical side.

Everything went well and in a friendly manner. Good team of passionate professionals. Online interview, four stages, divided into two days. All in all, nothing out of the ordinary. Your technical experience, experience in a team, behavioral issues, problem-solving.
Interviewer was 45 minutes late for a 30 minute interview. She had bad signal the whole time and ended the call several times. Overall, interview experience was average or below average.

You will have 4 rounds of interviews; each will be 45 minutes in length with short 15 minutes breaks in between.
Each interview will be comprised of technical and behavioral questions

Probably the worst interview experience I have ever had. It started off with a phone interview in which a recruiter read me questions and then wrote down my answers (not responding to them at all, merely pausing so he could write down what I was saying). Then I got invited to the final interview and I set up all the travel and got my flight booked. About a week later I got another email inviting me to the interview, and I responded saying I had already RSVPd but was there anything else they needed from me. They wrote back saying they had cancelled that interview and wanted me to come in three days earlier (which I would not have known had I not responded to the email). This new date was very inconvenient for me so I emailed back asking if it was possible to reschedule, and after a couple follow up emails, they finally replied on Friday in the middle of the night that there was no other possible date, and I had to come in on Tuesday (I live across the country). Their travel team only works monday through friday so they ended up booking my flight a couple hours before I had to leave. Nevertheless I reschedule my prior commitments and show up to the interview only to learn that they had changed the position I was interviewing for (even though I had asked to confirm several times if it was for the same position and they had said it was). I also found  out during the last interview that they had my resume from last year. They then told me that I would receive my results within two weeks, but took a month to get back to me, rejecting me. At that point I was so tired from the experience, I had lost nearly all interest in the position. It's a shame because I had interviewed the year before for an internship and had a very positive experience, but this time around I felt more like just a number than I had ever felt before.
Got call from HR for Hyderabad location regarding interview and interview got scheduled next week. It was for Azure Team. I had 4 rounds : 1 DS & Algo, 2 Design, 1 Technical Manager round

Good process: multiple phone interviews, and final onsite. Treated candidate well and candidate experience was good; felt respected the whole way through. Last round of onsite was only conducted if previous interviewers gave a thumbs-up. Last round was to determine candidate cultural fit.

Very clear structure. Applied through the MBA programmes. First HR call was short and introductory, then second dived a bit more on skills, experiences and fit with the company. Final round was a presentation based on any Microsoft product that a business can use - free choice for the candidate.

Submitted dozens of resumes, got referrals from employee contacts, finally got a phone interview w/ a Contracted Employee from out of the state. Interview went well. No callback, no response from interview coordinator. No response on numerous qualified job applications, referrals, etc. Process is cumbersome and seems like a drag for both interviewers and interviewees.

4 interviews on site in Seattle, the recruiters were super cocky and the reason I might never go to MS would be due to my experience with them. A friend of mine was told straight “even My ten year old son can code this” like really? Why not hire your son? Stop demeaning people

phone interview. asked about the programming problem. Leetcode problem. Use an online editor to program it out and asked about complexity analysis. The interview is about 30 minutes. After that there is no opening told by the recruiter.

Foram 4 etapas sendo elas todas faladas em português e escritas em inglês na apresentação. Foram 2 em grupo e 2 individuais, sendo que tinhamos de debater sobre resoluções de problemas e também sobre inclusão. A cultura na empresa se baseia na missão deles que é "impulsionar todas as pessoas e organizações do planeta a fazerem mais" eles fazem o que nenhuma, ou a minoria das outras empresas fazem, incluem as pessoas deficientes e buscam ajudar a sociedade de alguma forma. 
    Em todas as etapas éramos reunidos em uma sala onde haviam os 4 gerentes e a moça do RH, eles explicam a etapa e depois éramos divididos cada 3, 2 ou 4 em uma sala com um dos gerentes. Recebíamos uma folha com os detalhes da atividade (em inglês) e eram 15 minutos para pensarmos sobre e 5 para apresentar, as salas eram como a que nos reuníamos, com uma mesa de vidro e as cadeiras como se fossem de computador e uma smart TV. Na apresentação não usavamos nada a não ser o próprio conhecimento, não foram cobrados técnicas, mas para quem tem experiências em entrevistas consegue ir bem. Além de ser importante estudar sobre a empresa e tudo o que esta fazendo atualmente.

A phone call with the recruiter
Followed by a skype call with an engineer. It was general questions about my CV and experience and why do I want to change job
After that I was invited to attend the interview process in the office
Was 4 hours long
1 hour with a senior engineer
1 hour with a lead engineer
1 hour with PM and Creative director
1 hour with the head of studio

Phone interview, followed by an onsite interview. Reply withing one week. Mostly technical Questions, very friendly interviewers. Basic EE questions. Few Behavioral Questions. Nice Office and very lively city.

Gave resume to recruiter at campus event, contacted for interview a week later. On campus interview, questions about resume (courses, programing languages, work experience), a technical question at the end.

L’entretien était une étude cas qu’il fallait présenter en anglais, mais a été conduit en français. (Ambience franco-française). J’ai senti une arrogance de la part des 2 intervenants, pourtant junior.

Three rounds, first based on resume and basics of machine learning, second and third based on competitive programming. The questions in the second and third rounds were mostly based on link list and trees.

4 rounds 45-mins on-site interview:
interviewed for data scientist position, but mostly focusing on my programming experience and knowledge. Not well matched.
Related questions on data science is only a case study and a question about linear regression.

Received phone interview after meeting campus recruiter. Basic behavioral and lots of product questions. Lasted about 30 minutes and the recruiter was very kind. About 3 weeks later I was sent an email from a general Microsoft recruiting email that I was denied

The hiring process had 3 stages:--
1. 1 hour technical test consisting of MCQ questions. Questions were on Machine Learning and data science
2. Candidates shortlisted in previous test had to go through a 1 hour technical test consisting of subjective questions
3. Three rounds of technical interview of around 30 minutes each
