I applied online and had a phone screening interview a few weeks after. Then I got admitted to final round interviews a few months later. The initial interview was mostly behavioral and kind of PM, really straightforward predictable questions.

I had an on campus technical interview with one behavior and technical question about 30 minutes. 
Then I was invited for on site where I had two interviews both with technical and behavioral

I had a 30 minute phone screen (PM questions and behavioral questions mostly, nothing technical), after which I was invited to interview on site in Redmond. There were 2 on site interviews in Redmond offices

The whole process was very smooth!
Started off with a 30 minute phone screen with a recruiter. You must be ready to talk about your reason for Microsoft, also be ready to break down technical terms into simplistic explanations.  Should they decide to move forward, you would be invited for an onsite interview.
The onsite consists of 3 very subjective interviews where you would be making a 10 minute presentation of any topic of your choice in one of the interviews. The reason I said the interviews are subjective is because I was expecting behavioral interviews but my first interview was fully technical. I also had to whiteboard (pseudocode however). I was tested on what was on my resume so be fully prepared to defend your resume in its entirety. 
My second interview was where I did my presentation. My advice for a topic is one in which you can demonstrate technical knowledge and passion simultaneously.  I knew my interviewer enjoyed the presentation and the rest of the interview was very smooth. 
My third interview was a case study style. A lot of scenarios of working with clients and having to resolve issues. Tip: Utilize the whiteboard and show structured thinking in however you come up with an answer/recommendation.

Really smooth process, I met with multiple program managers on the team and they each asked me how I would design different things. The interesting thing is they did not ask me to design software but rather different things in day to day life. Refrigerator, Microwave oven, tape dispenser.

I applied online and emailed university recruiter, and was expedited to onsite due to having a competing offer deadline and passing phone screen in previous year. There were 4 onsite interviews, all a mix of technical and behavioural (I heard there are only 2 interviews for interns now). I received verbal offer shortly after.

I had an interview by phone and then 4 on site interviews. One interviewer did not pay me attention to the development of my interview's code problem. 
The other interviewers were nice and I resolved all of the problems.
I received a response after I asked for it to HR.

I interviewed with Microsoft Azure Team - Hyderabad at Bangalore location . 
Overall it was a very bad experience. 
It was a bulk hiring process, where they had flown in  interviewers from Hyderabad. 
Around 40+ candidates of more than 3 years experience had been called. 
Everyone was made to wait, and it was too stressful on the candidates - due to the longer wait time, and the panel - due to the high number of candidates to be interviewed. 
I had two rounds. Each round was less than 30 minutes and very short. Not sure if it is because I gave the answer rightaway or because the interviewers were not interested (seemed like it). 

First round : 
	1. Tell me about yourself
	2. About my current work and job.
	3. Then asked one coding question : Rotate array. 
	He asked to propose any solution first, and then optimise it. I said I have encountered this question and know the optimal solution with O(n) time and O(1) space. He asked to explain solution and then code it. 
	Once I completed - he asked to do unit test and say few test cases - I did it. 
	That was it. 

Second round : 
	1. Few questions about my current work and job
	2. One coding question : Clone LL with random pointer :  
	I had not known this question before and I came up with hashing based implementation . The interviewer asked me to write it down, and once done he asked me for alternative implementations. 
	I suggested two other methods all with O(n) extra space - but he wanted with O(1) extra space. I could not come up with it and was asked to leave. 

Other people who interviewed with me got the following questions : 
1. Implement singleton design pattern
2. clone circular Linked List 

Overall interview experience was very bad. I had to wait for more than 7 hours just to give 30 minutes of interview. 
The interviewers did not discuss or participate in problem solving - once I solved the given problem, interview was over. Also they seemed very disinterested in the entire interview process. 
HR co-ordination was also very bad. Both interviewers did not have my resume and had some one else's resume - so it was irritating. 

Major focus was on array, Linked List and design.

I applied online through the Microsoft website as a new/recent graduate. Then I received an invite after about a week for a 30 min phone screen with a recruiter. The recruiter had a list of behavioral questions, and asked me to describe a technical project I had done.

I went to a recruitment event on campus. I interviewed with a few people from the Bing Ads team where they mainly asked me to explain a research problem I've worked on.  Then was invited to do 5 onsite interviews.

Was contacted through LinkedIn, and then I applied online. Received an invitation for a video Interview by a Microsoft university recruiter asking most behavioural questions as well as questions confirming my CV and previous experiences

I have been interviewed at Microsoft Sydney at least 8-10 times and their interview process is flawed and a complete waste of time.

My first application ended with 2-3 rounds of interview and later HR disappeared without any feedback. 

Second application - 1 interview and HR stopped responding.

Third - had 5 interviews, and for 2 of them I had to drive 30km each way to reach the office. And as expected HR disappeared.

Fourth - had 1 interview and HR disappeared and later told after a month that position is on hold.

Fifth - had 2 interviews and HR disappeared.

All of the above interviews were above par there was hardly a question that I missed. 

So - I finally found that, MS fills up the position internally in 90% of cases and external interviews are just for a backup purpose. Which is complete waste of time.

The only thing I dislike about MS is the hiring process.

Smooth interview process. I had a phone screen with PM-related questions. Then, flew out to an on-site for two technical interviews. Overall, a relatively easy and straightforward process. Would recommend!

Phone interview, with a very nice employee. asked a few personal questions, and 2 riddles.
personal questions revolved around previous work experience, dilemas around work related topics. the general feeling was good, as the employee kept asking me if everything was clear [=were the questions understood].

This interview started with behavioral questions and questions about past experiences. Then the second half of the interview was a technical question.  This interview was done at my university. Interviewer was very nice!
Prior to interview the recruiter only mentioned about the coding rounds but all the 4 technical rounds were on System Design which seemed pretty unreasonable for a New Graduate position.
I was recommended through my tutor at the university I sent a CV and reference letter, someone contacted me and we scheduled a meeting online. This was the only meeting I had

1st round was a telephonic round where a HR went over my resume and asked basic questions.

He introduced himself first and then it was my chance to introduce myself. He was also interested in knowing what I wanted to become in 5 years. All the questions were pretty straightforward.
30 min on campus interview. Then flown in for onsite, 4 rounds 45 min each. Was notified of result 2 days after on site. This was pre covid, they take very good care of interviewees.

The standard Microsoft interview process, with 6-7 back to back interviews in a row (with launch break in between). They were with different people, from other Software Engineers, to people from marketing, Design PMs etc., each asking questions related to their area.

After my phone screening, I was invited to the Redmond campus for in person interview. I was taken into a very small meeting room for my interview with two senior engineers. One asked most of the questions, but they were both typing notes the entire time. After behavioral interview, it was time for technical interview. They asked some technical questions and then whiteboard was medium difficulty. This was my first technical interview ever. I presented a working solution, but after analyzing complexity, I determined it was suboptimal. I didn’t have enough time to fix it, so I talked about what I would do differently.

It was a good overall experience. The questions were easy and I was mostly talking about my project. There were some data related question which I chose to answer with python and the interviewer was open whether to write code with python or sql

more than 6 rounds of interviews, very intensive but worth trying.
Make sure you are fully prepared in the exercise session, you will be asked many practical questions regarding the solutions you've given.

The first step to watch out for is a questionnaire asking a bit about yourself for the position you applied, after that you are waiting for a phone screening or email stating weather you made it to the in store interview process.

The interview process was pretty expedited considering I went through most of it via campus recruiting. I had an on campus interview, which then lead to an onsite final interview. The full time position interview process consisted of four 45 min interviews with a 10-15 minute break in between.

It was a good experience although I was not able to get an offer and there were different rounds like one was a group fly round and second was a face to face round. It was my first interview so I was a bit nervous and I would suggest practicing from leetcode and geeks for geeks.

I had one phone interview with the hiring manager and it went okay. It took 2-3 weeks to get a phone interview scheduled. The manager had pretty normal behavioral questions. I sent her two follow up emails because i never heard back on a second interview. I reached out to the recruiter to ask if  no response from the hiring manager meant i didn't get the next interview and he said that they were still interviewing candidates. I never got an email that i didn't get selected-  I knew i didn't get selected because in the Microsoft action center the job was moved to the archived section.

The first interview was a phone screen about the resume and something about K-Means (picked from my work). The second stage was they flew you to Seattle and then onsite. It consisted of 3 interviews of different teams.
It was quite an interesting  process when you talk to a lot of stakeholders and you learn a lot not only from the position, but also from the team, the manager and such.

Gran profesionalidad, me hicieron sentir cómodo desde el primer momento. Principalmente interesados en la experiencia en mis trabajos previos.  Ser joven no resultó ser un problema, es una empresa dinámica y lo valoran. Realmente creo que habría aceptado de no ser por las condiciones geográficas, fue el único condicionante de peso.
Application was easy and fast, then got invited to a Skype Interview which was formal but friendly, had a list of questions which I answered. The interview is set to last 30 mins.

30 min phone interview + onsite 45min *4.  Get a phone interview through website (calculate simple math questions, I think acceptance is based on correctness and efficiency, this part is not hard), the phone interview asked about behavior questions. Onsite interview do not involve technical questions.

Interview was over a video call. 
Manager was very nice, and asked the usual job interview questions like successes and failures. It seemed he was looking into the fit more than the qualifications.

First stage: Interview on skype with a nice lady about my CV and past work dynamics in past positions
Second stage: A one-on-one interview in the offices in Herzliya. I was asked again about past experience and then same professionals questions.

Said it would be nontechnical but was very technical. I had interviewed with several consulting firms who had offered me the job based off of behavioral questions. This interview process was not the same. Almost everyone invited was rejected because we did not prepare for technical questions.

I received a phone call from an outsourced Microsoft recruiter as they receive all applications when you apply online. I got invited for a f2f interview with the Hiring manager onsite in Dublin, and he discussed with me the next steps in the interview process. I was supposed to come in for a panel interview 2 weeks later and was waiting for the confirmation email.
Two weeks later I reached out to the recruiter as I had not received any updates and saw that my application online changed to "not selected". He blatantly lied to me on the phone and said that it was a technical error and that he is still waiting for a confirmation from the Hiring Manager. Then asked me if I would be interested in other jobs at Microsoft, that I could interview for in the meantime. Jobs that I was not qualified for and low paid. So I rejected and waited. I never heard back from them again.

30-45 minutes scheduled. over the phone on Microsoft Teams. Before, the recruiter reached out and gave a few tips and extensive notes for the role you're applying for. Very friendly throughout the whole process and very accommodating

I was invited to the first stage which was a phone interview but didn't get to the next stages which will involve going to Redmond, Washington and undergoing about two to three sets of 45 minutes interviews.
It is a one and a half hour long interview process. It was taken by seniors in team. All they see is the basic approach to the problem statement given. Behavior contributes a lot to the success.

Almost fully technical phone screening, mostly questions relating to electrical and computer engineering, not many questions specifically about silicon verification. Also runs through your resume so be prepared to talk about your roles on different projects / jobs. If successful you are invited to further onsite interviews by 3-5 teams which take up a whole day.

Have to submit CV, followed by a video interview where you are asked questions on reason for applying and explain a technical concept to non technical audience. After that is the assessment centre which is a mix of group discussion and individual tasks.
Lento pero muy interesante, se baso en la experiencia previa y los aportes que pudiera ofrecer en caso de obtener el puesto. Fueron en total 5 entrevistas 2 por telf y las demás personalmente

1 screen interview, and then 1 interview at the LA headquarters. Essentially, I had already interned there for high school internships and then just contacted my recruiter. They then screen interviewed me and then had the main one later

Phone screen, 30 minute call going over behavioral and technical questions. Started with walking through resume, moved to more technical questions including favorite microsoft products and how to design products. Emphasis placed on technical experience in the past.

I talked with a couple of interviewers, one after another for a couple of hours checking my experiences from different angles. Mostly the things from my CV, only one, so called system design problem to analyze. Some interviewers were more, I'd say intentionally, provocative, probably due to the position.

Totally 4 rounds of interviews in one day, 3 rounds of coding and 1 round of design. The interviewer is nice and friendly.  The coding questions are medium.  When having lunch with one of the interviewers, they will ask some behavior questions, such as the proudest project you have ever done, the most challenging project? ...

Terrible experience. 
The recruiter forgot about my interview. I've waited 30 minutes for her to get it together. She didn't review my CV and did that right in front of me. 
Her mobile phone kept ringing, and she didn't put it on silent and didn't apologize for any disturbance.
her dog kept coming in-n-out of the room; I'm afraid of dogs and didn't feel comfortable to say that this was distracting me and make making me feel uncomfortable

Initial in-person screen at university was non-technical. Two interviews on-site were technical. Fairly moderate in difficulty, though in-person screen included an interesting philosophical question. Overall positive experience that I enjoyed.

Processo iniciado com candidatura online para vaga em Lisboa- Portugal, se extendeu por 5 meses, de dezembro de 2019 até abrir de 2021.

Todos contatos feito por email com a entrevistador, ondem foram marcadas 5 vezes a entrevista, nas quais eu estive presente, porém o analista de escalonamento do time (profissional com + 16 anos de Microsoft) se fez presente só na ultima vez.

Processo simples, porém como entramos em pandemia a vaga foi cancelada.

Three interviews with leads from different teams. Each interview consisted of ten minutes of personal questions. The rest was technical interviews, the questions ranged from sorting arrays, over binary trees to graphs.

1 online round, 1 phn interbiew, 2 off site rounds, wonderful experience, friendly interviewers. I applied on their interview portal. 1 online round was on mettl with easy level Q. Phn interview was quite medium level, onsite were mainly regarding projects and CS Fundamentals.

The interview was very relaxing, pleasant conversation, mostly about my CV and some information about the job. Noting hard or unexpected - just some basic information about previous experiences and motivation.

Behavioral questions were only asked:
Describe your recent project. what's your timeline for it?
Have you ever led a team? what were your challenges?
What you will do if you miss an important deadline?

Applied to MBA Programs and Operations via NBMBAA conference.
Recruiter reach out via LinkedIn to schedule interview during NBMBAA.
Had a 30 min interview during the conference typical behavioral questions and tell me about yourself.
Two weeks later was invited to fly to Seattle for loop. On the day of the loop interviews went from 9-noon, 3 1h interviews senior directors. Mostly behavioral questions, very conversational tone felt more like talk to people that wanted to know more about me then interviewing. Really important to be able to drive the conversation here.
Got the offer a few days later.
The interviewer was late for 20 minutes, and he cut me off at the 40 minute mark(the interview was suppose to be an hour) It was very unprofessional, I was quite disappointed about it.

Entrevista extremamente técnica e detalhada. 
Para cada tópico o entrevistador vai se aprofundando até você não ter resposta para entender qual seu comportamento.
Entrevista toda baseada em cenarios de mercado.
It was the assessment center and it was the last step of the procedure after the skipper interview. We were about 10 people. It last all the day but it wasn't stressful

1 hour process with directly talking to the hiring manager.  10 min for general background question, 40 min for presentation, and 10 min for any question related to work. The process was very smooth and very professional environment.

I initially got contacted by Recruiter in Microsoft and took two times of phone interviews. I failed to 2nd test but I got another opportunity from a different division as same as position in Microsoft so now prepare for another interview.

Multiple interviews over a day with different software engineers. It was a pleasant interview to do and they were all nice interviewers. Standard leetcode/hackerrank questions. Not particularly hard but not easy either.

Horrible experience! I only did the phone screening round but the interviewer was awful. I'm not sure why but she was in a poor mood and was reading off a list of questions sounding super bored. I would say a detailed answer to her questions and she would sit quietly and judge me, following it up with another question which made no sense because I had already explained it my response. It just showed she was not paying attention. Similarly, she kept hanging up accidentally. Overall, poor experience. I was super excited to discuss my passion for CS and she completely ruined my experience.

4 rounds of phone screen.
Initial round included technical, behavioral and research related questions.
Then 2 screening rounds, one with the program manager and his boss.
Another round to know more about my background and how I can contribute to their research and product development.

Interviewed last spring. Great process from beginning to end.  Smart and nice interviewers, and all the questions were mostly to be expected.  Everything went very smoothly and positively for me, although it probably depends on who you interview with.

Was contacted on LinkedIn. Was informed about the application and applied. Scheduled a phone interview from the email they sent. Interview was really dry. The guy interviewing me must of been having a bad day or something because there was no enthusiasm from this guy over the phone what so ever. Seemed like I was just another phone call in his day and he already wanted to go home. Had a monotone voice the entire time which is a huge turn off to me. Asked the typical interview questions. Why Microsoft? Explain a time when _________?  I feel like I would of had a much better experience had the guy been in a better mood. I would of expected a lot better from Microsoft. Hoping to hear back in a few weeks.  From the way this interview went, I'm not sure if this is a place I want to work at. Especially if everyone has the same attitude this guy had.

2h long - involved a presentation on a topic you're passionate about which had to be pre-planned. Questions revolved around teamwork, collaboration, skills required in sales. Make sure you know general info about Microsoft such as CEO, number of people employed, best selling products, etc.

Phone interview was great. Made it to an in person interview and was excited. In person (all day interview) was cancelled the afternoon before with no reason given. Was told they will reschedule and never heard back. Not the professionalism I am looking for in a new career and I suppose I shouldn't be surprised that a company this size is so unorganized with the hiring process.

I first had to do an online test on codility which was one hour long and included 2 coding questions. After passing that, I had 5 interviews in the onsite interview day: one with HR, one with the hiring manager, a debugging interview, a coding and a design interview. They got back to me very quickly - by the next morning I received a call from the recruiter.

Applied online. On campus first round interview. Some basic questions. The person was really helpful. No matter how you feel about the interview just understand that the interview helped you get better. It doest really matter if you got the offer or not.

In my opinion, it was absolutely amazing. There were four different interview rounds. First, once they gauge interest, there's a phone interview. Second, was the final round interviews which consisted of three, in-person, 45 min interviews with different kinds of people on the team.  because the interview was freshly done, we won't hear back for about two weeks on the results of the interviews, but overall it was great. Just be confident and trust that you made it to the final rounds for a reason.

I applied online through a referral and was contacted a couple weeks after for an on-campus at my school. I heard back pretty quickly for an onsite. It included two 45 minute interviews and a 15 minute break in between. Both included both behavioral and technical questions. I heard back about 3 days after the final round of interviews.

Ho inviato la candidatura online, ricevuto risposta dopo alcune settimane e mi hanno invitato a partecipare a un colloquio tramite skype, se superato ci sarebbe stato un ulteriore colloquio di persona in sede a Milano.

Had online assessment and phone call with recurinter. At onsite, It tests your thinking ability, logics, system design, customer obsession as a whole. Also have conversation with hiring manager who asks expeirience and behavioral questions

Online application with current employee referral didn't work and some how got the second chance for the phone screening with recruiter, but recruiter didn't ask me the relevant questions. For example, they should have asked how would you interpret this data instead of how to calculate a+b.

First, emailed VP Design. Second, call interview with Senior Industrial Designer. Third, a Skype interview with Senior Industrial Design team and Executive Assistant, going over a brief portfolio review on video. Fourth, an on-site interview in Bellevue, Washington, at the Design building on campus.

This interview was the most serious, and was 1 conference-style portfolio review, quite informal and talked a lot of process. From there, we broke into 4 other interviews, one of which was over lunch (which was rather heavily casual).

I was not given the position, largely because of experience and potentially not high enough caliber of projects.
I had 2 interview rounds. 1st one was video call it took 45 minutes asked .net related questions. 2nd one was coding round and asked questions on angular.  This interview was in 2015. Got offer.

I did my first round interview on campus. The recruiter was an engineer who first thought I was interviewing for the engineer position. He started by asking me about my previous experience and a few questions about how I led the team/communicated with engineers, etc. Then he asked me a product question and did a few rounds of follow-up on that. The interview ended with a technical one: write a compression algorithm.

white board coding and behavioral.

Tell me about a time you worked on a team and felt like the other members weren't as strong as you. 

Talk about experiences
What are you most passionate about? What programming languages do you know? What was your experience in data structures  
Are you a team player?
Any conflict with past coworkers or boss? How do u deal with conflict?
Where do u see yourself in 5 years?
Questions for me?
The people were very kind and caring.  The interviewer told me they were already almost filled up for PMs (which was what I was looking for), but told me I had a good interview nonetheless.
Great, was interviewed in person in Seattle. They flew me out for the interview. I had a few interviews within the span of a day. There were not really breaks in between the interviews.

I interviewed for Microsoft in January 2022. The interview process involved 4 rounds after a Codility coding round. 
The first interview was a coding session on Codility which involved solving two problems in the duration of a 45 minute interview. The second was Low Level Design of a Vending Machine on Codility as well. The third interview was for algorithm design
 I was promised 4 rounds of interviews but the 4th round wasn't conducted and I wasn't notified until in the evening. The waiting time was directly proportional to the round being conducted.

Had a first interview and never heard back from them again. When I go into my page, it still says I’m currently in works with them. But I never heard back, didn’t even get an email saying I didn’t pass the interview.

Il colloquio si è sviluppato in 3 fasi:
 fase 1: colloquio iniziale con hr
fase 2: colloquio tecnico di 15 minuti con domande teoriche relative alla posizione
fase 3: due colloqui da 1 ora ciascuna, uno tecnico con presentazione relativa ad un progetto fatto in tema di Cloud Migration e Platfrom Modernization e uno con il manager Consultant con domande personali relative all'esperienza

First screening interview with the recruiter.
She asked background questions and few easy technical questions
It was a phone interview, and it took like 15 minutes. She said she will contact in a month, but she haven’t contacted me over two months, and I am still waiting.

1 Phone screen round (2-3 behavioral questions and about courses studied)
Got response in around 4-5 business days
2 Final rounds (technical and behavioral questions based on experience and data structures and algorithm questions)
Got response in 2 weeks
Total process was about 2 months, little long for my taste. Applied and was sent online assessment and cleared to virtual interviews. 4 rounds of interviews with various hiring managers.

One round of interview with manager and VP.  It has been 1 month without response. The questions are all research agenda and background information. They let you discuss your research proposal and interest.
very back to back process, you will be exhausted by the end of the day.  Four rounds and you have to be very sharp for each, which gets more difficult as the day goes by.

We met over Teams for 30 minutes and the interviewer asked behavioral questions and wrote down the answers. In the end he gave me 5 minutes to solve a puzzle to which I kind of explained how to get to the solution but probably failed to convey what I was thinking.

First contacted by a recruiter via email to set up a phone interview. The phone interview with recruiter was mostly behavioral questions. Next, set up an interview with a hiring manager/senior engineer which was mostly technical.

1. Technical screening with hiring manager
2. Onsite 6 hours including 30 min lunch with Managers, engineer
Arrogant and short tempered Managers. Never heard from recruiter even after following up  requesting for feedback.  Never experienced this kind of  behavior from mid, smaller companies in town.

Interviewed for an SDE II position with the Microsoft Academic Graph team. 

I will say outright an absolutely terrible interview experience for me. The team asked me some specific questions about how I would add features in Microsoft Academic Graph. After this, during the second hour, they asked me an architecture question which I did very well on. Then they asked me to write the code for a specific data structure, going conceptually through the characteristics of this particular data structure with me, after a while telling me to write it in pseudo-code. I felt like I did pretty well up until this point, though I had felt that I didn’t implement the data structure completely.  (They later told me that I didn’t pass the interview because I didn’t write complete code in C++ for this data structure). 

What bothered me about this interview process however was that during the lunch interview my interviewer asked me a lot of very personal questions that were completely unrelated to the job. I told her about how I used to take care of children, and she told me that I should go back to doing that instead of being a Software Engineer. Furthermore, during the lunch interview the interviewer only consumed a single banana, and threw the rest of her food away. I strongly felt that, due to the nature of the questions that she was asking, and her generally condescending attitude toward me this was some sort of racist dig toward me (I am an underrepresented minority).

Going through this experience and watching her eat the banana while making chiding jokes about how I shouldn’t be a Software Engineer was completely humiliating, unprofessional and made this interview ultimately a waste of my time. Because of this, I keep a strongly negative impression of Microsoft as a company. There was another interview after this, but it was with the same person, and I felt completely uncomfortable about the entire thing. After this I was a pencil as a “parting gift”.

If this was some kind of a joke I am definitely not amused. Out of CS graduates with Computer Science degrees, Microsoft tends to not hire women and underrepresented minorities, including women of color such as myself. Microsoft should do better, including hiring interviewers that are sensitive to their own bias and blind spots, and who definitely don’t openly make fun of people. Furthermore, If they wanted me to implement the code, which was far more than 8 lines (the GeeksforGeeks.com implementation of this data structure in C++ is no less than 50 lines of code for instance) then it would be good to specifically tell the candidate to implement that data structure in actual code, in order to guide them in the right direction as opposed to the wrong one, even if the requirements somehow can’t be made clear for specific reasons during the interview itself.

Applied online, received an email in 2 weeks to schedule a phone interview. 30 minute phone call with a data scientist at Microsoft.  Friendly and non-intimidating interviewer, great experience overall despite the rejection.

Two 45 minute interviews via teams. One was technical one was management. Overall fun interview and gave the feel like the company wanted to bring me on board. The questions where not over the top and if you didn't know the answer that was okay because they do not expect you to know everything.
Applied online and referred by friend. It's a 30 mins interview. They called in on 3 mins later than the expected time, and finished in 25 mins. No response after that, So I believe I failed.

General Process:
4 rounds of technical interviews.
You will do the interview with one person. 
10 minutes behavioral and 40 minutes of coding/ design question. 
You will hear the result within a week.

There were 3 stages. 1st stage was a phone call with HR. We exchanged some general information, I explained who and what I am, they explained what kind of job it is and what interview was gonna be. 2nd stage was an online session with an technical interviewer. They asked to solve a relatively simple task online and explain the solution. Nothing special. Then they invited me to visit them in Prague to be interviewed in person. They provided assistance with visa process and booked/paid airplane tickets and the hotel. Interview was carried on in their Prague office (very nice one). It lasted 4 hours. I was interviewed by 4 persons (very high profile Microsoft employees seriously involved in development of Visual Studio and .NET). Each interviewer asked me some general questions to test my "soft skills" and also asked me to solve a problem writing code on a whiteboard (writing it on the whiteboard was the most uncomfortable part of all this). Some tasks were quite difficult, some were sort of tricky. Interviewers were very friendly and very nice. It was a pleasure to meet all them.

The role was part of the MACH Sales program. At the time of writing this post, I am still waiting for my final result.  
one test, one phone interivew, a 10 min presentation and two face-to face onsite interviews.

Three rounds. One where they just look at your resume and ask you question. Second, you speak for 30 min with someone on the phone. Third, the final round, they invite you to campus and you make a conversational interview with the team asking you behavioral questions

I applied online for a data scientist position, I was contacted about two weeks later for a senior software engineer position instead. The interviewer was quite pleasant and helpful, and gently corrected me when I made (minor) mistakes.

1. an online test which included solving 3 problems in 65 minutes on codilliy platform.

2. 30 minutes skype interview with the followinh qeustions:

1. Describe good code? Perfect code?
2. Why do you want to work at microsoft
3. Tell us about a difficult project at school

Very relaxing process
They made everything easy moving forward
1 phone interview 
Then 3 final round interviews that happened on the same day

Heard back 2 week after the phone interview 

Accepted my offer a few days after my last interview

1. Applied online in July 2019
2. Contacted for Phone Screen with HR in August 2019
3. Onsite in Seattle in November 2019: 
4 back to back white board coding interviews, 45 min each

Was contacted by a recruiter on LinkedIn for a hiring event in Redmond WA. First round was a codility test of 60 minutes and 3 questions. I solved 2 questions and mentioned the approach of 3rd question. They called me onsite for 4 rounds of interviews.

It was nearly 2–3 months back when I saw a series of messages from Microsoft employees on Linkedin. It was about Microsoft hiring pre-final year for an SDE summer intern. I got really excited about this and didn’t want to miss the opportunity.
I had mailed my resume, including all my projects, achievements, and experiences to 15–20 people from Microsoft, hoping at least one of them would refer me for the online coding test. And yeah there it all started.

3 rounds
1. Coding
2. Virtual Interview
3. Onsite(3 rounds)

Microsoft gives an opportunity to all undergraduate and postgraduate students for 2 months summer internship program. The basic criteria to apply for Microsoft internship program were to have CGPA greater than 7.0, no pending backlogs, and candidates should not have participated in the Microsoft internship hiring process for the last one year.

Enjoyable.  Typical algorithmic questions.  Similar to the sorts of problems you would encounter on Leetcode or Hackerrank.  The interviewer included both the behavioural assessment and technical component into one interview.  Typical behavioural questions.
I was contacted for an on campus interview. The interviewer was not very nice and clearly was in a hurry to get things done. I was asked one technical question and some behavioral questions.

Initial on-campus interview in Spring 2019 with a very friendly interviewer. Since this was at the end of the recruiting season for Microsoft, they could no longer accept any more candidates and so my application was pushed to consideration for start of next recruiting cycle. Heard back around start of September that based on Spring interview results, I would be moving on to final round interview in Redmond, WA. Overall, the interviewers were very friendly and made me feel comfortable. Question difficulty was scaled appropriately to my experience level.

Had one phone interview and then was flown out for my final round. Had about 5 hours of straight in-person interviews afterwards. The questions were over content that I had definitely not learned so I found them pretty difficult overall. After taking the relevant classes, however, I realized the questions were still decently difficult and covered the fundamentals of engineering (materials, fluids, thermo, manufacturing).

The interview process was simple. 2 interviewers, the first one gave a more general "design this system" problem (which ended being the problem that I worked on during my internship) and the second interviewer gave a coding question, which was somewhat easy. The first question ("design this system") is the more important of the two imo because it gives you a chance to show off what you know about the technologies you've been exposed to.
3 rounds of interviews. 2 behavioral and 1 technical. The technical didnt ask me to code or anything, but instead asked me to pretend to be a consultant while the interviewer was the client.
phone call, on campus, then onsite. Onsite was 4 interview questions with a lunch in the middle. After the 4 interviews I talked to a manager of a team and chatted about what his/her team does.

I was able to do first round interviewing on university campus. It was fairly standard entry level whiteboard questions. MS fills up their slots particularly early in their university hiring season though, so I ended up getting an offer to interview onsite to a remote office, and declined at this point.

Applied online, recruiter reach out for interview. Then after you agreed on an date, you will meet on interviewer on campus for interview. If you pass the first round, there's a second onsite interview in Seattle.

I had an expedited interview process because I did another affiliated Microsoft program the summer before. The interview process consisted of only 2 interviews, a behavioral and a "technical" part. Overall the interviews were very quick, and I was there for only half a day.

Have 3 levels of interview, with quick feedback and fast 
response. very supportive with good guidelines.

Have 3 levels of interview, with quick feedback and fast 
response. very supportive with good guidelines

Very friendly phone interview asking me basic computer science questions like "How would you explain a computer to a 5-year-old". The Onsite was pretty difficult relative to what I see online. I was asked a graph question, tree, and bit manipulation question.

Got a first round interview with a recruiter from a university recruiting fair (behavioral interview).  Mostly just 'why Microsoft' and asked about my background/resume.

Then got asked to fly out to Seattle (Redmond Campus) for onsite. There was an optional pre-meet dinner with current Microsoft employees. It was basically a big networking event and actually got to meet some of the employees that would interview me the next day. Was on the campus from 10-5. From 10-1, we had lunch and a lab tour. From 1-4 we had scheduled 45 minute technical interviews.

The final round was definitely a 10/10 interview experience! I had 2 interviews each with a software engineer. They are both so passionate, nice, and helpful. Both interviews, in the beginning, went more like a pleasant conversation than an interview; you really get to personally connect with your interviewers besides knowing the cool things they do! 
Then the first one started with why CS & questions about my project on the resume. I'd say having done/doing a project that you're really passionate about is important; also be ready to explain the technical details of it. The second one started with team work questions. Then I did a coding problem for both; last 10 minutes were time for questions for the interviewers.
I heard back 3 days after about my offer! Super thrilled.

It was a pretty smooth process. Got referred in August for the new grad position, had an on-campus interview with 1 LC medium and 1 LC hard in September.  I got invited for on-site interviews with a specific team in November. Microsoft takes amazing care of the candidates, reimbursing every expense and placing you in a Hyatt in Bellevue.

The first was with Hiring manager, totally behavioral. The second was OOD with coding logic, next was LC easy with an optimization that got tough but the interviewer was kind to nudge me in that direction. Next was system design.

Overall it was a great experience. The interviewers are friendly and seemed to really love their work.

Applied online and received an email from a recruiter requesting a phone interview the next day. During the phone interview I was told the next step would be a technical interview over the phone but he wasn't able to schedule on the spot. Was told he would contact me but never received another message.

This was by far the worse experience I ever had interviewing for a company. Not only he did not give me an opportunity to share my professional experience but also wanted to "coach" me in what I should and should not say. One of his recommendations was that I should not mention my age and wanted to tell me everything he wanted to hear instead of giving ME, the interviewed an opportunity to tell my history. The "interview" only lasted 20 minutes and out of that I probably only spoke for 2 minutes. The recruiter was rude, arrogant and when I asked a simple question about the requirement for that position he did not know the answer. Not to mention he never asked if I had any questions and did not care to make any connection with the person being interviewed.

If this guy reflects the mentality of Microsoft I will pass this opportunity and would probably not recommend others to apply. We are not robots and you may forget the human piece of an interview may be just as important as your "coaching" experience.

Arrive in the morning at 9 am at the recruitment building. You get anywhere from 3-5 interviews with various employees at all different levels of the company. Each interview has themes, usually one technical interview, another one focused on your ability to understand user needs, and a variety of personality / management and leadership experience talks.

First round. Simple technical interview. Talked about past experience. very friendly guy. helped me through the code. on campus interview at university of illinous urbana champaign. very short 30 min interview. got put on a wait list.
Work for programming and conversation to company employees and talking with clients who give us to work with our company. And I have skills for customer convenience to us. Profit for our company.

Applied for a position that mapped closely to my previous work experiences and was contacted by the recruiter within days on applying. Positive screening by recruiter, followed two days later by a positive video interview with a team member. Went up to the Redmond campus to meet with the hiring manager. I had a little trouble signing in due to the difficulty in spelling his rather unique last name, but got it figured out. When he came down to meet me, I asked him how he spelled his last name. He said, "With great difficulty" and didn't otherwise answer the question. Strike one. He then went on to tell me he came down 15 minutes ago to meet with me, even though he set the time for us to meet (noon, not 11:45). Strike two. He set us up for a "relaxing lunch meeting" but then led us into the obviously crowded cafeteria, where we would spend 30 minutes of a 1 hr interview waiting to get food. Since I was interested in talking with him about the actual position, I opted for just coffee instead. Strike two and a half. When we sat down with our coffee, he proceeded to regale me with disparaging comments about industry experts, outdated tools and antiquated practices. Strike three. There was no way I could see myself working with this individual and left scratching my head, wondering how this piece of work managed to get a job at Microsoft.

- Skype Interview with a Microsoft recruiter (30 mins)
- Assessment Center - Basically a 1:1 interview, followed by group exercise and then another 1:1 interview

I was given really positive feedback except for "lacking enthusiasm" and "looking tired" because apparently other candidates were "more energetic" compared to me. It seemed slightly controversial as I had to travel from 6 hours by train prior to the interview. 

I was also given a Microsoft backpack to remind myself of how I didn't get a job.

Got an email after a conference asking me to apply and that I would get an interview. Spots filled up and ended up doing a phone interview instead. Phone interview did not go well but still got final round. Final round I had to do a presentation on any topic for one of the three interviews (10 min). Overall very good culture and amazing experience. Interviews- one was mostly behavioural, another had a lot of hypothetical questions relating to the specific role (you are being considered for all the roles in the Aspire program but all are client facing). Everything on your cv is fair game and they went deep into some of my experiences- how I worked with teams, something I would change, etc.

Applied in July 2019, got my first feedback in October when I was asked to meet with a recruiter on my university campus. We had a ~30 minute interview with mostly technical questions, but also a few minutes for general discussion. A final series of on-site interviews was scheduled for the middle of December, but had to be moved earlier due to other offer deadlines I had. The on-site interviews involved meeting with four members of the same team, and each one had one or two technical exercises with whiteboard coding which had an initial solution and were then gradually improved, either by adding functionality or increasing performance. The next day, I got an email with positive feedback but was told that the team I interviewed with was already at capacity, so my recruiter would need to find a new team. After around a month of talking back and forth, we found a placement that worked and I received a final offer, which I accepted.

I would give a thumbs up for the whole process but (1) it took really too long in my opinion and (2) it seems strange that I was interviewed by a team that wasn't actively hiring.

The interview process was very nice. We were welcomed at the front desk and I had a pleasant chat conversation with the recruiter and other interviewers before we got started. There were 3 45-minute interviews that started with some brief questions about your resume then went into a coding portion. Overall, a very good experience.

Video Con Informational - 30 minues
Video con technical - 1 Hour
Onsite Behavioural - 2 hours

Overall I rocked every single interview. I would say I did 110 out of 100 (my gut feelings).

In the last interview, in last 5 minutes interviewer took pathetic uturns and it was utterly disappointing. As listed below.

- The JD did not mention 'Azure' even a single time. And my last question was does this job have 0365 and Dynamics work? The interviewer looked at me like I said soemthing stupid and said "Did u read the JD carefully, it says only Azure". I said the JD does not mention "Only Azure" even one single time. Guess he himself did not read the JD even once.
- Secondly, no where in any interview they mention I will have to handle 150-200 clients. In the last minute of last interview he says u will have to manage 200 clients. I was shocked and I said "hm so its a tech support role?" He goes no no, its Solution architect role where u have to sell to customers, I said "So its a sales role?" Interviewer had no satisfying answers.

How in a world can a Solutiom Architect manage 150 to 200 clients?

It is a Sales + Customer Support role and they disguise it with a fancy name "Cloud Solution Architect" IT IS NOT.

Anyways I stopped following up with them as I was not interested in such a worthless role. They get back after 2 weeks saying they hired someone else.

Well good luck to them.

It was an online interview. and i never got a return call. I am writing this because I want some information from glassdoor which will be available only after I review something , inspite of I having no experience in any of it.

Round robin type interview with 6 interviewees set in 6 separate rooms. Interview questions are relatively easy. Use the STAR method. There are 6 interviewers and the whole process is to last about 6 hours. 

The first interview went long (was supposed to be 45 minutes scheduled but was actually 30), and the hiring manager for the position interrupted with a rude and sarcastic tone to his employee interviewing me to move on. There was something that came up, so the second person I was to interview with had a substitute from another department. The third interview was with the hiring manager and most of it was him talking about his accomplishments and "how many irons he had in the fire".  The fourth interview was with a gentleman that was nice but ultimately uninterested. The fifth interview was with a woman who would have been my direct supervisor and I felt we had a good conversation. The final interview did not happen as the gentleman that was supposed to interview me never showed. Very unprofessional. That would sum up the interview nicely; unprofessional. I took a PTO day to interview with an office that was obviously not taking the process as seriously as I was. My favorite part was at the end after I had sat in a room alone for 45 minutes, and the hiring manager came in and said we were done. I informed him that the final interviewer missed his appointment with me and he then lied to my face and said that today we just did the 5 instead of 6 interviews. 

Awesome. Anyhow, I got the feeling that I was an addition as a filler to round out the sixth position as I only had 2 days to make PTO arrangements. The day before I got an email that was supposed to be intended for the "ringer" as he was coming in from an office in Kansas to interview for the position. I should have contacted the Kansas HR manager to let him know I got an email that was clearly not intended for me that had him as my POC. I guess I know why one of the interviewers badmouthed the hired head hunter agency that Microsoft uses. 

I still can't believe how laughably bad the whole process was. Here I was thinking all along that a company like Microsoft had their stuff together. Man, I was either really wrong, or everyone I met was having their worst day in a long time. Even though I was never really in consideration, I learned a lot and am thankful for the experience and more importantly, the story.

Got contacted from a recruiter to set up a phone interview. 

The phone process was very different from any interview I had done. When asked a question the interviewer would immediately ask another question based off of the answer you had provided. Very cool interviewing process and I am happy to have experienced this type of interviewing method.

About a week later I was informed that I made it through to potential next round of interviews which would be onsite. 

Few days later after that email saying I was potentially going to the onsite interview, got an email saying that I was out of the running for the interview being that the demand for the PFE role had decreased. I was provided with clarification on why I was no longer able to go to the onsite interview. I was very happy that immediate feedback was given because I was scared that I had done something wrong which knocked me out of the running.

This interview process was very good. I am happy I was able to go through the phone interview, it is unfortunate I wasn't able to do the onsite interview but I completely understand why they scaled back on candidates.

First stage was a 30 minute Skype interview, going over general questions about myself, my software experience and a short algorithmic question (no actual coding involved).
Next step was an hour and a half interview with a senior developer at the group I was being interviewed for. In this stage we thoroughly went through  a project I have recently finished, and did one algorithmic/data structure problem.
The last stage I went through wad an hour and a half interview with the team leader of the team  was interviewing for, and I was asked to solve (by code on paper) a few algorithmic/data structure problems.

It was three round 45 minutes interviews. In advance of being  flown to Seattle for a face to face interview, there is a phone screening.  The interview process is very straight forward and you are never in the dark.

I submitted my application online, was contacted to set up a phone interview less than a week later. The phone interview was short and easy with mainly behavioral questions. A few days after the phone interview I was contacted to set up an in person interview in Redmond Washington. I had two in person interviews each lasting about 45 minutes.

After a couple of phone interviews they request you block out half a day for standard sales interview questions that spanned over 4 1/2 hours via video with 5 different sales managers across the country. The managers were very good, engaged and asked fairly typical sales interview questions. Nothing too odd. However, after so many interviews there was absolutely no follow-up. The only way you knew you weren't selected is if you go in and see that the role was Archived on the MS careers page. After a candidate devoting such a substantial amount of time this was extremely unprofessional to not even get an email from the recruiter.

First participants had to take the online coding round in Mettle Platform. The test consisted of 3 easy to medium coding challenges . 
Whoever solved all three received a confirmation. After that shortlisted candidates had to give an online interview. Shortlisted candidates would be called onsite rounds.
Just several behavior questions to figure out what you are interested in, and then whiteboard algorithm questions, and you can ask him some questions at the end of the interview.

Am Anfang wirkte alles sehr zuverlässig. Doch im Laufe des Verfahrens ist einfach so viel schief gelaufen. Der Interviewer hatte mich eine Stunde zu früh angerufen, hatte sich danach jedoch entschuldigt. Es wurde ein bestimmtes Datum für die nächste Runde genannt wenn man es in die nächste Runde geschafft hat. Es kam nichts mehr. Obwohl mir versichert wurde, dass ich in den nächsten zwei Wochen eine Rückmeldung bekommen werde, hat sich keiner gemeldet. Auf Rückfrage kam erst nach 5 Tagen eine Antwort, die besagte, dass sie es noch nicht wüssten. Über eine Freundin, die bei Microsoft bereits arbeitet, kam jedoch heraus, dass die Abteilung nicht ganz ehrlich war. Es ist extrem unseriös angelogen  und hingehalten zu werden. Sehr enttäuschend. Nach zwei Monaten ( der gesamte Prozess hat zwei Monate gedauert) kam nach Nachfrage die Absage.  Nie wieder.

Interview process:
1. Skype interview
2. Assessment center ( 1 whole day with 12 other candidates)
- Shorter group case
- 2 personal smaller cases
- Situational questions

Everyone was very nice and open! The new office in Stockholm was very cool!
I met the recruiter at en event, they emailed me about a phone interview before I even applied online, then 3 months later they rejected me because they were full.

Skype call in English for 30 minutes approximately with recruiter.
It's was the first step of 4 interviews the 3 other interviews was more technical.
The interviewer was very nice and all the questions was clear.

The Interview was on 13th November 2019 at 5:00 PM sharp skype interview.
The interviewer asked me about myself, then we solved an algorithmic problem.
The person was very friendly and keen to help me at any point.
It's an on-site interview. He is a technical manager, briefly reviewing my resume. He didn't even care about my background and experience. Then just asking me a white board question, binary tree.

30 minutes phone screening. They asked of my background eg classes I was taking in school and work experience. I was asked to walk through a project i had on my portfolio and i was asked about my goals etc.

30-minute whiteboard interview @ my University. Initially questions about resume and experience, then tech related coding questions on the whiteboard. Interviewer seemed distant and uninterested. Could tell they had made up their mind before the interview had really progressed that far.

Few behaviour questions and 1 technical questions. 1st round, on-campus interview, which took ~30 minutes. The technical question was easy, about linked-list. They have experienced engineers to interview you. I was too nervous.

First round got a phone call and then two weeks later was invited to fly out to have an onsite interview. They were very relaxed because they knew we were all freshman and sophomores. They are really looking for diversity so try to stand out or you won't get it.
Phone screening + in person. They flew me there and paid for both lunch and the hotel. It was quite impressive. They also gave all some free goodies to all students that interviewed that day.

First did a Skype Interview with an HR and second went to an assesment center day where I got 3 individual interviews with different managers and one group activity. I had applied for a data science internship and got a bit shocked at first when all the interview questions were about customer service. After 7 hours of interviews they told me that there wasn't any data position available without even apologizing for the waste of time.
First was by phone, then an onsite interview. The time gap between phone and the onsite was long, but I do not remember the time. I went onsite on November 2019.

1. skype 30 min interview
2.codility test
the codility test was 60 min (3 coding problems) 2 problem were easy-medium , the last one was medium-hard.

the skype interview was a good experience, get prepared for talking about your experience and your achievements

There was a short phone interview, then moved on to an in-person interview. I arrived in the morning, where the other candidates and I got brought to the floor in the office we would stay at for the day. First, I gave a 10 minute presentation about myself to a group of Microsoft employees. I gave it, and that was that: there was no feedback portion although I did answer a few small questions about the technologies of projects in my presentation. Then, I had one hour long interview with mostly one engineer (although a second one was present to watch). We talked about my experience and the things on my resume, and then asked me a few more technical questions meant to find out how I solve problems, like "How would I speed up an app that takes a long time loading a list of 20 objects" or "How would I debug X issue". After that, I went back to the waiting room for a bit, and began my second interview. This was one on one, and my interviewer mentioned he did some robot related work for Microsoft, so I talked about my experience doing high school robotics, and we mostly just went back and forth having a good conversation. Then, they said I can go home! They said in their email I would get 3 interviews so I'm not sure why that was but it was already late in the afternoon so I'm guessing they were running low on time. I did not have to do any whiteboard coding.

I had a great experience. The conversations followed naturally and the questions were oriented around the flow of the conversation. I walked in feeling nervous but came out on the other side having made a connection. I really appreciated positive atmosphere the interviewers created for me.

Discussion of competencies, background and previous experiences, Basic knowledge questions, Test on Microsoft Office tools
- Interviews with different Account Manager, for 1 hour at least for each of them 
- Test on Excel, database and basic formula
- Fluency test in other languages

The woman I interviewed with was cold and rude. Every time I answered her question she provided no feedback and simply proceeded with the next question like a robot. I could tell she did not want to be giving an interview. It was the shortest interview I have ever been on and I knew she had already made up her mind about not hiring me. Every company is supposed to go over each applicants interview experience with the rest of the team but she made sure to send me a rejection email literally 30 minutes after the interview. I wouldn't even bother applying to a company who doesn't embody their values or treating everyone with respect.

The hiring experience was very nice . Interviewers are very cool and make you comfortable to ease of your nerves. It was a two round process. Scores of each round were added to get the result . Rounds were not elimination.

1 technical interview 30 mins
3 technical interviews onsite
Friendly interviewers, questions were moderate to difficult
After one interview they called me on site, first interview was easy but onsite was difficult
Very good culture

1 small interview 30 mins where they asked a very basic coding question. Logic was important and different ways of solving the same problem.
Next I was invited onsite for 3 interviews each with 2 or more questions. Here, the questions were moderate to hard.

Interviewer lacked knowledge. It was an online interview and they asked straight question from GeeksforGeeks. (By mistake the interviewer screen cast-ed her PC with the geeks for geeks question on screen). It was the worst question ever.

They had multiple rounds starting with a coding round followed by a written round then two technical interviews and a HR interview.
Coding Questions were mainly focused on areas like dynamic programming, Data structures and Algorithms.

Applied through university's Hand Shake and on MS website. Was contacted by recruiter for on-campus interview a few weeks later. The interview consisted of one technical question and several conceptual questions about Python/language of choice. It did not last very long and I thought I had given a satisfactory answer to the question. I was not offered a final round interview, but the recruiter told me I was "short-listed" should any openings appear. Unsurprisingly, I heard nothing for several months until the recruiter told me all positions were filled.

All remote apart from a final face to face interview. Two sets of technical tests by two different architects. Microsoft 'fit' which is strongly related to growth mindset and accepting we do not know everything. Very professional experience which I enjoyed immensely.

one round phone interview in November, then get invited to a onsite interview in January. There are five round back-to-back interviews on site at Seattle, with each lasting for 50 minutes. Two interviews were with cosine teams and the other two were with 365 teams.

Interviewed at Microsoft HQ in WA.
+ves:
great team, walked with me through all problems (data structures and algorithms)
-ves:
after flying me to WA and several rounds of interviews, they realized I was fresh grad and they were looking for 5+ yrs of experience

Everyone was extremely friendly.  Technical screening questions were easy for coding and medium for the data science portion.  The interview consisted of a general call first, and then a technical screening call where they ask you basic coding question, and then a call where they go deeper into ds/ml questions
Only had the on-campus interview. The interviewer was a SWE that didn't ask typical PM questions.  Was asked if I considered myself a good programmer. No technical questions.
I interviewed for the Explore Program. The interview process consisted of a short phone interview in November 2018 and then an onsite interview (at the Redmond, WA headquarters) in January 2019.

Submitted my resume to a recruiter on campus. Had a phone screen covering Computer Science concepts. Then moved onto three on-site interviews. All three started with some non-technical background questions and then went into a technical question.

This is a first round screen interview. The HR scheduled a half hour interview. Then a Microsoft engineer called. Not a lot behavior or technical question is asked.  The whole interview is about my previous experience.
Had one phone round. Was asked questions based on coding knowledge and behavorial questions. Got to the final round where I had back to back interviews. Was asked questions about my resume.

I had an on campus interview about a month after I applied online. Two days after this I found out I made it to the final round. I was flown out to Redmond a few weeks later where they paid for my flights, food, and hotel. I had two interviews 45 min each and was only asked one coding question the whole time. Other questions were behavioral, about my resume, as well as a logical puzzle just to see how I think. Everyone was SO nice and I had an amazing interview experience. I found out 2 days after that that I got the job! I was over the moon about it but ultimately decided not to work there because I wanted to work for a smaller company. Thank you Microsoft for such a great experience!

Interviewed with office 365 org. Had a Great interview experience with all the interviewers who were pretty seasoned. However had a very poor offer rollout experience after that. Rolling the offer out was painfully slow taking over a month. Recruiter not very responsive.

The guy was really nice and made sure that I was comfortable and relaxed. It was mostly about myself and how much I knew about Microsoft. There were only about 2 technical questions. This was just the Phone Interview and I have yet to hear anything back.
It was smooth. The interviewer asked me to do three coding questions which I finished on time. We also talked about job descriptions etc. He also asked me what a data structure is.
Weird to schedule, took forever to hear back after the interview. I only had one phone screen, so can't speak to next steps in the interviewing process. The call itself was very rushed.

First online coding then shortlisting based on that then a written round  and shortlisting based on that and then 3-4 technical interviews which were elimination rounds and then later results were announced.

Fairly simple, was only asked behavioral questions which was very surprising. I expected to code but interviewer was satisfied with my responses apparently. Selected for second round but I haven’t done the interview yet.

They ask me a question, then I have to answer them using my fluent spoken English. Also I need to know how to operate the Microsoft Windows operating system, so that I can tell others how to use it as well.

First, some brief questions about resume and past experience. For the later 20 mins, it was 2 coding questions. In the end, there was some question time for the interviewers. Overall, the process is as expected.

Phone interview first round where I talked to a current Program Manager, onsite interview (1st round from a PM from a different team, 2nd round was a lunch interview with a Principal PM, 3rd round with my future manager, 4th round with a Group Program Manager)

The interview process was what you would normally expect from a phone screen.  It was a quick and easy process. General questions were asked.  Medium difficulty level. Left a lot of time for questions to be asked which was helpful.
Had an initial phone screen which was a behavioral interview. Was then informed I would be flown out to Vancouver for a second interview. Was a presentation + three one on one technical interviews.

Asked behavioral questions and PM questions. Was about 30 minutes and then left time for you to ask questions at the end.  I got the interview opportunity by applying online and overall the interview was not hard. Additionally, they did not ask any questions related to my resume.

There was an initial phone interview. It was followed by an on-site interview consisting of three 45 min interviews with different interviewers. Overall, it was very straightforward and they provided a lot of info to help with preparation.

Dopo aver inviato la candidatura online, ti fanno un colloquio via Skype. Successivamente ti chiamano per fare un assessment center in cui ci sono degli esercizi da fare in gruppo e poi degli esercizi davanti a un manager.

The first interview was a phone interview and it wasn’t the best experience. I ended the call feeling like I hadn’t made any connection with the interviewer, hence I wouldn’t move to the next stage. Surprisingly, about a week after, I got an invitation for another interview.

The final interview was amazing, I was matched with 3 incredible CSMs and CSAMs who clearly had experience conducting these interviews. They were professional and asked a lot of follow up questions. I wasn’t asked technical questions like I had prepared for, so some of my questions were more behavioural and wanting to know about my experience. 

I’ll still recommend reading about the non-behavioural stuff like what are the 3 MS Cloud Platforms or how you’ll convince someone to roll out digital transformation etc. Doing this helped me make my interview conversational. It was no longer a question and answer session because I now had extra info to nudge the discussion further into other topics after answering the initial question asked.

I wish you all the best and I hope you have a great experience too and can share your feedback for the next person.

Total 5 rounds including the initial screen. Screening round involved discussion around projects and a couple of technical questions. Final round consisted of 4 45 min interviews with first 2 focusing on case study solution sketching and the remaining 2 on behavioral aspects.

Was contacted by main researcher - interviewed with two other researchers on the team for 30-45 minutes each. First interview was a screening interview and the other two interviews were more specifics about my research.

Microsoft Prague:
There was first series of the interview with HR then they hold for 1 month with the reply. 2d round is technical interview where I was requested to write simple algorithm in python. Then was series consists of 4 interviews: 1 again simple algorithm in python. 2 Interview with the data engineer without specific technical questions on data engineering, though they ask to propose the design of LinkedIn news list specific for each user implementation. That was the only interesting task. 3 is management interview with standard questions - how do you handle stress at work etc. 4. interview with data engineer again basic sql knowledge is enough to pass. Remarkable that during the whole process nor salary nor specific role description is not provided and despite I answered all the questions and mentioned that senior role is the only I can accept. They didn't came up with the offer and didn't explain why.  My thoughts is that they couldn't manage to open Senior position for this Job.

Straightforward and surprisingly casual. The interviewer was very nice, and the questions were easy to predict. The interview lasted for about 30 minutes then I got to ask my questions about the role and work culture.

Had a referral. Had an initial recruiter call and then a second (I think something got reassigned). Went through a virtual interview loop with four individuals: a Technical Specialist, a Principal Cloud Solution Architect, and two Directors (employee managers).
Technical interviews of 3 rounds followed by a final level fitment round with a senior director at Microsoft. The entire process was smooth with timely updates from the HR team.

Started with recruiter phone screening and then screened by Hiring manager and then multiple rounds of interviews including coding and system design. I thoroughly enjoyed the process but it's difficult to crack though.

Had 45 mins phone screen interview. Heard back 2 days later that I had moved to final round interviews. Had 4 interviews (an hour long each) Heard back a couple hours later that I did not get the job. Final Round Interviews consisted of 2 medium leetcode questions and 2 system design questions

1 coding assessment do to at home with 3 coding questions to di in 1.5 hours.
An HR interview in english, the HR asks questions about your experianses and 1 brain challenge.
2 technical interviews, each one with 1 coding question
It was a very brief (30 minute) process. We briefly talked about my resume and then dove into coding challenges. After that, we just chatted about microsoft and the industry in general. Good times!

I was part of the 2019 university hiring and the process was pretty interesting. It all began with the 1st round which was made up of a codility test and a Skype interview which I passed🤗.  The Skype was more of concept and design questions while the codility was to test your programming in which I coded 2 out of 3 problems very well.
Round 2 was an on-site interview which involved mostly technical questions and white board coding and they were 4 in number each lasting 45 mins.

The on-site interview was more like a discussion with the interviewer.  One thing I did to make the interview process this way was that; given each question, I described it the way I saw it before the interviewer and tried explaining to him how i will solve it then tried to optimize my algorithm. Along my explanation, if I was going astray, he could easily bring me back on track either by asking me a question or literally telling me to think in some other direction using some type or data structure. 

Before the interview, I was really nervous, but as i engaged in this talk with the interviewer, the fear just disappeared as he could  speak out to help me since he was listening to me and understanding what I was trying to do. 

I realized at the end that it doesn't pay you anything if you try to just jump into the coding and start writing code when given a question. You will end up getting stuck. You won't be given any credit if you  finish the interview in 5mims. Spend time and interact with your interviewer on the question. Talk to him and listen to him talk. This will also show him that you will do well in a team. Solving the question alone can show him that you are a bad team player. So even if you know the code to that problem, first discuss it with him. Explain the algorithm to him in plain words. At the end, i realized that this interview thing is just easy. This was my first ever interview immediately out of college and I nailed it ☺️

Phone and onsite interview.  4 hours onsite...
Dufficult to easy questions. Lot of fun visiting campus.   Team members and managers amd directors were on the panel. Relaxing interview. Sourcing and behavioral questions

5 interviews. 2 of them with technical leads and the remaining are with principal researchers.
the interviews included programming questions from the dev leads and general ML and DL questions from the researchers,
a lot of questions about my previous work

30min phone screen was easy.
Followed up with a 6hr on-site interview (lunch provided).
Disappointingly disorganized--didn't know who most of my interviewers were in advance, and many did not seem to have looked at my resume in detail.  Wasted a lot of time trying to figure out exactly what they were looking for in a candidate and learn more about the particular role.  Answers to my questions were fairly cryptic and vague--I suspect a couple of them were there for a personality/ general fit assessment and didn't actually know what the role entailed.

Sensed a lot of ego from a couple of them.

Technical questions did not seem entirely relevant.

Recruiter reached out to me on linked in. I received an email about 2 weeks later about on campus interviews. The slots filled up quick, so I  had a phone interview. The interviewer asked a series of questions regarding behavioral(mainly past experiences)and some technical questions.

The first interview went really well with only one technical interview. However, the final round was a little bit tricky with mostly technical questions about BFS, and hardware problems like memory allocation.

The first-round interview was a 30mins screening interview. The interviewer was super nice. Had a great conversation.  However, it was a very competitive position. Think the interview vs next round ratio is higher than 3:1

I applied online and received an invitation for a phone screen a month later. The person who conducted the phone screen was an analyst on a team. He asked me questions to gauge my interest in Microsoft and to learn more about my past experiences. Five days after my phone screen, I was invited to interview at their Reno, NV location. The super-day consisted of three back to back interviews. All interviews were behavioral. Two of them seemed to test for fit with Microsoft's culture.
