2. Professional and respectful type where Company recognizes lack of respect/recognition, poor process management and makes everything to fix it.

I got both:
First the professional answer from my recruiter apologizing for lack of follow-up, management and so on
Then, 2 hours later, the "Banana republic" answer informing me that I would not be selected.

I received first an answer stating that feedbacks were positive and decisions should be made soon... and less than 2 hours later, an email stating that I was not selected...

I then answered in the following terms:

Thank you for everything, for your patience, for the exchanges we had, for the time spent, for the positive feedback both you and my interviewers spontaneously gave me after the interviews which are worth the effort made to deliver the best of myself. Be ensured that I am much less disappointed with this news than with its context, however, from my perspective, this is a victory and this is where realism and professionalism are stronger than politics and ego although these latter often win on the playground.

it is a first round phone interview, the interviewer is nice and asked several behavior questions and dive deep to my project. She asked me a very easy array question, but since it is my first time software engineer interview, I was very nervous and did not have good performance.

Premier entretien équipe au téléphone, deuxième entretien RH en visio, très correct, personnes bienveillantes et à l'écoute, le travail correspond à mes attentes, ils ont été juste. 
Premier entretien équipe au téléphone, deuxième entretien RH en visio, très correct, personnes bienveillantes et à l'écoute, le travail correspond à mes attentes, ils ont été juste.

I had a recruiter telephone screen, where it seemed to me that the recruiter very clearly was just reading questions off a list.

Somehow I passed that round, and I received an email inviting me for an onsite, where they mentioned they'd provide more detail later. Then, two days before the interview, I received another email telling me when and where to meet some person and that another recruiter would reach out to me with yet more information. The next day, literally the _evening_ before the interview, I received the email with "more information": all it said was, again, when and where to meet some person, and it said that I'd go through 3-5 rounds of interviews, that I don't need to know my schedule, and that they would let me know when my day is complete. For all I knew, the day could've lasted anywhere from 1.5 hours to 5 hours... I canceled the interview because I was a full-time student with other commitments, and maybe I've been spoiled by other tech companies, but honestly I found it a bit ridiculous that I was given so little time and information with which to prepare for it.

first I was asked a few behavioural questions then we jumped to the coding challenge. during the interview, the interviewer was helpful in directing me in the right direction by giving me some useful hints

Applied online in November. Was given an on campus interview in February. Basic microsoft interview questions, with one pretty easy technical question. The process was during an MBA recruiting campaign. We went through a pre-screening, a call with an external assessor (behavioral questions), and then an interview on site, made up of a group assessment (40 minutes), and an individual interview with a manager, which was basically related to the CV. Completely waste of time.

Seriously, if you gonna hire someone, let them know what position you are going to interview them.

Caution guys, They invite 1 zillion people and treat you like trash.

I had a coffee chat with one of the hiring manager, and was brought onsite for a final round interview with 4 group managers/director in the team after 1-2 weeks.  I didn't get this one, but after a month or two one of the manager I interviewed with met me again and offer me the offer in 2 days.

First someone answer nobody shying to tell not become  one another begin to answer with questions to make the answer and neat dress form and later tell you discipline .

Scenario-based questions with Technical task during Assessment Centre. Was interviews on the soft skills, group task, and personal task. Everyone seemed very friendly and relaxed. HR were making everything possible for us to feel comfortable and not nervous.

- Appel téléphonique 
- Case study (2 choix de sujet) 
- Assessment Center au siège une demi-journée (présentation case study, entretien individuel, entretien de groupe, visite des locaux et échange avec les stagiaires actuels)

I got a referral and Microsoft came to my university to conduct interviews.
the whole process took one month from the referral to the interview.
my experience was very good, the interviewer was very nice and it felt like we where working together to solve a problem.

The Process started with an online coding test held on Mettl. Everyone had different questions so people were shortlisted based on their performance as per the difficulty of their question set. I manged to solve only 1 question completely out of 3. For the other 2 I submitted bruteforce solutions which almost passed(only 1 Test case failed in both questions). I heard people didn't got shortlisted even after solving 2 quesn so it all depends on your problem set. After this, They invited us to Bangalore for Interviews.

The First round was a Group Fly round in which we were given 2 questions to be solved on paper in 1 hour. They shortlisted only 8-10 people out of nearly 100 for further interviews. Sadly I could not get through this round :(.

Ultimately, I am here to voice a warning to other developers, and hopefully a wakeup call and initiation for action from Microsoft. The 60 minute online test which I took was stressed to be 3 questions, but instead had 5. The first three were all of the same question form (what is wrong with this code and fix it), but in different languages. It was clear to me these were standins for eachother, and you could choose which one to solve, as the test was only to be 3 questions in 60 minutes, not 5 questions. It would be absurd to have to finish all three of these (c++,typescript,react), especially as the test was also stressed to be language agnostic. Why am I even forced to a language type for these questions in the first place if the exam is language agnostic?

In addition, the test did not actually state that one did or did not have to complete all 3 of these quasi-duplicates, which means I had no way to tell whether this was a poorly stated 3 question exam, or a terribly constructed 5 question exam with an absurd timelimit. I was told I did not answer some questions, of which I did not answer the duplicates of course, and was not passed. Did the person grading it not know it was a 3 question exam? How is that even possible, unless the person was not informed on how to grade the exam properly? Do the people collectively managing this hiring process communicate together about the process itself? On communicating all of these concerns, I have received no feedback, and the recruiter has seemingly ceased communications. How ironic.

Red. Flags.

So many red flags.

This is a major failure on their part, and I cannot support or take part in this process, so I will not be re-applying to Microsoft for any position.

**And in addition to all these issues, the recruiter invited me to an event previously, which I prepared for... but since she invited me to a second event as well, the initial invitation was no longer on the table, which I was not ever informed of. It turns out there is a process of technical screening beforehand, which I was never informed or updated about. So I scheduled for a day at their campus, and that was a bit poor on their part, too.

Send Cv at 2 February, got skype interview at 1st March and yet i dont have any reply from them.Just waiting for any email, but for now i dont receive any feedback. I am going to update this thread when i receive any information.

I got an email from Recruiter and it was a team event. After applying for a position she sent me a online test. I completed the test(basic tree question and math question and find bugs in the given code snippet was an easy one ) and passed it. Fortunately or unfortunately I don’t know the event was full. So after two weeks she sent me one more team event recruiting this time I didn’t take any online test directly I got scheduled to attend onsite interview. I was scheduled to attend 4 back to back 45 min interviews with 15 min break between rounds. They asked me about my current project and general behavioral questions. Every one asked me one problem solving question and some follow up questions. They all are basic array, string, sorting and data structures implementation questions followed by i asking some questions. It was an easy interview overall and the interviewers and recruiters were very friendly and were helping me with some hints.

First one round phone interview then three rounds onsite. Lunch with team member. 
Each round starts with self introduction, then two problems. Interviewers are very nice and the working place is really nice.

Co ordinator doesn't choose the right profile for right JD. It will put the candidate to an assumption that only basics in the field is required to get into the job. But your profile will be rejected once after setting up the call with your interviewer. Ideally it should be thoroughly reviewed by the coordinator before it is being sent to the interviewer.

First of all, the interview was 20 minutes late and couldn't make her Skype connection work, which wasn't really a great start for a first impression and interview in general. The interview itself was very was very superficial. Nothing was presented in connection to Microsoft as a workplace or the position and it didn't seem like they wanted to know me as a person. The interviewer had a list of around 10 questions that she asked from a to z. Whenever I answered a question she would say: "Yes. Okay. Let's move on to the next question...".

They Conducted a Coding Round-it was pen and paper based.
the questions were easy but the most critical part of that was to write test cases which were bit difficult to think

4 interviews, 2 in the morning, 2 in the afternoon. First 2 where technical and the 3rd and 4th were more job oriented. Got a tour of the offices and free lunch and travel. Overall was a pleasant experience, it's a shame I didn't get the job.

Two phone calls, one with highly technical questions, one more HR related. Followed by a gruelling day of interviews in Redmond, 8:30 am till 5:30 pm  . Staff were friendly, especially the recruiters.

Questions were easier than anticipated but there seemed to be greater emphasis to get them correct. 4 interviews all day back-to-back, it was pretty exhausting by the end. Interview process was pretty rushed, had a call and they told me three days later to come on-sight. The developers and recruiters I talked to were nice but everything seemed unorganized until the day of the interview.

- Processus de recrutement très long pouvant aller jusqu'à 3 mois (un peu moins de 3 mois pour ma part)
- Etapes : Screening, Entretien téléphonique, Assessment Center
Entretien téléphonique :
Excellent entretien qui s'apparentait plus à une discussion passionnée (technologie, culture étrangères) qu'a un entretien classique. Chapeau bas à la personne de la RH de Roumanie qui m'a fait mon entretien, j'ai passé un excellent moment et échange avec cette personne. Conseil : Restez vous même et renseignez vous sur le monde des nouvelles technologies et l'intérêt de Microsoft dedans.

Assessment Center: Une fois l'entretien téléphonique, convocation à l'assessment center après un peu moins d'un mois (très longue la réponse !). On vous convie une semaine avant à une réunion Teams (en ligne) pour vous communiquer l'étude de cas et présenter l'assessment center. Vous avez une semaine pour préparer l'étude de cas à présenter lors du jour de l'assessment. 

Assessment center : Demi-journée à prévoir, une étude de cas suivi d'un entretien avec un premier manager, deuxième entretien avec un deuxième manager, travail de groupe. 

On vous prévient et on vous le répète mais la journée d'assessment center est à la éprouvante et passe très rapidement. Il faut pouvoir argumenter et restez sois même en tout circonstance. Plus de CV a cette étape, c'est vraiment votre personnalité et motivation qui prime.
Initial 30 minute phone call, then 1 1/2 hour skype call. It was mainly behavioral with just one technical question at the end. The technical question was only about what is a thread vs. process.

I applied online, interviewed at my university and was later called for an on-site at Microsoft, Redmond, WA. 

The interview had 5 rounds with questions on DS&A, ML algorithms (I have some ML experience on my profile), and SQL.

1 phone round 1 onsite. Had a 1 hour phone round after which I was called for on site rounds.
On site was a 4 hour interview with 4 interviewers 1 hour each. They asked me UVM, and oop concepts.

They contacted my via a short phone call. We scheduled an Interview for the following week.
The interview itself was pretty long - about 90 minutes. 2 Technical questions - at first we discussed them, and after arriving at a solution I was asked to implement the solution in code.

Un appel skype d'une quarantaine de minutes avant entretien physique dans Paris au siège, l'appel a été fait via Skype ce qui présentait un problème majeur vu la stabilité de Skype... 
Surtout pour un appel téléphonique et non pas vidéo

1. a group interview consisting of self introduction, basic knowledge of computer science (e.g., data structure, algorithm complexity, operation system), and English
2. two rounds of online coding tests whose difficulty is close to medium and hard problems in Leetcode

On campus interview. They asked me a question that wasn’t exactly possible, so it was kind of a stress interview. They then flew me out to the HQ for a couple of days. It was a really nice experience. For one day they had me do 3 or 4 interviews at HQ.

Initially, we had a 3 rounds of shortlisting process done by our college which led to around  40-50 max who got selected and went for the real coding contest hosted by the company. I was a cocky idiot who didn't prepare for the further rounds and flunked it at the round 2. They reimburse your travel cost if you have to travel to their location but sometime it may vary.

It was smooth. Phone interview, after that face to face interview with 3 senior managers. They saw my skills more in Project management in IT. Did well but my skills aren't what they needed. Got feedback from the recruiter 2 weeks after the interview. They were all nice. Wished my skillets matched what they wanted

Got an invite to do a video interview for a software engineering graduate position in Redmond. Was a video interview due to applying in AU/NZ. 

Skype is a horrible platform - I've done plenty of interviews where companies have actively avoided Skype. Microsoft obviously can't do this, so Skype was used. The lag and delay was unbearable and led to very poor communication on what was a simple binary search tree problem.

Interviewer noted that "this had not happened with other interviewees" so as to imply it was a poor connection on my end. Although I don't discount it, I have never had internet issues nor issues with the 10+ video interviews I did with other companies both before and after my MSFT experience. 

TL;DR: Skype is garbage, good luck

First was the call with HR then technical phone interview was scheduled. One technical question and more cloud based. On later asking the stack they use, I found out not a single technology was a match with what I have experience in. So later got a reject.

3 verschiedene Runden an Gesprächen hintereinander mit 5 verschiedenen Personen (inkl. Personalabteilung). War ein sehr nettes Gespräch, allerdings viel zu wenig Zeit und man muss sich mehrmals wiederholen wegen unterschiedlichen Gesprächsteilnehmern, die aber im Grunde doch das Gleiche wissen wollen.
Eines der Gespräche ist allerdings eine Präsentation (in meinem Fall über "Digitale Transformation").
Alles in allem nette Atmosphäre.

There were 3 interviews .Technical interview which was basically a hackathon between interviewees  then the second round of interviews are in person interviews followed by aptitude tests to assess the level of skill. Most of the coding questions were in C# and F#

First Round - Online Qualification round - 3 problems to solve (Easy - Medium Difficulty levels)
Pen-Paper Round - 2 problems to solve in 1 hrs
Technical Interview 1
Technical Interview 2
Technical Interview 3
Solving task on the board and a short conversation. I had to solve the task and explain the process. While solving, the interviewer guided me to the solution of the task. The task was a simple one.

The first round consisted of an online test, which was fairly alright I guess. Then the technical rounds. The hardest to go through is the pen and paper round where you have to answer the questions on paper.

Round 1: online coding round (3 Qns)

Round 2: pen paper coding round (main thing is they see your approach and you need to write only the required function and their helpers) 

then further 3 rounds were technical interviews

It's a 5 round interview
Round 1:  an in-home online test(Technical) Duration: 1 hour 30 mins
- 3 programming question was asked on DS and Algorithms

Round 2: Written Test(technical) Duration: 1 hour
- Again 3 programming question was asked

Round 3: Face to Face interviews(Technical)
- Be thoroughly prepared for the interview especially be through with DS, Algorithms, and Program solving skills
- Few questions were asked on OS, DBMS, and CN.

Round 4: Face to Face interviews(Technical)
- But the interview was same as the previous round apart from asking an additional question from resume
- Asking about what i do on a daily basis to improve my technical skills, etc.

- Got rejected in this round.

Round 5: Face to Face interviews
- They called selected student for final interview to Mumbai.
- I don't have any idea about this round

I went to the campus interview in March. No behavioral questions. Only a technical one: invert the string. The algorithm was pretty simple but the interviewer would keep asking where the code could be improved.
Round-robin of reporting manager and peers within the organization, each session is 1 on 1 and done in a relatively causal manner, interviews makes candidates feel at ease and are generally friendly.
Interview process was fun and easy. They mostly ask questions from Geeksforgeeks so make sure to prepare from those. Also, revise all DS. Make sure to solve questions from interviewbit as well.

Sélection sur dossier, entretien avec RH en visio-conférence, puis assesment center dans le campus d'Issy-les-Moulineaux (3 entretiens dont 1 en groupe). Managers bienveillants, à l'écoute, les RH  sont très aimables et donnent envie d'intégrer Microsoft. Réponse reçue le lendemain

The technical question was a sorting question with analysis of approach in regard to time complexity. Got back after two weeks in April with a rejection to the program.
The interview consists of a few stages: first with HR, then with the manager, and then with someone from the same team. The overall recruiting process can take up to 3 months.

Interview went well was asked about previous experience and skills I had and was asked about my salary. From there I was shown around the job and introduced to every in the office and floor. overall interview went well and I got the job in the end.
It is a 4 round process with 3 round technical and 1 HR round. All the technical rounds consisted of online zoom interviews of about 1.5 hrs. The HR round was basically about my fitting in the team.

Firstly, an online test on Mettle platform was conducted. There were 3 questions and an hour and half was given. Following this, the ones who were selected, were called to Microsoft office for the further rounds.

Very Friendly 
They seek for talent, bit knowledge over the product is extremely welcome
Questions were open for me to think on different approaches 
Process maybe long, e.g. one to two months

Amazing experience in the companies felt like the dream come true and delighted i felt like they are asked to do it possible for you to negotiate with companies for the day of the day of Small Cap 🧢 the 🤦🏻‍♂️ to !!
Two rounds of screening.  First phone, second Skype call. First round of calls were relatively quick, second round asked more detailed questions about experience. The lady was nice and professional.

It is a full day of about 4-5 interviews with different current team members. Each focuses on a specific point and asks questions to see if you have that certain quality or meet that certain criteria.

Recruiters came to my school to tell us about the opportunity. There was an online application, followed by a face to face interview, then an online technical assessment, then a final assessment in Johannesburg.

Had a phone screen setup with recruiter. Before interview recruiter gave materials which stated it was going to be a coding interview. The phone screen was completely opposite to what the recruiter had mentioned. Was asked only ML questions and no coding questions.

technical one, with a senior developer. All the usual, about me and my experience, about the role (cortana), then we went to technical question on the board.  She let me email her things I didn't have time to answer in the interview which was nice

1) initial call with recruiter
2) phone screen with a Cloud Solution Architect
3) In person 3 interviews, consisting of 2 presentations and a manager discussion
4) discussion with second recruiter
5) discussion with hiring manager and second Cloud Solution Architect
6) discussion with second recruiter again
7) offer
3 technical interview over skype and one managerial interview . The technical interviews were tuogh, about 20% related to Azure field and 80% is for scenrios like slow reponse and unreachabe VMs

Applied online and received an email to take a logic quiz. I took the timed quiz and felt pretty good about it. Next day I got an email saying that my skill sets do not match what they were looking for.

Chat on career fair to get interview opportunity. Phone call from HR to schedule. On campus first round. Then final round, which has 5 interviews, 3 in the morning, 2 in evening. Mostly behavioral questions and product questions. Emphasis on smart, product intuition, leadership and communication.

Worst On-site Interview Experience Ever.
 
I didn't receive any feedback from the recruiter after the on-site interview. I sent him a couple of emails then he promised me to provide the feedback by certain day then didn't send me anything. I reached out to him and the hiring manager via email, both didn't send me anything.

Contacted by internal Microsoft recruiter. Very easy to speak with. She said next step would be to bring me into a “loop” with four managers and the other candidates being considered for two openings. A scheduler took over from the recruiter and everything was handled well. Day of interview reported to the Microsoft office and was placed in a small conference room. Should mention I saw two other candidates in the waiting room before being brought back- no biggie, said hello to both shook hands. All three of us were placed in rooms down the same hall side by side. 

Each interview lasted 45 minutes. Hard to know what to expect with four completely different interviewing styles since obviously four individual managers. Really felt like the first person asked deep probing questions which really got me excited that I was able to describe myself and my experience very well. Second person was much harder to get that rapport going. Person was rather closed off, so much so I figure I was not favored at all. Struggled through second one. Had a 15 min break still in that same room. Third person also closed off. Didn’t ask many probing questions at all. Didn’t really dive into my experience was almost like I was filling a quota for number of candidates. Last interview and not going to lie at this point I am fried. Also pretty much know I will not be shortlisted. Fourth person was great. Gave me some energy back and really dove into my background again and was genuine with questions and paying attention to who I was. 

Overall, in am disappointed in my performance of the day and would change a dozen different things

Started with a Phone Interview in October 2018 mainly focused on behaviour question and no technical. Then got a follow-up mail from the recruiter saying selected for final round of interviews but had to wait cause all slots are full. Then recruiter left the Job so was very hard to find who was the replacement for them and finally scheduled my Onsite interview on February 15th. Onsite interview was mainly focused on Data Structures and Algorithms. Had five rounds back to back with all the question being a medium leetcode difficulty. Finally got my results negative with no feedback. The recruiter was rude saying, we always provide feedback but couldn't this time.

Online Bewerbung auf deren Plattform, danach kam eine Einladung zum Skype-Interview in dem ich mit einer netten Frau gesprochen habe und ihre ca. 10 Fragen beantwortet habe (auf Englisch und keine technischen Fragen)
I was surprised to find there was really not many technical questions asked they really wanted to get to know me, and my personality they asked mostly behavioral and hypothetical questions

Microsoft came for an on-campus recruitment drive. I had three rounds of interviews. The first was a technical interview, followed by a HR round and the last round was a combination of both. The interviewers were very thorough, but made me feel very comfortable.

Its very friendly and technically sound. More indepth questions over windows operating system. Rest is conceptual. Technical and manegirial rounds are there. Manegirial rounds are more of checking behavioural and team work attitude.

Skype interview with HR person, first round after CV screening. Questions were asked kind of randomly, so the conversation wasn't very fluid. The lady interviewing me didn't seem from the field, she took a lot of notes and said she was going to pass on those notes to someone else and I would be notified 2-3 weeks.
Phone and then On Site. On Site I had 3 rounds where I discussed my projects and some of their projects. All on sites round were with Data Scientists currently working at Microsoft

Overall it was fair, I thought. The interviewers were very personable and smart! First, I did a phone interview which was straightforward. Then I moved onto onsite, where I had 3-4 interviews, as well as a lunch.

1 screening interview with the recruiting team
2 separate technical interviews with your future colleagues. In my case I had to prepare a presentation, but it is not always like that
1 final interview with hiring manager (typically your future manager)

I was contacted by HR through instahyre. It was for HYD location, they came to Pune for the interview.  First round – a guy, which looked pretty junior to me, asked pretty basic question on java class modelling. 
Having 12 + years of experience in java , I did it with no effort. No algo or design questions were asked. That was the only question and then I was asked to leave , no further round. I asked HR what happened, HD denied giving any specific reason, however asked for feedback of guy who took the interview ( HR repeatedly  requested the feedback, got the feeling that there was something wrong with that guy , HR themselves were not happy )

This was for Microsoft EDGE team – they are really bunch of idiots. Never waste time for interview in this team.   I was interviewed for Microsoft 3 times before, cleared 3 rounds all the time , never had such a bad experience.  This team is really not an MS , or at least not as per Microsoft standard.

It started with a call from a recruiter. After that my resume got shortlisted.
The process had 4 rounds. Each round consisted of 2-3 hard DSA ques. The last round had DSA+ OOPS basic concepts. I would suggest preparing DSA well. The clarity in CS fundamentals is also a must.
Made it to first round, on campus interview (but got changed to phone interview because we got snowed in). Talked with a software engineer and he was friendly. Graduated from my college

Screening: They invited about 10 people on a week day at 9 in the morning and handed over a sheet of paper containing 2 programming questions to be solved in 1 hour. The questions were at easy and medium difficultly level. 

1st, 2nd round: Standard algorithmic questions

3rd, 4th round: Design messenger, online book reader

Positives
 - Some interviewers were polite and intelligent
 - Timely feedback after each interview

Negatives
 - The role and the team to be hired for wasn't clear even till the hiring manager round. They just said it's going to be under Office 365 umbrella but there are tens of teams I could have put in. Not even sure about role being a backend or a client one. They said I would get to know it when I join. They have to understand it's unacceptable for anyone who has some industry experience.
 - A lot of wait. They asked us to arrive at 9 but didn't start before 10. The whole day got wasted in the process without any meaningful takeaway.

The interview process was very enjoyable.  I was asked more situational questions to start, but as I asked questions in return, it was very conversational and collaborative.  Know your own story before going in and be yourself.  Try to relax.

Awful Interview, even if you answer the questions correctly, they still end up rejecting you because they probably didn't have an open position to begin with. One thing I would say is that I made it to the fifth round and answered all of the questions correctly, Microsoft was just there to waste my time to begin with since I did well on their questions and received positive feedback from my interviewers.

Telephonic followed by on-site interview. Only covered my projects because it was for a University Grad role. On-site consisted of four whiteboard rounds. Each of those was an algorithms/data structures question.

Nicely organized, but poorly executed. 

So my story started back in July last year. Saw this job on Microsoft careers site and applied. I was qualified enough to get a call and was confident about the interview. But I dint heard anything for a month. One day I was checking my SPAM emails and I found an email from Microsoft recruiter asking for details. This email was 3 weeks old so I immediately replied and also mentioned that somehow the recruiter's email went to my SPAM. Received a reply back that they are already interviewing and would not accept any more candidates at this time. REALLY? you just sent 1 email and never followed up. No call or follow up email. This is how you recruit talent? Great recruiters you have, Microsoft!

Nevertheless, I asked recruiter to consider me for a suitable role and she replied that she will call back once another role opens up. However, with my experience, I dint relied on the recruiter and kept an eye on the careers portal. Fortunately, I found a similar role opened up after 4 months. This time, I applied and sent an email to the same recruiter. She passed my resume to HM and as expected, I received a phone interview request.  

Phone interview - Super easy. Basic skill related questions. received a call back from recruiter that Microsoft would like to invite me for onsite interview. 

Onsite interview - Microsoft booked hotel, rental car and flight. Flew to Redmond a night before. Picked up my rental car and drove to Redmond Marriott. The give $75 for meals. So, had my dinner and slept early for a refreshing start next day. 

Interview day - reached MS building and waited in lobby for the first interviewer. He came to to the lobby and escorted me to the interview room. 
First interview - Background and skill related questions. With the type of questions he was asking, I became sure that he has no background in modernization and has just started picking up the pace. Hence, at the end of interview, I asked him when did he joined and the reply was just as I expected - 4 months back :). Anyways, the interview went OK. 
Second interview - This was the interview that made me think - 'Am I really interviewing for Microsoft or for a contractual job at a consulting company??' This person recently started learning things and was asking questions as he is an expert. I had no idea what he was talking about. He even dint knew the industry terms for migration, kubernetes, CI/CD, and was just asking irrelevant questions. Then he started asking developer questions from an architect REALLY? Out of those questions, some were logically incorrect, but I refrained from arguing as I was on the other side. I confirmed my inference the next day when I googled them. Due to NDA, I cannot disclose questions.
Third interview - the ONLY one which made me feel as I was interviewing with Microsoft.  Started with lunch and stretched to 2 hours. Nice interesting conversation with a group PM. Knowledgeable and interesting gentleman. He confirmed that the first two guys joined MS without any background and are still learning things. 
Fourth interview - the HM - 45 mins, with 30 mins questions and 15 mins for me. Initially, I thought that he is asking good questions. I started with explaining an approach which we 'actually' implemented at my work place. But then he interrupted! and started giving his own hypothetical solutions.  The solutions that he gave are good on papers, but when we actually implement (ask me as I have been there and done that), cause a lot of issues.  

After this experience, I was shocked as I expected better from Microsoft as I received from amazon recently. I strongly opposed using MS azure as a preferred partner for my company's modernization plan after this experience. Glad we ended up contracting AWS :)

Nach mehreren Telefongesprächen und Skype-Interviews wurde ich zum Assessment Center eingeladen. Alles lief super, das Team war sehr freundlich und die Manager waren herzlich und interessiert, nicht nur den CV der Beteiligten kennen zu lernen, sondern auch den Charakter des Bewerbers.

The worst interview process I have experienced by far. I interviewed on campus in February 2019 for 2020 roles. In July, I was informed that I would be moving forward in the hiring process, "likely" to a final round.  Over the next 4.5 months, the recruiter ghosted my 7 emails, (including some from current Microsoft employees I know).  I accepted a different offer last week but found out today that spots for 2020 summer roles are filled. I still never received any emails informing me whether I was still in consideration. Extremely disappointed with the disorganization and lack of transparency throughout this process.

I did a phone screen with recruiting. The recruiter asked me about my background and relevant experience as well as my expected salary range. The following week I was in for a half-day loop interview.

They almost never respond to applicants. I have submitted multiple times to the MSRA and other positions in China, and I never got interviews scheduled before. I don't even know what kind of resumes they are looking for, although I am not a top candidate.

It was a 30 minute phone screen followed by 4 rounds of interviewing. Took over a month so be patient.
Overall not a bad process, pretty fair. I would recommend the process to anyone who has the opportunity to try it
it was two parts, the first part was questions about my cv and projects i have done, the second part was technical and logical questions that i had to solve.

Did 6 interviews:
- Recruiter
- Hiring manager
- 4 interviewers (same day, different times)

Questions are situational, like how do you deal with an angry customer. 

3 months of process, still no offer
The first interview was a 30 minute technical interview, then the final was two 1 hour technical interviews. The problems were similar to many of those that can be found on LeetCode.

I applied through the company portal. There were 3 steps: first, 3 coding exercises on Codility (80mins) followed by a phone screen that included general and semi-technical questions in late November. In February, I was invited to the final round of interviews a month later. There were four 1:1 interviews, each 45mins with 15mins break, starting with ice-breakers and then a task in Codility. I had a confirmation one week after the interviews. There was some back and forth when it came to signing the contract but, in the end, everything was non-negotiable, which I wasn't happy with. My manager-to-be contacted me 2 weeks prior and only then I have learned what team I'm joining and what tech I'll use (X++).

TL;DR: long processing time, no indication of what the tech stack is

Interviewer was frustrated from a previous interview running long. Didn’t like my solution as preferred theirs (product design question). Was a little disheartening. Was confused by my question when I asked “How are teams decided at Microsoft for interns?”.

The interview consisted of four technical rounds, Each questions was a question that could be found on leetcode; however, the interviews would elevate the question dependent on how fast and capable I was at solving them.
It was a very tedious process. You start with a phone interview as the initial interview. If you pass that you then have four to five interviews in one day. It's not for the weak at heart.

First round behavioral and design question
Final round same things (4 interviews)
Brief intro with elevator pitch and then get straight into the questions answered in STAR format for clarity and give them concise answers
Quick and fair, it did not took too much time to be hired. The paperwork is extensive and make sure you are who you say. But very straight forward and no issues.

Throughout the process, I lacked visibility into the timeline or next steps and was passed back and forth to different recruiters. This is not out of line with my experiences at other tech firms, but it was difficult to get a sense of what was coming next so that I could prepare adequately.

Very Good, over the phone, at the scheduled time. The interviewer was very clear with the questions. Although challenging, the questions were fair. Next steps also explained to me. Looking forward to potential offer.

Recruiter screening, followed by technical phone interview.  Data science algorithms, coding and some MS product related questions. Finally on-site. Started at 9am, 3 team member interview before lunch, one lunch interview. Had break of 15-20 mins, probably team huddled up to share feedback. Had one more interview after that on ML topics. Finally hiring manager interview.

One phone interview in which I was asked 12 questions in 20 minutes and didn't get any feedback besides the word "okay." I was not given the chance to share anything about myself or ask questions about the company. I was told to give succinct answers because the interview was kept strictly to half an hour (which is fine) but when I finished the allotted questions ten minutes early I was hung up on. A day after the interview I was sent a form letter informing me there was no further interest.

It was a great experience to fly out to Seattle and be accommodated. We were placed in a room with the other candidates and were encouraged to socialize while everyone waited for their interview. There were 3 interviews with about 5 minutes between them.

I got a phone call for my first round, it was a quick 30 min phone call going over my resume and then answering some fairly easy technical based questions
Then I was called onsite and I was faced with 4 rounds of interview (back to back). They were extremely hard and drained me.

- Phone interview with a recruiter
- Coding interview on the phone
- Onsite which consisted of 3 interview rounds

During onsite, I met with 3-4 supposed team-mates. All of them were very nice and helpful throughout the process.  

Recruiter was helpful and responded on time.
Applied through the career fair at my college by submitting my resume. My interviewer was very friendly. I got very conventional questions. It was a really nice and helpful experience

In person technical interview with current developer. Was first asked a few behavioral questions about interests and proceeded to answer technical question and write code on whiteboard. Interviewer was nice.

Interviewed at Seattle Headquarters in 2019. Had multiple rounds of onsite interviews. Interviewers made me feel at ease. Questions were leetcode medium and a lot of custom questions based on the team.
I applied online and got an invite to a Skype interview. It was my first Skype interview so I was nervous but it went better than I thought.

I have a one hour phone call interview. First, ask me some questions about my resume and graduate time. It takes about 15min. The we use  a online codepad to write a code. It takes about 30 min. And then I asks some questions.

There was 3 1on1 interviews with a manager with an open position. There was also group case were the managers looked at the candidates interact. In the group case we had to present anew technology, just using our phones to gather information and then present for the managers.
Was contacted by a recruiter, had a thirty-minute phone call with him a week or so later, was invited to a networking event, had three 45-minute interviews back-to-back-to-back the next day.

Loop with 4 people and then two appropriates.  Recruiter was a no-show before the loop.  Recruiter mis-scheduled the first interview so I sat in a conference room alone.

Given the seniority of this role, I expected more organization.

Applied online  for a 12 months long internship (Dublin HQ), then got contacted for a Skype interview. The recruiter was very nice. Questions were primarily behavioral, which required to be answered with a STAR approach.

I was asked at 8:30 for a hiring event. Had the first round from 8:45am, it was about Data Structure and problem solving. I solved the problems and further variants, thought it went excellent. Then had to wait almost an hour before the second interviewer came. He himself said he wasn't prepared and it was a last minute. Then he proceeded to ask a math related coding question. I couldn't remember the property so I needed help, then it turned out the actual algorithm/coding needed was almost trivial. Again I waited an hour without any information and then called up the recruiter and was asked to go for lunch. After lunch, I had a Systems Design round. We started from generic problem to more designs. I thought it went well. The interviewer did say the they didn't have feedback from 2nd round yet, only 1st round. After this, I waited a few rounds and was told the feedback wasn't positive and I am pretty sure it was the feedback from 2nd round and I just had to waste a few hours more due to lack of coordination on the recruiters' part.

I should mention that the interviewees were polite and nice to talk to.

Was notified by recruiter of possible role available and would need to discuss it further with hiring managers in a  Interview offsite to see if I would be invited for onsite final round interview. Didn't get any job description information but was invited to visit onsite office for final interview and was told that it a client facing role and that was all that was provided as job description.
slow to hear back but otherwise precise. it takes a few rounds to proceed. During the interview, those people were helpful and friendly. Their culture looks nice and oriented.

Was contacted on LinkedIn by a University Recruiter about an opportunity. Got offered a first round interview over Skype. Interview went well. Asked a variety of questions, generic interview questions and technical questions as well. Less than a week later was contacted about a final round interview out a town. Although, was asked to fly cross country in less than 2 days notice. After a couple of days the recruiter set me up with a different position located in America. The interview took place in Redmond, but because of the snow the interviews needed to be conducted virtually. I was interviewed four times, each interview lasting about an hour each, mainly asked technical questions. Coded a couple solutions.

Assessment day, felt quite long and tiring as constantly being watches from 9am-4:30pm
Speed dating like start with hiring managers speaking to each for 5 minutes, which was relaxed.
Group activity which i found deceptive as i asked will we be presenting and they said no , then 15minutes in they give you a 5 minute warning to present.
3 scenario based interviews which i enjoyed as they were different.

3 part interview, phone call was made. interviewer was rude and cold. Kept interrupting me. Dint take kindly when asked to clarify her question.Overall bad experience with weird questions. Was meant to be behavioral interview but turned into cat and mouse interview.

Had 2 calls with the recruiter followed by a call with a manager. The recruiter was asking questions about salary expectation and willingness to relocate. The sales manager was asking questions regarding my previous target, quota and so on.

Great initial phone interview back in December 
Received invitation for open day with group question, interactions etc in February 
after 3 months waiting for a outcome received a standard automatic reply of not being selected

I was approached by a recruiter who told me about the private networking event. I attended that and was scheduled for in-person interview. The interview was 3 hour long one on one with Microsoft’s professionals. 1 Technical interview, 1 behavioral and 1 Domain specific.

One phone interview(30 mins): very short and the person was very insightful on advice about  how to further your career and 1 on site interview(4 rounds) 3 out of the 4 interviewers were very encouraging and thought provoking

Phone screen with team member, hiring manager and several 1:1 interviews on-site. This included giving  a PowerPoint presentation to several interviewers and also being asked to participate in a straightforward technical white-boarding exercise.

Pretty classic 5 person, 45 minutes each interview. In a Microsoft office. Several candidates for different roles also there. The interviewers had some prescripted questions and some ad-libbed. The process was professional and relaxed

Interview was pretty easy. The tech question takes 3 lines in python.
The Interviewers were inexperienced and the recruiter took 3 months to respond.
Would have rejected the offer the either way.

The first step was a phone interview. Did not hear back for 2 months. Got the rejection email saying no spots left. Got email after few days for setting up onsite. 4 rounds technical + lunch was kind of technical too with one of their engineers.

Very lengthy but very informative as well, they will go over your resume and ask you question on every position you have held before. Also be careful about your skill you will be tested on them , example keys on excel or what type of formula knowing the functions

Online Coding Test on mettle followed by on-site rounds.

round 1: fly-round - pen and paper based round with half the candidates eliminated
round 2, 3: Personal interview
round 4: HR interview + tech

The process went pretty quickly. I applied for the role about 2 months before. I received a questionnaire sheet. After completion I didn’t here 
from anyone! I assumed I didn’t get the job.

-1 hour Skype Interview with Hiring Manager
-1 Full day of interviews with the team (Interview Loop)

Once you get the offer the BGV is going to take atleast 3 months - Remain patient

I had one phone interview, one onsite interview at Redmond. The onsite one has three rounds. Interviews are not very difficult. Some questions are product management-related. Some questions are easy leet code questions.

Phone interview, followed by director of research discussing my research background. They got into detail and were very critical of what I had done in the past. But after that things became a lot more positive. However I didn't get the offer.

Interview process was fairly straight-forward, showed up was interviewed by about 3-4 different engineers. Questions were related to different algorithms, language of choice. Did not get a call back but definitely a good experience.

The usual channel: this can take 1-1.5 months
1) You will have a recruiter contact you and schedule a phone call to vet you.
2) If the recruiter call goes well you will have a call with one of the engineers 
3) If the call with the Engineer goes well you will be invited to an onsite

The onsite will have around 5-6 interviews with a lunch break where you will be accompanied by one of the folks on the team and you can ask general questions about the team/company etc.

Interview Process was pretty long but overall it was good. First there was a phone screening, followed by a more in depth phone interview. Finally after being accepted, I went in for an in-person interview with the hiring manager. Took about 3 weeks for this process,
After sitting down the interviewer started the programming question directly which is the design of backend API for a web project. There is no other content in that short interview.

De procedure bestond uit verschillende ronden waaronder een presentatie voor het management team. De gesprekken waren met mensen in dezelfde rol en met de leidinggevende. Het werd begeleid door een recruiter. Het geheel was zeer chaotisch en er ging veel tijd overheen. Ik kreeg bericht dat ik was aangenomen en daarna werd dat niet opgevolgd. Na wat vage smoezen (er was ineens geen positie meer open omdat men degene die de baan nu deed niet kon ontslaan) en excuses ben ik afgehaakt.

The first round of screening was a 60 second video interview (recorded and submitted online). The second round of screen was to then answer behavioral questions (written and submitted, which is in total six questions) and one coding problem (written, submitted and explained).

Interviewed with MSFT in the Spring of 2019 via my college recruiting. Process took over 6 weeks. Phone screen then onsites. Process was smooth for the most part. Interviewers were affable and engaging. Overall expeience was positive.

Me contactaron via telefónica para el puesto, no lo publicaron en ninguna página. La persona del departamento de recursos humanos fue muy atento y me resolvió todas las dudas que me surgían. Tuve posteriormente, 3 entrevistas con cada uno de las personas que serían mis compañeros/jefes de área.
.

applied the job online. after went through first round interview with hiring manager. The onsite interview was scheduled in a afternoon. I was interviewed by three persons . I was asked for some detail of my current project, then some scenario questions.

Ok. The interviewer did not ask any coding questions. Very general behavior+some technical background inquiry.  The interviewer was not very responsive. She sounds like she was trying to finish some sort of task. Did not hear from her until 7 months later.

Online Resume Review, 30 minute phone screen with a couple of basic questions & time to ask the interviewer questions about the company/role, 3 45-minute interviews that were focused on behavioral questions and relationship building
leetcode questions; then behaviour question. behaviour question was about the most difficult situation you have ever incountered. I did not gave a good answer. lc question was a medium one.

I got invited for a phone interview with Microsoft. People were nice, despite me being late to reply, and the interview itself was fine, the recruiter was good.

Later I was contacted by another recruiter telling my that my feedback was positive, but they don't have places left for this summer, and that if I get in touch with him I would be starting from the final on-site interview next year. Great - I thought, and waited.
When I contacted him 6 months later he said that I will be invited to on-site event in Warsaw and the details will be sent later. Then nothing, until 1 week before the event when I was told there is no place for me after all, despite the event taking place normally. I was pissed off since I already prepared and planned the trip.
He asked me if I could make it to 2 other locations, then he went quiet. After a month of not responding to my emails he told me there would be no more places for US internship and asked if Im interested in interning in Europe. I said yes, and then, after 2 months I was told that they are unable to place me anywhere....

I think it's terribly unproffesional from the company and they kind of ruined my motivation for top-flight internship seeking

Applied for Microsoft internship process Tech-Set-Go 2019 for Software Development Engineer role. Interview was scheduled at Chandigarh University(nearest location).
It was around 1 day drive. First an online test was there and then on site for furthur 3 onsite technical rounds. I was out from 2nd onsite round.

1) Application submission through the career portal
2) Phone call interview (General and behavioral questions)
3) Interview in the office ( Give a presentation on one of the technical topics such as Data & AI, IoT, etc, technical and scenario-based questions)
I had a phone screen with a recruiter, phone screen with team manager, and then on site. I interviewed with several different team leads on the team I applied to.

One online coding test, followed by a group fly around and then three personal interviews.
There was a difference of one and a half month for the whole procedure. Questions were mostly from linked list and trees.

This was an on campus internship process. First round was an online coding round. Students were shortlisted. Next was a group-fly round, where we had to write code on paper, and this was followed by 2 or 3 face to face interview rounds, with students being eliminated after each round.

1 Phone Screen followed by 5 onsite rounds. The Phone Screen was real world problem, emphasis was on algorithm rather than actual code.
Onsite rounds were like standard rounds with 3 of them focussing on design while 2 of them leetcode medium questions

Round 1 : Online Test
Test was conducted on Mettl. Test consist 3 Questions. All three questions were easy level.Those who solved at-least 2 or 1 and half questions were called for interview.

Round 2 : Pen Paper Coding Round
Microsoft conducted its interview process at around 8 centers across the country. I was called at Bhubaneshwar (ITER College). Around 50 Candidates from nearby region appeared for process. We were given 1 question (Removing duplicates from singly linked list) and 30 mIn to solve it. We supposed to write the code(in any language) . Judging criteria was how clean your code is, commenting, test cases etc.

20 students were shortlisted for interview round including me 🙂

Round 3 : Personal Interview
Interview started with some questions from my resume, about my projects, some real life applications of ML algorithms i have used. Then he asked me a simple question related to arrays(that i dont remember). After that he asked about basic OOPS related questions. Then he asked me to design microsoft search engine Bing. I was supposed to give appropriate classes and functions required to implement a Search Engine followed by some test cases. At last he gave me a situation that if i was given some work which i am unable to complete and deadline is approaching, what will i do .Also the only person who can help me is out of reach.

I was eliminated after this round.

There was one behavioral interview over the phone, and then they flew me out to Redmond to take the on-campus interview, which was all technical. There were two 1:1 interviews in person. The second one was harder than the first in terms of typical explore interviews since it required knowledge of trees and graphs.

The interview process was pretty smooth and the hr was very responsive. There were 4 rounds of 1:1s with breaks in between. Spoke directly to the hiring team and manager and learned about their work style.

I had three 45-min interviews and it was a smooth experience. There were questions that were thrown at me to be expected and it was a good experience! They had lunch and short breaks provided. The questions was a mixture of behavioral and technical!

Some one from Microsoft  HR global talent sourcing contacted me through LinkedIn and she shared with me the job description we made the interview and it was Ok it was general hr interview  questions and some technical questions .I suppose to have 2 round of technical interview but unfortunately she disappeared and i tried to follow up many times with no luck ..
I applied online and after about a month and a half I got an e-mail about the interview. The purpose was to talk about some of the works that I've done.

The skype interview was audio not video, straight forward questions with no room for discussion with the interviewer. Not that stressful if you prepare beforehand, research Microsoft and the products they have, have a clear reason why you want to apply to Microsoft.

phone screening and then online technical interview then presentation session after that HR session then Manger conference call then offering session and finally I god the offer then orientation session
It was a one on one interview with basic behavioral questions.  Looking for your experience and ability to interact with other people. Questions also regarding company culture and your fit.

Initial Phone screen Directly jumped into technical questions and projects on my resume. I have explained, But due to nervousness, I couldn't clear. Please be confident and maintain clarity on whct you are telling.

30min interview:

Typical algorithm based questions.  Brush up on Trees, Hash, Arrays and Dynamic Programming. Its as hard as any other Tech Firm. Typical algorithm based questions.  Brush up on Trees, Hash, Arrays and Dynamic Programming. Its as hard as any other Tech Firm.

at first phone screen, then there might be an on-site interview which would last for several hours. But i just finished the first round, i'm not sure if i can get into the second round

Round 1. 30-minute recruiter phone screen (purely behavioral stuff) 

Round 2. 45-minute technical interview in-person interview 

Onsite: 4 interviews. A mixture of behavioral questions, deep dive on experiences on my resume, and technical questions, with a heavy focus on product design and execution questions. 

Pretty straight forward interview process. Seems like unlike many other companies, Microsoft asks lots of Microsoft specific product questions so definitely have a good understanding of what products and features do and don't currently exist for the team you are interviewing with (Office, Azure, Windows). 𝗔𝘀𝘀𝘂𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗱 𝗖𝗿𝗮𝗰𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗣𝗠 𝗜𝗻𝘁𝗲𝗿𝘃𝗶𝗲𝘄 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗦𝘄𝗶𝗽𝗲 𝘁𝗼 𝗨𝗻𝗹𝗼𝗰𝗸, 𝘆𝗼𝘂 𝘄𝗶𝗹𝗹 𝗯𝗲 𝗳𝗶𝗻𝗲.

The process was lengthy specially for the first few interviews... my last 2 interviews was in the same day, detailed, 5 interviews in total... 

basically the process started with two technical interviews, where I was asked deeply technical questions and some behavioral ones.. later the process followed with three manager interviews focusing on behavioral things only.

Process was very simple it started with a phone call with a third party recruiter. First was an introductory call simple non-technical just to verify I have the experience they are looking for.

Second call was the a programming interview with one of the senior engineer (not the hiring manger), We discussed about the role and experience. He asked me to write simple C related programs on shared screen. Not very tough. Correct definitions type questions.

Third, interview was onsite with 4 team members, 3 interviews were 30 minutes long with one lunch interview of which was 30 mins lunch + 30 minutes interview. First 2 interviews were technical in nature focused on C programming, RTOS and communication protocols. Few questions related to source control. 3rd interview was 50% technical + 50% behavioral. (how do you work in team environments). After every interview your current interviewer tells the next one about your strength and weaknesses and also whether you are a 'HIRE' or 'NO HIRE'., based on which the next interviewer tailors his questions to test your strengths. Good thing is Microsoft wants to hire people for there strengths, and they wring you out on that so you better be good and confident. After 3 interviews (most of the times 4 ) if you get majority of 'HIRES' then they discuss whether or not to send you to the next level. Which is mostly with a senior level manager while you wait in the lobby. (which I found it extremely weird and insulting.) If there decision is in your favor then you get interviewed by the last interviewer. I got the last interview which was again 30% technical (just to test how you approach a problem), and 70% non-technical behavioral to see understand whether you will be a good fit for Microsoft's culture. 

Overall, timeline wise, extremely sluggish process. It took around 5 months from the first interview to get the offer and another 1+ month to perform background check and get the joining date. It took 2+ weeks for recruiter to tell me that I was selected, another 3 weeks to  get the offer. Another 1+ months for background check and finally the joining date.

So, if you have meditated your whole life and want to test your patience apply here. I wasn't actively looking so it kind of didn't really matter to me.

They really need to improve and be more agile in the recruitment process that could be another reason why they are loosing their employees to Amazon. Amazon has a policy to give feedback within 48 hours. And interview process takes around 3-4 weeks of time which is average and acceptable.
A phone screen with a recruiter, and hour technical screen share call, and 5x1 hour in person whiteboard interviews.  The last one was with the hiring manager who made the final call

Overall great experience, Applied online initially and was contacted back within a few weeks. Had a phone interview at first, then followed up and scheduled for an in-store interview. Waiting to see if i'm hired, but impressed overall.

*I interviewed for the garage program*
- completed phone screen (around 45 mins) where they asked about my interest in microsoft, some design questions and how to explain the cloud to a grandmother
- they flew me to do onsites a month later where we had to do a 10 minute presentation to a panel of interviewers followed by 4 back to back technicals/behaviorals (20 minutes for behaviorals & 25 minutes for technicals)
- Overall a fun interview process. Interviewers were very friendly, didn't really feel like an interview as much as a nice conversation. Left the interviews with a very good impression of Microsoft 
- I didn't do so well on 2/4 technicals but I think I left a good enough impression on the interviewers that they decided to take me on
It is the 30 min first round interview from an employee of Microsoft.  A few behavioral and technical questions on SQL.  The interview went smoothly and the interviewer was very nice.

Was recruited on Linkedin to apply. Had a 30 minute phone interview with HR and then was asked to come in for a final round interview. Final round consisted of a meeting with HR and then five technical interviews (all 45-60 minutes each). You were shuffled from one interview to the next with almost no time to go to the bathroom or get a drink of water.
They asked me about my experience and stuff, there was also a lot of focus on punctuality and dedication. I just talked about how great I was at being punctual and on time

Screening interview, onsite interview. Onsite consists of four 45 minutes sessions with lunch after two of them.
Screening is about your overall experience plus one algorithmic problem.
Onsite is quite interesting, especially in system design questions.

I passed the on campus interview which consisted of a quick tree recursive problem that took around 30 minutes. I was provided with a nice hotel in redmond for the on site interview about 10 minutes from the campus. The day was pretty tiring as it involved 5 interviews with one of them taking place during lunch. Each interview was a mix of behavioral and technical questions such as string manipulation, backtracking, and some networking stuff I didn't really understand. Overall it was a great interview experience but I would prefer to have no interview during lunch

Phone call straight to onsite. For phone call it just went over resume and asked me a couple technical questions - thread vs. process, describe recursion to 5 year old. Recruiter was not experienced so not sure how he judged me. On site was around 40 other people, all split into groups of four. In our group of four we had four interviewers who did 1 on 1 with us. Three technical and one behavioral. All super nice. Other than your skills they wanted to see your attitude, willingness to learn, how you accept criticism, and excitement to programming. All of them went through resume and asked questions on them. Also be prepared to know OOP principles.

They asked my research area, programming skills, the basic understanding of the area, and what want to do during the summer. Two weeks later they sent me an offer letter and asked me about my prefer working content.

Entire process took about two months. I had a phone screening with the hiring manager and team members. I was then asked to come on site about a month later.  And a month after interviewing, I was given a decision. 

The questions were very conversational and far less interviewy. No one asked the typical interview questions. It was more about will you get along with the team

Applied in October with a phone screen scheduled the following week. I thought the phone screen went okay, but then radio silence until December when I got an invite to fly to Microsoft. Flew out to Redmond, went through 4 back-to-back interviews for a PM Summer Internship. First interviewer was super kind, and everything went well. Second interview was much more difficult -- the interviewer didn't really give me any visual cues (such as nodding) to indicate whether my responses were in line with what he was thinking, and in general just didn't give me much guidance to go off of. Third interview was informal lunch, which was pretty good but I think having an interview over lunch is tough because you're trying to eat while also answering questions. Fourth interview was by far the best with someone who had been at Microsoft a really long time. Incredibly kind guy, and he offered me useful feedback on my responses as well as a framework for how to answer the case study questions. Everything was behavioral for the most part.

There were 4 rounds of interview, all technical, in a single day process in Mumbai.
1st interview: 2 coding problems, first write pseudo code, followed by actual code in the language of your choice
2nd interview: 2 logical questions on Data Structures. Explain logic and then write actual code
3rd interview: 2 coding questions, similar to the first interview
4th interview: 1 comparatively complex logical question  using Data Structures. Explain logic and write code for it
Each of the interview was 1:1 with a different interviewer, and lasted about an hour
Predominant Data Structures were graphs and trees, although questions on linked lists and array were also present.

I applied through a recruiter.  I interviewed at Microsoft Korea. 
There is a Phone screening with recruiter. After this, you will be invited for an on-site interview. On-site interview was split into four rounds. Overall a great experience. Very professional, friendly.
It was pretty easy going. I was brought before different departments of Microsoft and I was asked a series of questions. Everyone seemed nice and supportive, and I got to meet a lot of cool people.

Fairly straightforward, mostly behavioral type questions. One phone interview and onsite/panel (Skype). 

Specifically, my process was a bit unique in that I spoke with a team member first (phone screen) and then spoke with team/panel. I was not granted an onsite, rather a Skype based panel. 

Process was very broken and seemed recruiters did not actively communicate with hiring team. Was told 2 days prior that I would be traveling onsite. One day before, I was given instructions for a Skype dial in call. Was also not given schedule/timeline until day of.

Advise to interviewee -- make sure you bother the recruiting team for all details as the recruiting process seems a bit broken.
Over all  good experience with process   It was single day 4 face to face with various team .   I was really thrilled to have such solid question.

Interview process was fairly simple, I was contacted by agent and then my profile was selected for interview with two employees from Microsoft.
Here comes most annoying part, when the interview started there was no greetings or any explanation about what company does or what they are looking for.
Ethical and moral behavior was missing in whole interview process.
One of the guy was stressing as if I was ying on resume which I did not like at all.

Here is the scenario
Interviewer- Have you worked on LPKF?
Ans: Yes I have worked.
Interviewer: Are you sure you can work on LPKF?
Ans: Yes
Interviewer: We have LPKF at our facility, If I hand you a project can you work on it?
Ans: Yes, but then I had doubt on the interviewer lying to me, so I counter questioned him, which model of lpkf do you have? he said he doesn't know, and he have to check. LOL
Then with second interviewer initially i said i have no experience on spectrum analyzer, i have experience on VNA, oscilloscope, multimeter etc. 
But it seems like she had a set of questions on spectrum analyzer, and she was reading continuously one after another question on spectrum analyzer lol.
Why would keep asking question on something which was already told by candidate that he has no experience on.

Overall, I had higher expectations from Microsoft, but it turned out to be that everything is robotic there, I think employee should be trained on moral and ethical behavior and a matured professional should conduct the interview.

Pretty good overall experience. I had one phone interview one month after applying online, and then I had one on site interview two months later. I got an offer after 2 weeks.

The hiring manager sends an intro email asking for availability and before I could even reply she sends an email invite. I replied that I looked forward to speaking w her. No reply. On the day of the interview she arrives 12 MINUTES late to a 30 minute “screening interview”without explanation or acknowledgement!! Or apology. When I experienced audio issues for a few minutes trying to use Teams on a Mac (psst sorry MS but Zoom is so much better) she grew impatient even though I said nothing of her arriving so late. I should note I arrived 10 mins early - had she been on time or even slightly early to account for connection, we would’ve had more time and and her  composure over the issues. Also connectivity issues happen all the time. It’s technology not perfection. You’d think MS would know that. Nonetheless we managed to get thru her questions but when I asked the basics such as comp package to determine whether they could afford me she shakes her head saying she’s not going to have that discussion bc that’s an HR issue and would come up “later”. Later? I’m thinking why on earth am I having my first screening interview w a person who can’t even tell me how much this pays and why on earth would I give them a full day’s worth of interviews which was expected in the next round according to her  (at the busiest time of the year for a contract manager) without even knowing a range at least? The process was so disorganized and made no sense to me at all. As colleagues have pointed out - if this is how she manages an interview process then how is she managing the team?! I sent a post call email nonetheless, acknowledging the meeting starting late yet nonetheless thanking her for her patience and one question I had neglected to ask. No reply. Hey SE, I was interviewing you as much as you were interviewing me. You seemed to forget that. Arriving on time to your meetings is fundamental professionalism. I expected better out of MS. And MS or not, there are plenty of other and better options out there for those of us qualified candidates for which I hear there’s a shortage in the filed right now. Good luck!

45 minutes, casual, informal, it involved less questions about the role and more about my personality and ideas. two interviewers and they were patient and made it comfortable. Overall it wasnt very hard as long as you keep calm and prepare.

Recruiter got in touch with me via LinkedIn. I scheduled  a phone interview with her. The interview was more of a chat on my career; previous experience and future goals and a brief of the next interview step which was a coding interview.

I had a total of 5 interviews, although I was told beforehand I could have anywhere from 3 to 5 interviews. I did see my itinerary at one point and saw that the fifth interview was "as necessary" so take it as a good sign if you make it to the fifth interview I suppose (at that point you're probably borderline or soft yes).

All five interviewers asked some general questions about experiences I wrote about on my resume and they all had a whiteboard coding portion (most of the interview was whiteboard coding).

Logistics are pretty clearly laid out, although I had some technical issues with signing into my account/action center, but my recruiter was very responsive.

Overall the process seemed fair and questions seemed reasonable.

Sometimes I would have trouble either hearing or understanding the interviewer. All were fairly soft spoken except for my last interviewer and all of them spoke somewhat accented English. This was most notably challenging when I had lunch with one of my interviewers and could hardly hear what they were saying (we went almost exactly at noon so it was very busy).

I already accepted an offer from somewhere else, and therefore didn't really study for this one.

The interview process was good. Interviewers were very friendly. I liked the questions. They were pretty interesting and well thought out. Overall I thought it was a very cool and enjoyable interview.
