They don't even bother write to you directly. Quite frankly, I'm not sure I want to work with and for such people anyway. Lack of professionalism in every single step and detail. The test itself may sound cool and smart to them, but it's actually disrespectful and pointless since doesn't test any real engineering or coding skill; anybody with a little bit of experience could successfully do it. And even if you don't have a clue on how to do it there is plenty of guides online,  or have a friend do it for you.

Bottom line: the whole process is amateurish, the lack of respect for the candidate annoying, probably the worst interview experience of my life.

There were phone screenings, then in person interviews.  The interviewers were friendly and the questions were not difficult. Being enthusiastic about Microsoft core values is important. There were several rounds of interviewing.

Campus Recruitment for Product Manager. It started with GD round followed by three rounds of personal interview. 
First round went well. 
Second Round was post lunch. The interviewer was highly uninterested in taking the interview.
Interviewer: “I had a heavy lunch today, so, I am going to walk around the room for a while if you won’t mind”
Me: Fine.
Interviewer asked questions and seemed like he wasn’t so keen on listening to the solution. He was unable to grasp the solution and kept on telling that the solution was wrong. Finally he told me the solution, which was same as mine if he would have listened to me carefully.
p.s. I spent the whole day empty stomach, and the interviewer was roaming around the room because he had a heavy meal. Such unprofessionism is not expected from such a reputed company.

The process was pretty extensive - recruiter conversation, 4 individual discussions (including hiring manager), took about 3 weeks. Mostly fluid conversations, none were formal interviews. A couple of behavioral style questions and a couple of informal case-styled questions, no brain teasers and have plenty of time to ask questions. I prepared for 2 days and glad I did.

One phone screen with a recruiter. After I passed that screen, the recruiter scheduled  four 45-min interviews with 15 min breaks. I received an offer for the data science internship role after feedback from all these interviews was collected.
Got the call from the recruiter, schedule with 3 different team members of the Senior Leadership - got easy calls, not much technical - really human being. It was a good experience overall

The process consisted of an interview with a global recruiter (and a code test), followed by 2 technical interviews with senior engineers, which was followed by a technical interview with the hiring manager.

1. First contact through linkedin
2. Phone interview with an HR recruiter
3. full day interview with 4 person
4. feedback from the manager
5. offer
6. time to provide the answer

During the interview, I have been ask multiple question related to system design, scalabilities and software safety.
I had a few technical difficulties with the Microsoft teams software which reduce the interview time and did not allow me to be fairly interviewed, even if I received an offer.

It was a great learning process and although there were seven rounds in total spread out over 3 months, all the rounds were relevant to the position itself and were potent to screen out candidates with required skills for the role.
I applied for an off-campus role and there were more than 12,000 candidates applying out of which around 14 students made the cut. It was very competitive.

I applied on-line for several positions in October. HR sent me a list of questions to answer and my 1st round was in December with 4 rounds of interviews and then in January I had a final interview and received an offer one week later.

Had a great round of interviews for a PM role at Microsoft. Standard questions, super friendly team. Had a 1:1 chat with the hiring manager, was moved onto 4 rounds of interviews (all in one day), then a final person (AA round).

Three rounds. one technical recruiter (45min), one with the two members of Microsoft research group (30 min), and a whole day interview with the team that I will be joining. The third round consist of three 45 min interviews including a coding, a statistics, and questions related to my research.
The interview loop was held in one day for a total of 4 interviews. Each interview is roughly around 45 mins and there is a 10-15 in break between each one but its not as hectic as it sounds.

I had multiple interviews with multiple people. The first interview was with an HR rep who went over the general job expectations and compensation. After agreeing with the expectations and providing them with my compensation expectations, I had an interview with 3 managers over a 3 hour period. The interview involved technical and situational questions. Being honest about your level of technical expertise and how you handle situations is the best approach. Microsoft culture expects all employees to be open to learning everyday and to never expect to be the smartest person in the room. Be grateful and show some humility.

On campus interview - first round. Met through campus career fair. Was first interview in the day. Never opt for the first interview of the day. Asked Basic HR questions and projects on resume before proceeding forward to technical question. Only One question. Did not have time to code, asked for pseudo code.

The interviews started at 9am in Fargo, ND. I had interviews with a total of 4 engineers who had progressively more involved questions. After 3 hours of interviews with the first two engineers a third engineer took me to lunch on their campus, the food was fantastic. After lunch I interviewed with that engineer, and finished with the engineering lead manager to finish over 6 hours of interviews. The questions weren't too hard and the engineers were all more focused on how you approach the problems.

On campus interview(mix of tech and personal questions)-> final round interviews at Redmond. Had three interviews (one product design, two coding). The PD question was interesting and the coding questions were straightforward and simple.
Overall, the interview was fine. Asked basic / expected questions. Lasted about 30 mins. Completed the interview after I applied online for the internship. Took about 2 months to hear back.

Was brought onsite for the final round of interviews. Had a total of 5 and all my interviewers were very nice and personable. Questions ranged from simple Cracking the Coding Interview stuff to OS resource management to bit manipulation. I coded all but one question in C.
Got a call back after speaking to an engineer at the career fair in my university. The first round was held in person on campus. It was a very question.

Had an on campus interview in September 2018 and onsite in November 2018, 5 rounds in On-site. Covered Data Structures and Algorithms questions (leetcode medium mostly). Was expecting to get the offer but in the end it is the HR's call and didn't receive the offer. Be sure you are enthusiastic throughout the day as my interviews lasted from 9 am - 5pm with lunch interview as well.

I reached out to a recruiter via email after applying who redirected me to another recruiter. We set up a time to talk over the phone - she was a "reverse" Microsoft recruiter who let me pick positions to interview for if I found them on the website since I originally applied for University Grad Designer. She would simultaneously look for teams for me to join based on my preferences for location, position, and skill level. 

I found a few teams and then explained why I wanted to work for them. They were all located in Redmond. Didn't hear back for 2 weeks and then one team reached out to me and scheduled a 30 minute call with the hiring manager where we only had time to go over one project. After the interview, I heard back fairly quickly on setting up an onsite interview (called the LOOP) for the following week. I came onsite for a full-day of interviews from around 9am to 3pm (including a lunch interview). 

My onsite included a one hour long portfolio review in front of a panel of people, a design challenge where I was left alone for 45 minutes to whiteboard a problem (and 30 minutes to present + Q&A), and various other one-on-one interviews throughout the day. I believe this whole process was to help me find a team within the org as well. I did participate in a last-minute 30 minute interview with a senior member of the design team, that Microsoft is notorious for.

Overall, it was a great experience and great offer! The people I interacted with were friendly and gave really constructive feedback.
I was chosen to complete a skype interview. Then  from there I was reviewed by staff to go to an assessment centre. Unfortunately I was not progressed from there onwards

Recruiter screening followed by on site one on one with hiring manager and then a full day of interviews and portfolio review.  The process was very smooth but the whiteboard questions caught me off guard, especially since they were coming from other departments.

I was approached on LinkedIn by a recruiter and asked to apply, shortly afterward I was invited to an on-campus interview where they asked some basic coding questions and behavioral questions ( the coding questions are based on what you put on your resume).
Later I was invited for a second interview at their Hq in Seattle. it consisted of 4 rounds of interviews each 30 minutes long with 15-minute breaks between each session. I was interviewed by veteran engineers with on average 10 years experience. Some questions were technical some were puzzles

Nach 1,5 Monate und 6 Interviews wurde ich endlich eingestellt.

Es handelt sich hier um eine IT Projekt Manager Position fuer die ichangerufen wurde.
Interviews:
1. Vorstellung HR
2. Sprachtest Deutsch / Englisch
3. Hintergrund (Schulisch)
4. Technisch
5. Management
6. Reginal Manager (Mein vorgesetzter)


Danach erst wurde mir erst die Stelle zugeschrieben.

Terrible. I felt that the interviewers were uninterested and unhappy - in general! Even as I met them did they seem completely uninterested. It really rubbed me the wrong way. During the coding interviews I saw two of them scrolling through Facebook. It sadly threw me off my game.

Very laid back and chill. Met at a Starbucks in the mall not far from the Microsoft store. Was the assistant manager and manager that were present. The made the conversation flow naturally and mentioned  how everyone there was a family.

there was a phone screening or pre-interview which was mostly soft skills and a little technical, then a single person, non-panel interview for the role, half technical, half softskills, 100% awesome.

Two round phone interviews (via Skype). The first round was talking to a senior software engineer. There were two coding questions. The second round was with a team leader (?), and there weren't any coding questions, most questions are about my side projects.

Easy But Have to prepare. I first met with someone for a quick 30 minute  interview where she asked me 2  coding questions. Then the final interview in Seattle, where they pay for your flight and expenses while there.

Was called about a month after submitting my resume through online and had a non-technical phone screen with recruiter asking me about my projects listed on my resume.  It contains general behavioral questions and basic technical questions.

I applied for the SDE intern for Summer 2019 in last August and one person came to my campus to interview in November. It's a 30-min, pure tech one. My interviewer has a really weird accent (most like from India), and could not even explain the question clearly. I was writing down my solution on the whiteboard but he just kept breaking me in the middle. As a result I could not give a complete answer until I ran out of time.

The process is not very serious and strict. All of the three staff of the group attend the interview and all of them asked some questions to me.  They basically asked me about my previous working experience, what I did, what role I played in the project. They also asked my opinion on their current marketing and pr strategies.

University Recruiter put my resume in the system got an on-campus interview, went onsite to Seattle, I was trialed as a Junior but I was a Freshman so I did not get any of the questions correct. No offer received.

First, a behavioral phone interview. Next, super day in Seattle (four 45 minute interviews). Will have behavioral and a few technical questions. The interviews were very informal, it felt like a conversation.

(Agency worker) - 3 steps: one with the agency and two with the manager (one by phone and one in person).  As agency worker, the manager does not seem to be very interested in choosing the right person, as he only has to spend the budget.

Chill on-campus interview. Then there was an onsite with 4 interviews. Mostly technical. Leet code easy-medium. I made my process much longer than it had to be. They treat you really well during the on-site so take advantage if given the opportunity.

on site on university campus was 1:1 and pretty casual. final round in person was a long day. You meet and see all the other candidates interviewing at the same time. You're there for about 4 interviews (1 hr each) and then in the middle of the day you get to have lunch with other candidates and some people currently in the rotation program. Interviews ranged from behavioral and casual conversations to more marketing and strategy specific.

The first stage for me was a phone call with a recruiter, asking me about my experience and past project experience as well as two small conceptual technical questions (no coding).  Then from there, there were 4 onsite interviews where they were technical whiteboard interviews.

Calls with HR which led to 2 leads in a panel interview. Quick response and driven around my passions and impact for company. It was very thorough and gave me plenty opportunity to ask questions about the company itself.

Intern prospectives from Europe were flown out to Serbia to interview for positions in America. Interview day consisted of 4 interviews, each with short breaks in between. Got to meet and mingle with the other candidates.
Great as long as their software works.  They insist on conducting most interviews via Teams.  That's fine, but if the software glitches, which Teams is prone to do, it can cost you.
I was called for a second interview and I did not receive an offer. I was a sophomore in college. I was flown to Bellevue and under went 4 45 minute interviews over the course of a whole day.
Questions were not overly diffiicult. The engineers however were unfriendly. One interview just glared at me while we were discussing a solution. It felt like he was hoping i would fail.

Went in for 30 minute screening interview. The interviewer got my name wrong and called me "miss" but I'm a dude. I was told to ask any questions I had first, and as a result I think I spent too much time because we ran out of time for everything else. The interviewer didn't know the answers to my questions either and to be honest I had a very difficult time understanding what they were saying the entire time. I was asked to solve a coding problem in C, even though I listed python on my application. As a result, I did terribly even though it was a painfully simple problem. He spent nearly 10 minutes abstracting the beans out of " I was not asked a single behavioral question, just "when do you graduate" and "what language did you list on your application?" I took to long to understand what he was trying to ask that he told me right then we were out of time and I didn't have a chance at this job. 

The entire thing left me dazed and confused

I traveled to Seattle for on-campus interview. I gave fours rounds of interviews but couple of my friends gave three round of interviews as well. So, if you are lucky you can get it done in three interviews too. Two of interviews were technical and other two were behavioral/product design interviews.
I was asked about 7 questions, all of them are  behavioral. I prepared for some easy technical questions, but none of them are tested during the first-round phone interview.
It was an on campus hire. The interview was pretty standard with typical marketing questions to be expected. It lasted 45 minutes, and the last 15 minutes was me asking the interviewer questions.

I had an on-campus interview which was basically the equivalent of the screening phone call, with a couple behavioral questions and one technical coding question on a whiteboard. I haven't gotten a response yet, so I just chose one of the "did you get an offer" options randomly.

On campus interview with a GPU expert, 30 minutes. First he asked me why are you interested in Microsoft. Then ask a very simple technical question followed by a strange algorithm I've never seen before.

I had a phone screen followed by onsite interviews. I interviewed with two different teams. The first team was clearly not a match and it appeared they felt the same. The second interview team was better and they added additional interviewers on at the end. I also did a final interview with a member of the team that wasn't present by phone the day after I flew home.

I applied online and get back from a recruiter two weeks later. Then I took the first phone interview of about 30 min. After a week, I get back from Microsoft that I make to the final round of on-site interview.

Initial phone screen followed by an on-site. The on-site was an amazing experience and shows how nicely Microsoft treats their future interns/employees. There were 4 rounds of whiteboard coding, each about 45min and included some basic LC easy and medium questions, one design question and one LC hard

Llegue al proceso de seleccion por una postulacion de Linkedin. El proceso de seleccion es demasiado largo. Quieren que te entrevisten la mayor cantidad de personas posibles, en mi caso un total de seis. Las primeras entrevistas fueron en la misma semana, pero luego el reclutador desaparecio por 2 meses. Envie correo para consultar y me informaron que aun seguian el proceso de seleccion. Luego de 4 meses mas me contacte con una de las personas que me entrevisto y me informo que no me habian seleccionado. Me senti destratado, tube que comunicarme para que me den una respuesta, si no llamaba jamas me hubiesen dado el feedback.

Very attractive offices, cool enviorment and nice people. Interview isn't hard but you need to be curious and with passion, speak about projects and experience. process consist two technical interviews .

I have been interviewed by 4-5 MS recruiters for different SE roles so far.  It seems to be not only they were incompetent but they made assumption of what you LOOK for. One of them asked me specifically that out of these two SE roles which one would you choose and then said no you would be fit for the other one (which was more coding related btw). I feel that they do not respect candidates as they are many people who like to work at Microsoft and they are only numbers to them. I really wish Microsoft changed their recruiters cause they ruin the image of company with their arrogance and feeling of superiority.

Interviewed via Skype with three different people. Two during one interview and one in another. The pair of interviewers seemed rushed and slightly arrogant. Didn't want to work there after talking with them.

Four back to back onsite interview in Redmond. Includes product design, coding, behavior questions. Be sure to talk about your project experiences both technically and nontechnically. For product design questions, refer to cracking the pm interview book. It really helps.

I was contacted by Microsoft Recruitment after they found my profile on Linkedin.  I was interviewed via skype.  The interviewer was very polite and made me feel comfortable.  The first interview took about an hour.

One-hour interview, 60% technical and 40% behavioral (my past experiences, passion for a Microsoft product and how I would improve it, product development and design questions etc.). This was first one, the second one consists of 3 one-hour interviews at the company's HQ.

Muito dinâmico e desafiador, fazendo o candidato pensar e agir em equipe, sem deixar o próprio desempenho ser afetado. As etapas online foram bem tranquilas, a dinâmica foi super bacana também, e a entrevista com os gestores foi a melhor parte (aos escolhidos), pois foi uma conversa mais franca e direta

Online coding round consists of three coding questions which is easy to medium level shortlisted 30-40 candidates and divided into groups of 6-7 and pen paper coding round
Group fly round
Two technical rounds
Final HR round

One week before my classes started, I received an invitation to interview on campus. About a week later, I was invited to the onsite interviews in Redmond, WA. I completed 4 technical interviews, each lasting from 45 minutes to an hour.

I had an in-person 30-minute screen first, then was invited to the onsite interviews in Cambridge. The onsite rotated each of us through 4 different 1-on-1 interviews over the course of half a day. Each interview was with either a software engineer from various teams within Microsoft or the director of the program itself. They were not allowed to tell us what we were interviewing for until the day of (which I found frustrating, as I had applied for a couple of different positions within Microsoft and didn't know which one to prepare for), but when we showed up we were told it was for a Software Engineer position in the AI Rotational Program.
Each of the 45-minute interviews for me was a mix of technical and behavioral questions, but I heard from others there at the same time that some of them had 3 technical and 1 behavioral interview, with little cross-over. Either way, be prepared for both!
I heard back with results less than two weeks later, and then had about a week (pre-extension, two weeks when I asked for more time) to decide whether I was going to take the offer or not.
This was an all-day affair where I was interviewed by four or five different managers, including a lunch interview. I was asked to solve programming puzzles as well as about my work history.

You are in a group with 30 - 50 other people and you are called by name for each interview. There were four interviews at 45 minutes each. You are then taken on a small tour to their employee store and given a card to sue for lunch on site.
The first round was an online coding test with 3 very basic questions of stack arrays, strings. in the next round i was asked about dynamic programming. The next round was a group discussion round.

1st round was coding and aptitude. Two questions were given to code of very basic level. Technical questions were from trees , data structures and oops. And normal aptitude questions were there. Test was done on Oracle.

There was a phone interview which consisted of mainly behavioural questions with a couple small technical questions. In person, three problem-solving questions with three different interviewers, each one also asking about behavioural/past-project experience on your resume. Interviewers were very friendly and gave helpful hints if you get stuck.
5 interviews back to back. it was very hard, i will share my easiest interview question so other interviewers wont get ideas for had questions and you guys will thank me later!

I didn't get very far into the interview process because I only got to the first round of interviews before they declined me. It was understandable though because at the time I did not have much experience under my belt so there was not many projects I could elaborate on. This interview was all behavioral and ever phone.

Recruiter contacted me via LinkedIn. Got an online test. Test consist of 3 questions to be solved in 1 hour. No test cases and IDE were provided. 

I cleared the online test and was called for onsite interview. It was an hiring event. I had four rounds of interview there.
Very conversational - it was mostly about my past experience and the interviewer explained me various roles and where I thought I would fit the best. We then talked about his experience at Microsoft.

Applied through university. Didn't expect an interview invite. The entire process took around 3 months. 

Invited for a 30 mins on-campus interview in October 2018. Its a mix of technical and resume based given that I have around work experience. I was honest in every response I gave. The interviewer was really nice and it was more conversational. 

I didn't expect an invite for an on-site interview. Since I made it to this level, I wanted to clear it. I had around 20 days when I got the invite for the onsite interviews. Read "Cracking the PM interview" and "Decode and Conquer". Practiced some behavioral and basic programming questions. 

Microsoft took care of all the expenses to attend the interview onsite. 

On the day of my interview, I meet four people.  I had to meet the hiring manager first since she couldn't accommodate in a different time. It was purely behavioral. I thought I screwed it since she gave me feedback which implied "can do well and don't be nervous"  at the end of my interview. 

My 2nd interviewer did ask me a few design specific questions and some questions based out of my resume. I did better than my previous interview.

The third interview is the one I nailed. All questions were situation based like how I would handle a specific task or conflict. My experience as a Developer and Analyst helped me to answer these questions well. I asked a lot of questions in this round. By the end of this interview, I felt super comfortable and confident because my interviewer was really nice.

I then had my final lunch interview. Though I was hungry by this time, I decided to go lite and simple so that I could concentrate more on talking than on eating. This interview was much more casual than all of my interviews. It was very conversational but at the same time, we managed to take turns in asking role specific questions. The trick I used to do well in this round is that I asked the questions I was asked by my interviewers in my previous rounds and I guess it worked since I cleared the interview ;)

Since I only had 4 rounds as opposed to 5, I wasn't entirely positive.  (many successful PM interviews in glassdoor had 5 rounds with an "as is" round but not all. It looks like my lunch interview is my as is round).  

Within a week, I received an email saying I was a offered the job. 

Takeaways - 
* I have non-CS bachelors and Masters degree so my experience as a developer and analyst played a major role here. 
*If you have a degree in CS, you can expect some lite coding exercise.  
*Make sure you know everything you mentioned in your resume. If they point out something and you are not an expert or don't have an explanation for it, be honest and justify it. 
* Focus on STAR based questions and have some readymade answers. Read/practice them well. These were the lifesavers in my case since I come from a non-CS educational background. 
* Read "Cracking the PM interview" and "Decode and Conquer". You may or may not get questions from this book but it helps a ton to read these books. Tailor your answers based on how these books recommend. 
* Don't forget to put a smile throughout the interview process. Interviewers at Microsoft are very friendly and you will definitely enjoy talking to them.
*They don't expect you to dress professionally but doing so would definitely imply that you are serious about this job.
* Most importantly, make sure to have your breakfast before the interview. I was only offered beverages during my first three rounds and each interview lasts for around an hour roughly. I'm glad I managed to eat that leftover pizza before leaving for the interview. Skipping the breakfast will only ruin your day so try to squeeze in some time to have an energy bar or anything for that matter.
The interview was very casual. Met with a few different staff members. Process took about 2 hours. I would say everyone was friendly as easy going. Definitely made you feel welcomed.

Applied on Company Website. Got an email saying that a recruiter reviewed my resume and I was invited to have a phone interview with Microsoft.  The mail said that the interview would be behavioral, technical and would focus on a resume that I had to submit online.

2 technical rounds via Skype.
One  30 mins round followed by a 2 hr round.
Started with questions regarding my projects and then on my projects scenario based questions  were asked. 
A lot of networking questions like complete processes of a web request/response i.e. router->dns , root hints, etc.

The entire interview process was extremely professional. I have never had a more positive interview experience and would still state the same even if I had not got a job offer. I had applied for this job online and received a call from the recruiter in a couple of weeks. 

The 1st round was a Skype interview scheduled for an hour. The interviewer was very cordial and wanted me to succeed throughout the call. It was a conversation rather than an "I ask, You Answer" approach. This was in-fact true across all rounds. The 2nd round was a Skype interview as well with a business leader. It was for 30 minutes but I gained a lot of insights on how the company worked.

The 3rd round was a day long case study round with presentations and deliverables at end of it. It happened at the office premises. It was almost like a pre-cursor to "a day in your life should you join". I throughly enjoyed the approach even though it was intensive and very demanding with tight deadlines.

The 4th round was a face to face interview with a senior leader. It went for an hour. It was a conversation about my experience, technical, behavioural and leadership skills. I got a sense of how the interviewer wanted to make sure that I can fit in well with the work culture at Microsoft.

The 5th and final round was with the hiring manager. It was a 45 minute Skype call. I got a fair idea about job expectations, growth opportunities, challenges and immediate focus areas for this role.It was a very informative discussion.

I received the news about the job offer in a couple of days. The package was good and I did not have a need to negotiate.

Overall, the process was very smooth starting with the recruiter making sure that interviews were being scheduled at mutually convenient times. Kudos to the recruitment team at Microsoft! This process was an eye opener to me and helped me understand the diligence and thought process Microsoft has put behind their recruitment process. Fantastic!

First, I had a phone interview with the recruiter about my latest side projects, previous job experience and what are my interests in a position at Microsoft. At the end of the call she told me to chose one date for the on-site interview.

I interviewed in Dublin, Ireland. They paid for the hotel and the transportation.

At on-site, I had 4 interviews. The problems where easy-medium style similar to those from leetcode.

First interview:
20 mins talk about previous experience and side projects. I had the luck to be an intern before (2 years before) in the same organization as my interviewer. 
1 problem: Implement a function to simplify a unix based path.

Second interview:
5 min talk about projects and 1 problem with followup.

Third interview:
10 min talk about projects
2 problems, one with followup.

Fourth interview:
10 min talk about projects and afterwards a kind-of system design problem where we discussed how to implement the dynamic allocation of resources in Azure. This was related to what are they doing when you ask for 4 cores and if needed to scale at 16 cores. How do you actually find those cores and map them to that client.

There are 2 rounds Onsite interview and one  round of online interview.  I don’t know why they do not reimburse the travel fee. HR didn't not talk much. Mainly focus on algorithm. The problem is not very hard.

First round of interview: 
It was a remote interview, over skype call. The interviewer was very friendly, and all the questions in the interview were behavioral.  Mostly about getting to know you and your experiences, through questions. Nothing on my resume was discussed. 

Said they would get back to me in two weeks, and its only been one day yet so I guess I gotta wait some more.
Challenging open ended questions. They asked me about the types of meat my wife and I like to eat (pork chops, strip loin, etc) and the temps we like em at. Do not say well done!!

There was one phone screen, and four tech interviews over Skype. The overall process was smooth and very positive. Communication from the company was quick and effective. I got details about an offer within a day of completing interviews.

A recruiter direct messaged me on LinkedIn. Submitted my app that day. 30m phone screening that week. Two weeks later, I was flown out to Redmond for my final interview. Four 45m interviews with four different people from four different teams. Then whole rest of the day to explore Seattle on Microsoft's dime.

Applied directly through the school recruiting website. 1 on-campus interview. Afterwards, submit the preference and function for the  full time job. The on-site interview will be based on your preference, could be at Chicago, New York, Seattle.
On-campus interview followed by onsite 4 round interviews. The whole process took almost 7 month which is rare. They reimburse almost all the cost and I had fun in Seattle.

- A total of 7 rounds; 5 of them are technical.
- Starts with an online screening test. Prepare your basics of STLC and selenium, DB, Data Structures, Puzzles
- 2 back to back skype interviews (technical)
- Algo and Coding rounds (in MS premises)
- Architect Round
- HM and HR round
one technical design question.  I thought the interview was fair and really embodied what the role of product manager is like at Microsoft, which is what I was unfamiliar with.

Flew out to Microsoft's office in Pittsburgh, PA. The process was standard. 4 interviews with different people. Answered all of the questions with little help. Asked clarifying questions, explained my thought process, and expressed passion and the willingness to grow. Rejected shortly after I arrived home with no feedback on what I did wrong. They receive so many applications that I doubt they really care.

I was contacted by a senior hiring manager, who read my profile and made me apply to a few teams that matched my background and interests. After a phone screen, I was told to apply to a Senior position in one of these orgs. I was reluctant because I was aiming for a lower position, but they insisted it was not a problem. That was a mistake.

The day of the interview came and went. I felt like I hadn't done that well, I wasn't expecting a callback. I was surprised when their recruiter called me to offer me a position! It was not the level I was applying for, of course, but I was still happy to accept. The recruiter said a hiring manager would get back to me soon.

Three days pass, and no word from them. I emailed the recruiter to ask what was going on... An automated reply told me she had left the company. I immediately try to call the hiring manager I talked to before... Her phone line was disconnected. In a panic, I reached out to several recruiters within Microsoft in hopes to get some help. Finally somebody responds. Later that day, the new recruiter in charge of my case reaches out. All is good again, although of course I'm not as confident about the process anymore.

Two more days pass. I email the new recruiter to ask for a status update. She calls me back... To tell me the team had decided to move on with other candidates "because I wasn't a good fit for the senior position".

In summary, I was told to apply to a position I was not a good fit for, even though I had concerns. They left me in hiring limbo, without thinking to let me know the points of contact had changed. Finally, they let me go because (surprise) I was not a good fit for the level I applied for.

This whole thing feels like a bad joke.
The process took around three weeks long. I interview at their offices and I got rejected three weeks later. The interview was not hard and I thought that overall I did pretty well.

I applied online and got invited for all day interviews the next month.   The process included five 45 minute interviews.  Two were on Skype for Business (including with the hiring manager) which have to happen on the Microsoft campus.  Be prepared to bring your own device.

Face-to-face interview AND a role play Skype call to assess the knowledge and background on Microsoft products, customer facing activities and relations.  

FT Managers fro O365 is part of FT program of MS-Azure aiming to enable users and workloads on cloud. with Managers and Technical expertise, support activities purpose is to upscale solution utilization,  remove obstacles in cloud migration through best practices, and give advices cloud enabalement.

Around 4-5 interviews with hr business partner by phone, your future boss, regional director by video, sales director, and hr director. . . . . . That’s all. Nothing more to add at this part, I think it’s enough.

reached out by a recruiter, passed an online test with 3 quiz questions, had an onsite of 4 round of white board coding interviews. The event was nice, but some of the  interviewers were not friendly at all.
Interview process was fast. I applied online and got an interview scheduled in less than a month. Questions were mostly behavioural. Make sure to have solid answers on Why Microsoft? and Why HR?

Applied online in September 2018 after speaking with several people involved with the FRP (Finance Rotational Program) at Microsoft and was able to land a phone interview with an HR representative in the beginning of October. I received an email the day after inviting me out to Seattle for a final round in the middle of October. The final round consisted of a half day of 4 back-to-back interviews, each lasting around 45 minutes. You meet with different people working in the finance department and the majority of the questions are more behavioral and resume-based. Make sure you do know Microsoft's different businesses though as well as their most recent 10-Q or 10-K to answer any questions specific to Microsoft.

I first was emailed to have a phone screen. Then they got back to me in two days and said I was being flown up for a super day. I had  3 in person interviews on campus in Redmond and they all were behavioral. I felt that the interviews were very conversational.

Very neat University hiring. The process started with a university round then on site round. The entire process took about 8 weeks. Keep LinkedIn profile updated, recruiters search for candidates with a good profile.

4 rounds of technical each about 40 minutes with some behavioral
different interviewer for each round, very friendly interviewers, good experience
demo'd a project at the start, be able to talk about the features and show off your project
free food for lunch

3 rounds of interviews, first two by phone by HR and hiring manager.  Last round is in person and you have 4-6 interviews in one day.  HR is very good at organizing everything and communicating with candidate.

Two Phone screens. Machine Learning question and coding question. Interviewers were helpful and friendly. The turn around process was quick. The questions were easy and straight forward. GIven  a time series dataset how will you predict the future value.

You meet with three different interviewers from the same division. Two are technical interviews and one is a PM interview. Each interview is around 45 minutes.  For the technical interviews, you get through one technical question and then afterwards it is more personality and interest questions.

Several rounds of f-2-f interview. Lot of Programming Questions - Database, Logical Qs, USB related etc. The candidate has write the solutions on White Boards. It's good to talk to folks who challenge you on the programming skills

One phone interview for fit, then onsite for a day to Seattle. The phone interview asked a variety of behavioral questions/projects, and then technical and product questions. Make sure you know your past projects and microsoft products.

Just had my first interview from Microsoft. I felt pretty good and the problem was not that hard. First I send my resume via their jobs page and latter this year heard from them. I also helped that the recruiter came to the campus.
Submitted my application online and got a call on skype for an interview.  The interview was around 20 minutes long. The person called me 10 minutes late. Got a email a week later with a rejection.

I applied through the website and after a few weeks, I received an email for an on-campus, 30-minute behavioral and technical interview.  It was just one interviewer, and I'm sure that after this initial round of interviews there were more.

First I applied, then a recruiter contacted on LinkedIn and then a first round of phone interview. The interviewer was from Washington and she did not ask me about my skills or the typical questions. She told me that she will start off with questions ( between 10-12) questions and at the end I can ask anything. All of the questions were about Microsoft products. She said that the recruiter that originally contacted me would reach out to me in 2-3 weeks. It only took 5 days to hear back from them.

Started by receiving an e-mail from my university's recruiter during the summer. Was fast-tracked to final round interviews on August, but these ended up being pushed back to October.

I had four back-to-back interviews during this round. A couple were quite simple and straightforward, but others required more analysis, thinking and somewhat specialized knowledge. The interviewers took notes in their laptops during the sessions, but were still quite attentive and willing to answer any questions (in my case, they were A LOT) and give out the occasional subtle hint if needed.

On breaks between interviews, the group was accompanied by an HR representative who provided snacks, refreshments and conversation, and did their best to keep everyone's spirits up.

Still waiting for feedback/results. Will update once I hear back from my recruiter.

It was very simple. I spoke with 3 team members from my proposed team and they were all very pleasant. They wanted to understand my experience with project management. I was asked thought provoking questions about how I handled my last few projects.

Initially I had a recruiter call,  she was really good to me. 
I was asked to complete a take home online coding assessment test using Codility, got through that stage.

Then I was scheduled for a 4  one-hour interviews back to back on a single day. 3 of them were a combination of some behavioral and a couple coding questions each

2 interviewers were really good. But the other two were so rude and condescending.  When I was answering something/suggesting an approach they were dictating to me that they do not want that answer. Unprofessionals do not understand that interview need to be a conversation and not an interrogation. I was left intimidated and was so pissed off by the end of interview.

I was contacted by email to conduct a 30-minute interview via Teams. The person interviewing me was instructed to write down all the answers I gave to their questions. These would then be sent to a group of recruiters that would evaluate them.

Received interview email from HR 
Schedule available time for the meeting
English oral test for role play
interview with future coworker and team lead
interviw with the higher manager
Tell the job description.
use teams for interview
overall the about 2 months

It was a 3 hr interview and I spoke with a group of three people for 45- 1 hour each. Each person covered different topic and spent time talking about the different aspects of the job and asking questions.

Online application, followed by a 30 minute video conversation with someone from HR, and a 4-hour assessment center with questions and group tasks stimulating the job. It was fairly easy and they we're actively trying to help you on the process

Interview started from the basics of neural nets and became more focused on project specific and background specific topics (My background is NLP). Differences between L1 and L2 regression, etc were asked.
Had an hour long interview with HR and behavioural questions and at the end a logic puzzle. Answered everything great but I did not hear back from them even after a month.

There were two rounds of interviews. The first round was an over the phone interview with a university recruiter and contained questions about my resume as well as basic coding theory questions. The second round consisted of two interviews with different people. The first interview was a brain teaser with no coding, and the second interview was the coding interview. I thought I did really bad during both, but still got a job offer!

After I was reached out by the recruiter, I had my first technical interview over the phone while I had to solve one problem online in one hour. 
Then I just had my final round of interviews. There were four different interviews with different members of the team. Each interview lasted one hour where I had to solve either one hard problem or two medium-difficult problems.

On-Campus interview at my university. It was relatively simple- did a quick resume review, talked about some experiences, and answered a coding question. My interviewer was really nice and he took some notes on his computer as I spoke

I applied on through the website and I got a response in a week.I scheduled a 30 minute interview at our schools career services.The interviewer was preety chilled and he helped me through the problem.This was my first interviewing and I wasn't that prepared.

I was invited to an on campus interview. The interviewer was a Senior Engineer for the location that I was interviewing for. They had two days back to back of 30 minute interviews, with I want to say roughly 10 people each day.

Flown out to Seattle.  Was interviewed by 4 different people from 4 different teams. Was first asked questions about my resume and then given a question to code. The interviewers were very encouraging and helped in the solving of the question. In between round, other candidates would chill in a room with plenty of drinks for 10 minutes to recharge until the next interview.

Phone interview for the Microsoft internship in Vancouver. Was an okay experience. I stressed out a lot about the interview and botched it up. Was asked two behavioural questions and a coding question done on online editor. Not expecting to be called back for second round though.

4 rounds of back-to-back interviews onsite. The experience was very nice overall, and all my interviewers were kind and patient. Though I might have screwed something up during the last round of my interview as by the end my interviewer said something like "good luck" and "you should be notified the decision very soon" :(.

The interview process was great! A recruiter reached out to me over LinkedIn and asked me to apply to the position online. Once I completed my application, she reached out to me and booked in a 45 minute phone interview. The questions were quite general - asking me what attracted me to the role, projects that I was proud of and which team I saw myself working with and how Microsoft products could be improved. Once this interview was completed, I was called for in person interviews at the Redmond, Washington Office. 

The night before the interviews, I received an email asking me to prep a 10 minute presentation about myself for the interviewers. The day of the interview, I presented to the team of interviewers. They didn't ask any questions but reserved them for the one-on-one sessions.

I had 3 back to back interviews, all of which went relatively well. Once I was done, the recruiters on-site let me know that I would be notified of the results within 2 weeks. 

However no one reached out to me within 2 weeks. So I had to reach out to get an update. Received a reply about a day or two later. In all, it was a great experience, although they don't really give you any feedback on how your interviews went. They try to throw you a few curve balls to see how you adapt. Just stay calm and power through.

There was 1 online round followed by a Group Fly(written test), 2 Technical face to face rounds and 1 HR round. Each technical round took about 1-1.5 hours and the HR round took about 15 minutes.  Data structures based questions were not asked at all except the online round and Groupfly.

Screening test was held on Cocubes. It consist of 3 coding questions. Time Limit was 70min. 
Shortlisted candidates had to give written test.
After that face to face two Technical Interview.
Last HR Interview.

Received a DM on LinkedIn from a Microsoft recruiter, saying that she was impressed with my profile and asked me to apply to Microsoft's SWE/PM internship. I applied and messaged her back telling her I applied online. Got an on campus interview request 4 days letter. 

On campus interview was 15 minutes behavioral followed by 15 minute technical coding question. Got the onsite interview 10 days later, scheduled it 3 weeks from the call day (to give myself time to prep). Went onsite to Redmond, interviewed four rounds for Azure/Windows, and got the offer 9 days later.

Invited for an on campus interview, then after doing well I was flown out to Redmond, Washington for an onsite. There were 4 back to back interviews, each with a different person and an hour long.  About 10 minutes behavioral and the rest of time spent coding on a whiteboard.

Phone interview followed by an on site interview. On site interview consisted of 4 45 min meetings with microsoft employees. Phone interview consisted of a 30 min chat with mainly behavioral questions.

Round one was phone call with a tech recruiter. No problem solving, just behavioural questions and questions testing my technical knowledge.

Round two / final on-site was 4 technical interviews. Medium difficulty ish, the usual stuff.

One phone round with behavioral questions and a final round at Redmond.
The phone round asked about things in the resume and some creative questions like 'How would you explain a computer to a 5-year-old.
In the final round I interviewed with 3 PMs, and got no coding questions - this wasn't the case for most of the other applicants.

I had a great experience throughout the entire process.

I first contacted them when they came to my University. I then had a 30 minute on campus interview with one of their engineers. A week later I was notified that I was to be flown out to Redmond, WA for the final round of interviews. Microsoft paid for all hotels, flights, food, and taxi/uber! The final round consisted of four 45 minute interviews. Interviews were based on data structures, algorithms, and object oriented design. I was then notified about the results a week later.

Microsoft treated me great and made sure everything I needed was accommodated for.

It was an on-campus college interview. First we had an online test comprising of three coding questions(1-easy,1-medium,1-hard). For all those selected we had a group fly round. In which they asked to code solutions to two questions on a paper. Then next round was personal interview.

I had 2 phone interviews and 1 final round interview. The final round onsite was composed of 3 meetings with hiring employees asking technical questions or the usual nature. Overall I had a good time and they paid for everything in the final round interview which is always fun.
I Talked with a recruiter on campus. She Contacted me a few days later for an on-campus interview. The whole process took about 5 days. Someone reached out to me to schedule my on campus interview.

On campus interview, it took around 2 weeks for them to contact me after I applied. I felt super comfortable! They were very welcoming and I had a lot in common with my interviewer which made it a little easier to not feel nervous
Talked to recruiter at a career fair then applied online and did a first round interview on campus. A short 30 minute interview with a product manager and opportunity to ask questions
I interviewed on my college campus last Spring and received a follow-up in the fall inviting me to do a final round interview at their headquarters. I had three 45 minute interviews.
Microsoft visited our campus and there was on campus interview based on resume shortlisting. In the resume exchange event interviewer asked about resume and challenging project I have worked on

Le processus d'entretien est divisé en deux parties: Au début, on te passe un entretien par skype ou sur le campus de l'université puis si jamais tu es passé on t'invite à leur campus pour le tour final des entrevues.

Phone interviewed with the hiring manager. Then got the invitation to onsite interview on the next business day. Met three team leads and one organization manager. All interviewers were nice and willing to provide hints during the interview.

Applied initially through a referral and then applied at my university career fair. Took a few days for them to get back to me with a first round (1 on 1, on campus). Eventually, I was given an opportunity to interview onsite at Redmond.
Short 30 minutes on campus interview. 15 minutes of conversation about projects, resume. 10 minutes for coding on board. Very easy coding question, do not need to use any difficult data structure.

I was fresh graduated (2018 )the interview has two steps :
first : online test has some multi choice and some problem solving   .
second : onsite interview( 3 interviews ) with 3 different team first two was amazing but the last with one of the manger it was't good he laughed so much when you solve problem and he didn't introduce problem well we take about 15 minute in describing it and at the end it was also bad describe   .

Applied online pretty soon after applications opened. I was contacted about a month later to schedule an on campus interview at my school. The interviewer asked me a few questions about my resume for the first five minutes then we moved onto to a whiteboard problem for the remaining 25 minutes.
brief 30 minute call with a recruiter. went over basic questions about my resume and why I wanted to work at Microsoft. asked about my favorite MS product and how i would improve it

Got contacted for an on-campus interview, but completely failed the interview. Heard back ~3 weeks afterwards. Failed the coding question which was probably just a Leetcode medium. Some of my friends got questions that are Leetcode easy. If I were to do this again I would make sure to get a lot of sleep and not to be nervous (to the point that I'd blank out again):(.

Talked to recruiters during career fair, then submitted application online. Later I received on Campus Interview invitation, 30 minutes. Some behavioral questions like what projects have you done. Some technical questions. I had a decent conversation.

I applied in the fall of 2017, never heard anything back, then was offered an in-person interview in the spring when a representative from Microsoft was coming to my campus.  At that point the 2018 summer was full, so the interview was more for the next year potentially.  This fall (2018) I applied again and attended a Microsoft talk on my campus where I met my recruiter.  A few weeks later I was offered a phone screen, where they asked mostly behavioral and design questions.  A week or two after that I heard that I was offered an interview in Seattle, which ended up being changed to Raleigh.  It was two 45 minute interviews with very friendly and easy to talk to software engineers.  They both started off asking about my resume and then moved to either a whiteboard coding or a design question. They were really nice the whole time and made an effort to let you feel at ease & showcase your best side.

Applied through linkedin, had one phone interview and was then invited to Seattle for a super day which consisted of 4 back to back interviews. Two were conducted by HR reps or recruiters, and the other two by acting finance managers.

The interview was not too bad. There is a little bit of soft skills interviewing, but a majority is technical questions. Leetcode and doing your research online is great preparation techniques for this interview. Make sure to know your leadership and problem solving skills and experiences and know your resume inside out.

That was a campus interview in UCSB. Some MSFT engineers come to the compus, filtered out some candidates by email, then ask the remained candidates to take a 2nd round 1 on 1 interview. That was a 30 min interview,5 min behavior questions first, then 1 coding question.  Very easy.

I got a phone interview by talking to a recruiter at my schools career fair. It was 30 minutes long, but it somehow felt shorter (and a tad impersonal, though the lady was outwardly friendly). If you've never interviewed before (like me) practice giving fast and concise answers so you're not thrown off. The focus was on behavioral questions, and I was talking to someone who specializes in recruiting. Just keep your audience in mind when answering and try to make your answers show why you stand out.

On campus interview after campus recruiting: it seems they care more about quantity than quality during the first round process. Too many people leading to only 30 minute interviews, and the worst of the lot I knew went onto the on site interviews.

Was contacted by the recruiter a day after submitting my application online. The first round was a 30 min on-campus interview. Mostly behavioral questions and one technical question which was something along the lines of reversing every word in a string. The interviewer was friendly. Got selected for the second round of interview at Redmond. There were 4 back to back interviews. The first was an easy programming question about vectors/arrays. But it had a lot of edge cases to cover and the interviewer expected me to ask a lot of questions. The second interview involved thinking about how the touchButton function works internally in iOS app dev and reading some C# code (you were allowed to ask him questions on the syntax). The third round had a design question.  The first three rounds were not that hard. The fourth interview was completely random though. It involved OS and ML concepts - classes that I have not taken yet (The interviewer had any idea about my skills and resume).

Applied online through Microsoft website. Got an on campus interview 2 months after. The interviewer was super nice. Begining by asking my projects I mentioned in my resume and then go into the field i'm interested in.

Got an invite for a fly out interview in early September, then went to Redmond the first week of October. 3 back to back technical interviews from 3 members of the same team, it looks like the group you interview with is your project team if you accepted.

The process consisted of 3 rounds:
1. Online Round :- 3 data structures questions were asked. The test was conducted on cocubes platform. 
2. Groupfly: Two questions were given. Code had to be written on a sheet of paper in any language.
3. Technical F2F 1: Here questions related to projects were asked. No question of data structure was given and the interview just tested you on your knowledge of networking and web development. 
4.  Technical F2F 2 : A few puzzles were asked. One technical question was also given. The interviewer didn't seem interested. He was also not paying attention to the answers given.

As a university applicant, the overall process was understandably long (7 months) given the high volume of applications to process. I understood the inherent value of being a member of this company and my passion for this corporation allowed me to remain positive, inquisitive and hopeful. My final interview was seamlessly organized and the moment I met the warm, friendly, intelligent, and motivating employees of Microsoft- I knew the wait had been worth it. 

Let your experience speak for itself. Focus on how to translate your background and acquired knowledge into something impactful that will better Microsoft and those it affects. Show your enthusiasm for technology and how it affects the evolving world even if you haven't a tech background or any particular technical skills. Authenticity, passion, humbleness, and the desire to grow will get you here.

Interview process was pretty much standard.
1 or 2 phone interviews
An on-site interview where you will be meeting 4 or 5 interviewers (I met 4).
Questions were a combination of STAR pattern, System design, and job description based technical questions.
I went to Microsoft on campus Office hour and  applied online. An recruiter contacted me by e-mail and the interview took place 3 weeks after on campus. Asked few questions and a coding problem.

The process consisted of two rounds. (On campus recruiting.)
Round 1 was a standard behavioral interview. You "interview" for all sales positions. If you are selected for a final round, you think rank both your location and role preferences. They then combine this with the interviewer notes and if there's a match, you are invited to interview for that position.

The second round interview was with four people in the sales teams. It was quite conversational. They want to see if you are a good fit for the role based on experiences.

The process itself was quite slow. It also seemed to lack a cohesive structure. There was a main recruiter, but also two other people contacting me regarding logistics. When I asked a question, I did not receive an answer until the night before my interview.

Applied on their website
had an interview in university campus of 30 minutes, basic String question + some behavioral + system design.
a week later, I knew I was put on waiting list and could bump up my spot if I had other offer deadlines. However, they contacted me a month later and asked me if I was still looking for a job and willing to try out for the Garage internship program.

Flew to Vancouver for second (final) round SWE intern Garage.
you are put in a room with the other interviewees.
10 minutes self presentation + present a project.
3 rounds of 40-50 minutes of technical + behavioral 1v1
1 round of 25-35 minutes, I heard it was technical and behavioral, but I only got behavioral.
was expecting lunch with the manager, but I think that's just a Seattle thing, I had lunch with the other interns.



-------DONT READ THIS IF YOU STRESS EASILY-------
Basically you need to get almost all the questions to optimal solution. People in my group who did not get optimal solution, did not get the offer. The questions were not too hard. Also speak out your thought process, they help you a lot.

best of luck!

I applied through a referral in the fall, process took 1+ month. Had some phone interviews and 4 on site on one day. Each interview lasted 45min. In each one they would ask some behavioral questions using my resume.
Phone Screen with Director, Three hour onsite face to face with three rounds , Phone Screen with senior manager.  what do you think is the best approach for responsive web pages.

sent mail via their website - they called me 2 weeks later, had 1 phone interview who ask about VM java and modifiers, ans second on place. they were all very nice, and were very representitve. They said the interview will take 1:30 Hours, and that was exremely accurate.

On campus,  30 min long. First 5 min ask about resume. Next 20 min build a bst from a preorderly arranged integer array, write the code on a white board. When finished, interviewer took a photo of the white board. Last 5 min Q&A.

I contacted a recruiter, applied online, then was contacted to schedule a phone interview. They asked questions about my work experience and personal projects such as "What algorithms and data structures did you use in this project and why?" and "What was the biggest challenge for that project and how did you overcome it?". Then they asked various questions to see how you think like, "How would you explain recursion to a child?". A few weeks after this I was contacted by the recruiter saying that they liked me and wanted to move on to an in-person, on-site interview, but there weren't enough available interview slots. So, they put me on a wait list essentially.

I applied online. The recruiter told me about his job, then he gave me a very simple problem which turned a little bit complicated because some aspects I did not consider. As an advice do not make any assumptions before start coding. At the end I asked him a few queations.

Contacted by Recruiter,  followed by 30 min technical phone interview, followed by on-site at Redmond with 4~5 engineers. Whole process took roughly 6~8 weeks. Even though I was transferred to 3 different recruiters, they were all responsive.

2 Skype Meetings:
1.  The first will be with the hiring team's technical lead and another team's manager
2.  The second will be with the hiring team's manager.  You will do Role Play scenario to show your technical solution selling skills

applied with employee referral, three interviews two technical interviews and one with HR, they were very nice and polite in the interviews and helped when I was stuck.
they had one downside - the overall process took a lot of time

I got an email from a recruiter at Microsoft telling me that I had passed their resume screening process and I could schedule an on-campus interview. The interview went very well and the interviewer was very friendly. However, waiting for a reply from Microsoft after this interview took way too long. I couldn't get a reply from the recruiter even after repeated emails.

At first an online coding exercise using codility. A 2 hour exercise that included 4 questions, in 2 you had to write an entire code and in the other 2 fix a given code.
The next step was an interview with two people in Herzliya.

good interviewers, four rounds include one lunch interview, medium difficult but they care more on the code quality, after the interview got the schedule with recruiter to talk about the feedback received from the interviewers, did not get an offer

I basically got a phone interview, where they just asked me about my previous projects. The only technical question they asked me was "what is the difference between a thread or a process". I think the best thing to do for this interview is to show how much you want the job.

2 rounds- initial phone interview, followed by a onsite interview in Los Colinas, Texas, which consisted of 3 rounds. They put you in a room with 30 other candidates, which was nice because you get to meet people from all over the world.

Met a recruiter at my university's tech fair, had one on campus interview, and then an on sight for my final round. Was for Microsoft Quantum in Raleigh, so the process/interviews were a bit different.

An average of 6 interviews for the role. Some interviewers are good and very articulated while some are not. The Interview is conducted by the hiring the manager as well managers from the division that you will be supporting.
3 or 4 interviews and present an architecture, also had HR interview, hiring manager interview and a couple of peers, all very fast and organized many of them held online.

I had a phone call interview. The lady called in 5-10 minutes later than they said they would. It was pretty brief considering that this was primarily an interview for a position that didn't really require too much skills to start with.

First I had to complete the submition of my application. After this I received a phone call and an email detailing the time of the assesment centre and what was required to prepare for it. The Assessment centre consisted of 1 presentation and 3 individual interviews all spanning across half a day. I received the offer the day of in the evening.
Talked to a recruiter on campus, first round was over the phone. It was problem solving questions. Then you are flown out to seattle for an on site which is quite difficult.

I applied through an on-campus career fair. I was contacted a couple of weeks later and an in-person interview was scheduled. It was a mix of technical and behavioural questions. 
Overall, I thought it was pretty fair for the technical question.

Had 4 technical interview questions, where a problem was discussed and solved on the whiteboard. Everyone was very friendly. Last 10 minutes were for questions and going over your cv. Did not receive feedback after interview.
The interview went smooth, there were 5 rounds, 2 technical and 3 F2F interviews, The difficulty level is moderate to high, be thorough with the concepts and you should be good to go

Got onsite interviews after a single on-campus interview. Flown out to Seattle during the school week. Was in Redmond for two nights, flew back on the morning of the third day. 
Got to see the Microsoft commons and grab lunch (with a lunch voucher) with other interns. 
Had 4 interviews back to back. Each ~45 minutes, with about 20 minutes in between and one 1 hour break. 
Three of the interviews were technical, with some talk about previous work experience. If I finished the question early I was given another, harder question. 
One was behavioral. This was the most relaxed interview.

Phone interview - asked about 10 personality based workplace questions. Lovely, reassuring interviewer. Questions were not designed to trip you up. However, difficult to get hold of someone in HR if you need specific help or advice with the process.

1. Resume Submission
2. Phone Call Interview (45 Minutes)
3. Final Round (Four 45 Minute Interviews)

The interview process was straight forward and very organized. My recruiter(s) were responsive throughout. Very enjoyable process.

30 minute university on campus interview. Got an email from a recruiter that I would have an interview the following week. Asked about projects and one technical question. Technical question was the leetcode question atoi. Interviewer was very nice.
Had my first round interview at my university, I was then told the very same day (Friday) that I would be traveling to Seattle on Monday for the next rounds of interviews.

phone screen with recruiter and then in a couple of weeks I got an on campus product interview scheduled. This was a 30 min interview. Immediately after I was notified it went well and an onsite interview was scheduled.

Two rounds on campus, one on-site. The recruiters are really friendly. On-site is 3 rounds for interns. usually 2 rounds of technical and 1 round of pm question.  The team is trying to find the ones who matched with the team so definitely show ur personalities as a great team player. Good luck!

The first round interview was straightforward yet I learned you should communicate with the interviewer rather than just write on the whiteboard. He asked me about my background and to elaborate on every experience.
interviews themselves were okay. was middle signal so i was kept the whole 8 hour work day, pretty miserable. campus was nice, my lunch buddy was kind of awkward but i don't judge

Take two weeks, onsite interview a whole morning. because I got a personal referral from my friend. Three steps in total, the third one is the most important. Because he/she will decide whether you can go to this company.

We had the interview when microsoft came for hiring to our college. For preparation i would recommend geeksforgeeks and interviewbit as most of the questions come from there.
Had the following rounds:
-coding
-group fly
-2 interview rounds
- hiring manager round

1 phone screen and an on-site in Seattle. The two interviews were a mix of behavioral and technical questions. They weren’t very difficult, but required some thought. I would suggest grinding leetcode.

I met one-on-one with a recruiter who asked me some questions about my  background. Then we moved onto technical questions where I was asked to write code on a white board to solve a problem given to me.

I unfortunately had very bad experience with more than one Microsoft recruiters. They all treat candidates in a very sloppy and irresponsible way. All the other companies' recruiters have done their due diligence to complete some internal screening process, for example get the hiring manager looking at your qualification before contacting you, except Microsoft. They basically contact me out of whim, then I tried to treat them responsibly by agreeing to setup one hour talk with them, then one or two days latter without solid reason I received a rejection letter, not even going through a technical screen. In this case I have strong background and have very matching skill set the job requires. The funny thing is that my interviews are going well, I already get a few onsite interviews from a few top-notch companies. In another case, I honestly told the recruiter that there are some other Microsoft recruiters pinging me for opportunities, as this early stage, of course as an candidate I'd like to give consideration to more than one teams to test which one is a better match. Out of those companies which are way better than Microsoft, the recruiters basically all take a respective tolerate attitude trying to help you to team matching different teams if you show interest, except Microsoft. This recruiter, after spending one hour on the phone, and a few rounds of emails, after knowing this, just simply disappear in the air.
I will not waste my time on those terrible terrible recruiters again, it's just a pure waste of my life!

Phone interview:
Behavioural, design and basic technical questions. It was done on phone with the recruiter and she mostly just followed the script and took down notes.

- How many lines of code do you think you have written for X?

On-site:
3 rounds with different interviewers:
More in-depth questions about resume and then whiteboard questions. Interviewers were people from various Microsoft teams. I got a few array based questions.

Took 30 mins in all. Asked algorithm question. Left 10 mins to answer questions. Did not ask anything about resume or projects. I asked the difference between pm and sde interview, interviewee said that both had the same interview in previous one or two rounds.
El peor del mundo. 6 entrevistas y no te contestan más los mails. Una vergüenza para una empresa como Microsoft. En un año participe en 2 procesos distinto y en ambos me hicieron lo mismo.
It was a  1 hour long Skype Interview and after some basic questions about what I do, they asked me a bunch of logic questions and HR questions about why I would like to work at Microsoft.

on campus interview. 30 min (kind of atypical), and only one tech question. talked about resume for about 15 min and the question being asked was super easy. There should be 2 rounds of phone interview and two rounds of onsite interview though
It was good. Very productive discussion. I was asked a technical question right off the bat which I was able to solve efficiently. I'm currently waiting for a follow up from the recruiter.
Four 45-minute interview back to back. 3 of them are technical and 1 is behavioral. About 15 of us interviewed with the Azure team. Many of the questions are system based.
I interviewed through Skype. There were a total of three rounds of interviews and each interview may last for 60 minutes. All the interviewers were nice and the questions were not very difficult.

It was a skype interview. Was asked about myself and the projects I have done. Also how I worked in a team, how to achieve a better user interface. At the end i asked some few questions. Made it to the next stage of the interview.

Series of one on one interview, starting with the recruiter. I had a couple of initial screening interviews, followed by a long day of on campus interviews. After a mid-day break, I met with the senior hiring manager and the recruiter followed up within a few days with an offer.
First was a phone interview, then the next round was on site. The on site had 3 interviews in the day. Everyone was very welcoming and the entire process was nice.

Applied online, got an email saying that Microsoft would like to interview me as they were coming to my University’s campus in a week.
The On-Campus Interview was a 30 minute interview with a manager from the Office 365 team,  the interview consisted of personality questions at first, then some Computer Science “Trivia” asking about basic concepts such as object oriented programming.T0then we moved onto a whiteboard technical question where we proceeded to spend most of the time on the question but never moved onto writing code on the whiteboard just showing examples and talking out loud what some solutions to the problem could be as well as the space and time complexities that would arise from the solutions. As we began to run out of time more “Trivia” was asked, this time about data structures, then questions for the interviewer and that was the end.
Received an email 4 days later saying I had advanced to the second round in Redmond, WA.
The On-Site interview consisted of 4 x 45 minute interviews, one on one with various people from the Azure Cloud team. Each interview had similar structure to the on-campus one: Personality question for the first 5 minutes, then a technical question for the majority, then optional questions for the interviewer at the end.
Each of the on-Site interviewers started off the conversation by introducing themselves and talking about what their position on their respective team was. 3 people from Azure Storage division, one Engineering manager, two normal engineers. The fourth interviewer was an engineer from the Azure Health Division, helping to maintain the backbone of updates to the platform itself.
2 out of the 4 white boarding questions consisted of using Binary Trees with the third question being an Array-based question and the fourth question being a task scheduling question. Once a basic answer was given for each of the questions (with or without written code on the board), the interviewer would proceed to ask about drawbacks to the solution, ask if efficiency could be improved in time or space complexity, then they began modifying the original question to be more restrictive on what could and couldn’t be done (e.g. now solve the problem using O (1) space complexity)
As we would leave the interview room, the interviewer would either take a picture of the code on the board, or erase the board as we left the room. 
Oddities about my personal experience:
In my first interview of the day, once the question was asked and we proceeded to make examples of the question, I was struggling with coming up with a pattern to begin formulating an answer, so the interviewer proceed to make more test cases, however during the process both I and the interviewer became confused multiple times at finding a “solution” to the test cases, miscommunication for understanding each other occurred many times and we never moved onto the coding of the solution before time was up.
