We spent a good amount of time talking about the fundamental power supply topologies and discussed our common experience having gone to the same graduate school.

When we were finished, I got to share lunch with the next interviewer, an engineer who would tentatively be my peer in the group. Rapport was also good here. I was able to teach him a few things about the fundamentals of some electronics circuits and he seemed genuinely interested in what I could bring to the team. This all why eating; no pressure.

Next was a director of another group, parallel to the hiring manager. There was little formality to this (which kept nerves in check) and his questions primarily dealt with subject matter outside of my experience so he was surprisingly gracious with expectations. He was, as was the case through most of the day, seeking how I solved the problems, not so much the exact answers.

After that, I met with another engineer who would be my peer in another group. We discussed best practices of board layout and general circuit design. Again, good interaction, though not as technical as the prior discussion. He's a very quiet person, so I wasn't able to read his reactions in the interview itself, but I felt confident throughout.

Another engineer; rinse & repeat. Pretty much the same questions as the previous person.

Then I met again with the hiring manager who gave me some more technical questions than he'd previously asked. I was able to satisfactorily walk through the questions despite having not worked on such a circuit in some time.

Finally, I met the skip-level manager of the department. He was immediately enthusiastic about my then-employer and discussed a bunch of previous encounters with them. Then he handed me a piece of paper that showed a circuit he'd previously worked on and asked me how it operated. Again, I was able to satisfactorily answer these questions. He had a meeting immediately following so I was sort of unceremoniously dismissed for the day without being able to talk further with the previous interviewers or even being escorted out of the lobby. I went home that day with a pretty good feeling about how it all went, but wasn't sure how to handle the exit.

However, it was only 2 days later that I received a job offer from the recruiter and we discussed what the next steps were and when I could start. All told, the entire process from application to receiving an offer was about 2 weeks.

Microsoft arranged a Skype call with me. The interview lasted 20 minutes. First they asked me behavioral questions, of how I work in teams, my most interesting projects and why I want to work there. They also asked me a brain teaser, the common problem of having tree baskets with apples and bananas.

The interview face to face process was conducted on-site with a three person panel discussion, each providing all relevant questions, with the entire discussion lasting 3.5 hours with one break and plenty of opportunity for Q/A. Overall experience was good.

I applied during Microsoft campus recruitment event at my university. On the first day we sat for 2 online rounds- 1st one was an MCQ round focused on OS, Data structures, & details of C/C++ & JAVA programming languages. The questions were quite challenging. After that there was a coding round where 2 questions on data structures & simple graph theory had to be solved. This round was surprisingly easy.

After a day's gap the selected candidates were called for P.I's. There were several rounds spread over 2 days including a group round(not a group discussion though). Very high emphasis was placed on data structures, algorithms but they also wanted to test our ability to analyze & frame a solution( even if that solution is not the optimal one) for some open ended problems. The interviewers were quite friendly & helped out when they felt a liile nudge in the right direction was needed.

One suggestion, brush up on more "advanced" data structures like Tries, segment trees, red black trees, interval tree etc.. If you can demonstrate a good grasp over these topics, the interviewers seem to be impressed.

I applied at the campus fair. Then after one and half week a recruiter contacted me and arranged an interview in the campus. It was an one to one interview. The interviewer was very friendly and nice person. After couple of general question he asked me a technical question. It was easy, basic programming problem.

I was contacted via email by a recruiter then I had a phone interview. 3 days later I had an in person interview w/ the assistant manager & manager. It was a very chill interview, we talked outside the store and they were very personable. No need to be nervous! I dressed business casual. However the managers were wearing jeans and a Microsoft shirt.

6 different interviews. The first one with the recruiter who did the first candidate filtering. then with several worldwide managers via skype. It took about 2 months and it ended with a very detailed screening about past jobs, education, referrals etc...the last round was with the direct line manager in person.

I was contacted by a recruiter through LinkedIn.  She performed a very careful phonescreen of my sales qualifications.  I was moved to the next step in the process by speaking to a hiring manager, who would have been my manager.  The hiring manager appeared impressed with my qualifications and invited me in the Alpharetta, GA office for further interviews.  What I was surprised about was that the interviews were interviews with a total of four hiring managers AND three other candidates for the same position.  Each candidate was shuttled off to separate conference rooms and the hiring managers took turns interviewing each candidate.  Sandwiches were graciously offered for each candidate.  One of the hiring managers came in while I was eating and I had to choke down my sandwich while he asked me questions.  He did not appear to be impressed, but I was eating the sandwich that Microsoft provided and he ate one as well while we were chatting.

At the conclusion of the interviews, I was informed that they would be a making a group decision and they would be in touch regardless of the decision.  A couple of weeks went by and I contacted the recruiter, who was not professional enough to email me or return my phonecall.  I found out later by checking the Microsoft website that the position has been filled.  I understand that big companies don't always get back to all candidates who apply for positions, but it was very unprofessional of the hiring managers not to get back in touch with a hiring decision after being informed that I would be contacted regardless of the decision.

It was quite intense. 4 Interviews by 4 people. Initial it was phone screening. Then it was onsite interview done by 3 Managers. done at different timings. It took long to finish the final interview as the person was on holidays .

The interview process was very transparent and open - both parties (myself and my hiring manager) felt super comfortable throughout the process, and that made me feel confident about working for the company even more.

first was a coding round then 2 interviews each round tested ur skills aout coding and handling pressure they tend to check your imaginative power as well.The interview was mainly focussed on basics they wll aks u abut projects and ur contribution.How woud u behave in certain situations and sometimes they can even make u write down entire code or a part as such to get to know what your understanding of the project

It's mostly based on database, few coding questions in all the rounds.Totally there were 4 rounds.
First was based on funda in Computer Science. The interviewer was in a hurry, a little more patience from his side would have helped me

Basic phone interview with a few programming questions.  Conducted by an SDE.  Asked one question that I had heard previously and thus I knew the answer for.  Still, a pretty decent interview and the interviewer was the person I worked with the most so it made sense.

I met with the man organizing the sales team they were hiring for and two people that he worked with. I spent a long time talking to those three people and followed up via email. Throughout the entire process I spoke to about 6 people.

After clearing the coding round,I was invited for a 1:1 interview. The interviewer asked for a CV walk through and asked my favorite data structure. I said Linked Lists and next two questions were on linked lists. This round lasted for an hour. 

Second round was an HR round. The interviewer asked why software development, did a CV walk through, and asked about my dream/complex project. I named a project (Iron Man's armor), then he asked how I would implement it and what challenges will be faced. This round was of 45 mins.

talk about my resume. ask about my previous project, what is my contribution of that project, what is my role in the past job, and some detail background knowledge related to that position, some programming problems

It was a campus interview, and it lasted around 30 minutes. During the first 15 minutes, the interviewer asked many questions based on my resume. After that I was asked to write a short programme on paper. The process was very intensive, and you had to respond fast.

The interview process is great. I went to on-site interview and then we get to buy stuff from the company store. The campus is beautiful and the interviews were not too difficult. The interview process consists of four individual interviews with four different engineers. In general, I enjoyed my entire interview process with Microsoft. Unfortunately, I didn't get an offer.

the first round was MCQ's of about 60 questions with negative marking and the second round was programming round with 2 programming questions on graph and dfs concepts(difficult)  followed by 3 interview rounds.the first interview round was your solution to innovative ideas and a technical interview followed by HR. i could go further than two rounds.

Intern Interview. This was organised by the campus. Took 5 rounds in total. Many different aspects covered mainly testing and programming related concepts. Data Structures/Algorithms were asked.
The process was divided into levels and it was thorough examination.

Was very cushy as they fly you out to Seattle and pay for your accommodations for about 2 days.  However the questions were all over the place and some seemed not suited to the role I was applying for.

It was smooth and the staff were courteous to accommodate the duration of my stay within the interview time range. It was conducted in an open setting where there is not closed up window, probably relative to the design of the place.

An onilne test on Cocubes. 1st there was an aptitude test (standard quant, verbal, logic questions). Then there was a technical test (Computer networking & Active Dirctory basics). About half of the students were selected for the next round which was GD. Then there were technical, HR & managerial interview rounds.

First a video Interview, which has to be taken within the presence of you own home in your own time and no other interview partner. The questions are written and the response time is limited. 5 Questions in total. Both in English and German. The followup step was an Assessment Center (of which the elements are listed below). Took an entire day.

9 interviews in total, way too many interviews. Overall process is too lengthy and salary expectations was not clear beginning of the process. Not clear on the offer related to the bonus. Overall the interviews are fairly difficult and each interview is focus on different topics

Course of a few months, recruiter contacted me from careerbuilder I applied for a few positions. We did a phone interview, they contacted me a few weeks later and said that some would contact me for information. A few weeks later someone called for a group interview, a day after the group interview I was called back for an interview with 2 people then pushed through the same day to interview with store manager. 2 weeks later I received a call I got the job.

Contacted by an inside recruiter who was very responsive and worked hard to keep things moving (Even took me to lunch).  Was very clear about the position and opportunity and explained how the company worked, who the principles were and how they founded it.  Nice.

Interviewers drill you on all basics. Microsoft had conducted two one credit courses in our college - Networking and ADDS. One is expected to be thorough in both. In addition questions from OS, Networks, Software Development etc. were asked. The interviewers were friendly and not intimidating. The rounds were
1. Aptitude + technical(about windows,networking,ADDS)
2.Group Discussion
3.Technical Round
4.Managerial Round
5.HR
The interview process included 3 people in the interview was pretty simple, there was a recruiter in the room a lead and the manager of the group. I thought it was very similar to my Amazon interview

The first interview in microsoft. It was very cool and not too long (70 minutes).
but it was only the first interview and we need four  for  continue there. We will see

Thorough. A 2 part interview. They were having a hiring fare, so the first interview lasted less than 15 minutes which was a lot of pressure to market yourself as quick as possible. I lucked out and had mine towards the end of the day so I assume I was fresh on their minds. I was one of two selected to go to the second interview which lasted an hour.

The interview process was pretty straight forward asked a lot of question about my experience. Understanding of how to design an application is important. 4 interviews total after the initial phone screen.

Overall very quick, only took 2 days for the entire process and 1 week for results. Started with an online test with technical questions (basic coding, data bases, algorithms, aptitude tests), group discussion and then 3 interviews the next day focusing on technical questions, past experience, asking you for algorithms, etc.

I submitted my resume both at a college career fair and online. When I got to was invited to the on-campus interview, they told me I would be applying for a position with MSIT. This took me aback at first, but the interviewer said I would be working as a developer, so I decided to continue with the interview process when they invited me to fly out for another round in Redmond. 

The process of scheduling the interview was a bit difficult and I ended up going right in the middle of my semester final exams because they couldn't accommodate another time. That said, they were very attentive and detail-oriented when it came to scheduling drivers and hotels to make my trip as painless as possible.

The day of the interview I went with a group of other prospective interns to the campus recruiting building at Microsoft, where we got a brief introduction to the interview process and were then sent off to our first individual interviews. There were 4 interviews in total, with each interview clocking in around 45 minutes and involving a mix of interpersonal and technical questions. Interviewers drew on my resume to find starting points for the different technical questions, and though I often felt like I didn't quite reach some of the conclusions they were after, I had great conversations with the interviewers about the challenges involved in each one.

I received an offer two weeks later and accepted shortly thereafter.

Went through 2 rounds of Skype interviews and 1 HR phone call. They start off with the Lead of the role then the manager for that role and then HR (progress happens by being successful in each)
Overall, the communication was up to the mark where they convey that which level is being organized. The HR always calls to confirm incase there is a delay in e-mail communication. Naturally, if they tell you, it's round 2 means you were successful at the first round.

Usually there are six rounds of interviews. First round is kind of technical screening and next two rounds of technical problem solving questions. Two more rounds for design questions and finally a discussion with the manager or skip level.

Very long and arduous. Started with two phone interviews the first of which was fairly trypical but the second of which was asking a lot of very abstract questions designed to determine honesty, how you think, problem solving skills, integrity, etc. Then I had to complete a very long written work history with a good deal of questioning about why I wanted to leave my current employer and why I wanted to work for Microsoft. That was a very important key to being asked in for a face to face interview. Finally, once the interview process was complete and I was notified of a pending job offer, I had to clear a background check and credit history check. The entire process took about 5-6 weeks.

Got 4 round interviews including an additional one, the whole process lasted 4 hours. All the questions were technical. All travel cost were covered and they booked flight and hotel for me. They have a professional team to process flight booking and reimbursement for candidates. It was the most fantastic interview i have participated. Overall the questions were not that hard, they wanted to see the potential of candidates rather than the answer.

Very friendly interview. Focus based on why to work for Microsoft, what would you do in your first days at Microsoft. Very unstructured and spontaneous. very respectful, and thankful of my time for participating.

Had to go through 10 interviews but did not get an offer.   Very tough questions.  They ask you to put together a 90 day business plan and present in a group format.  They ask you about your biggest sales win from previous job and ask for 10 referrals from previous supervisors.  They also call each of these previous supervisors.   They ask for a written sales proposal and ask you to do it during an interview.

I was contacted by a Microsoft recruiter (who by the way gave me one of the worst customer experiences. The response time for each email was minimum of 3 days! ) who found a team for me to interview. 
I did not know that there was a Microsoft policy (and I was educated of this via my recruiter), that Microsoft does not schedule an interview more than 14 days in advance. So 14 days before I actually wanted to schedule an interview I contacted the recruiter. After being assured that my interview was scheduled, I applied for brief break from work. The interview did not happen when I had taken a leave of absense (so time off wasted!). I feel getting a good recruiter to work with is an important thing with Microsoft.
There was a 45 min phone screen.

There were 5 onsite interviews. 4 techincal and 1 hiring manager.

I did not get an offer because the hiring manager said I had a lot of UI experience and the team had another candidate who had more backend experience. The hiring manager requested the recruiter to help me find another position but I did not pursue as the recruiter was a pain to work with.

Weeks or several rounds of interviews as expected, be yourself, your personality counts! Synergy, passion, brand ambassador are all key terms to be aware of. No one wants a know it all, they teach you a lot no matter what your position is. Ongoing training and testing is part of everyone's role. Team Team Team - make that your mantra if it isn't already.

3 interviewers interview you separately, pretty much a basic software interview--ask you a technical question, then make you code it out on their whiteboards. Make sure to brush up on your syntax for all the languages you know.

It was described to me to be split into three parts.  First of all there was a quick chat with the recruiter who basically digested the CV with me as reference so that he could then present it to the hiring manager.  The hiring manager was interested and then there was a telephone interview organised.  This was mostly just a general chat about experience and then a very small technical element.  Unfortunately I was super super prepared for a problem solving question but he simply asked "How does the internet work?", which took me completely by surprised and I answered terribly.  Still I personally am not sure about asking that question for someone who is all about problem solving.  Also its a question that could be answered after about 5 minutes of Google-ing!

With regards to the recruiter though, he was excellent, super responsive and eager to help!

First saw this hiring post at a software conference.
After sending my resume, got interview request in about 1 week.
It was supposed to be a phone interview, but I went to the interviewer's office because I am local. The interviewer was pretty nice and I had a positive experience over all.

Pretty straight forward. First round was with the intern manager and the current intern. 45 min interview with standard interview questions and some situational about the jobs.

Next round was with different sales directors. These ones are less predictable as it depends on the managers interview style. Just show a lot of passion and energy and you will do well. Nothing too technical.
Had three phone interviews that took about two weeks. Offered the job on the first of the month. Flew out of state to various states for training. Came back to the state and did more training.

I had two phone interviews and one skype technical interview . 
The first one was with one Human Resources from Seattle to check my background and ask some questions about my resume. The second phone interview was with the same HR to ask me if I want to continue for the second part and talk about my salary expectations.
The last one was with a Lead Software Engineer and he asked me some technical questions.

Pretty typical of what else is on here, but with a different twist. Met with 3 engineers and then the final interviewer, the as appropriate is what they called it. Other questions were around  linked list traversal and working with arrays and indexes.

1 interview at my University followed by 4 interviews onsite. Each interviewer was very friendly. Questions were easy but all had extensions. I feel like the interviewers were judging more on personality during answering the questions than the questions themselves.

The hiring process was smooth and quick (at least in my case).
HR had contacted me on LinkedIn and scheduled interview on a Sunday.
Within 4 hours 4 technical rounds were completed,later on a small discussion with HR was done, so total there were 5 rounds.
The interview experience was very positive and the interview panel were also very friendly.
Questions were asked on all areas of Microsoft technologies (.Net, SQL, WCF, etc.)
In later rounds they were very keen to know my knowledge on my current project.

Once you are selected, HRs might take time to roll out the actual offer, so have patience :)

I had two interviews, each 45 minutes long. They were in person interviews, since it was campus recruiting. The first was a technical interview, followed by an HR interview. The technical interview focussed on the subjects I had undertaken while in college. The HR interview was more like a general conversation.

applied online and uploaded my resume and cover letter. Got a call from HR the next week. Had a short skype call after and then after heard that they were looking for interns in after 4 months. Declined the offer since i had no time, they told me to stay in touch. Not very hard interview questions

First a short interview over the phone, then, two interviews at the offices in Herzelia. The interviewers were very nice and make me feel comfortable. The questions that they asked were technical, and in increasingly difficult. I had a good experience although I didn't get the job. I would recommend to solve some interview questions, and go over basic courses - data structures, algorithms etc.

hiring process was good .you need a very good grip on subject to get through this. interviewer was good,formal.concentrated on data sructures mainly and a little standard questions

process
1.aptitude test
  it has 30 multiple answer questions moslty technical
2.coding round
3.interview

It was a Phone Interview. I applied through the University Career fair event. It was for a software developer Internship for the Summer. It was a pretty easy interview but I have no Idea why i did not get a reply back or an explanation that I was not selected.

It was an On-campus placement offer, where microsoft came for testing various skills like thinking and imagination skills , they also asked fundamentals of computer science. They put special stress on software Testing

Applied online for the summer internship. They did some background check based on resume and programming experience.
Interview was held in 1 day and contained 3 sessions. Session 1 (45 mins) was about presenting a topic given on the previous day. Session 2 (45 mins) was technical screening. Last session (30 mins) was HR interview.
The decision supposed to be given after 3 working days (the recruited said it to me), yet I got the decision after 2 weeks.

He was very polite. Show me the floor and the place. We went to the kitchen. Tell me about a.mistake you made.
Talk about a feature you have done.
ask interview question.
Write the code on the board or paper and we will talk about it.
we checked if it thread safe.

Was found by a recruiter through Linkedin. I had a one hour phone screen with the hiring manager, then was asked to come in for 4 one-hour in-person interviews with Software Engineers. The interviewers I met were friendly and professional. I struggled with some of the questions and wasn't given an offer.

First the regular discussions with HR, then you talk with someone at the same position you're aiming for. then you prepare a presentation for a panel of managers, who vote on a decision.
Of course you might not get to that last step.

Employee brought me to the attention of the hiring manager. I did a phone screen with the hiring manager and made a good impression. When I cam in for the on-site interview, there were some domain knowledge questions, but mostly behavioral interview questions. I had 6 interviewers plus the HR person. Average difficulty. Pretty friendly.

First: Online Portfolio application - Second: Interview with lead manager  - Third: Interview with HR - Reference check
Just a normal process as other companies' interviews. I introduced my works and careers for last years and my professional interest and etc.
One interview was from Skype and they asked me about my aspirations and motivations. The other one was in Microsoft with two people and they asked me about the Microsoft products and my worklike.

Started off with a phone interview.  Made a point of telling the recruiter that I was a Senior.  They said 'Don't worry, it's entirely skills based'.  When I rocked up, it was pretty obvious that I didn't fit the demographic. Still, got to play with some nice tech :)
Phone screen followed by tech screen over the phone followed by onsite interviews with multiple people. a lot of scenario based questions to assess soft skills as well as technical knowledge

Long interview cycle of 6 months. Each interview usually lasts about 1 hour. First is the hr interview, second and third here technical interviews while fourth and fifth were manager and skip manager interviews and finally last was hr interview again with the final offer.

Quick interview. Was called in for some live tests. First interviewer was interested to more about personal life than work. Clearly she did not have enough question to ask about work. Later on came to know she has very less experience in the process she was interviewing me for. Other two interviewers were no where related to the work I do (I am telling this because I am in the system now and I have not had to interact them for work till now). They showed lot of attitude and rudeness and was in a hurry to prove why am I not the right candidate for the job. This could be an interview strategy I thought then. Later I came to know they thought me to be very professional. They liked someone who was smiling and shying when she was interviewed. Still I got through because of the first one because she thought I may not be able to flirt but I am good at work. :)
Quiet difficult. Mostly question asked from data structures and algorithms. Mostly question were asked from Geeks for geeks. They will tell you to optimize the code from one complexity to another.

Started with HR and move to peer and never made to the line manager. I applied to the position online but followed up with manager, recruiter and person transitioning out of the role to try get an interview.
I had 3 interviews. One over the phone and the other 2 at the office. I meet with the Team Principal and other members of the team. And the last interview was with my manager, technical interview

It is a telephonic (first) round took for an hour. Asked questions on all areas of C# programming, solving puzzle, Web API, Restful, SQL, Azure components and design scenarios. HR did not give any prior intimation to get prepare myself. Interviewer called me and ask am I ready to take interview and I just proceed for it.

I had a great experience interviewing with Microsoft. The questions were both technical and analytical in nature. A lot of focus on algorithms and design, as expected. I had a presentation and 6 interviews in one day. First few interviews focused on technical details, while the later ones where more about scenarios and discussing my approach in given scenario.

I was contacted by a recruiter - that was a career hold in MSFT HQ. After talking to recruiter, there is a phone screen to write two functions before they asked me to go onsite. The onsite interview process did not take long - I talked to 4 senor engineers and finished the event in the afternoon. The questions are not particularly difficult, compared with other Bay Area SW companies.

I had a short call with the recruited and then I got 4 interviews. All those were focused on coding skills but something totally different than what were the job requirements, it was all very theoretical. I had a feeling the interviewers didn't even know what position I'm applying for and what I'm focused on. Sadly, it wasn't a pleasant experience.
Straightforward and to the point. Great with not too much jargon.  I did really enjoy the experience. At the headquarters in Lisbon with their recruitment manager.  Professional but down to hearth.

It was interactive. I made a mistake but corrected it in the end. I was asked one behavioral question and one leetcode  medium programming question. There was time to ask questions about microsoft and other things
Series of 3 interviews, were super intimidating and long. Did not get the job in the end. Super draining process to go through. Thé interviewer was pretty rude as well

On campus interview ,two technical rounds in which questions based on DSA are asked.2 questons per round .
At last there was an HR round .In this questions on projects on resume are asked.

1 phone screen, 1 final round interview with 3 back to back sessions. Product design and past project questions. Applied through campus interview process, had a very negative experience hearing back. They offered me a position 3 months after the final round interview because there was a glitch with positions getting filled.
Two or three rounds in total. A coding question was asked in each round. Difficulty level is between medium and hard. The interviewer will guide you to find the best solution.

After talking with the head hunter and then with the hr recruiter, I had to go through multiple Teams (remote) interviews with the key members of the team in Tel Aviv, then executives and peers in Redmond and some remote executives
Group discussion, one tech round, one cv based round, and one hr round - none were too difficult, the tech one was very broad but based on cv. Each round was eliminative

This was a face to face technical interview and went on for about 90 minutes. The interviewer was very friendly. We discussed the projects on my resume and then he asked me questions on DBMS and Data Structures. He asked me to design the entire database for Amazon on paper and then spoke about normalization. After that, I was given a puzzle to solve. He waited patiently as I solved it and kept asking me what's running in my head. We then discussed all test scenarios in a given "50 Floor Building with 3 Lifts" scene. I asked him a lot of questions based on the situation he gave me to make it clearer for myself ( always do that in an interview ).

First, telephonic interview by HR and afterwards with a tech guy. Then, two face-to-face interviews with different interviewers. Last, an interview with 'high manager'. They were very kind through the entire process.

J'ai postulé a une offre reçu par mon école. J'ai ensuite été contacté pour un entretien physique. Comme je n'étais pas sur place pour cause de vacance j'ai pu passer un entretien syr skype.
Aujourd'hui le processus de recrutement est beaucoup plus complexe. Il faut passer par une presentation video il me semble

Meet with 4 principal program managers. I had f2f meetings with 4 different principal program managers and each one in different discipline in the OSG. They explored my interest and tested my knowledge in the subject matter.  One of the person who i had contacted took me to lunch and talked to me about the process and expectations in the company.

3 interviews, one basic with recruiter in English, one about skills in English, and one more about skills and personality in Spanish since the role was in Spanish. The entire process took about two weeks and then you  get an offer through email and start completing a lot of online forms that are related to taxes, how you work with Microsoft privacy policies and online credentials

PPO Interview of 2 rounds, 1 technical, and the latter as AA(As Appropriate). Hard technical round, easy AA. Internship manager's comments were helpful. Technical interview was highly unrelated to the project, and also tough. One got the feeling that it was deliberately unrelated to the project. AA round was much more easier, and taking initiatives in drawing out project decks gets more points.

I applied online and got a phone interview about a week later. They started by briefly going over my resume and then delved into a few basic behavioral questions. This part was fine but I stumbled quite a bit when I started getting asked more technical questions. I'm not too surprised that I didn't make it any further in the process.

Had an initial interview with a recruiter. Then had a tech screen (phone interview), followed by an on-site interview with 3 engineering leads followed by an interview by the manager. Happened on Friday, got the offer on following Monday. 
Incredibly professional, engaging and challenging. Learnt quite a bit about myself in the process. Got to give it to Microsoft!
From the arrangements (Flight/Hotel etc.) to the actual interviews, it was a genuine pleasure. Highly recommend the experience.

Long and not all the interviewers were not prepared. Reading  your CV for the first time during the interview.
While the job knowledge is important, they way you hand yourself... Some questions are designed to get a reaction from the interviewee
Make sure you have multiple examples of were you can demonstrate to the questions

Got contacted by the recruiter with the online test first, I finished all six or seven questions. Then been invented to onsite interview for roughly half a day. Good Experience. No phone interview in between, that's is. Thank you.

The day consisted of four 45-minute interviews with team members and the manager of the team that was considering hiring me. There was 15 minutes between each interview where the interviewer from the last interview talked with the interviewer for the next interview so each interviewer knows what you have said and done through the entire day.

Applied through campus recruiting. One telephonic round and then 5 onsite rounds. Interview included solving one coding question, and then testing it. Focused more on how to would I test the code, and debug it.

The 1st interview was on my university campus. It was a 30 min and I wouldn't really call it an interview. It's just meeting someone who may think that you're a good fit or not. All they asked me was what I was interested in and why. 

I was flown out to Redmond for the final round interview. They don't spare any expense with candidates. The interviews started promptly at 8am and finished at noon. You will meet with different managers to see where they may think that you're a good fit. There are four 1-hr interviews all back-to-back. It's exhausting since some will ask comfortable questions while others will make you sweat in explaining why you made certain decisions in your projects. These managers have all had at least 20 years of work experience. Don't try to BS your answers because they will see right through it. Answer honestly! They know that you don't know anything :)

They will let you know if you got the job or not within a day or two.

I started with an on-campus interview that was originally rescheduled. After what I thought was a mediocre first round interview, I was told I would not move on due to no more availability for final round, which was later reversed. Despite putting certain offices and positions as my preference on the application, I was interviewed for a team I was not particularly interested in at an office I did not want to be at (it was not clear that the interview would be for a particular team until I walked in the door that morning). There were four 45-minute whiteboarding interviews focused on both coding and design principles.

I was contacted for a phone interview first. After a few months I was invited for an on campus interview. I was interviewed by four different people. The interviews consisted of some whiteboard questions and general talk.
long but it was worth it! in the end i got the offer!! they like high spirited people!! thats is what it is all about!! keep a smile on your face and laugh a lot!
Had a Skype interview, a week later they told me I had been selected for the next round, and at the end of the day of the interviews I was offered a job.

Online Tests - Telephone Interview - Assesment centre.

Tests weren't too daunting, telephone interview asks typical competency based questions, AC had an interview with more competency based questions (you need to have a LOT of examples ready), a presentation with 90 minutes to prepare and a group activity, the AC is a great day, it's quite daunting and nerve racking but also exciting, you have to remember that if you go there, they're already very interested in you!

I was approached by the campus recruiter. They came to my school and I did on-campus interview. A few weeks later, I was invited to onsite. I met with ~5 engineers & engineering managers. All of them asked technical questions or simple behavioral questions (how would you resolve situation where xxxxxxx happens....)

Referred by friend. Took a standard coding question on phone. 2 days on-site interview. 1 day for HR only, 1 day for techniques. 2 Technique interview, 1 lunch, then told me you'd better begone.

I was very unlucky. I know senior guys in Microsoft tend to ask puzzles, I met a senior like this. Furthermore, he was in VERY BAD MOOD. Because of Friday? My current job is despised like a baby game for him. He kept yelling why you do NOT know this windows system function, why you do NOT answer my question in the way I like. And he explained his work with a stupid pride. 

Overall, background not matching. Completely waste of time. But it is my fault at first place. I should not even apply, as a pure Linux application developer and Windows-hater. More sadly, all the technical questions in the first 5 pages of Glassdoor Microsoft interview are not asked. So it is hard to know how to prepare.

The interview process at Microsoft, for me, has been awesome and relatively straight forward. I appreciated this and have a greater respect for the company because of this. Not always is this the case. For this particular job, the process was quick, to the point, and extremely professional. I have enjoyed working with everyone from the very first recruiter via LinkedIn, to the interview scheduler, Sr. recruiter (great at her job), and four current employees/mngrs whom I met in person and interviewed with in the Microsoft office. 20-40 min interviews with each individual.

The first round was a coding test (2 DSA questions) to be done in 60 minutes
The next round was technical round 
After the introduction and discussing resume projects I was asked questions about Linked List

- Tedious 
- Lengthy 

Be sure to research the company and know what it represents. They ask a lot of informational questions 
Be prepared for a role play scenario.  Try and meet with someone within the role so that you understand the steps.
First round was a phone screen with my recruiter, second round was two coding rounds with some senior engineers from different teams in the org. Took about a week between rounds.

Microsoft was the client for the company which I applied to. Interview process was not very difficult. I had to attend 1 hour technical round with the software engineer.  The process was easy. I would love to get involved in the process.

Applied online, reached out to via e-mail by an engineer to set up a tech screen. Hackerrank/Code pair I recall.

Simple Leetcode question on numbers (messed up on the logic here), Received no result 3-4 weeks later.
It was stressful, but very good. They are very interested in what you have to say. You can tell they take the job very seriously, which makes it a great position.

totally 3 rounds  

mainly coding problems, medium or hard difficulty on leetcode. The interviewees can use whatever IDE they like.

the interviewers are very nice and can provide guidance during the interview.

intensive knowledge of DSA, OOP is required and good CGPA is a plus. 2 DSA question were asked followed by some questions on programming language C++. Also few questions were asked on python. This was followed by an HR round.
Started with a phone interview and after a week or two I went to the onsite interview. They asked behavioral and technical questions but ultimately I did not get any further.

It was pretty standard as far as interviews. I had 1 person conduct my first round interview and my 2nd round had 4 interviews. They mostly wanted to have a conversation to get to know me and why I wanted to work in HR for their company.
Not very in depth. 1 question pass or fail. Not many details provided and no questions were allowed to be asked. Interviewer was hard to udnerstand and didnt talk at all after providing question.

Applied online, got a 30 min call from a recruiter after three weeks. Got to the final rounds. Bombed the first interview because the interviewer asked me a DP problem and I froze, I let him know I'm not good at that so he then gave me a LC medium.  
One hour break in between
Second Interviewer was super chill and didn't care about writing perfect code. He cared about logic and covering edge cases.

Technical interview - A Subject Matter Expert will be discussing technical aspects of the position with you. Expect practical exercises and reviewing real life examples of problems you would need to solve. Methodologies, programs and tools you’ve used in your previous positions and would use in the role you applied for will be discussed.

Can’t comment on the offer process as still early days.
Really friendly interviewers who put you at ease. Very relaxed process and adapt the interview based on the answers you give. Many STAR interview questions as well as some scenario based questions too! Good luck everyone!

1 technical phone interview
Then 1 day of a full panel of interviews. 4 interviews with 3 behavioural + data structures and algorithms (mixed)
1 systems design interview, going over relatively simple systems.

Was referred by someone. Hiring manager reached out for phone interview. Phone interview was completely behavioral for 50 mins. Was informed to move to next round within 2 days. But the next round was scheduled 2 weeks later. Scheduling delays. 5 rounds of interview. 2 technical and 3 behavioral. One of the interviewers asked me to explain something challenging i have faced, when I explained, he was like what the hell is challenging in this. Maybe it was supposed to be a stress interview but my confidence was shaken up a bit by that. Overall went well. Would give 4/5. But I was strung along for more than a month with ghosting from recruiter and finally got a reject. Microsoft is such a good company but I fail to understand why after repeated feedback about how much their recruiters suck, they don’t do anything to improve it.

Professional, detailed, to the point. Do the research and know the position you're applying for as they are quick and don't mince words. Nice team, but are very busy and seemed to need to onboard quickly.
Good and smooth process  and smooth overall professional staff but testing was normal environment was good but great time it was a good experience and had fun and it was cool ok

Very friendly interviewer, talked to me about the culture of the company first, before asking me a Leetcode medium. After that, the process took a while, but they were extremely backlogged because of a shortage of people wanting to interview.

1 hr on-campus interview - basic technical questions, mainly logic design and C coding
Full day of on-site interview - at least 6-7 interviews. Questions mostly relating to the details of the resume, op-amp topologies, high-level design
The initial phone screen was not too bad. The recruiter was friendly. She mostly asked behavioral questions, with a few straightforward technical questions. Overall, I had a  pretty good experience.

During the loop interview, it seemed as though the interviewers weren't very aligned as they asked very similar questions. There were some behavioral, and some more analytical questions. The interviewers were extremely nice though! Overall a great experience.

Horrible experience!! Office NLX team
Referred by an employee, 
1. Recruiter called to do initial screening and proceeded to next round
2. This was with hiring manager, it went well and moved to next round.
3. Three back to back 45 mins interviews. Two of them DS, algo last one behavioral. 

Tech rounds were 50/50. I didn't heard anything back for about three weeks. 
Then recruitment coordinator reached out to me to set 4th interview. That was with the same manager in the first interview. I waited about 30 mins online and no one joined the meeting . 

I tried reaching out to the recruitment team, recruiter and the manager. Now one week later, still no replays.
They talk all big about the work culture, and these are the types of people you will be working, then it is not worth it.

Initial phone screen with a mix of behavioral and technical questions. Basic data structures and algorithm questions, based on results might lead to a final round interview day with 2-5 hour long interviews. Final interviews ask about previous experiences but mainly focus on problem solving and increasing efficiency using algorithms.

3 rounds interview: first with Microsoft EMEA recruiters; then technical interview with someone in the technical dept. Succeeded, I was introduced to two rounds (on the same day): one with two guys from the Consulting Services; another one with two hiring managers,

I was asked to prepare a presentation with general guidelines provided in Sway; then a more general discussion with the hiring manager in relation to skills; development and carrer path.

Erster Schritt war das Einreichen des Lebenslaufs, gefolgt von dem  1. Interview mit HR global (auf Englisch) und in der letzten Runde gab es das  2. Interview mit demHiring Manager. Die Gespräche gingen jeweils eine Stunde.

The usual 4 rounds of interview. 2 Coding, 1 Software design, 1 system design and behavioral. Behavioral one also close to technical one. The process took nearly 3 weeks. I asked 2 weeks for preparation after the screening. I requested interviews every other day.

I was initially interviewed for the Senior Program Manager position and after the first round, there was no response for a week, when I reached out to the recruiter, they said you will now be interviewed for the Program Manager-2 position. The first interview for Program Manager-2 was pretty standard and straightforward. After the meeting I didn't hear back from them for 3 weeks, I obviously thought I was not selected and let go of it. After 3 weeks, the recruiter calls and says are you ready to interview for the 2nd round tomorrow. 
Well, I was irritated, but ok, and proceeded with the next round. The next round was very similar to the first round. But this time the interviewer was so much better and friendly, for me, the interview went really well and I thought it was the same from the interviewer's end.
After 2 weeks of the interview, I checked in with the recruiter and they said that all candidates have been put on hold by the hiring manager. 

The whole experience with Microsoft has been really bad. Didn't expect this from Microsoft. Every time I as a candidate had to either wait or assume or reach out to the recruiter. It felt like there was no communication. There is not enough explanation for anything with the recruiter. Even if you ask what to expect in the interview, there are a random set of words thrown at you. You expect Mircosoft to be a little more professional, but unfortunately no. I have a feeling that this happened because it was MS India and the same thing wouldn't fly in other countries. Why do Indian companies act like you're doing a favor is something I don't understand.

The first round of interviews was over the phone. Some basic questions were asked. One of the questions was: "How would you explain Cloud environment to a 5-year-old.?"
The second interview was with the team whom I worked with over Teams.

It was the final round (AA) for an internship at Microsoft, India for Summer 22. The interviewer was quite friendly. The interview started with my introduction and was later carried out by a deep dive into my projects, a puzzle, and a few HR Questions. No Coding questions were asked in this round

First round was the online coding test, comprised of 3 coding questions, to be solved in 90 minutes. Difficulty of questions varied from easy to medium. After clearing this round, there were 2 Technical Interviews and 1 HR Interview

Got ontacted after about one week of applying to do a online technical assessment, then a virtual onsight interview that consists of 4 interviews. Your typical leetcode type of questions. Interviewers were very friendly.

We talk about my goals and expectation. I did some algorithm challenges in the tech interview. Amazing process. They were really nice with me. The algorithms problems were about searching,sorting and all normal type of problems about algorithms

I went through the interview process as a new grad. Got to the final round. Interview questions were leetcode medium mostly, with one design problem. I thought I did pretty well, but you have to be able to answer broader questions on your solutions to qualify for an offer. Unfortunately, I got rejected
Apply online on their careers site. Reached out to by an HR recruiter to ask a few questions over the phone. Was reached out to again to schedule an in person interview by the hiring manager.

1st coding round
Followed by 3 technical rounds where questions based on algorithm and Data Structures were asked. It also included some behavioural questions like what would be my approach to solve a problem (ideal answer is I should first try to solve the sub problems)

First they sent me a codelity exam to complete before the first interview.
Then an english interview that lasted 30mins mainly HR questions.
Now waiting for the response to come- they said it should take between 3 - 4 weeks.

Fue muy profesional, y muy claro. 
Fue en ingles, muy amable. Puntual. Y fue muy claro en lo que se espera del rol. Describió el proceso, y siguientes pasos. Se mando calendario de fechas, hay flexibilidad.

System process was very smooth and like the way HR followed up for scheduling interview and interview was conducted over the video call. It was a good interview and the interviewer had nice knowledge and he was very specific on what sort of candidates he was looking for.

An awesome experience that helped me develop my technical skills and get even more passionate about technology. We learnes lots of things and even designed a real project that made an impact in the computer science community.

1. First Round: behavioral question
2. Final Round: 4 interviewers separately. 
Technical question about your project and  also meed to do coding of leetcode medium level, and also behavioral questions
Avoid the bing group. The interviewer is serious and the whole process is stressful. You had better choose another group if you want to join Microsoft. Need to practice leetcode more as well.

Codility challenge followed by 30 minute teams meeting. Asked some high level questions followed by some questions about previous work and then some logic questions at the end. Was a pleasant experience overall.

First step is online codility test (80 minutes for 1 easy question and 2 medium level questions), second step is interview with a recruiter (more character questions and some logic ones), third step is 2 technical interviews . Afterwards is interview with a director and the offer.

One of the worst interviews I've ever been through. Interviewer was late, completely unprepared, and was unclear about requirements of the problem. Urged me from the beginning not to worry about time, until 10 minutes passed and then they tried to rush me through my thought process. Not a good look for the company
1st interview with hiring manager, 2nd with a member of that Sub Region Category team and 3rd with the Sub Region Director. There is potentially a final interview with EMEA Category Lead.
First there was a phone screen with a recruiter, an initial interview, and then a second round interview loop with those on the team and those who work with the team.

The first round was a phone screen but the final round was all over the place. The recruiters/help guides doesn't actually touch up on what is the agenda of the interview. It is like a blackbox for the candidate. This is something someone should have told me; 
1. There is a round of data science, this invovles some data query with SQL + using it to answer something the interviewer is asking you to do. Most likely studying your analytical side. 
2. A light coding round, it wasn't anything off LC but something like binary search. They check if it can run. 
3. and 4. these are higher ups in the chain. But they ask high-level questions and such as "how do you build a system to study feedback collected from users?". Then another interviewer would be on some ML concepts. 

These are not at all described in their guides! If their recruiters had more insights for candidates, they'd be able to perform better.

3 rounds were conducted. 2 DSA based and 1 HR based.
I was recruited through campus.  In last round questions on web development were asked like how to create schemas and fetch data basically whole designing.

Après un premier mail qui dit s'intéresser à mon background, s'ensuivent quelques échanges par mail pour définir un jour et une heure d'interview d'1h via Teams. Après l'interview, une dizaine de jours plus tard, je reçois une réponse négative.

Started with a GD, followed by a technical and two HR rounds. U will be asked to express your views about a given topic in GD. The topic our group got is, "Impact of pandemic on the pace of digitalization". After that in the technical interview u will be tested on your trouble shooting skills.

Zoom interview after computer test.
Questions about studies and projects i made.
Very informative before the interview, and take about three to four weeks to answer.
British interviewer, nice one.
Ask to solve a puzzle

I had three forty-five min interviews back to back. Interviewers were extremely friendly and easy going, questions flowed so easily it hardly felt like an interview! You can tell they each want you to succeed.
A three-part interview where the first was a set of behavioural questions and the rest a set of Leetcode. The Interviewer with whom I got assigned was very helpful and patient.

The interviewer was unprofessional, joined late, never introduced herself, showed some displeasure throughout the interview, straightaway started asking irrelevant questions. The interview was scheduled for 30 mins, but she wrapped up just in 17 minutes. I've had many interviews in my life, but this one was totally unprofessionally. Never expected this kind of treatment from Microsoft.

I do not even know if the person who interviewed me was from the documentation team. At the end of the interview, she asked me if I have any question, to which I responded yes and asked a question. She gave me a vague answer, which did not have anything to do with my question. This means that she was not attentive.

3 back to back interviews covering business acumen, sales acumen and digital transformation.
Really all 3 interviews were exactly the same and they asked high level questions, absolutely no depth to it. An intern could have answered their questions just as well

I got an offer but they did not have an actual headcount open for the role I interviewed at so the recruiter kept scrambling to find a role I could fill. They probably used dynamics 365 to manage the experience. They’re not put together whatsoever.
it was an hour interview, 10 minutes about my resume and experience, 40 minutes an easy  coding question and different approach of it. and 10 minutes just talking about the role.

The process took a month.
You have to complete a codility test then a skype interview (HR), then there were two technical interviews each interview is one hour. in each one I had one hard/medium question.
If you succeed in the technical interview they will call you to schedule another two interview with the manager.

Applied online, had 3 back to back interviews, received an offer two weeks after. The interviewers were very professional and it was a great experience. The questions were very much standard and focusing on the behavioral part.

30 minute technical interview. Interviewer asked me one behavioral question and then gave me a leetcode medium. Super short, felt pretty rushed. I guess it's too be expected from a company that gets so many applicants.
It was one -one interview over call. The question was tough. interviewer was friendly. It overall a good experience. After shortlist I got the interview link. hi hi hi hi hi hi

This was an on-campus recruitment process. There was an online coding round on codility with 2 coding questions. On clearing this, there were 3 interview rounds, all coding based (DSA and OS), which took place on Microsoft Teams. The coding questions asked in the interviews were all standard leetcode questions (1 medium, 2 hard).

there were 2 steps in the first stage.

It was one hour, some intro, coding question and ended with me asking few generic questions. The recruiter might help you solve the problem. Think aloud. And they might even suggest a strategy or point out your mistake.

Interview for intern conversion in Great China Region after 10 weeks internship, only 1 round (AA interview).

Got employment intention letter after 2  weeks .

I interviewed with Microsoft in September. I was referred by an employee, after which I had a phone screen. Pretty straightforward. I was put through to the final round for 4 45 minute interviews. These went okay for me, but I did not end up receiving an offer. I was however, contacted to apply for a different position instead.

Questions about the project on my CV
Ask about the difference between SQL and NonSQL
Ask about the basic info about hashmap 
One leetcode quesiton : top k frequent elements and need to consider how to solve it without using heap

Started with a phone screen with a recruiter, and then a 45-minute interview,  and lastly a super day that consisted of 4 different interviews. The interview on the super day consisted of both technical and behavioral-type questions.

the first stage interview include a simple codility test which had 3 questions about different subjects like backtracking, sorting problems, strings, arrays and  overall the questions are about basic cs knowledge.

I applied online. The process took 3 months. I interviewed online for a position in Power Automate team in Athens. 

First step was an online coding test with three questions. Topics tested were: string manipulations, arrays, trees, recursion. 

After submitting this test, a recruiter from Estonia contacted me via email and informed me that the process would have three interview steps with technical director and team members from Greece. 

First interview was a kind of theoretical (not so technical) with the tech director and the hiring manager. 

Second one was with the Engineering Manager and asked me questions about the online test I submitted in the beggining. We also discussed alternative implementations. 

Third interview was the most interesting with a member of the team during which we had a broad tehnical discussion and coded online on some tasks (async programming, linq issues etc). 

After the three interview cycle was terminated, after almost two months from the first contact, and having no information about whether there would be a next step, I tried to contact the recruiting manager in Estonia with no luck(no answer to my emails). 

A week later, Ireceived a call from another recruiter, asking me to schedule a 4th (final) interview with the tech director (again) and another team member. During this interview, the tech director announced me that they would like to move on with an offer but they thought that I would be a good fit for another team (not the initial one for which I had applied). The team leader of the new team asked me some technical questions and everything seemed smooth. We concluded that the recruiters would contact me for the next steps. 

After two weeks of shadowing, I received an email from the recruiter informing me that my candidacy was rejected because they would like to see more theoretical knowledge (totally incosistent feedback). 

To sum up, although Microsoft is considered a tech giant, its mentality towards the candidates is the worst I have ever seen.
 It is a fact that it is considered an employer of preference for lots of candidates, that's why they do not show any respect during the procedure.
4 rounds - 1 initial phone call with recruiter, 3 rounds on the final day. All behavioral questions. All the people were very friendly. They just want to get to know you so be your authentic self.

Inviata candidatura su sito ufficiale, contattato dopo 10 giorni circa per telefono. Fissato appuntamento su Teams per approfondimenti. Molto professionale e molto disponibili, si sono dimostrati flessibili sulle possibili date
Smooth and Friendly. Very well organized by the recruiter. A Fair use of available tools to make the interview process easy. Interviewer was humble and interactive which kept the interview lively.

Got Codility test - had 3 questions in 80 minutes.
Then a week after the test I had A 30 minute interview on teams.
askes about a project I did, about a project I did in a group that didn't work out and how did I react, what is my favorite Microsoft product why and what would I improve  in that product.
askes to explain about threading, and had another brain teaser question.

Na segunda etapa foi dividida em 4 etapas no mesmo dia que consistia em atividade em grupo, atividade para apresentar para um entrevistador de acordo com o tema escolhido dentre as opções e no final uma entrevista individual.

Interview process  wasn't the most straight forward. I applied to two internships at Microsoft. When I was selected for an interview, they didn't indicate which position I would actually be interviewing for.

I networked with a recruiter through a campus event and followed up with her to try and schedule an interview. She sent me an application, and I followed up with her again, and we scheduled an interview. I only had one interview and it was virtual.
First they conducted test which contains two coding questions Out of which the one who solved both got selected for interview rounds Then in the interview the interviewer asked some really good

Final Round - 2 rounds, all technical - leetcode medium and medium/hard questions. About 45 min each

The interview process is a multi-stage process for hiring new employees. From mine point of view, but also having a lots of other opinions from other people. It’s not the model of interview, is more the choice of candidates for the finals interviews.
Ok, Microsoft have quotas, but you need to choose the best and most experienced candidate, sometimes I seen that the person admitted, compared with others (even in soft skills, even with the personality) compared with others is not the best. Probably have some connections or networking.
And quotas regarding age, I have see a lot’s off people with more than 40 years very well qualified and with a lots of experience, that is not taking in consideration. Sometimes I see that the individual that was hire, ok is younger, but with several lacks about experience.
I don’t say that the model is wrong, but sometimes you should give some chances to other people that doesn’t have the internal networking our connection .

So far, I interviewed at Microsoft for some roles. Many times I encountered recruiters who were not polite or respectful. Some interviewers seemed arrogant as well.

I was approached several times for a PMM role at Microsoft PromoteIQ and decided to interview for the role. It turned out to be an absolute waste of time. They made me prepare an extensive presentation, which took about one week. Then during the final interview rounds, the hiring manager wouldn't introduce herself as such (I only knew who it was from a friend who works at Microsoft) and didn't offer me a chance to ask any questions about the job. Another person in the loop started fishing for highly confidential information about my current employer (their direct competitor). And the worst of all is that I haven't heard back from them at all after all this effort. I reached out to several recruiters, but received mail delivery notifications back, as if all of them quit the job out of the sudden. It was a disturbing experience and I will never apply at Microsoft again.

The typical process is a screening interview with HR first and then called for a Competency-Based Interview with the Hiring Manager. After that shortlisted candidates will usually called back to be interviewed by members of the team or other stakeholders
