I was selected for microsoft engage program, based on project what I did there, I got a chance to get interviewed. But I loose the this golden opportunity as it was my first interview and I was a bit nervous.

going to mountain and drinking soda and relaxing and eating some fast food and listening to music and watching a movie and submitting our information in their website and be with each other till midnight

I only had 1 round  which was conducted virtually on MS Teams.
So, the interviewer started off by asking me to give a brief introduction, the projects that I have done, and how I spent my college days.

I was asked what language I was comfortable in (C++).
He gave me a coding question based on anagrams of strings. And asked me for 2 optimizations for the solution that I provided.
Rest of the interview was full of theory questions based on CS fundamentals.
Although I had prepared for subjects such as OS, DBMS, I was surprised as the interviewer was focused more on theory unlike a complete coding interview (giving a lengthy question and asking for optimizations).
So be prepared for some uncommon questions and make sure you know the basics of your favorite language well !!

Had Initial discussion with HR regarding Salary Expectations, notice period extra.

After that 4 rounds of interviews scheduled- 
Technical Round
Communication Round
Hiring Managerial Round 
Group Managerial Round
 
After that received mail to send salary documents for further processing. 
Waited 1.5 months, sent multiple reminders to hiring HR. No update, no response nothing. 
Very unprofessional behaviour by the HR of company like Microsoft, very disappointing and unprofessional behaviour.

After 7 weeks, just logged in to portal to check the status of application and suddenly status changed from Interview to Rejected.

No transparency, unprofessional, disappointing. If they have issues with salary expectation, they should tell upfront, instead of wasting candidate time and scheduling multiple interviews just for formality.

Coding short list, resume short listing, interview 1, hr round (coding round had difficult questions, interview round had easy to medium question with interview guiding you. Hr round was general language based questions)

A recruiter reached out about a monthly hiring event. 
I did the typical online assessment first, and then was invited to a single day of 4 back-to-back technical interviews. 
Each consisted of 5-10 minutes of intro chat, behavioral, and resume questions. Then 30-40 minutes for a single technical question. 

They were all LC easy/medium. They were:
1. Longest palindromic substring
2. Smallest item in a rotated array 
3. Largest island in 2D array
4. Determine if a linked list is a palindrome

After the coding round of Microsoft, I was selected for the interview. The interview process went for the whole day and was full of new learnings and amazing experiences. The interviewers were supportive and happy to help.

Round 1 was an online coding test held on Codility.
Round 2 was a 45-minute coding interview with two coding questions.
Round 3 was a coding interview similar to Round 2.
Round 4 was HR and tech interview

One online round and three technical interview rounds. Online round had two basic DSA questions and similarly for the three technical interviews. I was asked some questions on binary trees and linked lists in the interview rounds.

First was a coding round (which was easy). They also focus on the CGPA and hence a good CGPA would be a boost. Then there were 2 rounds of face to face (virtual) tech interview and the last being the HR round.
We had three great coding questions in an hour. coding algorithm and data structure questions, practice makes perfect I guess. You need to be very familiar with linkedlist and trees.

There were four rounds in total.One was online coding round and other three were techincial rounds.Data structure questions were asked in the interviews like trees,linked lists etc.No seperate HR round was taken but some hr questions were asked in tech rounds itself

The recruiter reached out to me after reaching out on LinkedIn and asked for me to do a one-hour online coding assessment. After the coding assessment would've been an interview with a software engineer

Good overall experience. Should give once and experience it. Worth a while. If accepted, you get to work at MS. They treated me very nicely and everyone should learn from them how to treat candidates. I would end my words by saying MS is good.

The interview process was broken into 3 rounds- two technical, and one As Appropriate (AA) round.

In the first round, interestingly, I was asked questions about real-life applications and not about what students traditionally learn and expect(such as DS/Algo).

The second round focused on my resume, and I was asked about the projects that I had made.

The final round was an HR round, which didn't involve any technical knowledge, and mainly focused on my interpersonal skills.

Negative Experience

Great structure of interview process, had 3 separate interviews covering technical acumen, business acumen, and digital transformation.

Received a verbal offer the day after the final interview.

Was called the next week saying they over-hired and would be unable to actually extend the offer.

Terrible experience in the end, as I was excited at the opportunity and was given a verbal offer only to have it taken away. Know your headcount before you do this to people.

HR was terrible at scheduling the interviews, communicating during the process, and didn't follow up to close the conversation. Working with HR made me feel like a number on a spreadsheet, not a candidate they wanted to hire. Interviewers were great.

There were 3 rounds. All rounds involved DSA problems. The first two rounds involved 2 standard DSA problems each. Going through the questions asked in the past helps greatly. The final round involved a review on my resume and one DSA problem.

Had 5 interviews.
All of them were on data structures and algorithms.
They also covered behavioral questions.

The general interview took a month and feedback was provided a week after interviewing.

The data structures they mostly asked was on trees and also questions on strings and arrays. Others majorly focused on how you explain the question and the time complexity and how to improve it.

Applied at Microsoft for Sr Program Manager Role - Content and Learning. Within two days hiring manager contacted me and set up “Informative Call” of half an hour. He said he is meeting with short listed candidates through informative calls and that he wants to hire 4 candidates by December 2021. He explained MS hiring process and said recruiter will contact me to schedule 4-5 interviews of 50 mins and then he allowed me time to ask questions which  I did. I was very hopeful because he was looking for Power BI experience which I possessed and he was hiring 4 people  in the team but no recruiter contacted me ever. I followed up with hiring manager and as I expected he didn’t show even any curtesy to respond to my email. After 7 -8 weeks, my application became Inactive with a notification of the same. Not at all great experience.

The first round interview was a 30 min virtual interview which was set up on Microsoft Teams. It had mostly behavioural questions such as: "What do you think makes a good programmer?" and "What are some of the Microsoft technologies that you use" (this would have a follow-up to ask for an improvement upon that technology if you name one). This interview would end with a brain teaser/problem that you are given 10-ish minutes to solve. They may not necessarily be looking for the right answer, but they do want you to think the process out loud. The interviewer did a great job at making me feel comfortable and confident!

first it was on the codility platform andthey have given 2 questions and later they shortlisted 47 students for technical round and it was 3 rounds : 
given four questions of coding and asked some behavioural questions in the technical interview

4 step process, very intense. Interviews with various team members combined and separate. Questions are both tactical and high level in nature. Final interview seems like a formality but they have final interviews with numerous candidates

It was medium to easy level, one must be sufficiently  prepared in dsa to ace this round.
Typically they want us to start from a brute force solution  and then move on to more optimized one. Never start with an opitimized soln even if you know the correct approach and answer.

Had to go for several interviews, but did not have a first one with HR as I expected, instead I went directly to talk with the Hiring Manager. It was long and demanding: over 5 months, many interviews and some waiting periods.

This was by far the worst interview experience I’ve ever had. And I’ve interviewed and worked for almost every big tech company there is. I applied for the DSR position and was contacted for an interview a week later. The process consisted of 1) short conversation with recruiter 2) three consecutive interviews in a span of 3 hours via online video 3) final interview with director. 

Here are some things that made my interview experience less than ideal:

1) The recruiter was almost 10 minutes late to our phone conversation 

2) The recruiter assured me that this is a closing position. It is not. You will be passing off all deals to an Account Executive so you are essentially a BDR. I had to ask a series of questions to everyone I interviewed with to come to this conclusion and it was clear they were trying to hide the fact that the majority of what you’ll be doing is setting meetings for others.

3) I was told from the beginning that the process would end after my three hours of interviewing. However another interview was added once that was completed with little to no explanation as to why.

4) After 3 rounds and 4+ hours of interviewing, I received an automated email mentioning that I did not get the position. After emailing and asking for feedback, I received no response

If you’re going to be misleading candidates to get people with AE experience to do a BDR job, at least show some respect throughout the process

The first round was the online coding test on codility which required us to solve 2 questions within 90 mins The questions were the same for all and a total of 44 students were selected out of 200+ students. I was not selected

There was one coding round where we had to do some PCA along with some MCQs. And then an interview round which was related to scores, different types of methods and other issues faced while building a model.

The interview process began, he asks me to introduce myself and then he gave me my first question, check if binary representation of a number is a palindrome, consider all 32 bits. So, 5 would not be a palindrome by this logic. He asked me to write and run the code on my  own IDE, screen was shared and platform was MS Teams. After this, we moved to next question, mirror trees-he asked me to code it, and then again another question on trees - given the parent pointer of every node, find the leftmost right cousin of given node. I couldn't run the code because we were running out of time. I did a dry run and it worked for some sample cases, but after the interview, I found out that it didn't work for some cases. While I was writing the code, he said he was going for tea, and he came back in about 5 minutes. After that, he simply said the process is over, you can leave. He asked me to cut paste all code in the chat window.

It was an on-campus drive first round as an online coding contest(75 minutes) followed by 2 technical interviews(60 mins each) and 1 HR interview(45 minutes). Everything was conducted online in 2 days.

Very comforting, the interviewer asked about temp in my locality , how was my day , which movies i watch , all these things to relax me . When I got relaxed , he then asked a simple DSA problem (117. Populating Next Right Pointers in Each Node II on leetcode) . I gave both approaches . He seemed satisfied with the approaches . Then he asked me if I have any questions . I asked about his work. 
I was happy with my experience in interview ,  then few hours later I got my rejection mail.
Coding Round consisting of 2 easy question on greedy methodology which took place on codility then 2 interview rounds on campus. Some people also had to give three but it was 2 for me.

Very straight forward process. A recruiter got in touch with me about a week after I put in my application. Had a 30 minute Microsoft teams call to go over background, why I was looking for a change, salary expectations and all the basic stuff. I was then set up on a 3 hour interview with the hiring squad. It’s about 45 mins each interview with a 15 min break in between. All the interviewers were extremely professional, intelligent and truly passionate about the company. They made me feel very at ease and went extremely smooth. I got the job offer two days later. 

Word of advice:  it’s very important that you do a good bit of research on the position you are interviewing for, Microsoft’s mission and values, current events involving Microsoft, and also make sure you have intelligent questions to ask the interviewers. 

Also their background check takes about one week to complete and is extremely thorough so your start date is about anywhere from 2-4 weeks out from the time you get your offer letter. Good luck!

The first round was organised pretty quickly, the problem is, that the recruiting team doesn’t notify you when you are no longer considered, they just sitting on it, and it is very annoying that you should contact them to gain any information about the process.

It was very smooth. The first round was DSA based. The second round was development-based and creative. The 3rd round was HR and very small. He asked me a DSA question and what things I will keep in mind if I create a Weather API app.

I interviewed there in an internal referral, after unsuccessfully applying there a few times. The people were great. I liked them and generally vibed a lot with them, but the whole process threw up a lot of red flags to me. I also learned that the company had an internal studio model where designers were farmed out to different product groups on a per-need basis, but this was not clearly communicated at any point.  

I had 6 rounds of interviews with them for a junior-mid designer role, which is not standard at all. The interview panels did not share information. So when I interviewed with the 6th person, I asked him - how much longer would the process take? 

He was surprised when I told him it was my sixth interview, and he responded saying, he only had my notes from the first three panels, a few weeks ago

Further, they kept making me do whiteboard interviews for some reason. I ended up doing four of those (in rounds 2, 4,5,6) which was again not at all expected for a design interview.  When I asked why, since I'd already done so many earlier, they said it was just the process. 

The HR wouldn't tell me how many rounds were remaining or what is the next stage of the process, or the team I would be joining. While that process was taking place, I got an offer in hand from another company.  I accepted that and told my recruiter I was dropping out of the process.

Immediately the recruiter calls me and says, hey, your offer letter is coming, we'll fast track it, please wait. Earlier the recruiter said they were waiting for feedback, they didn't know how many more rounds more were needed, and now all of a sudden the offer letter is ready?

I couldn't wait! Either I proceed with the offer in hand, or I wait for the other offer which would come or would not come. I had completely lost trust at this point, and decided to go with  the other company because they seemed to actually want me.

I think I burned a lot of bridges there but that's fine. If they were willing to treat me like this, then I would not want to work there.

Una pequeña plática de 15 minutos sobre ti y tus proyectos. Finalmente una entrevista de programación de 15 minutos. Al finalizar hay un cierre muy breve con el entrevistador sobre preguntas generales. Siempre muy transparentes y están en constante contacto contigo mediante correo.

Totally lacklustre performance from such a reputable tech company. Interviews were easy and mostly conversational, starting in August 2021 and done remotely.

After the manager interview there was a frustrating 4 week delay in any feedback. I was not offered the position and it was explained to me that I was missing a Microsoft qualification that the successful candidate had, but asked if I was interested in the next position to come along, I said yes.

The application I had submitted online was kept open for this reason, and left open for 4 months, then transferred and then rejected. All without any communication. Really bad form and not what you would expect from Microsoft.

Started with an online coding assesment - fairly straightforward timed questions. 

This was followed by a screening call with a recruiter, where we discussed my goals, career ambitions etc. My recruiter was extremely friendly and welcoming and helped me through this interview a lot. I was told to expect to hear back from them in 4/5 weeks when they had finished this round of recruitement. 

4 weeks passed and I hadn't heard a word from them, so I contacted them asking for an update, and all I received back was that I had been "shortlisted" for an interview. 

3 whole months passed, and they finally got back to me to schedule final round interviews, at this point I had already interviewed (and received offers) at other companies. When told them I had accepted an offer and wanted to withdraw my application,  they responded that I should have told them I had pending offers, and they would have sped up the process! 

I was in disbelief honestly with the lack of communication throughout the whole process. Perhaps, I would have asked them to speed up the process if they had been more transparent with me. I understand that they have a lot of applications to get through, but the least they can do is give rough estimates of how long the recruitment steps will take.
Very simple and straightforward. They don't only look for the final answer; they look for how you arrived at the answer. Be sure to talk your way through deriving your answer.
